column2: The dismal job prospects for new college graduates have revived debates about whether college is “worth it.” The PayPal founder Peter Thiel is among the major skeptics, but there are plenty of others. Check out the comments on yesterday’s article about employment rates for recent grads to see what I mean.
Although the N.H.L. playoffs are continuing at breakneck speed, the international hockey season officially ended last week with the gold medal game of the 75th world championship.

Though there is great stuff to read this week (I promise!), I am going to focus on photography. Just last week, we won a National Magazine Award for a photo essay by Ashley Gilbertson on the bedrooms of dead U.S. soldiers. But as rewarding as the big events like that are, it’s the week-to-week excellence of our photo director, Kathy Ryan, and her staff that impresses me even more. They don’t pursue a particular style or idea about pictures. Their interests are gloriously catholic. They pull stuff out of archives. They come up with stunning ideas that enliven subjects that have been photographed a million times before. They scour the earth for new talent. And they are always receptive to ideas that photographers bring to them, a more important skill than you might think.

Talk about cravings. At one point in the eerily staged production of “Sleep No More” at a mock hotel in Chelsea, a showily pregnant Lady Macduff hikes up her blue velvet evening dress, hops on to a bar and laps milk from a saucer. At another moment in this crazily meandering interpretation of “Macbeth” by Punchdrunk, the British experimental theater company, her dress is laid out on a bed, leaving masked spectators free to pore over its capacious folds and seams.

“There’s no such thing as L.A.,” says the curator Benjamin Godsill. “There’s multiple, sometimes overlapping bits of community, ideologies and neighborhoods.” Organizing a group show around the theme of a major metropolis poses risks. Hyperbole, dime store anthropology and overlooked artists often crowd the presentation. But the best of these endeavors don’t seek to galvanize a scene, per se, but provide the most basic of contexts: place. In this way, the mercurial nature of Los Angeles provides a valid starting point for an investigation of its artists. This summer, two separate curatorial teams (both based in New York, funnily enough) will tackle the behemoth subject of art in Los Angeles with group shows staged far from home. “Greater LA,” on view until June 10 in SoHo, looks at the city’s contemporary artists, whereas “Venice in Venice,” which opens on June 4 at the Venice Biennial, revisits the city’s rebel artists from the 1960s and ’70s.

She had already staked her turf in the history books when Rachel Alexandra won her Preakness in 2009, and she saw Lookin at Lucky’s short burst of fame last year, too. The first volume of “Ai Ore-Love Me!” hits the manga list at No. 10 this week. The book is about what happens when Mizuki, the lead guitarist at an all-girl school, is approached by Akira, a student at an all-boys school, who wants to join her band. Seems like a reasonable enough premise, but things get more confusing, according to the description on the web site of VIZ Media, which publishes the book: “Love may be on his mind, but romance is difficult when everyone keeps mistaking Mizuki for a boy and Akira for a girl!”

Whether by filming an ode to NBC in a field or by having small-town Little Leaguers pace around a New York gallery and mutter ‘‘good game’’ to one another, Colin Snapp (left) and Daniel Turner frequently take aspects of globalized culture and consumerism and trickle them down to a rural level. The two New York-based artists, who recently began exhibiting collaborative work under the name Jules Marquis, share a Greenpoint studio but regularly shuttle to southeast Virginia, where they’ve created a nonprofit art space on a corner of the Turner family farm. Named Jericho Ditch, after a local logging canal, it serves as a venue and creative getaway for fellow artists. It also embodies the Jules Marquis ethos: from the outside, it’s a shed in a field; inside, it’s a big-city-gallery-style white box lighted by symmetrical fluorescent tubes. Snapp and Turner have two shows opening in June: at Jericho Ditch and at Martos Gallery in New York.

Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week makes the point that some investors are not any more aware of the risks involved in private equity and debt offerings than they were nearly three years ago, in the depths of the recession. The biggest risk is that they will lose all their money. That is probably not as big a deal for the wealthy as it is for those who aspire to be rich.

When President Obama met with Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, in the Oval Office on Friday, this photo caught our eye. The two men have had a sometimes rocky relationship, (see today’s story by Helene Cooper) but they exchanged cordial words on Friday. This picture was snapped as Mr. Obama listened, almost frozen, during long remarks by Mr. Netanyahu, in which the Israeli leader pushed back against the framework for a peace deal that Mr. Obama outlined in a speech Thursday at the State Department. It made us wonder: What is Mr. Obama thinking?

Stitched with Kate Moss’s infamous quote, Jonathan Adler’s needlepoint pillow is $119 at Kirna Zabête, 96 Greene Street (Spring Street). Or go to kirnazabete.com.

Everyone has some fascination with the combination of sex, money and power, but who would have thought they would all point to a career at the International Monetary Fund? Founded in 1945 at the Bretton Woods Conference with a mandate to prevent wild swings in national currency values, the fund, I would have imagined, would set itself against swinging of every kind.  That is clearly not the case. According to Alan Beattie’s interview this morning with I.M.F. semi-renegade Simon Johnson, the fund was firstly aimed at helping struggling postwar economies in Western Europe, and its first loan (in 1947) was to France.  For 35 of the fund’s 64 years, its managing director was French. When Western Europe had recovered, the fund went on to other things and secured for itself, let’s say, a mixed reputation.  From the 1960s onward, and culminating in the period of strict I.M.F. loan “conditionality” and rigid programs of “structural adjustment,” the fund earned a reputation as a corps of technocratic drones pitilessly contented in their air-conditioned hotel rooms as they imposed cookie-cutter “solutions” on prostrate governments. You would read from time to time of “anti-I.M.F. riots” in one poor capital or another, and you could guess what it meant, and it wasn’t pretty.    By the early part of our own century, the fund was entering a period of repentance, not least because some poorer countries were now “emerging markets” and making a big point of repaying I.M.F. loans and swearing never to take them again. Escaping the I.M.F. became a symbol of freedom. But if the fund wasn’t making loans it had no income, and we know what that means: time for reform! Emerging-market players, with a sympathetic United States, pushed for changes in voting power. In essence, the developing world would get more I.M.F. power at the expense (slightly) of the United States and (mainly) of Europe. Several reforms, first undertaken in 2006 and most recently last year, would take the voting share of “advanced economies” from 60.6 to 55.3, and of “emerging market and developing countries” from 39.4 to 44.7.

The new Summer Travel issue of T sets sail with the model-sailor-adventurer Daria Werbowy, who skippers a sailboat from St. Bart’s into the spectacularly blue Caribbean Sea. The watery idylls continue on Favignana, a tiny island off Sicily that has lately been discovered by the fashion crowd; in the Cape Cod town of Wellfleet, where a collection of Bauhaus-style bungalows conjures a lost bohemia; and on the banks of the Thames, in which amateur archaeologists called mudlarkers dig for scraps of history. We peel back layers of the past in Kuala Lumpur, one of Asia’s most cosmopolitan cities, then get lost in time in Tangier, a last redoubt for romantic dropouts. For beach-blanket readers, there’s an excerpt from Elaine Sciolino’s timely new book, La Seduction, about the role of flirtation and provocation in French society. And for wave-riders we’ve assembled a guide to cool new surf spots around the globe. Plus: the Selby heads to Melbourne. See all stories from the issue >>

This is our second straight week of superabundant sentence harvesting — which is good, given that it will apparently be our final Sentence of the Week post ever. (Does Twitter still work when the moon has turned to blood?) So let’s all really settle in and savor these together, the last good sentences ever tweeted in the Cycle of Human Time:

The “Little Boy” that devastated Hiroshima in 1945 altered the Earth’s axis, while also (albeit briefly) changing the way war would be waged. It virtually leveled an entire city — the scope of which is only hinted at in these dramatic photographs — and, followed three days later by a second, smaller detonation on Nagasaki, did what determined American military bombing was unable to do: it forced a Japanese surrender.

An island can be paradise or prison, Aruba or Alcatraz or both. Or neither. There are tourist islands and desert islands, islands of treasure or target practice, tropical atolls and frozen specks, islands for Gilligan or Godzilla, Dr. Moreau or Dr. No — even metaphorical islands, which no man can be. Each is a petri dish parenthesized by ocean, fermenting its unique varietal of weirdness.

In 1997, when I was first hired at New York magazine, Kurt Andersen, now a best-selling novelist and radio-show host, had just been fired as editor. Everybody was grieving about this, though not me, since I wouldn’t have had a job there otherwise. And though it wasn’t until years later that I even met Kurt, he unwittingly left me a gift: tacked to the bulletin board in the office I took over was a single page titled “Words We Don’t Say.” It contained, as you might surmise, words and phrases that Kurt found annoying and didn’t want used in his magazine. Just yesterday, I rescued it from a bunch of old office stuff that I was throwing out, and I have to say, 14 years later, it’s still a pretty useful list of phony-baloney vocabulary that editors are well-advised to excise from stories.

Apparently not content for musicals like “Evita,” “Phantom of the Opera” and “Starlight Express” to be his only gifts to posterity, Andrew Lloyd Webber has decided to make a more easily quantifiable contribution to British culture: he has said he will donate £32 million – nearly $52 million – to arts organizations in his home country, BBC News reported. The announcement comes at a time when the British government has drastically reduced its financial support of cultural institutions as part of a nationwide austerity program.

CANNES, France — By his own admission, Michel Gondry is not really cut out to be a judge. “I’m against competition,” Mr. Gondry, the French-born director of “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “The Green Hornet,” explained recently. This may present a challenge to his role as the president of the short film jury at the Cannes Film Festival here, where he is tasked with, you know, picking a winner.

Five Leaves, the Brooklyn cafe and bar known for its ties to the late actor Heath Ledger (he discovered the space while skateboarding), is about to expand its laid-back Aussie vibe with its new spot, Nights and Weekends, located around the corner on Bedford Avenue. “I’m sort of spellbound by how the restaurant comes alive and becomes part of the street,” says Jud Mongell, one of several owners of the popular watering hole. On any given sunny day, hungry patrons pack the pavement in front of the cafe, which is across the street from McCarren Park.

Indonesia’s president signs a two-year moratorium on new logging concessions in the island nation’s still-prolific virgin forests, part of a $1 billion climate change deal with Norway intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from deforestation. Under the deal, more than 150 million acres of primary forest are expected to be protected. Indonesia “will not return to the past of unsustainable development practices,” a top environment adviser says. [The Jakarta Post]

NOVICK--Shirley, passed away on Monday, May 16, at the age of 102. Born Shulamit Rabinowitz in Brestovitz, Poland, Shirley settled in New York City in 1930 where she began her working life of 47 years as a seamstress and became a lifelong labor union and civil rights activist. She was married to Paul Novick, editor of the Yiddish Daily, Morgen Freiheit, for 29 years until his death in 1989. Shirley is survived by her step-son, Allan Novick, and her family in New York, London, and Israel. Service will be held at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street on Friday, May 20, at 4pm.

But the stage version of ''Seattle'' will start in Southern California: the Pasadena Playhouse announced on Thursday that it would mount the world premiere of ''Sleepless in Seattle - The Musical'' beginning June 12, 2012, with performances set to run through July 15. The commercial producer attached to the project, David Shor, had said previously that he planned to open the musical on Broadway in 2010, then moved the goal to Valentine's Day 2011. Frieze, London's eight-year-old contemporary art fair, is expanding to New York, the fair's organizers announced on Thursday. The first Frieze New York will take place May 3-6 next year on Randalls Island and is expected to include some 170 galleries from around the world. The exhibitions will be housed in a temporary structure designed by the New York architecture and design firm SO-IL. Amanda Sharp, one of the directors of Frieze, said that she and her business partner, Matthew Slotover, had begun talking about expanding to New York more than a year ago. After they called a few dealers to gauge interest word quickly got around, and soon she had dozens of galleries around the world calling to express enthusiasm for the idea, she said. The next challenge was finding a site. ''When we happened on Randalls Island Park, that was when we got very excited,'' she said, because it meant they could ''do it on a scale that makes sense.''

FrontPoint Partners, once a multibillion-dollar hedge fund before it was battered by allegations of insider trading, will shut down most of its funds by the end of the month. The decision to wind down and restructure its business is a surprising reversal of fortune for the hedge fund. Earlier this year, FrontPoint had appeared to have weathered the scandal when it raised $1 billion for a new fund. And in March, its co-chief executives, Dan Waters and Mike Kelly, announced that the firm had bought back majority ownership of itself from Morgan Stanley, concluding a long-delayed spinoff.

LAZERE--Monroe R. Passed away peacefully at home on May 18, age 93. Beloved husband of Muriel for 64 years; wonderful, devoted father of Eric and Cathy and father-in-law of Maria; much loved and admired grandfather of Brian and Keith. The youngest of five children, he was born in New York City. A 1938 graduate of Cornell University, he majored in math and was junior Phi Beta Kappa. Ardent tennis and squash player. All around camper and boxing teacher. Waltz champion. Clever lyricist and poet. A 1943 graduate of Columbia Law School, he worked at Greenbaum Wolff and Ernst and served in the US Army. In 1951, he founded Lazere Financial Corporation which became a leader in asset-based lending. President and Chairman of the Board of the Commercial Finance Association. Author of first comprehensive textbook on commercial finance. Adjunct professor at Cornell and New York Universities. Despite becoming hard of hearing at age 18, he was an operaphile and music lover. Active in community affairs, he served as treasurer of the Westchester chapter of the National Urban League and on the White Plains Library Board. Member of Beachpoint Club. Above all, a terrific guy with a ready, dry sense of humor who will be missed by all who knew him. Private funeral services. Memorial service Sunday, May 22, at Ballard Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York at 4pm.

A judge granted bail on Thursday to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, allowing him to be freed from Rikers Island to stay in a Manhattan apartment while his sexual assault case is pending. Mr. Strauss-Kahn's lawyers said in court that their client would put up $1 million cash bail and wear an ankle monitor. They also said that Mr. Strauss-Kahn would remain under 24-hour home confinement in the apartment recently rented by his wife, with an armed guard posted outside -- presumably to ensure he stays inside. He also submitted a waiver of extradition, should the American authorities need to get him back from France.

Even though New York City's stalled construction industry has not begun to hire back laid-off workers, the city's unemployment rate dipped again in April to its lowest level in more than two years. The city's official unemployment rate was 8.6 percent last month, down from 8.7 percent in March, the State Labor Department reported Thursday. That drop kept the city's rate below the national rate of 9 percent and continued the slow but steady improvement that the local job market has shown since the beginning of last year, when the city's unemployment rate was at 10 percent.

GREEN--Eugene. Opera singer, painter, graphic artist, loving husband of Ethel, father of Daniel and Frederic, and grandfather of three. Passed away peacefully on May 16, at age 83, in the company of his family. Eugene sang with many opera companies in the U.S., Europe, Canada, South America, including Chicago Lyric, San Francisco Opera, Metropolitan Opera National, Deutsche Oper am Rhein, Goldovsky Opera, Kansas City Lyric, Cincinnati Summer Opera, and Canadian Opera. He was the Cantor at Temple Beth Emeth in Brooklyn for 20 years. Before his opera career, as a graphic designer he created the IBM logo in the 1950s. He created title pages for Nico Castel's collections of phonetically transliterated opera libretti. We shall miss him terribly.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — As someone who grew up in New York City, one of my fondest memories was of childhood trips to the main branch of the New York Public Library (now known as the Stephen A. Schwartzman Building). I consider myself lucky to have walked among the majestic columns, up the stairs past the solemn, stone lions that still guard the entrance and through the great halls into the reading rooms. In a quasi-Proustian way, I can still remember the smell of the books and the card catalogs, a sense memory that I wonder if today’s children will ever have. Can you really dredge up the memory of how an e-book smelled?

CANNES, France— Film festivals around the world have reacted to the arrest, banning and conviction of the Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi with official statements, special screenings and gestures of solidarity — at the Berlin Film Festival earlier this year, a seat was left empty for Mr. Panahi at every screening in the main venue. But the most meaningful act of all may be the Cannes Film Festival’s decision — announced just days before screenings got under way — to show new films that Mr. Panahi and his countryman Mohammed Rasoulof had made in defiance of their bans. (Like Mr. Panahi, Mr. Rasoulof, whose new film, “Goodbye,” is about an Iranian woman trying to leave the country, has been convicted for collusion against the regime — both were given six-year prison sentences, which are being appealed.)

The episode up for discussion is called “Swerve,” alluding both to Julie’s self-imposed car accident and various other instances of changes of heart and turns of fortune. Unable to muster the stamina to return to college after her run-in with Derek’s wife last, week Julie decides that the way to bide more time at home is to ram her car into a mailbox near her parents’ house. Maybe I’d be a really weak and bad parent to a teenager, but I don’t think I would have tried to force Julie to go back to Burleson, which is after all, a fictitious college and one at a significant psychic remove from her dreams of a Northeastern educational experience. Coach Taylor being Coach Taylor, he wanted Julie to man up and face the mess. The whole point of the affair now seems to have been to stack the deck so in favor of Julie’s return home that the show could easily situate her back in Dillon. Perhaps it was too implausible that Julie would just go to Dillon Tech in the first place, so the writers dispatched her to a place where she implausibly made no friends and experienced not a second’s worth of intellectual fulfillment or genuine freshman pleasure.It was interesting to see Coach having the correct perception of Julie’s motives rather than Tami. It is coach who realizes that Julie must have crashed on purpose. Tami is a disbeliever. It was interesting to see the show cast Coach’s impotence — he can’t get Julie in the car and back to school because she refuses with every fiber of her being to go — against Vince’s father’s assertion of paternal authority. Vince is in trouble with his thug lender, and his father steps in and solves problems by beating the daylights out of the guy, hoping to make sure the guy never gets within a yard of Vince again. Will this work? It sure felt as if it would. I’d hate to see this come back to haunt Vince’s father, or worse, for Vince to take the moral high ground against his dad in response.

CANNES, France— In his new film “Miss Bala,” the director Gerardo Naranjo, tackles a topical issue — drug violence in Mexico — though an unlikely protagonist: an aspiring Tijuana beauty queen (Stephanie Sigman) who gets caught up with the local kingpins. Instead of delving into the social or political aspects of the problem, docudrama-style, Mr. Naranjo fashions a tense mood piece steeped in confusion and anxiety. He sticks to the captive heroine’s frequently befogged point of view while ruthless cartel operatives and corrupt cops remain on the periphery or outside the frame, their actions often unseen and their motivations murky.

When the board of the Morgan Library & Museum meets on Thursday afternoon, a new president will preside for the first time in time 23 years. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, a retired I.B.M. executive, is taking over the post from S. Parker Gilbert, who held it for more than two decades. ''If I hold it a quarter as long as Parker, that will be a lot,'' Mr. Ricciardi, who is 70, said in a telephone interview. A trustee since 2003, Mr. Ricciardi said he was originally drawn to the Morgan because it was ''a place of scholarship, of connoisseurship and of passion, and those are things that one doesn't normally find in a day-to-day business career.''

The Democratic National Committee significantly outraised its Republican counterpart in April, powered in part by millions of dollars from successful fund-raisers that featured President Obama, a D.N.C. official said. Democrats brought in $12.4 million in April, more than double the $6.1 million that the Republican National Committee reported raising in the same month. The D.N.C. totals will be filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday, the D.N.C. official said.

My patience with ''Sleep No More,'' the elaborate haunted house masquerading as theater in Chelsea, began to wear thin at about the time the pointy plastic mask I was wearing started pinching at the bridge of my nose. This was perhaps a half-hour into the experience, and I had been studiously obeying the request made to all patrons to keep the mask fixed to my face, despite the clammy trickle of sweat filming my forehead. For another half-hour or so I fought hard against the pinch, the trickle, and the wild urge to fling the mask off. But slivers of anxiety have a way of expanding into big, fat wedges with remarkable speed. There soon erupted in me one of those weird, irrational flare-ups of panic everyone has probably experienced.

ACKERMANN--Henry Harry J.,Sr., 90, of Freehold, NJ, died peacefully on May 18th, on the 65th anniversary of his marriage to his beloved wife, Margaret (nee Bauernschub) who died in 2004. Born in Baltimore, MD, to the late Henry A. and Isabelle (Dicke) Ackermann, he was the youngest of nine children and was predeceased by all of his siblings. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, after which he had a distinguished professional career as a chemist and computer scientist. However, the true loves of his life were his family and his faith. He was the devoted father of Henry, Jr (Valerie), Sister Marialice, ASCJ, Bruce (Judy), Philip (Susan), and Mark (June). He adored his 21 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. As a committed Roman Catholic, Harry was a daily communicant at St. Robert Bellarmine Church, Freehold and participated in numerous ministries in the various parishes that he was a member of throughout his life. He dedicated his life to the Blessed Mother and to the protection of the unborn. He was an active life member of the Fourth Degree of the Knights of Columbus for over 70 years. He was a Past Grand Knight of Hamilton Council 6213 and former Faithful Navigator of the Bishop Griffin Assembly 655. Visitation will be held on Sunday, May 22nd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Clayton & McGirr Funeral Home, 100 Elton-Adelphia Road, Freehold, NJ. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Monday at 11:00am at St. Robert Bellarmine RC Church, Freehold, NJ. Interment will follow at St. Rose of Lima Cemetery in Freehold. Memorial contributions may be made to the Apostles of the Sacred Heart, 295 Benham St., Hamden, CT 06514. Condolences may be sent to: www.claytonfuneralhome.com

Apparently not content for musicals like ''Evita,'' ''Phantom of the Opera'' and ''Starlight Express'' to be his only gifts to posterity, Andrew Lloyd Webber has decided to make a more easily quantifiable contribution to British culture: he has said he will donate 32 million - nearly $52 million - to arts organizations in his home country, BBC News reported. The announcement comes at a time when the British government has drastically reduced its financial support of cultural institutions as part of a nationwide austerity program. The funds pledged by Mr. Lloyd Webber were raised from the sale last year of a Picasso painting owned by the composer, ''Portrait of Angel Fernandez de Soto (The Absinthe Drinker),'' which fetched about $51.8 million with commission at a Christie's auction. (Don't cry for Mr. Lloyd Webber even though Christie's had estimated the painting would sell for up to to $60 million.)

In an interview with the Kansas radio station The Rock (98.9 FM) reported by NME.com, Mr. Taylor said his invitation to Oxford was ''very ironic seeing as I didn't graduate from high school.'' Most everyone has had the experience of searching carefully for the best airfare and booking a flight, only to see the ticket price later drop. (With fuel prices rising, that might not be happening as often, but it still occurs.) Airlines typically offer credits or vouchers for the difference in price when that happens, although most of them mute the benefit by imposing a hefty change fee when you try to claim the credit. But a lot of consumers don't realize they may be eligible for a credit, or don't act fast enough to claim it. The flier first has to know the fare has dropped, and then must call the airline in time to request the credit before the price goes up again. For that reason, a lot of travelers don't take advantage of the credit. A recent survey by MasterCard found that 71 percent of people searching for airfares weren't aware of the availability of such credits and that 10 percent knew they existed but didn't know how to take advantage of them.

8 P.M. (HBO) GET HIM TO THE GREEK (2010) Russell Brand (above right, with Jonah Hill) reprises Aldous Snow, his snake-hipped British rocker from ''Forgetting Sarah Marshall,'' in Nicholas Stoller's comedy about a record-label drone (Mr. Hill) dispatched to transport Snow -- a wreck after the failure of his latest album -- from London to the Greek, a famous concert hall in Los Angeles. Need we add that mayhem ensues? As played by ''the brilliantly unpredictable'' Mr. Brand, Snow ''is more than a pop-culture museum piece or a MacGruber-like bit of sketch comedy nonsense,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''He has feelings, ideas and a dollop of talent to go with the uncontrolled appetites; even though he's narcissistic and self-destructive, he is also kind of fun to hang around with.'' As Aaron Green, ''Mr. Hill, wide-eyed and anxious as ever, makes a fine visual and temperamental foil for Mr. Brand,'' Mr. Scott said. ''The two of them are like the Trylon and Perisphere of comedy.'' The result, he said, is ''the bawdy-sweet mixture that is the signature of the Judd Apatow school of screen comedy.'' (Mr. Apatow was one of the producers of ''Get Him to the Greek.'') Mr. Scott added: ''It is basically a ribald road picture, with not much of a plot beyond Aaron and Aldous's journey from London to Los Angeles via New York and Las Vegas, and not much for women to do that allows them to be funny in their own right. They are around to be ogled and exploited, and also sometimes to provide emotional sustenance, a duality that makes this movie both a hymn to, and a subversion of, the ideal of heterosexual monogamy.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Paul Nurse, the British geneticist and biologist who is a Nobel Prize winner in medicine, president emeritus of Rockefeller University, current president of the Royal Society and director of the United Kingdom Center for Medical Research and Innovation, continues his discussion of whether scientists have earned the trust of their paymasters: the public.

Another aging rocker, another tell-all memoir. Gregg Allman, one of the founding members of the Allman Brothers Band, will tell his life story in a book to be published by William Morrow, an imprint of HarperCollins. The deal follows one that was made earlier this week in which HarperCollins acquired the English-language rights to an autobiography by Pete Townshend of the Who. ''When I got out of high school, I thought, I'll take a year or two off and play the clubs, get this out of my system, and then go to med school,'' Mr. Allman said. ''More than forty years later, I figure it's finally time to write about this crazy journey that's taken me around the world and back.'' The book will be released in spring 2012.

Credit reports have increasingly become consumers' passport to the financial world. Whether you want to rent an apartment, get car insurance or apply for a credit card, the data in your credit report will be one of the crucial measures used to judge you. That's why you want to ensure that the information in your report - which is used to formulate your credit score - is free of any inaccuracies. Even if you're not denied credit, a small error here or there can cost you more in interest.

SILVER--May. Our hearts are broken by the sudden loss of a cherished friend. May's strength and beauty brightened our lives for 70 years. Love and gratitude never die. Phyllis and Howard Schwartz

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Golf Ball That Won't Slice Comes With a Catch: It's Illegal,'' May 10: That this golf ball is so popular speaks volumes to the state of America's ethical quandary. No self-respecting golfer, no one truly interested in improving his or her skill and actually playing the game would ever consider using one.

Surf culture has long produced its own aesthetic, along with a tradition of surfer-artists. On the visual vanguard at the moment are Alex Kopps and Tin Ojeda. Kopps's films, graffiti and collage-like prints (alexkopps.com) give an urban edge to what is usually a beachy domain. ''The content and events that have influenced my artwork were not discovered at the beach,'' says Kopps, who lives in the Bay Area and sells some of his T-shirts and posters (right) at Mollusk Surf Shop. His film ''Displacement,'' about ''displacement hull'' surfboards, uses 1970s Super-8 footage with abstract effects. Ojeda, the Argentinian-born painter and surfer behind the Drug Money Art clothing line (drugmoneyart.com), is bringing the beach to the city. His tees, on which he hand-prints phrases (''Beauty Is Boring,'' says one), first gained a following in his home base of Montauk, N.Y. Now they're at Barneys and in stores in Tokyo, Berlin and London. Related: Surf Report

RASKIN--Marjorie H. Devoted, dedicated, appreciated assistant for 39 loyal years to Melvin and Norman and 15,000 students whose hearts she touched at The Stecher and Horowitz School of the Arts in Cedarhurst. She was unique. Deepest condolences to her family. Melvin Stecher Norman Horowitz

An article on May 8 about the federal government's raids on medical marijuana dispensaries around the country misidentified the status of cocaine on the government's list of illegal drugs. It is a schedule 2 drug, which can be prescribed for medicinal purposes -- not a schedule 1 drug, which cannot be prescribed.

Elaine Sciolino Elaine Sciolino, a Paris correspondent for The Times and a recent recipient of the Legion of Honor, made her name as a hard-charging reporter: she covered the Iran-Iraq war and has been imprisoned in Syria, shot at in Lebanon and arrested in Poland. But for her new book, ''La Seduction'' (Times Books), which is excerpted on Page 63, Sciolino seized on a softer subject: French culture's broad concept of séduction, from perfume and wine to politics and diplomacy. Still, she says, she approached the book ''with the same rigor as if it were an investigation of Iran's nuclear program.''

PORTZ--Charles R.,died at the age of 73 at his home in Williamstown, MA on March 17 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Bette Craig, and a host of sociology students from MCLA, Montclair State, Black Hills State and BMCC. Daring to go back to school at the age of 52 to earn a Ph.D. from the CUNY Grad Center, Chuck Portz was the co-founder of NYC's Labor Theater and Realizations Productions and was nominated for a Writers' Guild Award for the script of A Mistaken Charity that was part of PBS' American Playhouse Series, which he also directed. The son and grandson of rubber workers, he was born in Akron, Ohio, and graduated from Stetson University. He is the author of more than 25 plays and screenplays, including Railroad Bill and The Bayside Boys. His first feature film, Bucharest Express was shot in Moldova in 2001, where he taught on a Fulbright Fellowship.

WANG--Lillian Y.,87, died on May 14, 2011 at her home in Greensburg, PA. She was born in Shanghai, China, left home at 25 with a pioneer's optimism and settled in New Jersey where she and her late husband, Richard, dedicated themselves to raising their children. She always worked, forging an early career in the new field of computer programming and retiring as a senior systems analyst at ABC where she helped coordinate the live feed for the 1984 Sarajevo Olympics. After retirement she worked for Merrill Lynch and volunteered at the Hackensack University Medical Center gift shop for many years. She was highly organized, phenomenally competent, and extremely energetic, making it possible for her to juggle her activities as a devoted mother, full-time professional, new immigrant, expert seamstress, accomplished cook, entertainer, and much-loved friend. She drew energy from being around people and she helped everyone. She was preceded in death by her husband Richard Y.C. and her beloved son Richard D. Wang. She is survived by her proud children Barbara Wang, M.D. and her husband Bill Kennedy of Latrobe, PA, Pat Wang of New York City, and daughter-in-law Aljo Lee Wang of Austin, TX; loving grandchildren Laura, Katie, Isaac, Frederick and William; and three devoted sisters and many nieces and nephews in China and the U.S. The family invites donations in her name to be made to the UPMC Cancer Center, Arnold Palmer Mountain View Pavilion, 200 Village Drive, Greensburg, PA 15601.

An article on May 8 about a social movement in Sicily that steers tourists to businesses that do not pay protection money to the Mafia rendered incorrectly the Italian term used by members of Cosa Nostra to refer to themselves. It is uomini d'onore, not umoni d'onera. (The English translation is men of honor.)

Michael Aubrey was leaving the Syracuse Chiefs' ballpark last Sunday when he stopped to sign autographs in the parking lot. As his 5-year-old daughter, Madelyn, watched, she had a question and a suggestion. ''Daddy, why do they want your autograph?'' she said. ''Because you hit four?''

BALTIMORE - I never watched Harmon Killebrew play or had the pleasure of meeting him, but I felt a connection with him. One of my favorite things to do when I got home from school was to turn on ESPN and watch reruns of ''Home Run Derby,'' which pitted some of baseball's top power hitters against each other in, yes, a home run hitting contest. As an 8-year-old, I was drawn to Killebrew because of his name. It sounded mean and threatening, which, as I learned later, was the opposite of how you would describe the man. Still, it seemed as if he would crush balls farther than anyone else, and I liked that.
BARBEOSCH--William P. 1954-2011. GenSpring Family Offices mourns the death of esteemed friend and colleague, William P. Barbeosch, Esq. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife and family.
Bloomfield Colonial

Thank you, Bill Keller, for your brief but insightful view on the inner lives of war photographers. The recent deaths of Chris Hondros and Tim Hetherington in Libya reminded me of my own friends, John Hoagland and Richard Cross, killed 25 years ago when we worked together covering the wars in Central America. Despite his loss, John's young son, Eros, chose to follow his father's craft and is now a war photographer shooting for The New York Times, among others. For those not on the front lines, I suggest you look closely at the next image of armed conflict you see, for the fine print on the bottom or along the side that gives the name of the person who took that image and who, for whatever personal reasons, is risking his or her life to show you another face of humanity. DAVID HELVARG Richmond, Calif., e-mail

DEGENER--John Michael, died Sunday, March 20 on the Caribbean Island of Mustique of a heart attack. Born in New York City, he was the son of the late Nouche Lucien-Robert and George L Degener Jr. He attended Trinity School, boarded at Riverdale School for Boys, and graduated from Millbrook School in Millbrook, NY. He was a 1956 graduate of Williams College and received an MBA from NYU in 1972. He is survived by his wife of 38 years Helen MacDonald Zottoli Degener and two children from his first marriage, Carol Marie-Laure Degener of New York City, and J. Michael Degener, Jr., his wife Henriette Kets de Vries, and a granddaughter Belen Degener of Southampton, MA. A Memorial Service is to be held on Saturday, May 28, 2011 at Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon, CT at 11am. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sharon Audubon Society in Sharon, CT 06069.

Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, is examining 20 stock trades by the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, a spokesman for the lawmaker said Saturday. The inquiry is the result of a letter sent by Mr. Grassley on April 26 to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority asking it to provide information on the ''potential scope of suspicious trading activity'' at SAC, the hedge fund run by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen.

''It's thrilling to feel the global reach of Newsweek, because there are very few brands left that have that kind of traction,'' Tina Brown tells The New York Times Magazine, which explores her ''queasy mystique'' in a profile. ''There's the BBC, CNN, The New York Times, The Times of London, Time and Newsweek.'' That was probably an accurate statement last time Brown was editing a weekly magazine, in the closing years of the 20th century. But Newsweek's star has been in rapid descent since then, and now it barely cracks the list of the 100 most influential news organizations, as measured by citations of their reporting in Google and Google News. A few of the up-and-coming news outlets that have passed up Newsweek in the traction game: Bloomberg (No. 5), Al Jazeera (No. 11), Politico (No. 19), The Huffington Post (No. 37), The Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel (No. 38), Mashable (No. 59) and Us Weekly (No. 83). JEFF BERCOVICI 4:55 p.m., May 6, Mixed Media blog, Forbes.com
Television Ginia Bellafante

A picture caption with an article on April 10 about the possibility that the Sacramento Kings basketball franchise will move misidentified the 2002 Western Conference finals game between the team and the Los Angeles Lakers shown in the photograph. It was Game 4, not Game 7. The error was only recently pointed out by a reader. Corrections in other sections: Real Estate, Page 2; Sunday Business, Page 2; Arts & Leisure, Page 2; Travel, Page 2.

DUNHAM--Robert Lee Robert Lee Dunham, affectionately known as Lee, the son of the late Colena Elizabeth Dunham and Albert Dunham, was born in Kannapolis, North Carolina on September 12, 1932. He transitioned from this life to his eternal home on Tuesday, May 17, 2011. At an early age, Lee moved to Brooklyn, New York. Following graduation from High School he enlisted in the United States Air Force. Not long after completing a term of service with the Air Force, Lee returned to Brooklyn and joined the New York City Police Department's Motorcycle Division. While working for the NYPD, Lee also matriculated at John Jay School of Criminal Justice. He proudly served New York City as a police officer for 20 years until retiring from the force. In 1972, Lee Dunham began his second career as a McDonald's Owner/Operator. He made history by opening the first McDonald's restaurant in Manhattan, and went on to operate seven McDonald's locations in New York and Northern New Jersey. Lee was an exemplary leader and mentor in the McDonald's system for over 39 years. He was one of the founding members of the National Black McDonald's Operators Association (NBMOA), serving as its President from 1982-1986, and was the organization's Chairman Emeritus. A tireless advocate on behalf of minorities, Lee successfully helped many to acquire McDonald's franchises and/or become National McDonald's suppliers. He made training and mentoring a lifelong priority, and was known throughout the McDonald's family for his passion of the brand and as a guiding counselor to others. Lee was also famous for asking tough questions and always advising everyone to do the right thing. His leadership in the McDonald's system was second to none and he was considered a true pioneer. During his stellar career Lee Dunham amassed numerous awards including: McDonald's Corporation Ronald Award McDonald's Corporation Golden Arch Award The Extraordinary Trailblazer Award from National Black McDonald's Operators The Black Businessman of the Year Award Samuel D. Proctor Phoenix Award from Abyssinian Development Corporation New York Urban League's Building Brick Award African American Male Empowerment Summit Entrepreneur Award, and The Public Advocate's New York City Advocate Award. Lee Dunham leaves behind to cherish his memory; his devoted wife, Linda; two sons, Bradley Jay Dunham and Brian Hairston (Candace); a brother, Bill R. Dunham (Barbara) of Burlington, NJ; sister, Lillie Mae Douglas of Kannapolis, NC; two granddaughters, Brianna and Courtney Hairston; and Sister in Law, Delores Washington of Alpharetta, GA; Brothers-in-law, John Hairston (Kathy) and Gerald Wayne Hairston of Charlotte, NC; nephews; William Dunham (Patsy) and Wynton Dunham (Marilyn) of Burlington, NJ; and Craig Dunham of London, England, Eric Newland of Greensboro, NC, Gregg Newland (Yolanda), John Hairston, Jr., Gerald Wayne Hairston, Jr. and Jeffrey Hairston all of Charlotte, NC;. nieces, Betty Dunham of Philadelphia, PA and Rheayanna Dunham of Hyland Park, NJ., Regina Hairston Jones (Edward) of Augusta, GA, and Jennifer Hairston of Charlotte, NC; and a host of aunts, cousins, relatives and friends who loved him dearly. He was predeceased by his brother John Wesley Dunham. Viewing and visitation will be held on Monday, May 23rd 2011 at Abyssinian Baptist Church 132 Odell Clark Place, New York, NY. Viewing from 10:00am to 11:00am. Funeral immediately following.

WE'D been hiking for a half-hour when Mark Thornton raised his hand and drew us to a halt. Tracing a circle in the air with his index finger, he whispered, ''They're all around us.'' About 50 yards off, in every possible direction, were zebras. Dozens of them. The night before, sitting by our campfire, we'd heard distant hoof beats rumbling across the savanna. Now we had found the source. They milled around stubby acacia trees, black tails swishing against striped hindquarters, noses down in the grass.

BENSON--Honorable James DeWitt, born in Dutchess County, N.Y., died in North Carolina, on May 20, with family nearby. Following three years as a U.S., Army Captain in WWII, Judge Benson returned to Cornell, where he earned his J.D. Admission to the NY Bar Association was followed by his private practice in Pawling. He served as Pawling Town Clerk, In 1976, he became Dutchess County Attorney. He became Acting Supreme Court Judge of the 9th District, in which he served for ten years. He then served as and of the Surrogates' Court. Judge Benson coedited the 1998 series, general Practice in New York, published by the West Group. His children thank his peers and associates in Dutchess County and the County Bar Association for their kindness and continued support.

IT starts with a well-worn fiddle, held in equally well-worn hands above a tapping black cowboy boot. Then in comes the banjo, plucked with steel finger picks, followed by the autoharp, the mandolin, the percussive beat of an upright bass. Another banjo grabs the melody, and suddenly the room is bursting with knee-slapping, country-porch music. A man in a crisp checked shirt gets up and starts to dance, bouncing out a complicated bumbumBAM bumbumBAM with his feet, moving as smoothly as a Martha Graham dancer, hitting the floor on the downbeat. It is Thursday night in Fries (pronounced freeze), Va., population 600, on the wide New River. In the century-old Fries Theater, the silk wallpaper, once a glorious aquamarine embossed with gold ferns, is faded. A sign promises movies for 10 cents, 25 cents on weekends, but there hasn't been a film here in years. The Fries high school closed in 1989 after the cotton mill that gave birth to this hamlet in 1902 shut down. But where the economy has faltered, the local music culture is thriving. Take a drive through the dozens of one-stoplight towns that are planted along highways that twist through this region's blue hills and green valleys, and you'll find that music is the manna of the community.

Richard Gasquet Richard Gasquet has often wilted under the crushing expectations of being a tennis prodigy. On the cover of France's Tennis magazine at age 9, he failed to live up to his promise and has been ridiculed as an underachiever.
An article last Sunday about the racial divides in San Mateo County incorrectly identified the town in which Steve Jobs, the C.E.O. of Apple, lives. He lives in Palo Alto, not in Atherton.
Pop Jon Caramanica

Tampa Bay's James Shields entered the weekend tied for the major league lead in pickoffs with five, which is unusual for a right-handed pitcher. Even though he does not face the runner at first base, a few things work in his favor. Shields has quick feet, he said, and he also studies the layout of each infield. During batting practice on the road, Shields will measure the distance from first base to the outer edge of the dirt cutout. That way, when he peeks at the runner, Shields can accurately measure his lead based on how close he is to the cutout.

Intentional walks are often viewed as a benchmark of the amount of fear a batter instills in theopposition. Few could argue that the 120 intentional walks that Barry Bonds received in 2004 werean appropriate strategy, but the five that Jose Bautista has received since the start of last seasonseem striking by comparison. As teams continue to pitch to Bautista, he continues to punish them asbaseball's top power threat.

THE sole purpose of my in-basket this week seems to be to goad me into looking at fashion from the Cannes Film Festival. Everybody from Armani to those Chopard people has been sending e-mails, and, I swear, I don't know why Jude Law needed to borrow a white gold Chopard watch. Didn't he bring his own? And who's going to see it under the cuff of his tux, anyway? That's why I don't look at this kind of e-mail until I absolutely have to. They make me crazy. You, too? I know. Looking at some of the pictures from Cannes, I can't tell if I'm watching a rerun of ''Gunsmoke'' or ''The Love Boat.'' I do know that if the jury were to give a Miss Kitty award for the worst dawggone dress, it ought to go to Penélope Cruz, in a lavender, corseted Marchesa. There are just too many people on the poop deck of the ''Love Boat'' to name.

It's rush hour in St. Bart's, and the model Daria Werbowy has stopped traffic. The photographer Cass Bird has decided to shoot the Canadian stunner on top of a hill that overlooks the island's airport runway. Werbowy agrees, slips into a Missoni bathing suit and runs across the highway. Although it's off-season in St. Bart's, a line of cars has paused to watch this long, beautiful creature skip across the road. Within five minutes, the bathing suit is off and Werbowy is naked with nothing to cover her but a street sign. ''She's like a wolverine,'' Bird says. Though Werbowy, 28, is one of the most sought-after models in the world - she stars in campaigns for Celine, Balmain and Salvatore Ferragamo, and is a face of Lancome - she seems to be most comfortable in next to nothing. At the shoot, she greets the team in her typical tomboy getup: jean shorts covered in patches she sewed on herself, an old Nirvana T-shirt, lots of silver rings and an enviable tan. Werbowy loves the sea as much as the sun - a few years ago she took a break from modeling and sailed across the Atlantic from New York for 24 days with her father, brother and sister. A few days after our shoot, she would be embarking on a two-month sailing expedition from Guatemala to Belize, island hopping along the coast, then traveling through Central America to Costa Rica. There would be no staff, no captain, no chef, just a few friends and family members. Werbowy would do it all: sail, steer, clean and cook. ''Daria can morph into so many different things,'' Bird says. ''She's tough as nails.''

The Ethicist says the writer's husband, who is a registered sex offender, ''committed a terrible act.'' But we are not told the act nor the circumstances surrounding the conviction, except that his crime involved an adult woman and that it occurred two decades ago. Who does or does not belong on the sex-offender registry is a controversial issue. Some states require men to register if they are caught visiting prostitutes, urinating in public, streaking and, until 2003, engaging in sodomy. Lumping these crimes with pedophilia and aggravated rape has ruined the lives of many people who made the mistake not of committing a terrible act but of being caught in behavior that harms no one. CAROLYN STACK Cambridge, Mass., e-mail

Filling your time during a cheap weekend in Rio de Janeiro would seem like a no-brainer: head to Ipanema beach on Saturday, spend a couple of bucks to rent a beach chair and a couple more on tempting snacks from roaming vendors. Rinse (in the on-beach showers) and repeat (on Sunday). But if you want to eat actual meals, drink the local grog (ice-cold beer), listen to music and get around town, too, you're asking for trouble. The Brazilian real is at its strongest this century - the weekend I was there $1 got you 1.57 reais - and by one consulting group's measure life for expatriates in Rio is more expensive than anywhere else in the Western Hemisphere, except Sao Paulo and New York. Tourists will feel that pain as well, especially when it comes to restaurant meals, taxis and entrance costs to attractions.

THE NEWS After 45 years as the spirited host of his annual Labor Day telethon to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association, Jerry Lewis, 85, said the 2011 broadcast will be his last. BEHIND THE NEWS Starting on a single New York station in 1966, Mr. Lewis built the event into a high-wattage national charity juggernaut lasting 22 often maudlin hours and raising more than $1 billion over the years. But its hold on the spotlight has ebbed in recent decades as charity megaconcerts, pledge weeks and celebrity appeals have proliferated; the show is being shortened and reformatted.

FIRST-TIME travelers along the Hudson River might have been forgiven for thinking, upon first astonished glance, that they had seen Brigadoon emerging midway between Beacon and Cold Spring, N.Y. For everyone else, the view of that mysterious Scottish castle known as the Bannerman's Island Arsenal had grown more disheartening over the years. Into the late 1960s, the fantastic confection was still pretty much whole, until fire gutted it in 1969. Just a few years ago, the ornate shell of the tower keep was largely intact, encrusted with turrets, crenels, merlons, oriels, corbels, loopholes and bosses that looked like cannon balls. Whatever providential force held the walls precariously upright expired in the winter of 2009-10, when much of the tower crumbled.

Elaine Sciolino on Seduction, and France It is not enough to conquer; one must also know how to seduce. - Voltaire, ''Merope'' The first time my hand was kissed a la francaise was in the Napoleon III salon of the Elysee Palace. The one doing the kissing was the president of France.

ROSENKRANZ--Gerardo Miguel, Greenwich resident, passed away peacefully on May 11, 2011 surrounded by his loving family. Jerry was a beloved father of Lili, Tommy and Emma and loving husband of Lauren. Jerry is the son of George and Edith Rosenkranz and brother to Roberto and Ricardo. Jerry was the Founder and Chief Executive Officer of Ventech International, a private venture capital firm concentrating on early stage communications, information technology and internet companies. Prior to Ventech, Jerry was a senior executive in business development, marketing and sales worldwide for Sprint International. He established Sprint's European headquarters. Jerry was born and raised in Mexico City and graduated from Stanford University in 1973 with a BS and MS in Electrical Engineering. He received a graduate degree of ENGR in Electrical Engineering Administration and wrote his dissertation on Management Information in Multinational Organizations. At the young age of 12 Jerry's interest in electronics became apparent when he built the first color TV from a kit for the family. His curiosity for electronics and technology was the guiding light for his career. He was at the forefront of technology with a deep understanding of Latin America and was recognized as one of the important forces to bring technology entrepreneurship to Latin America. Over the course of his career, he contributed to the formation and growth of many leading businesses including Blade Logic, Mercado Libre, Patagon and Bling. Jerry expressed his passion for life through his many pursuits, which he started enjoying as one of three brothers growing up in Mexico. These interests included skiing, golf, scuba diving, photography and wind surfing. He loved to travel and was fluent in four languages including Italian, French, Spanish and English. His education and career took him many places, yet these interests were a foundation for sharing life with his family and close friends. Jerry was extremely philanthropic and was involved in many organizations including the Mouse Foundation, Stanford University, Greenwich Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DonorsChoose.org, as well as Brunswick and Greenwich Academy where his children attend school, just to name a few. Jerry will be remembered as a loving, warm, and genuinely compassionate father, friend and mentor. Throughout his life, and especially over the course of the last eight years as he confronted the challenges of cancer, he was a fountain of courage and grace for all who were fortunate enough to cross his path. His bright light will be missed. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests that you consider a gift to the Rosenkranz Neuroendocrine Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. For more information, please visit: www.bike13mskcc.com

CITYBUMPKIN 10:35 p.m., May 5, nytimes.com

The common refrain about Venice, besides that it's sinking, is that it is no longer a city for Venetians. The native population is declining (as is most of Italy's), replaced by some 20 million tourists a year. But several recent restoration projects, both well financed and small-scale, are bringing a sense of localism back to the city. On the quiet island of San Giorgio Maggiore, the Giorgio Cini Foundation has transformed a wing of the 10th-century San Giorgio Monastery into the Nuova Manica Lunga library (cini.it). The architect Michele De Lucchi gave it a modernist gloss, creating a public library with more than 150,000 volumes. Elsewhere are spaces for jazz festivals, theater performances, art exhibitions and academic symposiums.

A Summer Trip to Tibet Out of the blue, my husband asked me if I wanted to visit Tibet. It was a complete and intriguing surprise! What would be your advice? Would this summer be an ideal time to go? No doubt Lhasa would be incredible. How could we make the long trip traveling there memorable? Above all, is it safe?

GLOTZER--Marguerite (Maggie) Horst, 93, on May 5, 2011 Beloved wife to the late Albert, she was adored by her extended family and friends. Teacher, writer, artist, and poet, active in the UFT and committed to Social Democratic causes. Memorial, June 11, 1-3 pm, Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, kindly donate to Cabrini Center for Nursing & Rehab. NYC or Felix Neck Wildlife Sanctuary, Edgartown, MA.
Art Ken Johnson

For her latest collection, the jeweler Monique Pean went in search of sustainable pearls - and wound up working in a lagoon in the South Pacific. Pean says she furthered her commitment to eco-minded jewelry during her CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund mentorship at Tiffany & Company; she and the company's C.E.O., Michael Kowalski, share what he calls ''an approach to precious materials that is sustainable and benefits the communities involved.'' The quest led Pean to the Ahe atoll in French Polynesia, where the Kamoka Pearl Farm uses fish and sponges to clean its oyster shells. The farm harvests without chemicals, feeds its employees (''Raw oysters, fried oysters, oyster risotto, a lot of oysters!'' Pean says) and turns the shells into beads. Pean's line uses Kamoka's keshi pearls in hues of blue, aubergine and gold for pieces like a ring set with delicate pave-diamond tendrils (conflict-free, of course), which Pean says was inspired by Ahe's ''pollution-free midnight sky reflecting against the waves and the light.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MINNEAPOLIS - Harmon Killebrew's reputation as one of the nicest and most approachable people in baseball was well deserved. He made several trips a year to the Twin Cities, and if he passed you in the hallway at the Metrodome or at Target Field, he would, without fail, say hello first. That's just how he was. It didn't matter if Killebrew, who died Tuesday at age 74, knew you or not. He certainly didn't know me in my first few years covering baseball here, but boy did I know him. Even though I rooted for the Mets growing up, Killebrew was one of my favorite players.

Jodie Foster (right): I was thinking what a dumb thing it was to put my sister in an outfit to be my double in ''Taxi Driver.'' The child-welfare bureau had decided that a 12-year-old playing a part with such sexuality was a problem and insisted on a double for any shots that were physically suggestive. So my mom said: ''I've got a great idea. Why don't we bring your sister?'' But honestly, what did that accomplish? Did they think that I was too young to understand the script; that I couldn't delineate between being a prostitute and a regular person? But it was a really good excuse to have my sister hanging out with me in New York.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Harmon Killebrew, Hall of Fame Slugger for the Minnesota Twins, Dies at 74,'' May 18: Harmon Killebrew inspired generations with his athletic feats as well as his strength of character and his good works. His announcement that he was entering hospice care was his greatest act of heroism. He made a point of framing his death in the way he hoped the public would understand it.

The Polish prose stylist Andrzej Stasiuk takes a Kerouac-style amble from the Baltic to the Adriatic in ''On the Road to Babadag'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23). Andrew P. Haley's ''Turning the Tables'' (University of North Carolina Press, $40) is a social history of fin de siècle American dining, which ties the birth of the restaurant to the emergence of the modern middle class. Andrea O'Reilly Herrera's ''Cuban Artists Across the Diaspora'' (University of Texas Press, $25) measures the pull of home and history on artists like José Bedia and María Brito. Never published in the United States until now, ''Chike and the River'' (Anchor Books, $10), Chinua Achebe's 1966 parable told from the perspective of a Nigerian boy, is about the promise and peril of travel. And in ''Irresistible North'' (Knopf, $26), Andrea di Robilant retraces the journey of Nicolò and Antonio Zen, Venetian brothers who reached North America in the 14th century.

From the late '80s through the early 2000s, much of surf culture was marked by homogeneity. The gear companies became behemoths, and the most popular boards (many shaped by computers) looked largely the same. In recent years, though, surfing's zeitgeist has begun to celebrate individuality - a shift back to the homespun ethos of the sport's early days. A surfer now is more likely to be riding a board he made himself, often a radically new shape. Even high-ranked pros are working collaboratively with their preferred shaper to come up with original, untested designs. Here, from left to right, some of the California-based gear guys who are leading the way.Mitch Abshere The owner of the Captain Fin Company produces surfboard fins and wet suits from Japanese rubber, which is especially soft, allowing for more agility (captainfincompany.com). Ryan Burch The 22-year-old pro surfer and shaper is fast gaining recognition for his ingenious D.I.Y. boards (related video) - particularly his rectangular, finless, un-glassed foam plank, the Lord Board, which minimizes drag and optimizes planing speed - and for his ability to ride boards of almost any shape and size with grace (bobbersandsinkers.tumblr.com).
SAMET--Harry. Dearest Dad- Twenty years. Lovingly remembered. Elaine

What might Guy Laliberte do next? He was a stilt walker and fire eater in Montreal before founding Cirque du Soleil in 1984. He later became a world-class competitive poker player, and in 2009 he rocketed into space as one of the first astrotourists. A study in teleology as much as topography, ''Gaia'' (Assouline, $65) is his space scrapbook, filled with digital photos that zoom in on dramatically abstract 300-square-mile swaths of Earth. ''Day after day, I was amazed by the beauty of this planet,'' he said. ''It is an infinite living art in motion.'' The full text of T's exclusive interview with Laliberte is after the jump. Q.I wanted to start by asking you about the title page. You say the book is ''curated'' by you? Why did you choose that phrasing when you actually went into space and took these photographs yourself?

A landmark of the Toronto skyline is providing travelers with a dose of extreme adventure starting this summer. The CN Tower is home to a new attraction called EdgeWalk (edgewalkcntower.ca), which will allow visitors to walk around the observation deck, 1,168 feet, or 116 stories, above ground. Guided groups of six to eight walkers (who must be 13 or older) will be attached by harness to an overhead safety rail that encircles the deck, absent of any hand rails. The first of its kind in the Western Hemisphere, EdgeWalk, seen above in an artist's rendering, is higher than its precursors, the 630-foot-tall SkyWalk (skywalk.co.nz ) in Auckland, New Zealand, and the 764-foot SkyWalkX in Macao (macautower.com).

Business or pleasure? I'd given this a lot of thought, but I don't have a ready answer at Heathrow Immigration. Technically, the purpose of my trip to London is to don rubber boots and climb down onto the bank of the Thames River at low tide, where I intend to rummage in the mud for bits of garbage. Business? Not really. Not even the mudlarks I would be joining on the riverbank, the obsessed history buffs who ditched their day jobs for every good tide, got paid. But pleasure? What kind of demented person takes pleasure in wading around in a vast urban dumping ground?

12:13 p.m. | Updated On the morning of May 16, from a foggy trailhead in north-central Scotland, Neil Tuckett and Jamie Davidson embarked on a mountain drive. Their destination lay roughly a third of the way up Ben Nevis, the tallest mountain in the British Isles, where they would stop, disassemble their car and, along with a phalanx of volunteers, carry the pieces to the top and reassemble them.

DURING a telephone interview from Paris, the fashion designer Alber Elbaz seemed to find it a little funny that he was being asked about real estate. But then, as if thinking out loud, Mr. Elbaz, artistic director of Lanvin, suddenly made a connection between housing and couture.

The Harvard historian Roger Owen is one of the pre-eminent minds on the modern Middle East, but even he was dumbstruck by the civil unrest sweeping the Arab world. The books that will shed light on it all, he says, have yet to be written. In the meantime, one could turn to the classics: ''The literature you need now is almost Shakespearean. We're dealing with family rule with fatal flaws.'' Or to the following volumes, selected by Owen, which give some background on this complicated revolutionary moment. Libya: ''A History of Modern Libya'' by Dirk Vandewalle (Cambridge University Press). An authoritative primer on the country, which reveals how oil and the peculiar impulses of Muammar el-Qaddafi turned a post-colonial backwater into an unpredictable rogue state.

ROBBINS--Libby, 97, died on May 17, 2011. She lived in Yonkers, NY with her husband, Bernard Robbins, violinist with the New York Philharmonic. She was a talented homemaker, an avid reader, world traveler, and a delightful wit in both English and Yiddish. She is survived by her daughters, Sheila Reid, Worcester, MA, Ellen Robbins, New York City, Julie Mainieri, Woodstock, NY, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

AT a time when the whereabouts of the artist Ai Weiwei are unknown, the theme of disappearance in Liu Bolin's work seems particularly relevant. Mr. Liu, a Chinese artist born in Shandong Province in 1955, has created an entire oeuvre based on a vanishing trick: photographs in which he blends (almost surreally) into backgrounds as grand as the Forbidden City in Beijing or as humble as a pile of coal. What Mr. Liu does may be a gimmick (each photo can take hours to set up, and the artist insists there's no digital retouching), but it's a gimmick taken to fascinating lengths. They can be seen at Eli Klein Fine Art Gallery, 462 West Broadway (Houston Street), starting June 29. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

The French took pity on their cooks and stopped serving cheese souffles 30 years ago, but not Jonathan Dawson, a British journalist in his 60s who turned in his press card to become a voluptuary in Tangier, a full-time job in this Moroccan city within winking distance of Spain. When I phoned Dawson to introduce myself and invite him for a drink, he cut me off, insisting, ''But you're coming to me today!'' - a perfect example of how Tangier society and its famous grapevine works. I had had dinner the night before with the retired antiques dealer Christopher Gibbs, whose clients-slash-chums have included everyone from Jaggers to Rothschilds, and before the last morsel had been downed, a big lunch party at Dawson's was already in the works. In Tangier, you are only as grand as your rooftop terrace. Dawson's tops off an apartment house that's a little more distinguished than most buildings in the scrappy Ville Nouvelle, the architecturally neutral (and that's being kind) ''New City,'' much of which went up after Morocco became a French and Spanish protectorate in 1912. Smothered in bougainvillea, Dawson's terrace has jaw-dropping views of the port, Gibralter and Spain, not 10 miles across the strait. The table service at lunch was French, expertly executed by my host's majordomo, a dwarf in a fez whom he rescued from a hard life on the streets, so it was difficult to be blase.

ROSENTHAL--George, 82, of Midland Park, NJ, died Sunday, May 15th of heart failure. He was raised in the Bronx and was a Veteran of the US Army. George spent his entire career as a respected property and casualty insurance broker. After retirement, he dedicated his personal time to The Insurance Information Institute in Manhattan. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lillian, his children, Caren, David, and Steven, their spouses, Barry, Leslie, and Angela, and his five cherished grandchildren, Eric, Matthew, Emma, Jack, and Sam, who all loved him dearly. He was a dear friend to many, had a wonderful sense of humor, and he will be missed by all.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''After an Outburst of Pride, Posada Says He's Sorry,'' May 16: Let me see if I understand this. The Yankees' Jorge Posada, a 39-year-old who makes $13.1 million a year for playing a glorified children's game, throws what is referred to in schoolyards as a hissy fit, and newspapers, talk shows and all sorts of people spend countless hours discussing it, and people stand and cheer when he graciously agrees to once again step up to the plate.

CHUSID--Sydelle, Our more than 50 year friendship will be sorely missed, but our cherished memories will last forever. Our thoughts, love and condolences are with her family. Rest in peace our dearest friend. Bobbi and Mel Weiss and Family

Nothing lasts forever - and that includes these far-flung destinations, which are changing as they balance their own needs with those of ever more curious travelers. The Galapagos Islands

Filling your time during a cheap weekend in Rio de Janeiro would seem like a no-brainer: head to Ipanema beach on Saturday, spend a couple of bucks to rent a beach chair and a couple more on tempting snacks from roaming vendors. Rinse (in the on-beach showers) and repeat (on Sunday). But if you want to eat actual meals, drink the local grog (ice-cold beer), listen to music and get around town, too, you're asking for trouble. The Brazilian real is at its strongest this century - the weekend I was there $1 got you 1.57 reais - and by one consulting group's measure life for expatriates in Rio is more expensive than anywhere else in the Western Hemisphere, except Sao Paulo and New York. Tourists will feel that pain as well, especially when it comes to restaurant meals, taxis and entrance costs to attractions.

5:05 p.m. | Updated When the Florida Marlins have reason to celebrate, which happens often these days, center fielder Chris Coghlan knows his place: on the fringes of the throng, being careful, without a pie in his hands. Last July 25, Coghlan, the 2009 National League rookie of the year, watched his teammate Wes Helms single home the winning run to beat the Atlanta Braves. Helms, now 35, is among the oldest Marlins, and is not shy about reminding his teammates. So Coghlan seized the chance to surprise Helms - Uncle Wes, as he calls him - with a celebratory pie.

One evening last fall I was walking through Chinatown in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, when, suddenly, in the midst of Cantonese restaurants, shops selling knockoff designer bags and food stalls hawking exotic-looking meats, I came across the wholly unexpected sight of a Hindu temple with a voluptuous gate tower: a riot of gilded idols and precious stones and wafts of thick incense. I walked on, under a freeway, past a pretty North Indian-style mosque, and, abruptly, the narrow vertical signs and single-column ideograms of Chinese shops gave way to something intensely familiar: I was in a South Indian market town, all gaudy silk and glittering jewelry shops.

Ben Brantley's theater column last Sunday on Broadway's creative freshness this season erroneously attributed a distinction to the musical ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert.'' The Tony nominees for best musical are ''The Book of Mormon,'' ''Sister Act,'' ''Catch Me if You Can'' and ''The Scottsboro Boys.'' ''Priscilla'' was not nominated.

SILVER--May, beloved wife, best friend, and partner of Irving for more than 65 years; cherished mother of Ron, Mitchell, Keith, and Ora and Claudia; grandma extraordinaire of Adam, Ali, Isaac, Andrew, Hadass, and Matt; devoted sister and aunt; remarkable friend to all. Service 12pm Sunday, May 22, at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th. In our hearts--always.

''The days of the 'easel' painting are fading,'' predicted the American artist Ellsworth Kelly, while living in the French fishing village of Sanary-sur-Mer in the 1950s. As Kelly experimented with color grids, dozens more artists followed suit, kicking off a contemporary art revolution on the Cote d'Azur. In Nice, Yves Klein ''signed'' the blue sky, calling it his first and biggest work, while Arman immortalized his neighbors' trash under plexiglass. Down the road in Antibes, Hans Hartung splattered his canvases with spray guns and painted with olive branches; in the hills of Vence, Jean Dubuffet turned soil, stones and butterfly wings into paintings.

CLARKE--Mary M.,of Westport, CT, passed away May 8th in Princess Royal Hospital, Haywards Heath, West Sussex, England. Wife of Nicholas Clarke, mother of James, Angela and Jennifer Clarke. Services will take place Wednesday, May 25th at 11:00am in Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Westport, CT.

MARKS--Leonard, a New York entertainment lawyer whose clients included Billy Joel, the Beatles, Elton John and Eddie Murphy, died Saturday, April 30, 2011 in his Manhattan home after suffering from advanced stages of dementia. He was 69. Born in NYC in 1942, Marks graduated from Stuyvesant high school, received his BS from Baruch College and his law degree from Yale. He was founding partner of the law firm Gold, Farrell & Marks in 1970. Marks, a former federal prosecutor, is survived by his brother Michael Marks, his beloved twin daughters Gabrielle Marks and Amy Marks-McGee, son-in-law Matthew McGee and his grandchildren Lucy and Miles McGee. He was married to Sara Ginsberg Marks for 17 years. Donations in Leonard's memory may be made to the Temple of Understanding at: templeofunderstanding.org or The Weill Cornell Dept. of Neurology, 1300 York Ave., NYC, 10021 designated for the Cornell Memory Disorder Program. Memorial service to be held on Tuesday, June 28, 2011 at 6pm at St. John the Divine Cathedral.
