Herman Cain, who made his fortune pitching soda, burgers and pizza before turning to politics, declared himself a candidate on Saturday for something that few others seem to want these days: the Republican nomination for president in 2012. At a noontime rally at a park in Atlanta, his hometown, Mr. Cain, 65, whose conservative fiscal credentials have made him a favorite among some Tea Party backers, promised ''a real vision'' to confront the nation's growing economic and foreign policy problems.

The Big Ticket item in the Big Deal column last Sunday misstated the sale price of a 10-room co-op at the San Remo. It was $13.5 million, not $14 million. (The higher figure, provided by the seller's broker, included the flip tax paid by the buyer.) The error was repeated in the headline.

CAR collectors, in their quests for the Find, would not let the pending liquidation of a salvage yard full of rusting vehicles go unnoticed. Hemmings, the collector-car classifieds service, publicized such an event last week. In Maxwell, Neb., on July 17, more than 150 cars from the 1940s to the 1970s, acquired by a 50-year-old wrecking yard, will be auctioned.

''I DON'T work out at all (shame),'' wrote the emerging model Flaviana Matata, 23, in an e-mail message, despite the fact that she's pictured here in Y-3 exercise gear. ''I'm just not ready to start (lazy).'' Ms. Matata, who at 5-foot-10 is a size 2 (envy!), was discovered at an event that raised money for health care in Tanzania, her home country. In 2007, she was the first Tanzanian to compete in the Miss Universe contest. Since then, she has appeared in magazines and ad campaigns and has modeled for designers like Vivienne Westwood. Still, running is a whole different story: ''I think I'll start exercising ... next year.'' Y-3 hoody, $245. Go to y-3.com. Adidas by Stella McCartney tights, $70. Go to shopadidas.com.

BEEDE--Patricia Fleet, age 75, of Concord, MA passed away peacefully of a stroke surrounded by her family on Monday, May 16, 2011 at Emerson Hospital in Concord, MA. She was the wife of Russell Stearns Beede. Born in Cutchogue, New York she was the daughter of the late Clarence Cooper and Evelyn Sample Fleet. Mrs. Beede graduated from Mattituck High School and Wheaton College, Norton, Mass. where she led the Wheatones before teaching for a year and then attending Graduate School at Syracuse University. Mrs. Beede moved to Concord, MA in 1962 where she raised her three children and lived until her death. A wonderful wife and mother, Mrs. Beede enjoyed gardening, playing tennis and spending time with her family and friends. She was a Girl Scout leader and volunteer with the Junior League, Tri-Con shop and the Emerson Hospital Gift shop. She was also an enthusiastic Red Sox, Celtics, New England Patriots and Bruins fan. She loved ice cream, Rogers and Hammerstein musicals, and early rock 'n' roll, especially the Beatles. Besides her husband she is survived by her children, Robert Jenks Beede and his wife Katherine Godfrey of Concord, MA, Susan Fleet Beede and her husband Jay Copeland of Concord, MA and Kimberly Ann Beede and her husband Richard Soule, Jr. of Brooklyn, NY. She is also survived by eight grandchildren and her sister in-law Jaquelin Perry Fleet. She was also the sister of the late Charles S. Fleet. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, June 4th 1:00pm in the Trinitarian Congregational Church, 54 Walden St., Concord, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Concord Players, Box 22, Concord, MA 01742 or Wheaton College, 26 East Main Street, Norton, MA 02766. To share a memory or offer a condolence visit: www.concordfuneral.com

NASA's shuttle program may be winding down, but consumer space travel is not, spurred by companies like Virgin Galactic, the space tourism company founded by Richard Branson that promises suborbital space flights in the not-too-distant future. Travelers who want a taste of what's to come can now tour Spaceport America (above), the facility near Las Cruces, N.M., whose anchor tenant is Virgin Galactic. During the tours, which started this month, visitors are taken to a number of nearby sites (Elephant Butte Dam, the grasslands near a Ted Turner ranch) before concluding at the spaceport. Among the attractions there: the vertical launch area, the mission control building and other features under construction, including the terminal hangar facility.

CELADA--Maria Cristina E.,on May 18, 2011. Beloved daughter of the late Raymond Joseph Celada and Maria Cristina Fernandez de Troconiz Esteban. Cherished sister of Raymond Richard, Maria Teresa, Maria Magdalena and John Paul. Adored sister-in-law of Monica and auntie of Ella Cristina. Funeral service private.

As the marathon Mad May benefit party season draws to a close, it is both startling and delightful to see whimsical headdresses and hats worn with long evening dresses. Certainly the recent London hat fest has had an influence. But some New Yorkers were already wearing diamond and feathered headbands before the wedding. These fantasies recall the doll-size hats Schiaparelli paired with her fabulous evening dresses before World War II. A few women are experimenting with the rolled hairstyles of the 1930s. Others have reached back even further, braiding their hair into halos.

BENSON--Muriel Valentine Genus, 93, of New City, NY - actress, model, band singer, director for 26 years of the Music Makers senior singing group, craftswoman, housewife, mother, and co-founder with her husband Karl Genus of the Totem Pole Playhouse in Fayetteville, PA gracefully exited the stage on May 18 with her wits intact and her bright eyes shining. Her cheerful spirit, ever-ready energy, and Scottish practicality carried her through accidents, diseases, and broken hips. A memorial celebration will be held at Squadron Gardens community room in New City, NY, 2pm, June 11. She is survived by daughter Tiane (TC), son Terry, three grandchildren, Ross, Kara, and Irina. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Totem Pole Playhouse.

DE STAEBLER--Stephen. 78, noted sculptor, at home in Berkeley, Ca. with family by his side on May 13, 2011. Survived by wife of 14 years, Danae Mattes; their daughter Arianne; and his sons Jordan and David. Predeceased in 1996 by wife of 39 years, Dona. Born St. Louis, MO, 1933, to the late Herbert and Juliette Hoiles De Staebler; predeceased by brother Herbert (Hobey) and sister Jan Angel. Graduated Princeton University (A.B. Religion, 1954). Studied at Black Mountain College with Ben Shahn, 1951. Served in U.S. Army in Germany (1954-56). Earned M.A. in Art, UC Berkeley (1961). Taught at San Francisco Art Institute (1961-67) and San Francisco State University (1961-62; 1967-90; retired 1995). De Staebler, known for fragmented figurative sculptures in clay and bronze, exhibited widely for five decades. A retrospective at San Francisco's De Young Museum opens January 2012. Works are in the Metropolitan Museum, NY, Museum of Fine Arts Boston, Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco and others; with public commissions in SF Bay Area and nationwide. Recipient of honors and awards from NEA, Guggenheim Foundation, American Craft Council, and others. Memorial service in July in Berkeley (TBA). Donations in his memory may be made to Doctors without Borders or Amnesty International.

APPEARANCES matter in Milan. For proof, just stroll past the sights: the majestic Gothic cathedral, the stately Teatro alla Scala opera house, the smartly dressed Milanese (yes, they're an attraction, too). But the true charm of Italy's most cosmopolitan city is its refusal to coast on these beautiful treasures. A few blocks from Leonardo da Vinci's 15th-century masterpiece ''The Last Supper,'' an ambitious project is inching toward completion: CityLife, a new center-city neighborhood featuring a trio of dazzling, futuristic skyscrapers. And in advance of hosting the 2015 Expo, the city is already blossoming with new museums and restaurants. In Milan, Italy's future is already on display. Friday

AFTER almost three years on the market, a sprawling penthouse at One Jackson Square in the West Village with a private swimming pool on its roof terrace sold on Monday for $16.6 million, according to the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which represented the owners. The penthouse sale was the priciest of the week, according to transactions posted on Streeteasy.com.The four-bedroom five-and-a-half-bath condominium, a 5,574-square-foot duplex with an additional 1,690 square feet of out- door space, comes with a staff studio on the fifth floor of the building. It was first listed in 2008 for $21.75 million. The last asking price on the unit, owned by the building's developers, Hines and RFR Holding, was $18.95 million. James Lansill, a senior man- aging director of the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, declined to identify the buyer. Big Ticket includes sales from the previous week, ending Wednesday. E-mail: bigdeal@nytimes.com
An article last Sunday about a change in business strategy at Ferrari misstated the year when Enzo Ferrari, the automaker's founder, died. It was 1988, not 1998.

An island can be paradise or prison, Aruba or Alcatraz or both. Or neither. There are tourist islands and desert islands, islands of treasure or target practice, tropical atolls and frozen specks, islands for Gilligan or Godzilla, Dr. Moreau or Dr. No - even metaphorical islands, which no man can be. Each is a petri dish parenthesized by ocean, fermenting its unique varietal of weirdness. Take Favignana. Favignana is a particularly weird little archipelago off Sicily; the island appears as a stark stone iceberg piercing the azure Mediterranean. This vista was once awash in Roman triremes and Carthaginian blood. Later, there were Moors, crusaders, Fascists and fishermen. One recent summer, it was Giorgio Armani. His personal black-on-black battleship crowded the harbor like a toy in a bathtub.

For eco-minded eaters - not to mention radiation alarmists - fish is a quandary these days. Much of the seafood served in American restaurants is imported, caught using methods that endanger other animals or farmed unsustainably. But a few chefs around the country are trying to turn the tide with local, eco-conscious menus. Tataki in San Francisco offers local catches like Monterey Bay sardines, horse mackerel from California and wild salmon, when it's available. (When it's not, the kitchen uses closed-containment-farmed Arctic char.) Casson Trenor, an owner and a seafood sustainability expert with Greenpeace, is especially proud of the restaurant's vegetarian menu. ''There's no more sustainable sushi eater than a vegetarian,'' he says. 2815 California Street, (415) 931-1182; 1740 Church Street, (415) 282-1889.

An article on May 1 in the Summer Movies section about ''The Honeymoon Killers'' (1969), a favorite of the president of Magnolia Pictures, Eamonn Bowles, misspelled the surname of the actress who played the film's female con artist. Her name is Shirley Stoler, not Stoller.

''I wanted to do something with my hands,'' says James Roberts, explaining how he became a shoemaker. Together with Thom Grogan, Roberts owns Captains of Industry, a ''gentlemans outfitter and cafe'' in Melbourne, Australia. Grogan, who runs the bespoke-suiting side of the business, thinks the Internet Age has inspired a craving for things that aren't mass-produced. ''People are getting pretty sick of being anonymous online and just buying stuff through online stores,'' he says. ''They want interaction.'' Roberts and Grogan don't stop at shoes and jams: they even make their own thread from scratch. ''It's kind of relaxing,'' Roberts says, ''if all goes well.'' ETHAN HAUSER

With summer approaching, many parents are planning family vacations. And just in time, some hotels are offering specials for travelers with children. Langham Hospitality Group (langhamhotels.com) has started a ''Linger Longer for Less'' promotion, in which a two-night stay gets guests 10 percent off the room rate, three nights equals a 15 percent discount and free breakfast, and five nights means a 25 percent savings, free breakfast and Internet and a room upgrade. Eleven Langham properties, including ones in Boston; Pasadena, Calif.; Melbourne; and Hong Kong, are participating.

Birthers, truthers, Osama-death doubters. These paranoiacs are distracting us from the real menace:one of the government's most powerful agencies is sending sinister messages through its logo.

ON little Star Street, a sliver of a lane in Hong Kong's Wan Chai neighborhood, a group of hungry friends and I walked up and down the same block, iPhone maps in hand, a handful of times before pausing before a quiet apartment building. ''Is this it?'' I asked, triple-checking the address before pressing the buzzer. After a quick elevator ride, we landed in a tiny, dank alcove before a nondescript apartment door. Before doubt had time to set in, the door swung open and a smiling woman in a powder-pink chef's uniform cheerily ushered us in. Just inside lay an elegant and modern dining room lined on all sides with crates and racks of pricey wine bottles.

AMONG the objects on view last weekend at the Sight Unseen Pop-Up Shop -- one of the many off-site events surrounding the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center -- coasters called Cold Cuts, by Chen Chen and Kai Tsien Williams, were a surprise hit. The two Pratt alumni wanted to make a loaf of material that could be sliced at the point of purchase; the coasters are cut from a sort of terrine of studio leftovers: fabric, clay and beads from a board game. Originally the designers had wanted to make bracelets, so they were gratified when the women at the opening were holding the coasters up to their shoulders as if they were brooches. For information, chenchenworks.com. PILAR VILADAS

THE folks who run Five Leaves, the cafe and bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, known for its ties to the late actor Heath Ledger (he discovered the space while skateboarding on Bedford Avenue), have opened a second pub, Nights and Weekends, around the corner. Large galvanized doors and windows that open onto the sidewalk give the new space (below) the ''look of a Caribbean taco truck,'' said Jud Mongell, one of several owners of Five Leaves, which is still connected with the Ledger family. Ken Addington's menu at the new spot, inspired by Cuba and the West Indies, offers small seasonal plates and many rum drinks, suitable, said the bartender, Dan Sabo, ''for pirates and desperadoes.'' Nights and Weekends, 1 Bedford Avenue (Nassau Avenue), Brooklyn; (718) 383-5349. STEPHANIE LA CAVA

As one of the world's most in-demand makeup artists and the artistic director of Shiseido Makeup, Page traverses the usual New York-Paris-London-Milan-Tokyo circuit. When it comes to his coveted downtime, however, he gets off fashion's beaten track, heading for rugged destinations like Iceland and the Arctic. The Long Island country ''shack'' he shares with his husband, James Gibbs, serves as the starting point for his favorite way to explore: camping. ''Our Teardrop trailer is always ready to go,'' he says. As is his Olympus digital camera: ''I photograph everything.'' Naturally, Page's photos don't merely serve as souvenirs -- they also become makeup colors. SANDRA BALLENTINE
Chelsea Condo MANHATTAN: 315 Seventh Avenue (at 28th Street), #10B

Turning a historic house - whether designed for laborers or lords - into a hotel is never easy. When Fred Krehbiel, a Chicago industrialist, decided to buy Ballyfin, a Georgian manor on 600 acres in Ireland's County Laois, the property was being used as a school, he says, ''and we had to give them six years to build a new building.'' During that time, Krehbiel's team of more than 100 workers began transforming the 1812 mansion into a hotel with 15 rooms, all while working around 500 teenagers. Krehbiel and crew restored ornate plasterwork, bought back some of the previous owner's paintings, rebuilt the conservatory (which had to be disassembled and shipped to England for repairs) and even uncovered a Roman sarcophagus bathtub, now installed in one of the guest rooms. (Appropriately, a family motto of Ballyfin's original owner, Sir Charles Coote, was ''coute que coute'' - ''cost what it may.'') In Montenegro, meanwhile, the Australian interior designer Marylou Thompson of the firm Denniston had an equally complicated task: turning Sveti Stefan, a village on an island in the Adriatic Sea, into an Aman resort. Not only couldn't the exterior of the buildings - some of which date to the 14th century - be altered, but Aman had to promise Montenegrins access, during festivals, to the island's ancient churches. Everything had to be done ''without making large holes in the walls,'' says Thompson, who encountered more damage to the buildings from a 1979 earthquake than anyone had expected. Most lights are lanterns, for example, hung from wall hooks, rather than ceiling fixtures requiring hidden wiring.

Information about the Crooked Road can be found at crookedroad.org.On the Blue Ridge Parkway, the Blue Ridge Music Center's new exhibition, ''The Roots of American Music,'' is scheduled to open Memorial Day weekend with a full slate of nonstop (free) music. If you miss it, every day at noon in the summer there are musical performances and there are concerts on weekend nights. The center is at milepost 213 on the Blue Ridge Parkway (276-236-5309; blueridgemusiccenter.org).In Floyd the Hotel Floyd (120 Wilson Street; 540-745-6080; hotelfloyd.com) is two blocks from the Floyd Country Store; dou- bles start at $99 on weekends and $77 on weeknights; all woodwork was done by local artisans. From Floyd you can also visit Blue Ridge Institute & Museum (20 Museum Drive, Ferrum; 540-365-4416; blueridgeinstitute.org).The General Francis Marion Hotel (107 East Main Street, Marion; 877-783-4802; generalfrancismarionhotel.com; doubles from $100) was built in the 1920s and restored in 2006.A bit farther down the road is the Carter Family Fold (A. P. Carter Highway, Hiltons, 276-386-6054; carterfamilyfold.org).

''The option was either to sell my truck and get something smaller, or to try to get closer to work.'' Loraine Greene, a customer relations manager in the Hudson Valley of New York, who decided to move closer to her work because of the high price of gasoline. ''Secret flying is like secret love. You do it, you don't tell people about it.'' Guan Hongsheng, one of the superrich of Wenzhou, China, and owner of three helicopters. He flies them clandestinely in defiance of Chinese authorities who restrict their use.

BROWN--Sylvia, 103, died peacefully at home on May 19, 2011. Devoted wife of the late Morris Brown; beloved sister of Hilda Turchin and the late Emanuel Tepper and Abraham Tepper; wonderful mother of Armin and Miriam Brown and Phyllis and Ralph Lusskin. Adored grandmother of Shari Lusskin and Robbie Wagner, Elizabeth Lusskin and Marc Solomon, Amy and Alan Zwerin, and Michael and Marji Brown; cherished great-grandmother of Lauren, Eric, Sadie, Isaac, Jessica, Danielle, Rachel, and Joshua. An entry in the July film listings on May 1 in the Summer Movies section, about ''All In,'' a documentary about the resurgence in poker's popularity, misspelled the surname of the film's director. He is Douglas Tirola, not Triola.

T asked insiders from the surfing and design worlds to weigh in with their favorite surf spots. The queen of nose-riding Kassia Meador sticks to her home breaks in Oceanside, Calif., using Donald Takayama's long boards (hawaiianprodesigns.com). For newbies, she stresses patience: ''Surfing takes a lifetime to learn. It's about having a good time.''

The laid-back Basque town of Biarritz has been Europe's surf capital since the 1950s. Yet despite the crowds and the casinos, it has retained its scruffy coolness. The Bay of Biscay provides the town with two main waves: the Plage de la Cote des Basques, a popular and consistent sandbar break; and the Grande Plage, an unpredictable, high-performance beach break up the coast. At least a dozen groups give surfing lessons, among them Jo Moraiz (011-33-6-62-76-17-24; jomoraiz.com), France's first surf school. Biarritz's plushest beach hotel is the Hotel Du Palais (011-33-5-59-41-64-00; hotel-du-palais.com; doubles from about $665), a palace-turned-hotel where Alain Ducasse worked one of his first kitchen jobs. You're less likely to see surfers there than at one of the campgrounds on Biarritz's outskirts. A happy medium between opulence and outdoors is Hotel Le Caritz (011-33-5-59-24-41-84; hotel-lecaritz-biarritz.com; doubles from $210), a handsome inn with a terrace restaurant. For the closest surf proximity, try the basic but comfortable Carlina Lodge (011-33-5-59-24-42-14; carlina.com; doubles from $190), which has direct access to the Cote des Basques. For post-surf refueling, the lovely covered market Les Halles (halles-biarritz.fr) offers outdoor fish and tapas restaurants, palpable reminders of the city's vicinity to Spain. And Le Surfing (011-33-5-59-24-78-72; lesurfingbiarritz.fr), an inviting bar and restaurant where vintage surf memorabilia serves as decor, might be the only brasserie in town that allows sandy feet. Related: Surf Report

Well, it was a club,'' says Eleanor Stefani, the longtime owner of the Colony of Wellfleet. ''It was a private club. You had to have your name in the Social Register - literally!'' The 10 Bauhaus-style cottages, which have housed devoted guests for decades, were first known as the Mayo Hill Colony Club. They were built on the bay side of Wellfleet, the little Cape Cod town, in 1949 by Nathaniel Saltonstall, an architect from a prominent Boston family who was a founder of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. Along with his business partner Oliver Morton, he designed it as a midcentury Modern retreat for high-society art collectors, with views of the sparkling bay and grassy fairways of the Chequessett Yacht and Country Club through the pines. At the same time, Wellfleet itself - much quieter than its flashier neighbor to the north, Provincetown - was becoming another sort of club. Edmund Wilson, the literary critic, arrived with his third wife, Mary McCarthy, in the 1940s, and they were followed by what seemed like the entire faculties of Columbia and Harvard, the staffs of Partisan Review and The New Yorker, and half the psychoanalysts on the Upper West Side, who began to descend upon the village every summer, and particularly in August. (McCarthy famously called Wellfleet ''the seacoast of Bohemia'' in her novel ''A Charmed Life,'' and Wilson, in his journal, credited the historian H. Stuart Hughes with the memorable sobriquet ''la plage des intellectuels.'') But as weather-beaten shacks and skinny-dipping in the ponds became the order of the day, the colony continued to maintain certain standards.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Going Public, N.B.A. Figure Sheds Shadow Life,'' May 16: Congratulations to the Suns' Rick Welts for coming out about his homosexuality. Not only can a sense of healing and wholeness now begin for him, but his example will also help athletes and nonathletes who struggle with accepting their sexuality. May he live the rest of his wonderful life in the freedom that comes from having the courage to be who he is. Phil Hall

The purpose of foreign policy,'' argued John F. Kennedy, ''is not to provide an outlet for our own sentiments of hope or indignation; it is to shape real events in a real world.'' And the real world is populated by other leaders, each with their own competing hopes and indignations. Below are the actors who, since Jimmy Carter, have strutted and fretted their hour upon the world stage.

On a stroll these days among the cheerful edifices of the Over-the-Rhine neighborhood in Cincinnati, originally the city's German community, it's easy to spot the pride locals take in its reputation as the country's greatest collection of 19th-century Italianate architecture, as well as one of its largest urban historic districts. It's also nearly impossible to believe how precarious its future seemed 10 years ago this spring, when riots erupted in this part of the city just north of downtown, prompting national headlines. A stream of revitalization efforts by both nonprofit and corporate entities since then is finally yielding a rush of new, independent businesses. ''It's a real village economy,'' said Seth Schott, who founded OTR Matters, a grassroots network that promotes the district's preservation and development, in January. ''When a new store opens, the established businesses help advertise and spread the word -- even if the only thing they have in common is their shared love of the neighborhood.'' ROSE MAURA LORRE

LESSER--Herbert, July 3, 1919-May 20, 2011. Devoted husband to the late Shirley. Beloved father and grandfather. A retired dentist in Valley Stream who served many local hospitals. Pops you made it to the finish line. Rest in peace. Love, Betty, Seth and Andy Kaye.

LOVITT--Priscilla (Patti) Taft, died peacefully in her home in Mill Valley, California, surrounded by her family, on May 15th, 2011 after a long battle with cancer. She was 70. She is survived by her devoted husband of 49 years, Ronald Lovitt of Mill Valley, California; her son Jonathan T. Lovitt of Mill Valley, California; her daughter Laura Lovitt Pandapas of Muir Beach, California; her daughter Sarah E. Lovitt of New York, New York; and her sister Sally Duplaix of Chatham, Massachusetts. Patti was a naturally gifted painter, a brilliant mind, extraordinary mother and loving wife. Her warmth, compassion, sense of humor, keen insight, sharp intelligence and wisdom will be missed beyond measure.

Bethanie Mattek-Sands After beating two former French Open champions, Ana Ivanovic and Francesca Schiavone, on clay in Madrid, Bethanie Mattek-Sands said, ''I feel like a true dirtballer.''

Now that Costa Rica's best breaks have been overrun, Nicaragua is luring wave riders with low-key surf camps and undiscovered beaches. Popoyo, on the southern Pacific coast, has the most consistent barrel, along with hotels like the Popoyo Beach Lodge (popoyobeachlodge.com; doubles from $55 ). But two and a half hours north of Managua and just west of the town of Chinandega lies the country's undeveloped northern Pacific coast - and dozens of breaks so new that many don't have names. This is where the pro surfer and model Holly Beck set up her camp, Suave Dulce (surfwithhollybeck.com) after she stopped competing in 2008. Nicaragua, says Beck, a California native, is the ideal place to ''help people experience the joy of getting pushed by the ocean.'' Many of Beck's students stay at El Coco Loco (011-505-8999-8662; elcocolocoresort.com; doubles from $100), a rustic resort near the town of Santa Maria del Mar with five palm-thatch cabanas near several surf spots. La Bahia Beach Hodel (011-505-8958-5075; labahiabeachhotel.com; doubles from $150) is a more luxurious option: four stone-and-teak casitas with outdoor showers, private pathways to one of Nicaragua's most beautiful beaches and three breaks in front of the hotel (with more nearby). Both resorts serve seafood delivered daily by local fishermen, and there's also plenty of the local catch at Al Cielo (011-505-8993-4840), a popular open-air palapa run by two French guys, with 360-degree views. Related: Surf Report

Stewart, a close friend and Board Trustee of NYU Langone Medical Center and former Trustee of NYU Langone Medical Center's Hospital for Joint Diseases. ABELE--Manlio G. Research Professor Emeritus, Department of Radiology, NYU School of Medicine died on May 5, 2011. He is survived by his son, Michael, as well as close friends and colleagues who were like family to him. Dr. Abele was born in Turin, Italy, on June 6, 1920. He graduated from Politechnic Institute in Turin, in 1943 with a doctorate in Electrical Engineering. He was appointed a Professor of Electromagnetics, at the National University of Cordoba, Argentina in 1948. In 1955, he joined the Atomic Center, San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina, where he directed a research laboratory and taught Physics in the graduate program. In 1959 he moved to the USA and taught Electrophysics at the Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn until 1965. From 1965 to 1976, at the General Applied Science Laboratories, Inc., in Westbury, NY, he led a team of researchers in a DARPA-funded study of the effects of the plasma flow fields and plasma wake on electromagnetic fields. He was recruited as a Research Professor to the Department of Radiology at NYU School of Medicine in 1976. His initial research there focused on novel CT reconstruction algorithms. In 1982, he won a landmark decision from the US Court of Patent Appeals that gave rise to the Freeman-Walter-Abele test used to determine if mathematical algorithms were a patentable subject matter. Since the early 1980s his research focused on MR imaging systems based on permanent magnets, the field where he left his important and lasting marks. His novel design methodology is described in his book: Structures of Permanent Magnets. Abele's yokeless magnet design provides a systematic mathematical formulation for prismatic structures that generate uniform fields in arbitrary cavities without the need of an external ferromagnetic yoke. The utility of yokeless design has been experimentally verified on fully operational medical MRIs, and more recently, on the magnetic spectrometer launched aboard the PAMELA satellite, which was launched into orbit in June 2006. The experimental demonstration of the properties of field confinement of Abele's yokeless magnetic structures was first established in the 1990s, at the US Army Electronics Technology and Devices Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ and later at the laboratory of Sumitomo Special Metals, Japan, where a large scale experimental model was built. The research work on medical applications of permanent magnet technology at NYU was done in collaboration with Esaote Biomedica, Genoa, Italy. Esaote developed several types of MRI units based on Abele's designs, including a lightweight Artoscan MRI dedicated for imaging the extremities. During his long and productive life Dr. Abele was awarded over 30 patents and published numerous scientific papers. As a colleague, he was inspiring both as an original thinker and for his high level of dedication. Although a perfectionist, he was always quick to reward a job well done with cookies from his ample supply, kept for many years in an impressively large safe. Dr. Abele was also a gifted artist, who at 19 had to choose between his love of art and science. Although he chose science as a profession, he pursued graphic arts as an avocation throughout his life. Many original sketches of family, friends, and favorite places decorated his home and office. In the company of family and friends, Dr. Abele revealed a wry sense of humor, a generous spirit, a heartfelt compassion for the welfare of others, and the highest degree of personal integrity. He will be long remembered and deeply missed.

ACKERMANN--Henry Harry J.,Sr., 90, of Freehold, NJ, died peacefully on May 18th, on the 65th anniversary of his marriage to his beloved wife, Margaret (nee Bauernschub) who died in 2004. Born in Baltimore, MD, to the late Henry A. and Isabelle (Dicke) Ackermann, he was the youngest of nine children and was predeceased by all of his siblings. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, after which he had a distinguished professional career as a chemist and computer scientist. However, the true loves of his life were his family and his faith. He was the devoted father of Henry, Jr (Valerie), Sister Marialice, ASCJ, Bruce (Judy), Philip (Susan), and Mark (June). He adored his 21 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. As a committed Roman Catholic, Harry was a daily communicant at St. Robert Bellarmine Church, Freehold and participated in numerous ministries in the various parishes that he was a member of throughout his life. He dedicated his life to the Blessed Mother and to the protection of the unborn. He was an active life member of the Fourth Degree of the Knights of Columbus for over 70 years. He was a Past Grand Knight of Hamilton Council 6213 and former Faithful Navigator of the Bishop Griffin Assembly 655. Visitation will be held on Sunday, May 22nd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Clayton & McGirr Funeral Home, 100 Elton-Adelphia Road, Freehold, NJ. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Monday at 11:00am at St. Robert Bellarmine RC Church, Freehold, NJ. Interment will follow at St. Rose of Lima Cemetery in Freehold. Memorial contributions may be made to the Apostles of the Sacred Heart, 295 Benham St., Hamden, CT 06514. Condolences may be sent to: www.claytonfuneralhome.com

DANNY DIAZ stared out into the Pacific, scanning the water, ready to dash at the right moment. ''We are here to catch a sider,'' Mr. Diaz, 24, said, referring to what he considers the perfect wave, as he stood on the sandy embankment where the inlet Estero Marga Marga meets the ocean in Viña del Mar, Chile. He was with a group of friends, all skimboarders, a sport Mr. Diaz described as ''a mix between skateboarding and surfing.'' Mr. Diaz, a South American skimboarding champion, called Viña del Mar ''the Chilean version of Laguna,'' adding that ''here you need to use more technique than in California.'' The water is chilly -- the reason he's in a wetsuit -- but that doesn't stop wave fanatics in this stretch of the Pacific coast.

LAZERE--Monroe R. Passed away peacefully at home on May 18, age 93. Beloved husband of Muriel for 64 years; wonderful, devoted father of Eric and Cathy and father-in-law of Maria; much loved and admired grandfather of Brian and Keith. The youngest of five children, he was born in New York City. A 1938 graduate of Cornell University, he majored in math and was junior Phi Beta Kappa. Ardent tennis and squash player. All around camper and boxing teacher. Waltz champion. Clever lyricist and poet. A 1943 graduate of Columbia Law School, he worked at Greenbaum Wolff and Ernst and served in the US Army. In 1951, he founded Lazere Financial Corporation which became a leader in asset-based lending. President and Chairman of the Board of the Commercial Finance Association. Author of first comprehensive textbook on commercial finance. Adjunct professor at Cornell and New York Universities. Despite becoming hard of hearing at age 18, he was an operaphile and music lover. Active in community affairs, he served as treasurer of the Westchester chapter of the National Urban League and on the White Plains Library Board. Member of Beachpoint Club. Above all, a terrific guy with a ready, dry sense of humor who will be missed by all who knew him. Private funeral services. Memorial service Sunday, May 22, at Ballard Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York at 4pm.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Some Sports Figures, Opinions Have a Price,'' May 12: The gold medalist Peter Vidmar resigned as the United States' chef de mission for next year's London Olympics after several reports revealed that he supported initiatives against same-sex marriage, based on his Mormon religious beliefs. As same-sex marriage is gaining greater acceptance, would Vidmar have had to resign if he supported initiatives for same-sex marriage? Gerald F. Holland

HAYNES--Beverly, 91, passed away peacefully in her East Village home on May 19, 2011. Beloved wife and mother to her predeceased husband Robert and daughter Sara Bauman, she will be dearly missed by her son Henry and grandchildren Daniel and Emily Bauman. Service Sunday, May 22, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. A beautiful and inspirational woman, Beverly's memory will remain strong in all their hearts.

The globe-trotting surferati have been quietly colonizing Mexico's Pacific coast for years. Alongside cheap and cheery beach shacks, you now find famous artists hanging out in French bistros. But not all is spoiled; the stretch of coastline from Acapulco to Puerto Vallarta offers a range of surf towns, from established to emerging. Pick your paradise. Sayulita

LIBERATORE--Nicholas A.,of Weston, CT, the beloved husband of Marianne Westpalm van Hoorn Liberatore, passed away peacefully on Friday, May 13, 2011 at the age of 94. Born on June 19, 1916 in New York City to Alexander and Angelina Liberatore, he grew up one of seven children on Staten Island. He served as a Captain in the US Army during WWII and later embarked on a successful career in international business that took him to Latin America and Spain. At retirement, he was Executive Vice President of Gentstar Ltd., San Francisco, but remained active well into his 70's as a full time consultant to the Royal Bank of Canada. He was an avid sailor, an inveterate story-teller and an active member of the business community who will be missed by all who knew him. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his children Virginia, George, Nicholas, Elliott and Mark; his stepchildren, Joseph and Willem Jewett and ten grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Jean MacAdam. Services were held at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, CT. To send an online condolence visit www.shaughnesseybanks.com

The queen of nose-riding Kassia Meador sticks to her home breaks in Oceanside, Calif., using Donald Takayama's long boards (hawaiianprodesigns.com). For newbies, she stresses patience: ''Surfing takes a lifetime to learn. It's about having a good time.''

Tavarua, the small, heart-shaped island in the Fijian archipelago, has two of the world's most sought-after waves, Cloudbreak and Restaurants. Since 1984, access to them had been controlled by the Tavarua Island Resort (tavarua.com). But last year, Fiji's military dictatorship put an end to the hotel's exclusive rights, to the delight of local Fijians and international surfers, who have begun boating to the breaks from neighboring islands. Look for other resorts to spring up nearby and take advantage of the new access. Related: Surf Report

This is an issue devoted to obsessives and ferreters -- who are always, invariably, my favorite people. We begin with Daria Werbowy, our cover girl and one of the fashion world's most sought-after women. When we first approached her with the idea of doing a little sailing for us in St. Bart's, the answer was an enthusiastic ''yes,'' followed by a pensive ''when?'' And that question had little to do with her busy life in fashion. Would her father's boat be in Barcelona or Guatemala? Would her own boat be in Latin America or Canada? In what vast expanse of water was her brother tossing an anchor? Everything was about knots and crafts and routes and captain's logs. It was like trying to book Patrick O'Brian's Jack Aubrey and not the face of Lancôme. Werbowy is a sailor first, model second, and her passion for the sea and ability at the helm is as jaw-dropping as her beauty. Then there are the writers. Consider Jean Hanff Korelitz, the novelist, who enjoys picking minuscule scraps of history out of the banks of the Thames, or Christopher Petkanas, who heeds Tangier's siren call to passionate eccentrics and pleasure seekers. Or Elaine Sciolino, the longtime New York Times foreign correspondent who has lived in France since 2002. Her new book, ''La Seduction,'' excerpted here, is a wonderfully nuanced investigation of how flirtation and provocation function in French society.

Because of an editing error, the 36 Hours column on May 8, about Detroit, misstated the history of a restaurant that recalls Detroit's French colonial roots. Good Girls Go to Paris Crepes opened in 2009, not 1702, and it was not called Le Detroit. That was the name of the city at its founding in 1701.

Claude Pimont, Partner, Casa Pestagua: Although Pimont has lived in Colombia for 30 years, the French-born screenwriter and archaeology enthusiast only moved to Cartagena in 2007, to renovate Casa Pestagua. The 11-room hotel, with its frescoed ceilings and lush, columned courtyard, was built in the 17th century as a palace for one of the city's richest men. ''After everybody talked about Cartagena as this hot spot, all these investors came in and bought up the old houses,'' Pimont says. ''The architecturally and historically important houses are rare these days.'' When he's not tending to his guests, Pimont indulges in the city's fabled night life, whether dining at the clubby La Vitrola restaurant (Calle de Baloco No. 2-01; 011-57-5-660-0711) or salsa dancing at Quiebra Canto (Carrera 8B No. 25-119; 011-57-5-664-1372). (PHOTOGRAPH BY DAVID NICOLAS)

Whether by filming an ode to NBC in a field or by having small-town Little Leaguers pace around a New York gallery and mutter ''good game'' to one another, Colin Snapp (left) and Daniel Turner frequently take aspects of globalized culture and consumerism and trickle them down to a rural level. The two New York-based artists, who recently began exhibiting collaborative work under the name Jules Marquis, share a Greenpoint studio but regularly shuttle to southeast Virginia, where they've created a nonprofit art space on a corner of the Turner family farm. Named Jericho Ditch, after a local logging canal, it serves as a venue and creative getaway for fellow artists. It also embodies the Jules Marquis ethos: from the outside, it's a shed in a field; inside, it's a big-city-gallery-style white box lighted by symmetrical fluorescent tubes. Snapp and Turner have two shows opening in June: at Jericho Ditch and at Martos Gallery in New York. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Poor urban neighborhoods in America are often food deserts — places where it is difficult to find fresh food.   There are few grocery stores; people may do all their shopping at bodegas, where the only available produce and meat are canned peaches and Spam.  If they want fruits and vegetables and chicken and fish, they have to take a bus to a grocery store.   The lack of fresh food creates a vicious cycle; children grow up never seeing it or acquiring a taste for it.  It is one reason that the poor are likelier to be obese than the rich.

Last week’s Numberplay puzzle, presented by Gary Antonick and suggested and masterfully moderated by Joshua Zucker, had all the hallmarks of a classic. This puzzle, known as the Ducci game or 4-number game, is easy to state and understand, uses a procedure a child can carry out, and yet it unlocks the door to fabulous mathematical riches. For those who missed it I would urge you to go back and take a look at it. Here is a brief restatement, given a slightly different visual model from last week. Given any four arbitrary positive integers a, b, c and d, representing the top rung of a ladder, you construct another step below it, consisting of the positive differences between them taken cyclically: |a-b|, |b-c|, |c-d| and |d-a|. An example 2-step ladder is:1 2 5 91 3 4 8It turns out that all such ladders eventually end as all the numbers become zeroes. One challenge was to find what initial numbers gave rise to the longest ladders, and it turned out that the champion quartets had a fascinating mathematical property.

At this time of year the Central Garden at the Getty Center in Los Angeles is particularly sublime. The unorthodox collection of more than 500 plants, shrubs and trees was brought together and landscaped by the artist Robert Irwin. London plane trees line a path that traverses a stream and descends into a plaza where purple bougainvillea draped over specially constructed metal arbors form a shaded canopy. And the lower bowl is a riot of herbs, vegetables and other plants in constant rotation. Work on the garden started many years before the museum opened in 1997. And despite the fact that, in garden years, 15 is relatively young, it feels very sure of itself.

With one fell swoop, Showtime has eliminated several female personalities from its lineup of original programming. On Monday it announced the cancellation of “The United States of Tara,” the comedy-drama starring Toni Collette as a housewife with dissociative identity disorder (commonly known as multiple personality disorder); the current season will be its last. “Tara,” which made its debut in 2009, came with an impressive pedigree, which included its creator, Diablo Cody, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of “Juno,” and the executive producer Steven Spielberg. And Ms. Collette was widely praised for her performance in the title role, winning an Emmy Award in 2009 and a Golden Globe in 2010. But ratings for the series have diminished, from 816,000 viewers for the premiere of Season 2 to 411,000 viewers for the debut of Season 3 in March, The Hollywood Reporter reported. By comparison, the season finale of Showtime’s historical drama “The Borgias” was watched by 810,000 viewers at 10 p.m. on Sunday, the network said.

Who better to judge Bally’s new Bally-Rina collection than the real ballerinas of the New York City Ballet? The differences between the Swiss luxury-house’s flats and your run-of-the-mill ballet ones are vast according to the company’s senior corps de ballet dancers, Gretchen Smith and Marika Anderson. The women work in nude leather Bloch dance shoes both in the classroom and throughout rehearsals. And when they’re not dancing they still prefer to slip into flats. “I’m really picky when it comes to flats because I wear them to the bone,” says Anderson, who previously wore Cole Haan because of the Nike-Air instep. “We really like the Bally-Rina’s in blue,” says Smith pointing out the shoe’s ultra low vamp. Smith also likes that the sole of the shoe is comfortable and how the inside looks like an actual pointe shoe. This summer, the company heads for a slew of performances in Saratoga and both women see themselves wearing Bally-Rina flats, Smith with a flowy high-waisted skirt; Anderson with fitted jeans and a T-shirt. They’ll pair them with matching Bally-Rina bags stuffed with the tools of the trade: several pairs of pointe shoes, flat shoes, tape, scissors, glue, needles and thread, water and vitamin B. The cute but functional special Bally-Rina collection comes in shades of navy, grass green and yellow – that should be more than enough to keep more than New York City ballerinas dancing.

(VH1) 50 CENT: THE ORIGIN OF ME This rapper, born Curtis Jackson, left, from Jamaica, Queens, traces his ancestry to Edgefield, S.C., where his great-great-great-grandmother Jane Jenkins was the slave of a prominent citizen. While in Edgefield (the birthplace of Senator Strom Thurmond, who died in 2003), 50 Cent confronts a museum docent about the racially charged symbolism of the Confederate flag. She, in turn, informs him that some of the slaves in the area were from Mongolia -- a statement that baffles 50 Cent. ''Black citizens of this country really needs to study the history, because it's just as much the black ancestry as it is the white ancestry,'' she tells him. Later, 50 Cent responds: ''She's offering her truth, what she's accepted as the truth based on information given to her. But I don't agree with it.'' In another segment, he talks about being adopted by his grandmother after his mother, a cocaine dealer who gave birth to him at 15, was killed when he was 12. 10 A.M. They know where you're standing, the direction you're moving in and if you're holding the phone vertically or horizontally. CHABRIS--Peter Daniel Peter Daniel Chabris, husband of Grace Amaral Chabris, died May 19, 2011, at his home in Cincinnati. He was 93. Born in New York City on August 11, 1917, he was the son of Italian immigrants Luigi and Esterina Caciagli. Mr. Chabris attended the College of the City of New York and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in English. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II. While stationed in North Carolina, he met and married his first wife, Anne Lee Butler, currently of Wilmington, NC. They had four children, Margaret Chabris of Dallas, the late Thomas Louis Chabris; Paul Chabris of Midlothian, VA, married to Dale Theriault Chabris, and John Chabris of Washington, NC. He later married Melody Richardson of Cincinnati with whom he had a son, Peter Chabris Jr., of Cincinnati, who is married to Lynn Rielly Chabris. He and his third wife, Grace, lived in Montclair, NJ, before the couple retired to Cincinnati. Mr. Chabris' professional life included executive positions in human resources and industrial relations with AT&T, W.R. Grace, Xerox, Travelers Insurance Company and Interpublic Group of Companies. He was Renaissance man, fluent in several languages, an international traveler, accomplished chess player, musician, sculptor, expert swimmer and devotee of opera and classical music. He also acted in little theater. In additional to his children, Mr. Chabris is survived by two brothers, Daniel D. Chabris of Madison, CT; Anthony Caciagli of Oceanside, CA; and three grandchildren, Krista Chabris, 20, of Midlothian, VA, and Sophia Chabris, seven, and Christopher Chabris, three, of Cincinnati.

There is no such thing as a really terrible golf course. If you're playing golf on it, how awful can it be? But if some courses are indisputably better than others, then inevitably, some are worse. Quite a bit worse, in my experience. So bad that they're worth a detour - if only because they make you grateful for the other better kind. Worseness is not necessarily a matter of maintenance, or the lack of it. One of the best courses I've ever played is Auchnafree, which was laid out by a shepherd, John Pollock, in a glen in Perthshire, Scotland. The cups were tin cans, and the groundskeeping crew consisted entirely of sheep, who took care of the mowing and the fertilizing. On the other hand, I have played resort courses so lush, so perfectly kept up, that they feel a little soporific and unnatural, with the fairways spooling away as if from rolls of Astroturf.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama struck back at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday, defending his stance that talks over a Palestinian state should be focused on Israel's pre-1967 borders, along with negotiated land swaps, and challenging Israel to ''make the hard choices'' necessary to bring about a stable peace. Mr. Obama, speaking before a conference of the influential American Israel Public Affairs Committee, offered familiar assurances that the United States' commitment to Israel's long-term security was ''ironclad.'' But citing the rising political upheaval near Israel's borders, he presented his peace plan as the best chance Israel has to avoid growing isolation.

Our family constitution gives a veto to the women's caucus, and there is no override provision. MITCH DANIELS, Governor of Indiana, announcing that he would not seek the Republican nomination for president, partly because his wife and four daughters had deep reservations about campaigning. [A1]

Nearly two weeks ago, I wrote an article about the Polara golf ball, a newly redesigned ball that is said to correct slices and hooks off the tee by as much as 75 percent. I tried to slice and hook the ball without much success. Then I went to a driving range, where I approached other golfers and told them I had a ball that wouldn't slice. Almost universally, the reaction was: ''Oh, yeah? I bet I can slice it.''

SAN FRANCISCO -- Cisco, the maker of Internet routing gear, customized its technology to help China track members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement, according to a federal lawsuit filed last week by members of the movement. The lawsuit, which relies on internal sales materials, also said that Cisco had tried to market its equipment to the Chinese government by using inflammatory language that stemmed from the Maoist Cultural Revolution.

STEINBROCK--Jack, on May 22, 2011. WWII veteran. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Susan Steinbrock and father-in-law of Patrick Smith. Dear brother of Bess Blumenfeld. Loving grandfather of Harriet and Simon Smith. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Alzheimer's Association. Services Tuesday, 1pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Three artists who are tops in their genre have new albums out this week, including Brad Paisley, above, who is releasing his ninth studio album, ''This Is Country Music.'' ''Born This Way'' by Lady Gaga, and ''Glee: The Music, Vol. 6,'' from the popular Fox TV series, will also be released. Music sales are mostly a matter of individual songs sold by MP3 download, so album sales for these artists are impressive: Lady Gaga sold 2.6 million albums last year, and Glee Cast, 3.6 million. Brad Paisley has sold 10.1 million albums over his career, and sold 617,000 in 2010. SHELLY FREIERMAN

NATIONAL An article on Friday about the growing difficulty caused by light pollution at astronomical observatories in southern Arizona misidentified the part of the large telescope at the MMT Observatory that was endangered by an accumulation of ash from a recent wildfire. It was a mirror, not a lens.

Every few minutes in ''Too Big to Fail,'' the film about the darkest days of the financial crisis in 2008 that will have its premiere Monday on HBO, something happens that once seemed unbelievable. Banks collapse. Balance sheets crumble. Government officials plot extraordinary interventions to curb the free fall. And every few minutes, a news clip or a sound bite from CNBC pops up, seemingly as a reminder to the viewer that it all really happened in real time. In a sense, the news became an extra actor in the film.

LYNCH--Bernard E.,83, of Katonah, NY, died May 20, 2011. He was born in Hamden, CT. A graduate of Fordham College, he received an MBA from NYU. After rising through the ranks at Macys, Gimbels and Alexanders department stores, he had a second career at Baruch College where he was Director of Business Programs, Continuing and Professional Studies until 2003. He also taught management courses at Baruch's Zicklin School of Business until 2008. An Army veteran, he married Ann-Marie Brady in 1951. They moved to Katonah in 1956. He was a lector at St. Mary's Church and into his 70s, an avid ice hockey player. He is survived by his wife; his children and their spouses Thomas (Gael); Kathleen (Brian Robinson); Eileen (Peter Meyer); Patricia (Brian Moss); John (Francesca), and Jim (Marilena), 16 grandchildren, and his sisters Barbara Ortoleva (Guy) and Carol Driscoll. A wake will be held at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Mary's Church, Katonah, Tuesday, 10am. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne.

Last Tuesday, Sony's top managers defended their response to the attack that forced them to shut down the PlayStation Network for almost a month. The network went back online on May 14, but some said the company's reaction to the attack was too slow. In an interview at the company's New York offices, Howard Stringer, below, Sony's chief executive, argued that Sony had responded to the attack in a timely manner, and said that as executives learned about the extent of the attack, they regularly shared information with customers.

NEW YORK The On Religion column on Saturday, about a nationwide pilot program intended to keep actively Catholic college students just as actively Catholic after graduation, misspelled the surname of a Wall Street executive active in philanthropy, who was one of three people whose meetings in 2004 led to the initial notion of the program. He is Geoffrey T. Boisi, not Biosi. The article also misstated the organization under whose aegis the pilot program was begun for the 2010-2011 academic year. It is the National Leadership Roundtable on Church Management, not the National Leadership Council on Church Management.

Most social networking services are for sharing what you've done in the past or what you're doing right now. A new one, WhereBerry, is for sharing what you want to do in the future. On WhereBerry, which opened to the public last Tuesday, people post activities they want to do someday, like restaurants they want to try, movies they hope to see or events they plan to attend. Their friends can comment and make plans.
INTERACTIVE FEATURE Musicians who found a practice space and home at 106 Rivington Street in the Lower East Side, which is being shut down, discuss what the building meant to them.

RASKIN--Marjorie H. Devoted, dedicated, appreciated assistant for 39 loyal years to Melvin and Norman and 15,000 students whose hearts she touched at The Stecher and Horowitz School of the Arts in Cedarhurst. She was unique. Deepest condolences to her family. Melvin Stecher Norman Horowitz

International audiences carried ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,'' the fourth film in this series from Walt Disney Studios, to $346.4 million in worldwide ticket sales since the movie opened abroad on Wednesday. The film has posted $90.1 million in domestic ticket sales since opening in the United States on Friday, making it the top-ranked film in North America for the weekend. Though the performance for ''On Stranger Tides'' lagged that of the previous two installments, it was strong enough to lift overall North American ticket sales to about $167 million, up 11.34 percent from the same weekend last year, according to Hollywood.com, which tracks box-office results.

A once sleepy special election in western New York has turned into a national battle, with the candidates, parties and outside groups spending more than $6 million on radio and television advertising. REPUBLICANS
DELEHANTY--James B. May 23, 2010 We miss you everyday and you are always in our thoughts and prayers. Your Loving Family

MILKOVICH--Zoran, age 89, of Hackensack, formerly of Teaneck, died peacefully on Friday, May 20, 2011. Beloved husband of 60 years to the late Annette (nee Dziama) (2011). Devoted father of Lisa Madara and loving grandfather of Nicholas, Daniel, Anthony and Erika. Zoran was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava in New York since 1950, serving on the Executive Board and Restoration/Development Committee. He was the 1st President and a Board of Trustees member of St. Vladimir's Theological Foundation. Zoran was the Vice President of Personal Trusts & Estates for Chase Manhattan Bank for over 35 years. He was a member of the FROC and FOCA. Friends and family will be received on Tuesday from 1p-3p and 6p-8p at Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck. A Funeral Mass will be Wednesday at 10:00am at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 20 West 26th St., New York, NY. Interment will follow at St. Tikhons Cemetery, South Canaan, PA.

A police spokesman said Thursday that the hotel housekeeper who was allegedly assaulted by Dominique Strauss-Kahn did not knock on the door of his suite, and did not use a card key to enter. Instead, she entered a door that was already open, as a room-service waiter left. The new details were part of a fuller picture of the events in the hotel suite that emerged as the authorities worked out the final details of Mr. Strauss-Kahn's bail package. While it means they will not have the electronic footprint of the housekeeper's card key as evidence, they will presumably have the room-service waiter's testimony -- and the information on the time when he entered if he used his card key -- to set the time of the attack. Paul J. Browne, the New York Police Department's chief spokesman, also offered some other additional details of the encounter on the 28th floor of the Sofitel on 44th Street last Saturday afternoon. He said the housekeeper cleaned the living room and dining room before she entered the bedroom, and that she discovered Mr. Strauss-Kahn there, naked. Before, police accounts indicated she may have been in the bedroom when he emerged from the bathroom.

PARK--Henry C. 1962 - May 17, 2011 of Somerville, MA and formerly Hopewell Junction, NY, passed away much too soon and unexpectedly from aortic rupture. A courageous champion of social justice, Henry was well known by Harvard classmates for political activism against apartheid, his involvement in the student assembly, founding of the Radical Academics group, and contributions to The Harvard Crimson where he worked to inform and create change for the better. Henry graduated cum laude from Harvard. Henry loved to swim, run, workout and play electric guitar, but his greatest passion was to research, read, write, and contribute to discussions on social and political issues. It directed his life. Henry managed staff and co-edited the opinion page of the Michigan Daily while earning his doctorate in sociology at the University of Michigan. Afterwards, Henry taught sociology at various universities in hopes of educating and inspiring students and pursuing research. He was a research scholar interested in China and Russia. He later worked as a statistical consultant while independently publishing, reading, researching, and attending lectures about social and political issues. His family and friends miss him very much. He is survived by his mother Margaret Park, his father K.C. Park, his brother Stuart Park, his sister Rosanne Park and a nephew and niece. A memorial service will be held at the MIT Chapel, 44 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA on July 10th at 1pm.

Robert Selden Garnett, the first general killed in the Civil War, was buried in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, but his family did not want visitors to the cemetery to know it. Named brigadier general in 1861, Garnett briefly commanded Confederate troops in western Virginia before being shot dead in the battle of Corrick's Ford on July 13, 1861.

This week, it was announced that ''America's Most Wanted,'' hosted by John Walsh, the longest running perp walk in television history, would no longer be regularly broadcast on Fox. With the future of Mr. Walsh's hunt for bad guys uncertain, who will speak for the victims of crime? Well, there's always Nancy Grace.

The balance of power between the United States and Asia has shifted dramatically since 1956, when John D. Rockefeller III founded the Asia Society to promote greater understanding of Asia in the United States. In response, the Asia Society is shifting its center of gravity from New York to its outposts in Hong Kong, Mumbai, Manila and elsewhere. As part of this effort, the Asia Society is for the first time naming two leaders of the board, one based in the United States and one in Asia. Henrietta Holsman Fore, a former chief of the United States Agency for International Development, and Ronnie C. Chan, a real estate developer in Hong Kong and China, will assume joint leadership of the board on June 10, taking over from Charles R. Kaye. Ms. Fore is the first woman and Mr. Chan the first Asian, to lead the board. Next year the Asia Society will open a new $52 million center in Hong Kong, which will include a museum, theater, cafe, event spaces and offices.
A look at the members of the GoDown Arts Centre in Nairobi, Kenya.
The prospective buyer of 49 percent of the Mets, whomever it is, will inherit a team in serious financial straits. The Mets are seeking $200 million for the minority stake.
A look at the day in sports from a marathon match on the French Open clay courts of Roland Garros to an N.B.A. showdown on the hard court in Miami.
The recent public offerings by LinkedIn and Yandex have grabbed the attention of investors, but small technology startups are expecting more than just scraps from the venture capital table.

The recent initial public offerings by Internet companies including LinkedIn and Yandex are grabbing the attention of investors and making headlines, but small technology start-ups are expecting more than just scraps from the venture capital table.

NBC announced during the Tuesday night finale of “The Biggest Loser” that professional tennis player Anna Kournikova will be the new celebrity trainer on the reality show, replacing Jillian Michaels.

WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, you learn something new every day. The American International Group‘s long-anticipated stock sale raised at least $8.7 billion on Tuesday, with most of the proceeds going to taxpayers.

Another favorite television character will be disappearing next fall with the departure of Elliot Stabler, the detective played by the actor Christopher Meloni in the long-running NBC series “Law & Order: SVU.”

Waves of sorrow and indignation rippled across the Northern states in the wake of the fatal shooting of Elmer Ellsworth, a charismatic young colonel who had built a national following in the early days of the war only to be shot dead by an Alexandria, Va., innkeeper on May 24. But few felt the loss as keenly as his trusted lieutenant and friend Edward Knox.

Shares of Yandex, a Russian search engine barely known in the United States, surged by more than 55 percent on Tuesday, signifying the latest multibillion-dollar technology offering and stoking the debate about whether this market has the makings of a bubble.

Give “American Idol” producers credit for having a proper sense of dynamics. Michelle Obama seems to be pleasing both sides of the Atlantic with her fashion choices during the state visit to England. She arrived in the country on Tuesday morning dressed in a royal blue outfit by Preen, a British label. Later, at Buckingham Palace, she wore a dress by the American Barbara Tfank. She then changed into a purple dress by the London designer Roksanda Ilincic for a visit to 10 Downing Street. For a white-tie dinner at the palace on Tuesday night, the first lady chose a ruched ivory georgette gown by Tom Ford, an American who has his design offices in London, where he lives part of the year. The Ford number looks super on her — flattering neckline, perfect fit, just right for all the pomp.

My column this week looks at Amherst College’s impressive recent track record of recruiting low- and middle-income students. Amherst now has a much higher share of Pell Grant recipients — who tend to come from the lower-half of the income distribution — than most other elite colleges.

José Cláudio Ribeiro da Silva, a Brazilian rain forest activist, and his wife are shot dead near their home in Para State, in the Amazon. In a speech last year, Mr. da Silva acknowledged that his work battling illegal loggers put him in grave danger. “I will protect the forest at all costs. That is why I could get a bullet in my head at any moment — because I denounce the loggers and charcoal producers,” he said. [The Guardian]

In researching my contribution to our list of Stuff We Like That Maybe You Won’t, I’d originally intended to recommend the poetry of Frederick Seidel, which I turn to habitually for a rush of dread and pleasure, until I realized it’s quite possible you will like it, or that you already do. Which is not to say Seidel is impossible to not-love: He has been called “crass, disturbing, a name-dropping, upmarket sinner”; he has also been called “America’s greatest living poet.” In fact, he was called both in the same article (specifically, the display text to the article), when Wyatt Mason profiled him for the Times magazine back in 2009.
A House panel approved a plan on Tuesday to delay several rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market, a leading player in the financial crisis.

President Obama’s campaign manager, Jim Messina, met privately on Monday night with donors close to his erstwhile rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, as the campaign sought to knit together and mobilize the Democratic fund-raising elite in advance of the 2012 election.

Balking at the high price of coal that fuels much of China’s electricity grid, the nation’s state-owned utility companies are defying government planners by deliberately reducing the amount of electricity they produce, Keith Bradsher reports. The companies say they face financial ruin if the government continues to tightly limit the prices they can charge customers.

As protesters filled Tahrir Square in Cairo this spring, one of them turned to Alaa Al Aswany and asked him to write a novel about the revolution. Moments later the protester was dead, killed by a sniper. This would be enough to throw any writer into the spotlight, except that Al Aswany didn’t need any help getting there. What made him a household name in Egypt was his first novel, “The Yacoubian Building.” It portrayed Egypt as a corrupt society, whose public mores were belied by private sins. Considered somewhat scandalous, it nonetheless became a bestseller in the Arab world and was even made into a feature film.

Starting Sept. 1, double-digit increases in health insurance premiums for individuals and small businesses will be subject to a review and possible rejection by state and federal officials. The change is part of the new Affordable Care Act, and is meant to make sure that premium increases are justified.
Invoking the Fukushima disaster, a new study warns that crowded pools of spent fuel at nuclear power plants in the United States could pose an even more serious risk, Matthew L. Wald reports.

The director Mike Mills is considered a jack-of-all-trades in the indie world (he’s directed music videos and designed album covers for bands like Sonic Youth, Air and the Beastie Boys). So it’s no surprise that his soon-to-be-released dramedy, “Beginners,” about a young man who learns that his father is gay and has terminal cancer, is more than just a film. “I seem to need to make a lot of stuff,” he jokingly says. Collateral material includes a book of sketches, aptly titled “Mike Mills: Drawings From the Film ‘Beginners,’ ” and some animated shorts to accompany them. T caught up with Mills to talk about “Beginners” and its never-ending possibilities.

Before a hand-picked audience of boisterous fans, Oprah Winfrey taped the final hour of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” in Chicago on Tuesday afternoon, effectively lowering the curtain on the nation’s most popular daytime talk program.

Small museums don’t often find themselves at the center of international investigations, but last year the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., did, when agents from the Department of Homeland Security tracked an altarpiece stolen in Italy in 1971 to the Speed’s store rooms. The piece, a triptych featuring a Madonna and child that may date from as long ago as the 14th century, was stolen from a villa in Goito, southwest of Verona; two years later, the museum bought it from Newhouse Galleries in New York for $38,000. Under a settlement negotiated by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and announced on Monday, the Speed will soon turn over the work to Homeland Security, which will transfer it to Italian cultural authorities. (The collector who had owned it in 1971 has since died, and the authorities will be responsible for determining who is now entitled to the work.)

This month we're experimenting with a new format in which we feature a multimedia project on NYTimes.com and provide questions and activity ideas for teaching and learning with it. American Ballet Theater has announced a replacement for the injured principal dancer Herman Cornejo. Ivan Vasiliev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, will appear with Ballet Theater as a guest artist for three performances during the company’s spring season, said Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director. Mr. Vasiliev will replace Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew from scheduled performances in “The Bright Stream” for the June 11 matinee and the evening of June 14. He will also replace Mr. Cornejo in the leading role of Franz in “Coppélia” on June 16.

KABUL, Afghanistan — There’s an old saying here that goes “awaza sar-e chowk,” a rumor from the roundabout. If a bit of news seems hard to believe, you might hear it. Kabul residents found themselves saying it plenty on Monday when Afghan media reported the news that Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban’s reclusive, one-eyed leader, was dead. The news sprang from the National Directorate of Security, the country’s main intelligence agency. Yes, it came from unnamed sources inside the agency, which publicly would say only that Mullah Omar was missing, but it carried enough currency that Western officials, though skeptical, would not come right out and say it was wrong.

I was on the “Today” show on Monday discussing my Sunday column about “legislating parenting.” It was an interesting day to be in the studio, with news from Joplin, Mo.,  breaking all around. The everyday struggles of parenting get put in their place when you know there are parents out there who have lost everything.

Tiger Woods said Tuesday that he spent the last week wearing a protective boot on his left leg to immobilize his sore left Achilles’ tendon, and hobbled around on crutches to protect the strained medial collateral ligament in his knee and prevent further pain to his sore back. “I’ve been creating China ink paintings pretty steadily for the eight past years,” says John Patrick, the designer of Organic by John Patrick. But they were done only as gifts, not as a way of making money. All of that changed when Alicia Lubowski-Jahn of Fair Folks & a Goat, the artsy specialty store, contacted Patrick to sign him up for an art show to promote sustainable and socially responsible designs. There were two problems. Lubowski-Jahn, who organized the show, “Leaf // Cloud: Nature Tangible and Transcendent,” loves color, but Patrick’s paintings are black and white. Also, Patrick, who is an environmentalist, did not previously use organic paint.

Reversing the food safety dictates of decades, the United States Department of Agriculture has announced it is no longer necessary to cook meat (except ground meat) to an internal temperature of 160 degrees. The new magic number for pork chops and other cuts is a much juicier 145 degrees, plus a three minute resting time. This allows the internal temperature to rise slightly, but also has the culinary benefit of thickening the juices so they don’t run out when the meat is cut.

The music executive Clive Davis is giving an additional $5 million gift to the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, allowing the expansion of the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music into the Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, school officials announced Tuesday. The gift will make it possible for the school to recruit additional working professionals as faculty members, establish a generous scholarship fund, facilitate the recruitment of young talent from around the world and increase the number of students, university officials said in a statement. Two new programs will be created to bring in talented high school students. Future Music Moguls will be a free program for students in the New York City area, and the Summer High School Programs in Recorded Music will be open to students everywhere.

Social media, eco-lodging and a D.I.Y. ethic intersect at HI Matic, a new B&B-hostel hybrid in the hip Paris neighborhood of EsBas (East Bastille). The hotel takes a plugged-in approach to hospitality, eschewing full-service concierge and staff for a digitally customizable experience. Not only can guests tailor nearly every detail of their stay on touch-screens throughout the building, but they can also share information with the room next door – or, if they want, with all 42 rooms at once. The organic breakfast is served through futuristic vending machines, which also offer books, aromatherapy diffusers and other goodies. Each visitor receives a personalized list of exhibitions and shows recommended by local experts, and two electronic music stations – one mellow, one groovier – are available on every floor, courtesy of the German record label Kompakt. Matali Crasset, a Philippe Starck protégée who has opened three other hotels with the HI group (two in Nice and one in Nefta, Tunisia), created Ryokan-inspired rooms with modular furniture and floor mattresses. She chose the area for its authenticity and charm. “There are lots of bars and it’s fun, but the neighborhood is not touristy,” she says. “It has kept its local flavor, with mom-and-pop shops and cafés.” Among her favorite spots is Septime (80 rue de Charonne), a new foodie hotspot directly across the street from the hotel where the star chef Bertrand Grébaut concocts simple but sophisticated dishes that le tout Paris is raving about.

This list of recommendations was generated with a twist. Staff members were asked to identify things that differentiated their taste from that of their friends and colleagues: What do we like that others in our lives either don’t like or don’t know about? What is idiosyncratically ours? Some, you’ll see, took this occasion to reveal their particular guilty pleasures. Others showed us a side of themselves we didn’t know existed — is there really among us someone who enjoys “Alf”? And who watches shark videos? Explaining war to kids is always hard, but when you’re part of a military family, the task is even more difficult because it’s so personal. When my sons were little, their father was in the Navy Reserve as an intelligence officer with the Seabees, the Navy’s construction division. The boys understood what the military was in a very hazy “It must involve a ship, Daddy going away, and a large yellow bee” kind of way. But because their father wasn’t directly in harm’s way, I was able to gloss over hard questions about war and just concentrate on the fun parts of having a dad in the military from a toddler’s perspective — serving the country and wearing really cool hats.

By the way, Daniel Klein conducted an experiment for a George Mason University working paper that illustrates our hunger for cooperation. He asked groups of people in a room to sing a song together. But one person in the room was instructed not to sing unless the other people paid him some money. The question was: Do people desire complete group cohesion so much they are willing to pay to avoid having an outlier/dissident in their group. The groups decided to pay money to achieve what Klein calls “encompassment” 47.4 percent of the time.
