Harvard researchers following 47,911 men found that those who drank six or more cups a day were almost 20 percent less likely to develop prostate cancer over two decades than those who drank none.
Doctors in the Netherlands say a 6-year-old boy allergic to peanuts went into anaphylactic shock after receiving a blood transfusion from donors who had been snacking on peanuts.
A 47 million-year-old lizard specimen found in Germany indicates that snakes and the limbless lizards that superficially resemble them evolved independently.
Theodore J. Forstmann is tired. Sitting on a couch last week in his office on the 45th floor of the General Motors building, he apologized for his lack of energy.

Here's hoping that the approach of his 70th birthday finds Bob Dylan in a better mood than the weeks preceding his 25th. In an interview from 1966, conducted by the critic and journalist Robert Shelton and recently posted by BBC News, Mr. Dylan, then 24, talks about having overcome a heroin habit and shares some grim thoughts on death and what he calls ''this suicidal thing.'' Mr. Shelton, who covered folk and pop music for The New York Times and wrote several reviews of Mr. Dylan's performances that proved crucial at the start of that singer-songwriter's career, held the interview while Mr. Dylan was traveling in a private plane to Lincoln, Neb. The BBC said that the interview tape was rediscovered amid research for an anniversary edition of Mr. Shelton's 1986 biography, ''No Direction Home: The Life and Music of Bob Dylan.'' (Mr. Shelton died in 1995.)

SCHONHORN--Irwin P.,74, on May 23rd. Surrounded by his family, wife Judith, and three children Jill, Susan, and Gregg. Beloved brother of Harold and grandfather of Julia and Ben. Service Wednesday, 12:30pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

An article on Monday about President Obama's defense of his proposals for Middle East peace talks before a pro-Israel group misidentified the leadership position of Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, who said on Fox News Sunday that the proposals are ''not good for Israel.'' He is the Senate minority leader, not majority leader.
SCHONHORN--Irwin. Our very dear friend. We will miss you. Maureen and David Kwiat

FARRINGTON--Betty W.,was born October 31, 1923 in Philadelphia, PA and died in Sarasota, FL on May 20, 2011. She was the daughter of Clarence Edward Wood and Helen Boley Wood. She married Richard Korb Farrington on June 12, 1948 in Philadelphia. He died August 5, 1980. Surviving are three daughters, Diane Farrington Macia (Gary) of Hampton, NJ; Deborah A. Farrington, New York, NY; Elizabeth Farrington Statman (Eric); three grandchildren Nicholas Farrington Macia, Matthew Farrington Statman and Olivia Katharine Statman; one sister Joan W. Petaccio of Medford, NJ and one sister in law Joan H. Wood of Sarasota, FL; nieces and nephews Paul, Virginia, Susan, David, John and Amy. She was preceded in death by her parents and brother David C. Wood. Betty moved early in her marriage to Morristown, NJ where she was a member of the Presbyterian Church on the Green and then to Scituate, MA where she was a member and deacon of The First Congregational Church and active in community affairs including as President of the Scituate Garden Club. She came to Sarasota, FL in 1991, home of her sister in law, and enjoyed Selby Gardens, the Symphony and Opera. She was the kindest, most considerate, thoughtful person her daughters had ever met and leaves many friends as a testament. She was gracious, loving, fun and made us laugh. She loved flowers, nature, travel and her family. We will smile every time we think of her and were blessed to have her as our mother and grandmother. Funeral services were held in Sarasota, Florida, with interment to be in East Hanover, New Jersey at a later date. Arrangements by Toale Brothers Funeral Homes, Sarasota, FL.

GOLDMAN INQUIRY Goldman Sachs may receive subpoenas from the Justice Department, and the firm will probably then face a sweeping criminal investigation of its mortgage securities operations. Such subpoenas would indicate that prosecutors have found enough information about potential criminal conduct. Subpoenas alone would not mean that the Justice Department is poised to file criminal charges, since the inquiry could end once Goldman responded. But the specter of federal prosecutors taking such action would certainly weigh on the firm. White Collar Watch looks at the possible steps in a Justice Department inquiry.

It was the spring of 1961. President John F. Kennedy, speaking of new frontiers and projecting the vigor of youth, had been in office barely four months, and April had been the cruelest. On the 12th, Yuri Gagarin became the first human to orbit Earth -- one more space triumph for the Soviet Union. Though the flight was not unexpected, it was nonetheless deflating; it would be more than a month before Alan Shepard became the first American in space, and that was on a 15-minute suborbital flight. On the 17th, a force of anti-Castro exiles, trained by the C.I.A., invaded communist Cuba at the Bay of Pigs -- a fiasco within 36 hours. Mr. Kennedy's close aide Theodore Sorensen described him on the 19th as ''anguished and fatigued'' and ''in the most emotional, self-critical state I had ever seen him.''
This just in: Lt. M. K. Schwenk's first name was Milton, not Melton, as his obituary said. In 1899.

The leap Jose Bautista took last year was impressive. After spending four years as a fringe part-time player, he hit 54 home runs and was rewarded with a five-year, $65 million contract. But what Bautista, the Toronto Blue Jays' new star slugger, has done so far in 2011 defies comprehension. Entering Monday's game against the Yankees, he was hitting .353 and leading the league in home runs (18) and walks (39), even as the American League over all slumped to its lowest offensive level since 1981. As a result, his on-base and slugging percentages, of .500 and .816, were a combined 165 percent above the league average - a ratio only 3 points shy of the record set by Barry Bonds in 2002.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the ''Nancy Grace'' true-crime show on HLN, misidentified in some copies the university at which Jonathan Turley teaches. Mr. Turley, who commented on the show, is a law professor at George Washington University, not Georgetown University.

An article on April 27 about the unforeseen challenges created by the decline of cursive handwriting paraphrased incorrectly comments by a spokesman for the ACT standardized test. He said that students are not required to write in cursive on the ACT, not that he was not familiar with a cursive requirement.

GROOPMAN--Jacob, M.D.,The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the sudden death of Dr. Jacob Groopman. Dr. Groopman was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center for 37 years beginning with his residency. He was Chief Resident in 1977 - 1978. In 1980 he became the Assistant Director of the Pulmonary Division and in 1986 thru the present he was the Associate Director of the Division of Pulmonary and Critical Care. From 1985 - 1999 he was the Director of the Department of Community Medicine and Community Health Services. He was a caring and compassionate physician, teacher and friend. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his sister. H. Wasserman, MD, Pres. E. Fitzpatrick, MD, Pres. Elect G. Neiderman, MD, Secy. E. Chapnick, MD, Treas. W. Wexelman, MD, Past Pres.

A free concert series in Brooklyn promoted by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, will move to a new performance space in Coney Island after a dispute with neighbors around the park where the concerts took place for 20 summers. Mr. Markowitz announced on Monday that the Seaside Summer Concert Series, held since 1991 at Asser Levy/Seaside Park, on the border of Coney Island and Brighton Beach, would move this year to West 21st Street in Coney Island, a space once used by the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. Last summer two synagogues across the street from the stage sued the city over noise violations by the concerts, and the synagogues and other local residents also opposed a planned $64 million amphitheater for the park. Earlier this year the city's corporation counsel decided that the concerts would not be held at Asser Levy.

An article on Dec. 13, 2008 about President Obama's closest circle of Chicago friends misidentified the medical specialty of Dr. Cheryl Rucker-Whitaker. She is an internist with expertise in hypertension, not a cardiologist. (The error came to the attention of The New York Times only recently, in the course of a correspondent's research.)

PAYTON--Robert L.,84, of Carmel, IN, passed away on May 19, 2011. Born August 23, 1926, in South Bend, IN. Son of John and Mamie Burns Payton. Married Pauline S. Payton, with whom he spent 60 wonderful years. Philanthropist, first professor of philanthropic studies and founding director Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University (IUPUI); author; foundation executive; president C. W. Post College and Hosfstra University; US Ambassador; WWII veteran. Above all, he was a remarkable public teacher, inspiring action through "books, ideas, talk." Survived by a sister, one son, two grandsons, and an adoring family. Preceded in death by two sons, two brothers, and his wife Pauline. Donations to the Matthew and Joseph Payton Philanthropic Studies Library at IUPUI.

The new Broadway musical ''The Book of Mormon'' and the musical revival of ''Anything Goes'' each won five Drama Desk Awards on Monday night, while ''War Horse'' and ''The Normal Heart'' won for outstanding play and play revival at a ceremony honoring theater work on Broadway and Off Broadway. ''The Book of Mormon,'' one of this season's biggest critical and commercial hits, won for outstanding musical, director, music, lyrics and orchestrations. ''Anything Goes'' won for outstanding revival, actress in a musical (Sutton Foster, above center), choreography (Kathleen Marshall), sets and sound design. Norbert Leo Butz won for actor in a musical (''Catch Me If You Can''), while the featured acting awards for musicals went to Laura Benanti (''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'') and John Larroquette (''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying''). Among the recipients in the play categories, Bobby Cannavale won the outstanding actor award for ''The ---------------------- With the Hat,'' and Frances McDormand won for outstanding actress for ''Good People.'' The featured awards went to Brian Bedford (''The Importance of Being Earnest'') and Edie Falco (''The House of Blue Leaves''). The director award in the play competition went to Joel Grey and George C. Wolfe for ''The Normal Heart,'' whose cast also received an ensemble performance award. A full list of winners is at dramadeskawards.com.

Freddy Adu came in from the cold -- and from the second division in Turkey -- when he was one of 23 players named to the United States roster for next month's friendly against Spain and the Concacaf Gold Cup. The United States plays Spain on June 4 in Foxborough, Mass., then opens play in the Gold Cup against Canada on June 7 in Detroit. Adu, 21, a midfielder, was signed by Major League Soccer at 14. He was transferred to Benfica of Portugal in 2007 and has since played at Monaco (France), Belenenses (Portugal), Aris (Greece) and his current team, Caykur Rizespor. More at nytimes.com/sports.

The telephones, intercoms, typewriters and piano keys of Franklin Shepard Inc. will soon be ringing, buzzing and tapping away again in a revival of ''Merrily We Roll Along'' that James Lapine will direct for the 19th season of New York City Center's Encores! program, press representatives for the musical-revival series said on Monday. ''Merrily,'' the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical that takes a backward-in-time look at the disintegration of a songwriting team's professional and personal relationships, will open the Encores! season on Feb. 8 and run through Feb. 12. The musical, based on George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart's play of the same title, played just 16 regular performances in its original Broadway run in 1981 but has gradually gained stature with Sondheim aficionados and musical-theater fans; many directors have since mounted revivals of it, including Michael Grandage and Mr. Lapine, a frequent Sondheim collaborator. No casting was announced for the Encores! production (though Raul Esparzahas memorably played Franklin Shepard's long-suffering creative partner, Charley Kringas, in past revivals, as did Euan Morton in the recent Broadway revue ''Sondheim on Sondheim.'')

8 P.M. (TCM) PLAYING THE PONIES Turner Classic Movies continues its tribute to horses and those who love them with ''Kids and Horses, Part 2.'' The lineup begins with ''The Black Stallion'' (1979), Carroll Ballard's adaptation of the Walter Farley novel about a boy (Kelly Reno, above) who becomes the soul mate of an Arabian steed after the two are shipwrecked. After being rescued, the boy trains the horse to race against the world's fastest thoroughbreds. ''The Black Stallion Returns,'' the 1983 sequel in which the horse is stolen from its young friend (Mr. Reno, again) by its former Arabian owners, follows at 10:15; ''Run Wild, Run Free'' (1969), about a mute 10-year-old English boy (Mark Lester) who begins to speak after meeting a wild albino pony on the moors, at 12:15 a.m.; ''White Mane'' (1953), a winner of the Cannes Grand Prize for best short film, in which a boy (Alain Emery) goes in search of a wild stallion in the marshy Camargue region of France famous for its ancient breed of horses, at 2; ''Sylvester'' (1985), about an orphaned girl (Melissa Gilbert) who tries to rear her younger brothers while training a Texas bronco for the National Equestrian Finals, at 3; and ''Gypsy Colt'' (1954), Andrew Marton's film (a remake of ''Lassie Come Home'') in which a faithful horse undertakes a perilous journey to return to the family he loves. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The finalists, Lauren Alaina and Scotty McCreery, sing for the title. In the hourlong Season 2 finale of ''Glee,'' at 9, the choristers head to New York City to compete in nationals and take in the sights. Patti LuPone guest stars as herself.

Network television ads appearing in the Washington area feature an anxious woman who cautions that ''community banks and credit unions will be squeezed'' by ''bad'' regulation. Subway cars serving suburban Virginia carry similar warnings, while Capitol Hill newspapers have run ads from small banks that show an empty pocketbook alongside an alarming notice that ''Washington is helping you clean out your wallet.''

Less than one week after LinkedIn's blockbuster debut, Wall Street is gearing up for the initial public offering of yet another multibillion-dollar Internet start-up. Yandex, one of Russia's largest Web companies, will price its offering at $25 a share, well above expectations, according to a person briefed on the deal who was not permitted to discuss the offering. The Moscow-based company, which is set to go public on Tuesday morning, will sell 52.2 million shares in its initial public offering and raise $1.3 billion. Its group of underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank Securities, also has the option to sell an additional 5.2 million shares to cover over-allotments.

Frank Bruni, whose writing career at The New York Times has spanned two presidential campaigns, part of a papacy and more than five years as chief restaurant critic, has been named an Op-Ed columnist. Andrew Rosenthal, editor of the opinion pages, said in an e-mail to the staff on Monday that Mr. Bruni would write a new column in The Times's redesigned Sunday Op-Ed pages.

SMITH--Quentin I.,Jr., died peacefully on May 20, 2011 after a short illness. He was 83 years old and a resident of Kendal-on-Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY at the time of his death. Born in New York City, Quentin was the eldest son of Alice Lawson Smith and Quentin Irving Smith. He grew up in Edgemont, NY and graduated from Scarsdale High School, where he met his wife of sixty years, Beverly Pertsch. After a stint in the Army, Quentin graduated in 1950 from Yale University where, among other activities, he played on the varsity baseball team. He also graduated from the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School. Quentin began his business career at the Prudential Insurance Company. In 1957, he joined Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby Inc, later known as Towers Perrin and now part of Towers Watson, a leading international management consulting company. He rose through the ranks at TPF&C and, in 1971, at the age of 44, became the firm's President and Chief Executive Officer, a position he held until his retirement in 1987. During Quentin's tenure, TPF&C grew from a firm with annual revenues of $12 million and a few offices to a business with annual revenues of close to $500 million, thousands of employees and offices around the globe. He helped to engineer a series of strategic acquisitions that diversified the company's service offerings and transformed it into one of the largest, privately-held consulting firms in the world. Quentin's colleagues credited him with transitioning TPF&C from a loose coalition of individual practitioners into a focused, disciplined and integrated worldwide professional services firm, a leader in its field. Quentin was a tireless executive who valued greatly all the people he worked with regardless of position or title. During his career, Quentin also proudly served as a member of the Board of Directors of The Guardian Life Insurance Company, The J. Walter Thompson Company, Omnicom Group, UGI Corporation, and the Employee Benefit Research Institute. In retirement, Quentin lived in Sanibel Island and Boca Grande, FL, as well as East Orleans, MA. He was a fixture at his grandchildren's many sporting events, concerts, and plays. He also performed volunteer work for the United Nations. He continued his lifelong passion for baseball, always watching and rooting for the New York Yankees and personally playing softball well into his seventies in the Cape Cod Old Timers Softball League. He was an avid tennis player and occasional golfer. He was a long time member of the Eastward Ho Golf Club in Chatham, MA and Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, NY. Quentin was a wonderful man and leaves behind many adoring family members. In addition to his wife Beverly, Quentin is survived by two brothers, Peter L. Smith of Richland, Washington and Donald L. Smith of Rock Island, IL, his three children, Jeffrey Q. Smith of Purchase, NY, Lance A. Smith of Westport, CT, and Karen L. (Smith) Salinaro of Hastings on Hudson, NY, their spouses, seven grandchildren, and a host of extended family in Florida and elsewhere. When in the last several years his health deteriorated and his activities became much more limited, his spirit remained strong. Quentin always had a smile and wave for those he saw. He never stopped caring about his family, friends, and former colleagues. He will be greatly missed. Quentin was interred at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY following a private family ceremony. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held in New York City during June. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Quentin's name to support either research into the aging brain under the direction of Dr. Richard Mayeux, Department of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center, 710 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032, or Yale University, Ray Tompkins Associates, P.O. Box 1844, New Haven, CT, 06520.

The curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles announced on Monday that she was stepping down to take a job as the director of the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y. Karol Wight, an expert in Roman glass, has spent her entire professional career at the Getty, where she was instrumental in the reopening in 2006 of the Getty Villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif., where the museum's antiquities collection is housed. Since 2007 Ms. Wight has run the museum's antiquities department, succeeding Marion True, who left the job after being accused by the Italian government of trafficking in looted artifacts. The case against Ms. True, which dragged on for more than five years, ended in October after a court ruled that the statute of limitations on the crimes she was accused of had expired; her legal team had not yet had the chance to call witnesses in her defense. The case put pressure on several American museums with extensive antiquities collections, and the Getty and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, among other institutions, reached agreements with the Italian government to return some disputed artifacts.

“Godspell,” the parable-driven musical based on the Gospel of Matthew that ran on various New York stages from 1971 to 1977, will be revived on Broadway for the first time this fall, the producers announced on Wednesday. The revival had originally been aiming to open on Broadway in the summer of 2008, but its financing plans did not come together, largely due to the approaching economic recession. The lead producer of the upcoming production, Ken Davenport, said on Wednesday that the musical would be staged at Broadway’s only in-the-round theater, Circle in the Square. Preview performances of the open-ended run are scheduled to begin on Oct. 13, with an opening night of Nov. 7.

In this week’s magazine, Susan Dominus writes about Tatiana and Krista Hogan, 4-year-old conjoined twins whose brains are linked by a neural bridge. It’s an incredible story that leads to all kinds of fascinating questions about empathy, consciousness and the nature of the self: If the girls share sensation, could they also share higher thoughts? Do they experience some kind of cross-talk in their brains that they are constantly having to filter out? Will their identities merge together over time or become more differentiated?

Yankees reliever Rafael Soriano will miss the next six to eight weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed an inflamed ligament in his right elbow. Soriano was examined Wednesday by the renowned orthopedist Dr. James Andrews, who recommended rest for the next two weeks before beginning a conservative throwing program. General Manager Brian Cashman said the Yankees hope that Soriano can face hitters four to six weeks after that, which would place his potential return around the All-Star game, which is July 12.

Alec Friedman has the hustler mentality of the native New Yorker that he is. He is most often contextualized by the work he does as the associate creative director of the uber-hip, twice-a-year glossy Dossier Journal. Friedman, who is constantly on the move, can be found at the chicest parties world round, including the photographer Tim Barber’s late night bash during Miami Basel (see above). The ultimate consultant, he is also one of the nicest guys in fashion and publishing, a soft-spoken example of how far a smile can go in a generally cutthroat universe. Brands have begun to tap him for his creative insight, not to mention his casting skills, asking him to nominate cool kids and artists for modeling gigs and video spots. Friedman himself is something of a style icon in the downtown creative scene, and appears regularly in the pages of magazines, and lately in subway entrances via the most recent Cole Haan campaign, along with the rest of the stylish Dossier staff.

The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, struggling to find its feet after a bitter six-month strike, has suffered another loss. Its concertmaster of 23 years, Emmanuelle Boisvert, is moving to the Dallas Symphony Orchestra as an associate concertmaster. The announcement, which came on Wednesday, was made not by the Detroit Symphony but by a committee of orchestra members that was set up during the strike and sponsored their own concerts. The orchestra’s spokeswoman, Elizabeth Weigandt, confirmed the move and said Ms. Boisvert had told the players but not yet formally informed orchestra management. “Management has the news release, and that’s what we’ve got,” she said.

For a night, Mike Miller was a star. He converted from inside and out, initiated the fast break and racked up rebounds in Game 4. His influence on the court was just as significant as that of any player on the floor; despite sharing the court with the likes of LeBron James, Derrick Rose and Dwyane Wade, Miller posted the game’s highest plus-minus rating (plus-36), a testament to his impact. He did the little things and hit the big shots, and in a game with a razor-thin margin for error, it’s not hyperbolic to say that Miller’s 12 points and team-high nine rebounds made all the difference.

You have to posit that there's a kind of buffalo called a Buffalo buffalo; what the sentence then asserts is that beast of this kind, if buffaloed - that is, intimidated - by fellow members of their species, go on to do the same to other co-speciesists. In 1782, George Washington created the Badge of Military Merit to honor any enlisted American for, in Washington’s words, “any singularly meritorious action … not only instances of unusual gallantry, but also of extraordinary fidelity and essential service in any way.” Washington described the form of the honor as “the figure of a heart in purple cloth or silk, edged with narrow lace or binding.” Only a handful of people have been known to receive that high standing, all of which were awarded in 1783.

“For all of the other ways that top colleges had become diverse,” David Leonhardt of The Times writes in his Economic Scene column today, “their student bodies remained shockingly affluent.” In calling on universities to mount, in effect, a concerted affirmative action program for low-income students, Mr. Leonhardt writes: “At the University of Michigan, more entering freshmen in 2003 came from families earning at least $200,000 a year than came from the entire bottom half of the income distribution. At some private colleges, the numbers were even more extreme.” As a template for the future, he points to Amherst College in Massachusetts, which, he said, has bolstered its enrollment of lower-income students by devoting more resources to financial aid and using its transfer program mostly to admit community college students.

“There’s a renaissance in the shellfish world right now, especially oysters,” says Robert Spaulding, the executive chef at Elliott’s Oyster House in Seattle. Elliott’s considers the oyster to be emblematic of the Pacific Northwest’s thriving farm-to-table — or, in this case, beach-to-bar — dining scene. Elliott’s has an expansive raw bar and many direct relationships with Northwestern oyster growers. As Spaulding puts it, shucking knife in hand and flanked by a seemingly endless battalion of shells on ice, “It’s part of that movement to get out there and create something yourself.”Though traditional oyster season has just come to a close, modern aquaculture growing techniques have helped to extend Elliott’s oyster program year-round. Spaulding is able to offer 10 to 15 varieties at the moment, a number that rises to around 30 in the fall. Current standouts include the Sweetwater varietal, an oyster from the nearby San Juan Islands chain, offering mineral notes and a subtle sweetness. Also consider the Bald Point oyster, hailing from the Hood Canal in southwestern Washington, just a few hours from Elliott’s pier-top perch on the Seattle waterfront. According to Elliott’s head shucker, Jorge Hernandez, spring rain runoff in the region helps to sweeten the overall taste of the Bald Points, imbuing them with a local earthiness that matches the gray skies, soft rain drizzle and sea breeze coming off the Puget Sound — a climatic possibility even in July.

The passion for resurrecting pre-Prohibition cocktails has helped fetch out of history's dustbin several forgotten elixirs, including Creme Yvette, allspice dram, orange bitters and, most famously, absinthe. The latest one to be rehabilitated is Swedish punsch. Beginning this summer, the sweet liqueur will return to liquor stores courtesy of Eric Seed, the owner of Haus Alpenz, a Minnesota-based importing company that specializes in unique and arcane liquors. Mr. Seed was the logical candidate for the job. The base spirit of Swedish punsch is Batavia arrack, the southeastern Asian liquor derived from sugar cane and red rice. This, too, was lost to Americans, until Mr. Seed began importing it a few years ago.

ACQUISITION TALKS Diageo, the British spirits giant, is in talks to buy the Jose Cuervo brand of tequila from its family owners, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday. If Diageo strikes a deal with the Beckmann family, the longtime owners of Cuervo, it would be the company's most prominent purchase of a drinks brand in years.

New York City Ballet's spring season is in full swing but there's already much to anticipate in the months to come. The world premiere of ''Ocean's Kingdom,'' a collaboration between Paul McCartney and Peter Martins, is among the highlights of the company's 2011-12 programming. The previously announced work, which will feature costumes by Stella McCartney, will be performed at the company's gala on Sept. 22. The fall season will also include a farewell performance by the principal dancer Charles Askegard on Oct. 9. And as part of the company's winter season City Ballet will present an all-Christopher Wheeldon program (Jan. 28), with a world premiere as yet untitled as well as ''Polyphonia'' and the company premiere of ''DGV: Danse a Grande Vitesse.'' In addition to generous helpings of Balanchine and Robbins works, balletgoers can take in the holiday classic ''George Balanchine's The Nutcracker,'' this year running Nov. 30 through Dec. 31. Next spring's performances begin May 1 and that seemingly distant season will include world-premiere ballets by Mr. Martins and Benjamin Millepied as well as a revival of Balanchine's ''Symphony in C.'' More information is available at nycballet.com.

CAMERON--C.A. Kim, 80 years old, passed away on May 21, 2011. Kim was born August 11, 1930 in NYC to Muriel and C.A. Cameron. He is survived by his wife Suzanne (Soozi), three children: Mark Cameron (Laurie Kadet), Tricia Kleinberg (David), and Kim Iarocci (John), two step-children: George Glasser (Alexandra) and Toni O'Brien (Andy), ten grandchildren: Kevin, Madeline, and Steven (Kleinberg), Melissa, Jenna, and Raina (Iarocci), Charlotte and Thomas (Glasser) and Tara and Drew (O'Brien), as well as his sister Lee Slocum. Kim graduated White Plains High School in New York and attended Williams College. After serving honorably during the Korean Conflict, he joined ARAMCO, working in the treasury department. A few years later, he met Emmett Leahy and joined the consulting firm Leahy and Company where he became a respected expert in the field of records management. Upon Leahy's death in 1964, Kim assumed control of the company and changed the focus of the business to record storage and management. Under his leadership Leahy Business Archives became one of the largest record storage companies in the US. In addition to authoring books on the subject of records management, Kim was a strong supporter of ARMA (Association of Records Managers and Administrators) and the founder of the Emmett Leahy Award for records management excellence. Upon his retirement as owner and CEO of Leahy Business Archives, Kim stayed active in the field and eventually retired to Tequesta, Florida. Visitation Thursday, May 26, 2011, 2:00pm, service at 3:00pm at the funeral home. Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail Jupiter, Florida. Condolences may be offered at: aycockfuneralhomejupiter.com

Do Tony Award nominees for best play sell unusually well during the weeks between the nominations (this year, May 3) and the awards ceremony (June 12)? Not always. This time last year, for instance, two of the four best-play nominees (''In the Next Room, or the Vibrator Play'' and ''Time Stands Still'') had already closed, while ''Next Fall'' earned $150,982 and ''Red'' earned $463,639 for performances between May 17-23. But this year's nominees for best play have been posting good-to-excellent gross receipts through May, according to weekly data collected and released by the Broadway League, the trade group of producers. Last week, for instance, ''War Horse'' earned $897,133, ''The ------------------------ With the Hat'' grossed $736,699, ''Jerusalem'' took in $523,813, and ''Good People'' made $443,776. ''Good People,'' ''Hat,'' and ''War Horse'' were all playing at or near 100 percent capacity at their respective theaters for the week.

John Malkovich's latest turn as a psychopath, new productions of ''The Threepenny Opera'' and ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergman's ''Cries and Whispers'' and the last planned appearance by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are among the eclectic events planned for BAM's 2011 Next Wave Festival, organizers announced on Tuesday. The series, during which BAM will begin a 16-month celebration of its 150th anniversary, starts on Sept. 21 with the New York premiere of ''Awakening: A Musical Meditation on the Anniversary of 9/11,'' a work that will be performed by the Kronos Quartet, featuring the Brooklyn Youth Chorus. Other highlights of the festival's 17-event schedule include Brecht and Weill's ''Threepenny Opera,'' as conceived and directed by Robert Wilson, which will run from Oct. 4 through 8; the Toneelgroep Amsterdam production of ''Cries and Whispers,'' adapted from Bergman's film about a dying woman and her sisters, directed by Ivo van Hove and running from Oct. 25 through Oct. 29; the New York premiere of ''The Infernal Comedy: Confessions of a Serial Killer,'' starring Mr. Malkovich as the Austrian criminal and author Jack Unterweger, directed by Michael Sturminger and presented from Nov. 17 through 19; performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which is planning to disband after its current Legacy tour, from Dec. 7 through 10; and Samuel Beckett's play ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' starring John Hurt (of ''The Elephant Man'' and ''I, Claudius'') as presented by the Gate Theater of Dublin and directed by Michael Colgan, in multiple performances between Dec. 6 and Dec. 18.
ERTEL--Vivian. Coconut Creek, FL, May 22. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Always loved.

WHEN ads for the Army used the theme ''Today's Army wants to join you,'' a joker rewrote it this way: ''Today's Army wants to join you. At your place.'' These days, the Army is getting social -- if not quite that sociable -- as potential recruits increasingly spend time with social media like Facebook, Flickr, Twitter and YouTube. The next phase of the Army's recruitment ad campaign keeps a theme, ''Army strong,'' that was introduced in 2006 and adds a focus on the Army uniform as a ''symbol of strength'' as well as symbolic of qualities like commitment, achievement and leadership.

An explosion on the set of Peter Jackson's film version of ''The Hobbit'' is the latest bout of bad luck to befall the project, though a publicist for the movie said no one had been seriously injured in the incident. The Sydney Morning Herald reported that firefighters were called to the Stone Street Studios in Wellington, New Zealand, where the ''Hobbit'' movies are being filmed, around 11:24 a.m. local time on Tuesday. A spokesman for the local fire department told The Herald that two people working on the film, who were not identified, had been treated at the scene after an ''explosion'' and taken in an ambulance to a hospital.

8 P.M. (ABC) THE MIDDLE An evening of season finales begins as Frankie (Patricia Heaton) anticipates the end of the school year. That is, until she realizes that Brick (Atticus Shaffer, above, with Ms. Heaton) has three days to complete a big assignment he has put off for the year or risk being held back in the third grade by Ms. Rinsky (Doris Roberts). Meanwhile, Axl (Charlie McDermott) has failed to fulfill his required 30 days of community service. And Sue (Eden Sher) must prove that she never took a sick day from school to receive a perfect-attendance award at her graduation ceremony. In ''Modern Family,'' at 9, all that Jay (Ed O'Neill) wants for his birthday is a quiet day fishing on the lake. But everyone else insists on a big celebration. While planning the blowout, Claire (Julie Bowen) and Mitchell (Jesse Tyler Ferguson) end up trapped in the yard of their childhood home; Phil (Ty Burrell) runs into his college nemesis at the mall; and Cameron (Eric Stonestreet) finds his bakery expedition anything but a piece of cake. Now Jay's head won't stop throbbing. In ''Cougar Town,'' at 9:30, Jules (Courteney Cox) and the gang head to Hawaii for a vacation after Travis (Dan Byrd) makes a hasty decision to move there. And in ''Happy Endings,'' at 10:30, the group faces unexpected consequences after receiving a sudden invitation to the wedding of an old friend (T. J. Miller). 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW After 25 years of hosting this talk show, Ms. Winfrey, left, bids farewell.

The live Web show ''What's Trending'' at cbsnews.com, an attempt to build a news-and-chat program driven by social networking -- sort of a digital ''Today'' -- is a self-consciously experimental project. That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: ''We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. It's what you need to know to be in the now.'' What's obviously different about ''What's Trending,'' which will webcast its second episode Tuesday at 1 p.m. Eastern time, is its approach to the news -- its content and format -- an area in which it's already been taken to task. It's probably unfair, or at least unrealistic, to criticize the show for a lack of seriousness or news judgment, given its premise and its Twitter-driven title. In the premiere episode the struggle by Ms. Lazar and her producers to find an intelligent way to discuss current events through the lenses of Facebook and Twitter (here, as in most discussions, the alpha and omega of social networking) was palpable and mostly unsuccessful.

As once-heralded New York baseball trios go, Carlos Beltran, Jose Reyes and David Wright were not the first to invoke their owner's ire for their team's failures. Two decades before Beltran joined Reyes and Wright on the Mets, Rickey Henderson formed a Yankees Big Three with Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield. The partnership ended after four-plus seasons, but not before George Steinbrenner held his stars responsible for the Yankees' inability to reach the postseason and whatever else he could accuse them of in his many moments of pique.

Can Wall Street save Barnes & Noble? Or is it leading the nation's largest bookseller astray? Liberty Media, a company controlled by John C. Malone, announced a proposal last week to acquire Barnes & Noble for $17 a share in a transaction that would value the company at $1.02 billion. The offer underscores that when a company is seen as in play, a deal can take on a logic and a life of its own.

The music executive Clive Davis is giving an additional $5 million gift to the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, allowing the expansion of the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music into the Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, school officials announced Tuesday. The gift will make it possible for the school to recruit additional working professionals as faculty members, establish a generous scholarship fund, facilitate the recruitment of young talent from around the world and increase the number of students, university officials said in a statement. Two new programs will be created to bring in talented high school students. Future Music Moguls will be a free program for students in the New York City area, and the Summer High School Programs in Recorded Music will be open to students everywhere. With a $5 million gift from Mr. Davis in 2003, the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music opened its doors. Its curriculum was designed to provide professional training for students seeking work in the music industry as creative entrepreneurs, with courses like ''The History of Def Jam'' and ''Branding.'' Twenty-eight students enrolled in the department when it opened, Richard Pierce, a spokesman for New York University said Tuesday. The expansion into an institute will allow the program to accept about 80 students, he said.

An explosion on the set of Peter Jackson's film version of ''The Hobbit'' is the latest bout of bad luck to befall the project, though a publicist for the movie said no one had been seriously injured in the incident. The Sydney Morning Herald reported that firefighters were called to the Stone Street Studios in Wellington, New Zealand, where the ''Hobbit'' movies are being filmed, around 11:24 a.m. local time on Tuesday. A spokesman for the local fire department told The Herald that two people working on the film, who were not identified, had been treated at the scene after an ''explosion'' and taken in an ambulance to a hospital.

FRONT PAGE A picture caption in some copies on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about the Supreme Court ruling that conditions in California's overcrowded prisons violate the Eighth Amendment's ban on cruel and unusual punishment misidentified a justice of the court. It was Antonin Scalia, not Samuel A. Alito Jr.

An obituary on Tuesday about the songwriter and filmmaker Joseph Brooks misstated Mr. Brooks's role in the production of the movie ''Eddie and the Cruisers.'' He was a producer and musical adviser; he did not write the score, which was written by John Cafferty. (This error also appeared in an article about Mr. Brooks on June 24, 2009.) The obituary also misstated Mr. Brooks's birthday in 1938. It was March 11, not May 11. And it misspelled the surname of the woman who is heard singing Mr. Brooks's composition ''You Light Up My Life'' in the movie of the same name. She was Kacey Cisyk, not Cicyk.

SMITH--Quentin I.,Jr., died peacefully on May 20, 2011 after a short illness. He was 83 years old and a resident of Kendal-on-Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY at the time of his death. Born in New York City, Quentin was the eldest son of Alice Lawson Smith and Quentin Irving Smith. He grew up in Edgemont, NY and graduated from Scarsdale High School, where he met his wife of sixty years, Beverly Pertsch. After a stint in the Army, Quentin graduated in 1950 from Yale University where, among other activities, he played on the varsity baseball team. He also graduated from the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School. Quentin began his business career at the Prudential Insurance Company. In 1957, he joined Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby Inc, later known as Towers Perrin and now part of Towers Watson, a leading international management consulting company. He rose through the ranks at TPF&C and, in 1971, at the age of 44, became the firm's President and Chief Executive Officer, a position he held until his retirement in 1987. During Quentin's tenure, TPF&C grew from a firm with annual revenues of $12 million and a few offices to a business with annual revenues of close to $500 million, thousands of employees and offices around the globe. He helped to engineer a series of strategic acquisitions that diversified the company's service offerings and transformed it into one of the largest, privately-held consulting firms in the world. Quentin's colleagues credited him with transitioning TPF&C from a loose coalition of individual practitioners into a focused, disciplined and integrated worldwide professional services firm, a leader in its field. Quentin was a tireless executive who valued greatly all the people he worked with regardless of position or title. During his career, Quentin also proudly served as a member of the Board of Directors of The Guardian Life Insurance Company, The J. Walter Thompson Company, Omnicom Group, UGI Corporation, and the Employee Benefit Research Institute. In retirement, Quentin lived in Sanibel Island and Boca Grande, FL, as well as East Orleans, MA. He was a fixture at his grandchildren's many sporting events, concerts, and plays. He also performed volunteer work for the United Nations. He continued his lifelong passion for baseball, always watching and rooting for the New York Yankees and personally playing softball well into his seventies in the Cape Cod Old Timers Softball League. He was an avid tennis player and occasional golfer. He was a long time member of the Eastward Ho Golf Club in Chatham, MA and Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, NY. Quentin was a wonderful man and leaves behind many adoring family members. In addition to his wife Beverly, Quentin is survived by two brothers, Peter L. Smith of Richland, Washington and Donald L. Smith of Rock Island, IL, his three children, Jeffrey Q. Smith of Purchase, NY, Lance A. Smith of Westport, CT, and Karen L. (Smith) Salinaro of Hastings on Hudson, NY, their spouses, seven grandchildren, and a host of extended family in Florida and elsewhere. When in the last several years his health deteriorated and his activities became much more limited, his spirit remained strong. Quentin always had a smile and wave for those he saw. He never stopped caring about his family, friends, and former colleagues. He will be greatly missed. Quentin was interred at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY following a private family ceremony. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held in New York City during June. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Quentin's name to support either research into the aging brain under the direction of Dr. Richard Mayeux, Department of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center, 710 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032, or Yale University, Ray Tompkins Associates, P.O. Box 1844, New Haven, CT, 06520.

New York City Ballet's spring season is in full swing but there's already much to anticipate in the months to come. The world premiere of ''Ocean's Kingdom,'' a collaboration between Paul McCartney and Peter Martins, is among the highlights of the company's 2011-12 programming. The previously announced work, which will feature costumes by Stella McCartney, will be performed at the company's gala on Sept. 22. The fall season will also include a farewell performance by the principal dancer Charles Askegard on Oct. 9. And as part of the company's winter season City Ballet will present an all-Christopher Wheeldon program (Jan. 28), with a world premiere as yet untitled as well as ''Polyphonia'' and the company premiere of ''DGV: Danse a Grande Vitesse.'' In addition to generous helpings of Balanchine and Robbins works, balletgoers can take in the holiday classic ''George Balanchine's The Nutcracker,'' this year running Nov. 30 through Dec. 31. Next spring's performances begin May 1 and that seemingly distant season will include world-premiere ballets by Mr. Martins and Benjamin Millepied as well as a revival of Balanchine's ''Symphony in C.'' More information is available at nycballet.com.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a sharp decrease in AIDS mortality in China misstated the origin of a report that found that the Chinese health care system fails homosexuals, drug users, prostitutes and members of ethnic minorities because of lingering prejudices against them and against the disease, and that care does not reach the elderly and migrants. It was by Chinese government scientists and published in Lancet Infectious Diseases; it was not by the International Labor Organization, which issued a different report.

SEGALMyra Cohn, 72. An accomplished violinist, Myra attended New York's High School of Music and Art, Queens College, and the Juilliard School. She performed nationally and abroad; in California with the San Francisco Ballet, Oakland Symphony, and artists ranging from Tony Bennett to Jefferson Airplane; in New York in Broadway productions including Evita, Sweeney Todd, and Sunset Boulevard. Energetic, vivacious, a friend to many, Myra's positive outlook and strong will served her well in her five-year battle against a terrible disease. Myra is survived by her husband Cyrus Segal; sister Barbara Cohn Schlachet (Liam Mitchell); children Gillian Bucky Kahtan (Meir Kahtan) and Jason Bucky (Betsy Barron) and stepson Peter Segal (Fran Hawthorne); grandchildren Lauren, Mallory, Benjamin, Joseph, Rachel, Elio, Desmond, and Abigail; cousins Erica Erdberg and Claudia (Jim) Warburg. Services Wednesday 11:45 am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in Myra's memory to your favorite charity are welcomed.

Shares of Yandex, a Russian search engine barely known in the United States, surged by more than 55 percent on Tuesday, signifying the latest multibillion-dollar technology offering and stoking the debate about whether this market has the makings of a bubble. The debut of Yandex defied already lofty expectations, coming on the heels of the initial public offering of LinkedIn, the professional networking site whose shares more than doubled on their first day of trading.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about the Australian actor Bill Hunter referred incorrectly to the area of Australia where he grew up. He was born in Melbourne, which is in the southeastern state of Victoria, and grew up in a rural part of the same state; he did not grow up in ''the rural southeastern state of Victoria.''

John Malkovich's latest turn as a psychopath, new productions of ''The Threepenny Opera'' and ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergman's ''Cries and Whispers'' and the last planned appearance by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are among the eclectic events planned for BAM's 2011 Next Wave Festival, organizers announced on Tuesday. The series, during which BAM will begin a 16-month celebration of its 150th anniversary, starts on Sept. 21 with the New York premiere of ''Awakening: A Musical Meditation on the Anniversary of 9/11,'' a work that will be performed by the Kronos Quartet, featuring the Brooklyn Youth Chorus. Other highlights of the festival's 17-event schedule include Brecht and Weill's ''Threepenny Opera,'' as conceived and directed by Robert Wilson, which will run from Oct. 4 through 8; the Toneelgroep Amsterdam production of ''Cries and Whispers,'' adapted from Bergman's film about a dying woman and her sisters, directed by Ivo van Hove and running from Oct. 25 through Oct. 29; the New York premiere of ''The Infernal Comedy: Confessions of a Serial Killer,'' starring Mr. Malkovich as the Austrian criminal and author Jack Unterweger, directed by Michael Sturminger and presented from Nov. 17 through 19; performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which is planning to disband after its current Legacy tour, from Dec. 7 through 10; and Samuel Beckett's play ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' starring John Hurt (of ''The Elephant Man'' and ''I, Claudius'') as presented by the Gate Theater of Dublin and directed by Michael Colgan, in multiple performances between Dec. 6 and Dec. 18.

On Tuesday I wrote about Kedai Balitaku, a for-profit company started last year by the development group Mercy Corps in Indonesia.  Mercy Corps took this unusual step because it realized that its programs to educate mothers about nutrition were not changing what mothers fed their children.  Healthy food is expensive, and the crowded conditions in the Jakarta slums mean that many families have no place to cook or eat.  So they buy their children the cheapest street food, which is usually either sweet or deep fried.  Kedai Balitaku, which usually goes by the name KeBal, aims to become a chain of street carts selling low-priced healthy food to children.

When I first encountered Mary Chesnut as a starting point for exploring the American Civil War while an undergraduate at Harvard, I could not have been more fortunate. She provided a riveting antidote to the “fiddle-dee-dee” school of southern womanhood on which I had been weaned as a teenager in the 1960s. Although Scarlett O’Hara was a beguiling screen heroine, Mary Boykin Chesnut was a flesh and blood Rebel, whose wartime scribbling brought to life intimate and important aspects of southern culture. One of New York City Opera’s key unions on Thursday charged the company with unfair labor practices and sought a court order blocking its proposed move out of Lincoln Center. The salvo from the American Guild of Musical Artists comes nearly a week after City Opera said it could no longer afford to stay at the arts complex. Opera officials have so far remained silent on what they will present next season or where. The Guild, which represents singers, chorus members, dancers, stage managers and directors, said City Opera was using the move to break its contractual obligations and had refused to negotiate or provide any information about it.

Practicing safe sun just got a whole lot sexier. Thanks to the young designers Anne Botica and Monique Moore, whose recently launched clothing line, Mott 50, contains brightly colored basics with UPF (ultraviolet protection factor) 50 — which is 10 times the protection of a typical white tee. “It really started because we noticed a shift in trends amongst our friends,” says Moore, 28, who quit her day job at Condé Nast Digital a few short months after starting the line in the pink-walled apartment she shares with Botica (fittingly located on Manhattan’s Mott Street). “Girls were finally starting to cover up with hats, sun block and tunics rather than trying to get as tan — and burned to a crisp — as possible.” For the 27-year-old Botica, fashion is really a family affair. “There’s a history of skin cancer in my family,” she says. (An olive-green cotton poplin shirtdress with gold accents is named after Botica’s younger sibling, Faith, $125.) “Our clothes block both UVB, which causes burning and tanning, and UVA rays, which cause aging, wrinkles, sunspots, and skin cancer.” This summer, a portion of Mott 50’s proceeds will go towards cancer research. Go to mott50.com.

Haans Nicholas Mott's traipse into designing clothes was kind of an accident. "Someone who just liked my style one day unexpectedly asked me if I wanted to work on the line with him," says Mott. Perhaps because of his background in architecture, the New York-based designer, who is 33, is very particular about the construction of his unisex private label line. The clothes have been featured alongside Rick Owens, Ann Demeulemeester and Yohji Yamamoto in editorials for "SOME/THINGS" magazine. His collection includes hand-painted striped tops (five to six hours of painting) that are frayed in all the right places (36 hours to machine-sew and hand finish) and have the perfect dose of weight to shield against a cool spring breeze. The fit is boyish and over sized but the imperfection of the lines add a touch of whimsy. The collection also has unconventionally shaped short jackets (another three to five days of sewing) and rich-hued duffel coats with detachable hoods (hand sewn for eight to nine days). "Architecture gives you a set of problem-solving skills," he says. "Once I started sewing, I got very into cutting patterns, developing stitches and constructing things." Each collection has only about a dozen pieces and is only available through special order. "When things become large, you can't control it," says Mott. That firm control of his process, he says, is the most exciting part of clothing making. "If the process become boring, I'll quit."

Nature abhors a vacuum, and tennis, like physics, obeys the laws of the universe. So when Kim Clijsters got the yips late in the second set against Arantxa Rus and began backing off of her forcing groundstrokes, Rus surged in to take control. It was barely discernible for a minute or two, but when Rus saved the second match point against her with a beautiful lefty forehand cross-court winner, the energy and dominance that Clijsters showed took leave of her and the momentum shifted.

STEWART--John M. The partners of McKinsey & Co. mark with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, John Stewart, who served our clients and our firm with distinction for 37 years. John joined McKinsey in 1961, with degrees from Yale and the Harvard Business School, after serving in the U.S. Navy and working at TRW. He became a Partner of McKinsey in 1967 and retired as a Special Status Director in 1998. John was a revered and gracious presence and a beloved colleague. Possessing one of the most brilliant minds of his era, he relished the problem solving process and was known for his penetrating questions, imaginative thinking, and stunning insights. With a self-effacing style and a fondness for parables, he became a masterful counselor to CEOs, who cherished his wisdom, his great humanity, and his deep instinct to help. So did we. To John's wife, Eliot, his children, and the rest of his family, we offer our deepest condolences and join in mourning the loss of a great man.

Dinan, Pres./CEO

Q.I'm going on vacation next month and plan to ignore my e-mail. Can I make my Gmail send out a bounce message to friends saying I'll get back to them when I return? A.Google makes it fairly easy to set up an automatic response note that bounces back when someone send a message to your Gmail account. Just log into Gmail through your Web browser and click the gear-shaped Mail Settings icon in the upper right corner of the window.

Pitchers rarely throw a nine-inning complete game for the Yankees, and for one very simple reason, as C. C. Sabathia pointed out Tuesday night: Mariano Rivera. The ninth inning has been Rivera's domain for the last 15 seasons, and his dominance has eased the workload of many a starter. With the Yankees trailing through eight innings and Sabathia pitching efficiently, Rivera sat idly by, waiting to make his 1,000th career regular-season appearance.

''Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed.'' Seventeen characters left to complete a tweet. It just might work. What would James Joyce think of Twitter? More important, what would his handle be? It's impossible not to imagine the inherent fun the great English-language experimentalist would find in translating his voluminous ideas onto the 140-character template, or at least the irresistible challenge. On June 16, Bloomsday for those not in the know, lovers of Stephen Dedalus, Leopold Bloom (no relation) and Molly will have the opportunity to dip into the mind of Joyce and try to tweet his thoughts. Ulysses Meets Twitter 2011, a project created by one ''Stephen from Baltimore,'' invites devotees of the approximately 265,000-word work to recast the novel through tweets from start to finish within the 24-hour period that the novel's odyssey through Dublin (on June 16, 1904) takes place. ''Would it be horrific? Beatific? Hence this experiment,'' Stephen asks. We'll find out, but for now the call is out for a global-volunteer army to tweet ''Ulysses'' on the @11ysses account. All volunteers need to do is choose a section, or several, from the 18 episodes, structured loosely on Homer's epic, ''then thoughtfully, soulfully, fancifully compose a series of 4-6 tweets to represent that section.'' You have until May 30. More information is available at 11ysses.wordpress.com. Circe is taken.

Mark Rylance had better have a healthy appetite for the concoction of milk and a raw egg that he consumes at the opening of ''Jerusalem'' eight shows a week, because he's going to be swigging it down for an additional month: that Jez Butterworth play, in which Mr. Rylance stars as the manly, mangy, quasi-magical trailer denizen Johnny ''Rooster'' Byron, will extend its run at Broadway's Music Box Theater by four weeks, press representatives for the production said on Wednesday. Its limited run will now end on Aug. 21, having previously been scheduled to conclude on July 24. The play, which is directed by Ian Rickson and which also stars Mackenzie Crook and John Gallagher Jr. as members of Johnny's entourage of hangers-on, has been a critical smash since its April opening; reviewing ''Jerusalem'' for The New York Times, Ben Brantley described it as a work that ''thinks big - transcendently big - in ways contemporary drama seldom dares.'' The production has also received numerous laurels during Broadway's awards season, and is nominated for six Tonys including best play and leading actor in a play (Mr. Rylance).

Weeks after the United States operation that resulted in the killing of Osama bin Laden, the Columbia Pictures division of Sony Pictures Entertainment said it had acquired a new film project by Kathryn Bigelow, the Academy Award-winning director of ''The Hurt Locker,'' about that mission. Columbia said in a news release that the as-yet untitled film, to be directed by Ms. Bigelow and written by Mark Boal, the journalist and Oscar-winning screenwriter of ''The Hurt Locker,'' will focus ''on the black ops mission to capture or kill Osama bin Laden, which culminated in his death earlier this month during a high-stakes raid on his compound in Pakistan.'' The studio added that Ms. Bigelow and Mr. Boal, who will also produce the movie, ''have been developing the project since 2008 and plan to incorporate recent events into the film.''

An article last Thursday about the décor at a new Manhattan restaurant, Pop Pub, misstated its address. It is 83 University Place, not 63 University Place. The picture caption with the article omitted the photographer's name. He is Joshua McHugh.

SEEKING CLARITY Members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency responsible for putting into effect Dodd-Frank's restrictions on derivatives trading, told lawmakers on Wednesday that the exact scope of the law was vague. ''I think that we need to cut through that morass to provide some certainty to market participants who are concerned about what laws are going to apply to them,'' said Bart Chilton, above, a commissioner. His comments echo larger complaints made by banks and other financial firms, which argue that the Dodd-Frank rules could push derivatives business and profits overseas. BEN PROTESS

WEINTRAUB--Moses, died on May 24 at the age of 90. Beloved and adored husband of Marian for over 62 years. Devoted and loving father of Steven (Judy) Weintraub, Jeffrey (Judy) Weintraub, and Sharon (Michael) Dashow. Dear brother of Roslyn Besdine, the late Alfred Weintraub, and the late Esther Miller and adored grandfather of Wendy (Yehuda), Jenny, William, Erica, Jordan, and Allison, and adored great-grandfather. His devotion to the Jewish community was exemplified by his service as a founding member, former Chairman of the Board, and former Israeli bond Chairman of the Young Israel of Oceanside, in addition to his other philanthropic activities. He spent 31 years as an Assistant Attorney General with the New York State Department of Law and 21 of the 31 as a prosecuting attorney with the Special Prosecutions Bureau, now known as the Criminal Prosecutions Bureau. He had a private law practice for many years and was a Certified Public Accountant. He never had a bad word to say about anyone. His beautiful smile lit up the world. He was deeply loved, will always be remembered, and will be greatly missed. His passing leaves a void in our hearts.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has begun an investigation into the mortgage-servicing arm of Goldman Sachs, looking at whether it systematically rejected borrowers' efforts to lower their loan payments through government programs. The inquiry by the New York Fed arose from a letter sent by an anonymous employee, who accused the Goldman unit, Litton Loan, of denying loans without properly reviewing applications.

PARIS -- The day's most compelling match ended at dusk, with Sabine Lisicki of Germany carried away on a stretcher, sobbing. Lisicki looked to be on her way to the French Open's biggest upset, leading No. 3 Vera Zvonareva, 5-2, in the third set. But leg cramps ultimately toppled Lisicki, leaving her in a heap after losing, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5.

Aerial photographs from MJ Harden/GeoEye show the path of Sunday's tornado that ripped through Joplin, Mo. The three-quarter-mile-wide tornado was the deadliest in the United States since modern record-keeping began in 1950. It killed at least 125 people and destroyed about 2,000 buildings in the town's southern portion. The before and after photos below show three areas of the city that suffered catastrophic damage from the tornado.

Another favorite television character will be disappearing next fall with the departure of Elliot Stabler, the detective played by the actor Christopher Meloni in the long-running NBC series ''Law & Order: SVU.'' NBC executives quietly confirmed Tuesday night that Mr. Meloni, who played detective Stabler for over 270 episodes, beginning with the show's premiere in 1999, could not come to an agreement on a new contract and would be leaving the series.

An article last Thursday about Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister who is a candidate to head the International Monetary Fund, misstated the length of time she lived in the United States. It was six years, from 1999 to 2005; not 25 years, though she was with the Chicago-based law firm Baker & McKenzie for nearly 25 years. The error was repeated in an article on Friday about an international dispute over whether to install a leader from Europe or an emerging-market nation as head of the fund.

The newest version of Adobe Photoshop, CS5, has some pretty tricky tools, and at least one that the developers at Adobe didn't know about. But it's a surprise that can come in handy. The new tool is called content aware fill. What it does is to allow you to remove an unwanted element from a photo and to automatically fill the spot with a background that matches the rest of the photo.

''Godspell,'' the parable-driven musical based on the Gospel of Matthew that ran on various New York stages from 1971 to 1977, will be revived on Broadway for the first time this fall, the producers announced on Wednesday. The revival had originally been aiming to open on Broadway in the summer of 2008 but its financing plans did not come together, largely due to the approaching economic recession. The lead producer of the upcoming production, Ken Davenport, said on Wednesday that the musical would be staged at Broadway's only in-the-round theater, Circle in the Square. Preview performances of the open-ended run are scheduled to begin on Oct. 13, with an opening night of Nov. 7. Daniel Goldstein will make his Broadway debut as director; among his previous credits are the 2007 Off Broadway musical ''Walmartopia,'' and a production of ''Godspell'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse in 2006. The choreographer will be Christopher Gattelli, a Tony Award nominee for Lincoln Center Theater's revival of ''South Pacific.''

An article on Wednesday about an order by the State Supreme Court of New Jersey to raise spending on poor, urban schools paraphrased incorrectly a separate majority opinion by Justice Barry T. Albin. He said he would have told New Jersey to stick to a 2008 school financing formula for 205 districts, not for every district. The article also misstated the effect that Justice Albin's plan would have had on the cost to the state. It would have roughly doubled it, not more than tripled it.

The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, struggling to find its feet after a bitter six-month strike, has suffered another loss. Its concertmaster of 23 years, Emmanuelle Boisvert, is moving to the Dallas Symphony Orchestra as an associate concertmaster. The announcement, which came on Wednesday, was made not by the Detroit Symphony but by a committee of orchestra members that was set up during the strike and sponsored their own concerts. The orchestra's spokeswoman, Elizabeth Weigandt, confirmed the move and said Ms. Boisvert had told the players but not yet formally informed orchestra management. ''Management has the news release, and that's what we've got,'' she said. In a statement, Ms. Boisvert said she performed with Dallas during the strike several times and, in what could be seen as a stab at Detroit's management, said she marveled at the Dallas Symphony's ''commitment to classical music, the intrinsic respect offered to musicians by the administration and esteemed music director, Jaap van Zweden, and the emphasis they place on communication and teamwork at all levels.''

A mystery since the 19th century, the Leather Man will apparently remain that way forever. From Sunday to Tuesday afternoon, a team of about 20 historians, geneticists, archaeologists, anthropologists and other researchers descended on the Sparta Cemetery in Ossining, N.Y., hoping to exhume the remains of the Leather Man, a homeless wanderer who fashioned his clothing from discarded boots and roamed around Westchester County and western Connecticut for decades in the 19th century.

FRELINGHUYSEN--Hon. Peter H. B. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of distinguished colleague, friend, and benefactor. Peter Frelinghuysen, whose long-time and generous support was felt in many areas of the Museum for nearly 50 years. A Trustee since 1968 and Trustee Emeritus since 1990, he served on a number of committees, in the areas of acquisitions, education, and drawings, prints, and American paintings and sculpture. With his late wife Beatrice, and through gifts from the Frelinghuysen Foundation, he donated important works of art and contributed funds toward the Museum's curatorial and scholarly activities, capital projects, publications, and acquisitions, including his partial gift in 1999 of Manet's The Kearsarge' at Bologna. He cared deeply about the Metropolitan Museum, and his friendship, dedication, and generosity in its many forms have contributed greatly to the Museum's continuing evolution and excellence. We will miss him, and we extend condolences to his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

8 P.M. (HBO) HOW TO DIE IN OREGON (2011) In 1994 Oregon established the Death With Dignity Act, becoming the first state to legalize doctors' aiding the death of some terminally ill patients. Since then more than 500 people have ended their lives using the law. This film from Peter D. Richardson, which won the grand jury prize for an American documentary at the 2011 Sundance Film Festival, explores the law through the stories of those who have considered using their legal options, including Cody Curtis, 54, above, a woman suffering from liver cancer who has obtained lethal barbiturates to hold in reserve as a final option. ''It's very comforting to know they are here,'' she says. ''It's my choice when to take them and whether to take them.'' Among those not so comforted is Randy Stroup, 53 -- uninsured, with prostate cancer -- who is outraged when he is denied health care and offered doctor-assisted suicide instead. The film also follows the campaign of a woman intent on honoring her husband by fighting for a similar act in Washington State. 10:30 A.M. (TV5Monde) FRENCH OPEN Live coverage of fourth-round play from Roland-Garros in Paris.

Except for screen size, the first tablets on the market pretty much look alike: glass-faced slabs without much to set them apart. On the outside, the new Google G-Slate from T-Mobile isn't much of an exception. But it does have one distinction: On either side of a metal strip embossed with the Google logo are a pair of camera lenses. That's right, a pair. The G-Slate takes 720p HD movies in 3-D.

GREENE--William Teich. We at New York-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and colleague William Teich Greene. Words cannot express our sense of loss and sorrow that he is no longer with us. Bill began his extraordinary career at what was then known as The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in 1976, and at the time of his passing was VP of Operations at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. His skills as a hospital administrator were unparalleled, his commitment to the work of our hospital unmatched, his contributions immeasurable and his devotion to patients, employees and staff set the standard for excellence. His sense of humor, his smile, his joie de vivre we remember them all. We mourn him and we miss him. We were blessed and privileged to have known Bill, and we will never forget him. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO Steven Corwin, M.D. Exec. Vice President & COO Robert Kelly, M.D. Group Senior Vice President Laura Forese, M.D. Senior Vice President New York-Presbyterian Hospital

Stephen De Staebler, a sculptor whose fractured, dislocated human figures gave a modern voice and a sense of mystery to traditional realist forms, died on May 13 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 78. The cause was complications of cancer, Jill Ringler, his studio archivist, said.

DURST--Henny Bernstein, on May 24th, 2011. Born in Leipzig, 1929, her family moved through Holland, Brussels and England during WW II before settling in New York City. In 1948 she wed David Durst, and during their twenty year marriage, she raised four children and earned a doctorate in psychology. Henny worked for a time at Veritas Drug Rehabilitation Center, the Ford Foundation, and The Multiple Sclerosis Society. She found her true vocation, though, when as a lifelong lover of the arts, she began painting at the school of the National Academy Museum. During these years, despite her battle with cancer, she became an accomplished artist, winning the admiration of her classmates, and prizes for her delicate and incisive Martha's Vineyard landscapes. She is survived by her four children, eight grandchildren, her sister Ruth Bernstein, two aunts Lily and Jana, and her beloved cousins. Services Thursday, May 26th, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

After months of planning, the federal government has sold the first batch of shares that it owns in the American International Group, the most prominent reminder of the wreckage of 2008. But much hard work remains.

Mike Brown left the epicenter of the N.B.A. last summer when his Cleveland Cavaliers imploded in the playoffs against the Boston Celtics and LeBron James arrived at his long-speculated free agency.Before James made The Decision to leave for Miami, the Cavaliers reached their own and dismissed Brown, who had steered the Cavaliers to the N.B.A.'s best record for two seasons, but not to a championship.By the fall, Brown served as a part-time assistant football coach in Ohio for the team of his son,Cameron. He inched closer to a return to the N.B.A. in his role as an analyst for ESPN during the regular season.Now, it appears Brown is on the verge of re-entering the N.B.A.'s main stage by coaching the Los Angeles Lakers and their superstar, Kobe Bryant.Brown and the Lakers verbally agreed to a four-year contract,according to two people with knowledge of the negotiations.Brown rocketed up the list as a candidate to replace Phil Jackson after an interview with Jim Buss,the Lakers' executive vice president for player personnel and the son of the owner Jerry Buss, over the weekend, Yahoo reported.The Lakers also considered Brian Shaw, an assistant to Jackson,and Rick Adelman, who previously coached the Portland Trail Blazers, the Sacramento Kings and the Houston Rockets.''In response to rampant speculationand reports about ourhead coaching position and MikeBrown, we've met with Mike andare very impressed by him,'' theLakers said in a statementWednesday. The crossover is based on quickness and deception.It has become one of the most effective moves usedby ball-handlers to elude opponents -- a tactic infull view in the 2011 N.B.A. postseason. Those who master the crossover have been called ankle-breakers for their ability to send defenders falling in embarrassment.Miami's Dwyane Wade, whose team hasa commanding lead over Derrick Rose and the Chicago Bulls in the Eastern Conference finals, found inspiration for his version from players like Allen Iverson and Tim Hardaway. Although Hardaway was one of the first to popularize the crossover,Wade credits Iverson for inspiring his generation.Iverson's barely legal ''hanging'' crossover and his commercials teaching the move helped make him an icon in the mid-to-late 1990s.

I flew to Kinshasa in order to help a man help a boy. Scott Sherman and his family had recently adopted a four-year-old boy from an orphanage in the capital city of the Democratic Republic of Congo. When Scott’s son arrived in the States, he was severely underweight, suffering from a variety of illnesses, and indicated that he had been sexually abused at the orphanage where he’d lived. Scott’s son told his new parents that one other boy, Moise, had tried to protect him from the abuse. Scott and his family asked me if I could try and help find a better situation for Moise.

Habitat loss, climate change and disease are taking a toll on Australia’s koalas, prompting a call by wildlife experts to declare the species endangered. Roger Federer defeated Janko Tipsarevic in straight sets, mauling the feisty Serb with pinpoint serving and aggressive all-court tennis. Tipsarevic has a penchant for scoring upsets in Grand Slams, but Federer broke serve early in the first and played with great variety and imagination to run away with an easy victory.

I don’t always highlight the magazine’s cover stories because, well, they’re on the cover. Of course, we think they’re brilliant and worth every minute of your Sunday morning (or whenever). But this week’s cover story, about conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan, deserves every extra little bit of attention I can bring to it. I expect that the cover picture will make some people squeamish. But I urge those of you who feel that way to get past it and read Susan Dominus’s powerful story. It won’t make you feel bad, I promise. It’s a story about the richness and complexity of human life. There really is something miraculous about these girls, and though the challenges they face are daunting, this is the life they have to live, and it is not without joy and love.

Several commenters responding to Susan Dominus’s story about Krista and Tatiana Hogan said that they would be interested in seeing images of the girls’ unusual neural anatomy. Here is a brain image provided to The Times by the twins’ neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Children’s Hospital. The attenuated line stretching between the two organs is what he refers to as the “thalamic bridge” that may allow them to share sensory perception.
