“Paying for It,” a memoir about prostitution by the cartoonist Chester Brown, lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list. The book, published by Drawn & Quarterly, has received a number of reviews: “Brown believes that prostitution is a logical and healthy choice for him, and the women he engages, to make,” reads the write-up on the Monkey See blog on npr.org. “His friends disagree, for a host of reasons. “Paying for It” is, at its cool, affectless heart, an argument for a deeply unpopular position, and as such it seems destined to become one of the most controversial memoirs of the year, graphic or otherwise.”

Flour milling is not the first thing that comes to mind when you think of Brixton, a neighborhood in South London that is better known for jerk chicken and live music. Owned by the Lambeth Council, the Brixton Windmill has just reopened this month after a £580,000 (about $937,000) renovation. The effort was initiated by a local residents’ group, the Friends of Windmill Gardens, which was established in 2003 to restore the landmarked but derelict windmill and transform its surrounding park. The restoration and landscaping, which were overseen by Dannatt Johnson Architects, took seven months to complete, and the building now looks unpretentious yet elegant, with a tasteful color scheme.

When the Philadelphia Phillies added Cliff Lee to a formidable group of starters that included Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Cole Hamels, pundits wasted no time predicting greatness for the team's 2011 rotation. Although the hype was unreal, many of the predictions proved accurate. The Phillies' starting rotation has the lowest earned run average in the National League, and it includes the best 1-2 punch in baseball, based on Wins Above Replacement. The statistic measures how many victories a player contributes compared with a fringe starter from the bullpen or a minor leaguer.

One of New York City Opera's key unions on Thursday charged the company with unfair labor practices and sought a court order blocking its proposed move out of Lincoln Center. The salvo from the American Guild of Musical Artists comes nearly a week after City Opera said it could no longer afford to stay at the arts complex. Opera officials have so far remained silent on what they will present next season or where. The Guild, which represents singers, chorus members, dancers, stage managers and directors, said City Opera was using the move to break its contractual obligations and had refused to negotiate or provide any information about it. The Guild filed its complaint with the National Labor Relations Board, and said it would ask the board to seek a federal court injunction barring the move. A departure would leave the performers' lives and careers ''irreparably damaged,'' said Alan S. Gordon, the Guild's executive director. The union also accused the company of violating the contract by failing to tell its members the number of guaranteed weeks they would have next season. City Opera did not immediately return a call seeking comment.

SALEM, Mass. -- Like any good psychic, Barbara Szafranski claims she foresaw the problems coming. Her prophecy came in 2007, as the City Council was easing its restrictions on the number of psychics allowed to practice in this seaside city, where self-proclaimed witches, angels, clairvoyants and healers still flock 319 years after the notorious Salem witch trials. Some hoped for added revenues from extra licenses and tourists. Others just wanted to bring underground psychics into the light.

SAMRA--Victor Michael, Jr.,69, passed away at his home in Bronxville, NY on May 23, 2011. He was the beloved husband of Alexandra (Sherrer), devoted father of Victor and Christina, their spouses Laurie Maher-Samra and James Karper, adoring grandfather of Owen Samra. Predeceased by his loving sister Lorraine Maloof. Friends may call at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, from 5 to 8pm, Thursday. Funeral Service will be held at St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, 192 81st St., and Ridge Blvd, Brooklyn, NY on Friday, May 27 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Samra Foundation at Poly Prep Country Day School, Brooklyn, NY, Lawrence Hospital Center, Bronxville, NY; or to your favorite charity.

FRIEDMAN--Ruth, grand lady. May 25, 2011, age 95. Beloved of her entire extended family and her many friends. She had a sense of humor, a sense of love, and a great sense of life. She will be deeply missed. May her memory be for a blessing.

JOPLIN, Mo. -- The number of people unaccounted for in this tornado-ravaged city was reduced to more than 200 on Thursday from more than 1,500 earlier this week, and officials released their names for the first time to the public. The list of the missing -- which was immediately posted in buildings around the city -- followed growing frustration from some residents who had filed lengthy missing person reports for family members. They had received little information back, however, including whether their relatives were among the at least 125 known to have died.

FRANKLIN--Roger, PhD, the Broadway veteran actor, singer and stage manager, opera director and author, died on May 23, 2011. He was 84 years old. Dr. Franklin, with his resonant baritone voice, played Officer Krupke in the original Broadway production of "West Side Story." Other Broadway appearances included "Canterbury Tales," "The Vamp" and "H.M.S. Pinafore." The "Dean of New York City's Santas," and one of few to earn the much coveted five-candy-cane rating from "The New York Times," Roger personified Christmas for 22 years at the South Street Seaport. Rutgers Presbyterian Church mourns the loss of our beloved Elder. For many years Roger wrote and edited the church's newsletter, Renewal. He served as both friend and generous host for more than a decade at the church's weekly film series, which follows Thursday night's community dinner. He was preceded in death by his life partner of 35 years, Robert Bruce Holley. Plans for a memorial service will be posted soon on the church's website at: www.rutgerschurch.org.

ROSE--Barbara, nee Janus, 73, of Stamford, passed away May 26, 2011. Born Chicago, IL. In lieu of flowers, donations to Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Attn: GIST Research.

MEMORIAL DAY OBSERVANCES (Saturday through Monday) Memorial Day, or Decoration Day as it was once called, was first observed in the 1800s to honor those killed in the Civil War. Much later it became a national holiday to commemorate those lost in all wars, and this season the tradition continues. Maj. Gen. Richard P. Mills, commanding general of the First Marine Division, will join Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and others on Monday in Riverside Park at the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument, at Riverside Drive and West 89th Street. A Marine Corps band from New Orleans will start things off at 10 a.m., followed by what George Chall, president of the Soldiers' & Sailors' Memorial Association, characterized as a solemn commemoration. (Last year's event, above.) The 150th anniversary of the start of the Civil War will be the centerpiece of events this weekend at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, as well as at other sites. And Fleet Week events on deck at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum will include a performance of ''Homecoming,'' a ballet set to letters from Iraq and Afghanistan, on Saturday at 11:30 a.m. It was choreographed by Roman Baca, a Marine veteran and the artistic director of the Exit 12 Dance Company. Events on this page list other opportunities to watch parades, run races, listen to music and, of course, eat. (Anne Mancuso)

FRELINGHUYSEN--Peter H. B.,loving husband of the late Beatrice P. Frelinghuysen and proud father, grandfather and great-grandfather to a grateful family. A man from a different era, he was modern in his outlook. He found his vocation in politics and was blessed with an inquisitive and critical mind. Passionate about plants of all kinds, he delighted in his gardens, collecting palm trees in Maui and his favorite daffodils in New Jersey. In conversation, he choose his words carefully, mixing wit with an occasional barb. He found wonderful companionship playing bridge, where he showed his competitive side. With his late wife Bea, he had beloved friends of all ages from every stage of his life. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, June 3 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 121 South Street, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Friends of The Great Swamp Wildlife Refuge 241 Pleasant Plains Road, Basking Ridge NJ 07920 or the Raptor Trust 1390 White Bridge Road, Millington, NJ 07946.

An article on Tuesday about the move by New York City for new tests to grade teacher performance misstated the percentage of its $256 million in Race to the Top money the city would spend on developing the tests. After the article was published, the Department of Education said it is 10 percent, not up to a quarter. (It will spend up to a quarter to develop the overall teacher and principal evaluation system.)

SAMRA--Victor. The Board, employees and volunteers of the South Carolina Aquarium mourn the passing of board member Vic Samra. Vic's wisdom, generosity and compassion for the Aquarium's mission served as an inspiration to all, and he will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to Vic's wife, Alexandra, and the entire Samra family. Ken Seeger, Chairman Kevin Mills, President and CEO South Carolina Aquarium

SCHNEIDER--Carmen. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on Tuesday, May 24, of Carmen Schneider, beloved mother of our friend and partner, Kenneth M. Schneider. We express our deepest sympathies to Ken and all other members of the family

The Maple Group has announced that it would take its $3.7 billion bid for the TMX Group, the parent of the Toronto exchange, directly to shareholders even as TMX and the London Stock Exchange have set the date for a stockholder vote on their proposed merger. Luc Bertrand, a spokesman for the Maple Group and vice chairman of the National Bank Financial Group, said in a statement Wednesday that the TMX directors, by refusing to negotiate and stepping up efforts to merge with the London exchange, ''have given us no choice but to make our offer available directly to TMX Group shareholders.''

STEWART--John MacKenzie, 79, died peacefully at home on May 19, 2011. Born in Glen Cove, NY, in 1932, he graduated from Yale University ('53) and Harvard Business School ('57). He served in the US Navy from 1953 - 1955 and as a program manager for TRW's Saturn missile project. In 1961 he joined McKinsey & Company where for 37 years, he dedicated himself to client service. In addition, he served on the Defense Science Board, Yale University Council, National Council on Economic Education and as Executive Director of the US National Commission on Productivity. Most recently, he was a trustee of NYU Medical Center, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and on the Dean's Advisory Council at Boston University School of Medicine. He also consulted with a Gates Foundation initiative to reduce HIV/AIDS in India. John's many civic commitments reflected his lifelong interest in the intersection of management with science and economics, and a deeply held belief in "giving back". Even his love of flying became a way to help others through Angel Flights. John was a great human being. He brought integrity, creativity and compassion to every endeavor with family, with friends and with professional colleagues. He had a unique way of guiding those around him to new and deeper insight. And he was a lot of fun to be around. He loved his family: his wife, Eliot; their four children: Diane Stewart, Sandi Stewart, Ian Highet and Eliot Patty; and nine grandchildren: Anna, Colin, Ali, Dash, Gil, Lisa, Andrew, Liam and Eliza. Services will be held at the Yale Club on Sunday, June 19 at 4:30pm, reception following. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: John Stewart Memorial Fund, Amyloid Research Program, Boston Univ. School Of Medicine, 72 E. Concord St., Boston, MA 02188 or Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Fenno House, Woods Hole, MA 02543.

LUCKS--Vivian F. Vivian F. Lucks died peacefully on May 25, 2011 at age 91. Mrs. Lucks, formerly of Cedarhurst, N.Y., was predeceased by her loving husband of 67 years, Dr. Abe H. Lucks, and is survived by her cherished children, Karen and Dr. Steven Metzger, and Joan and Paul Feinstein. She was an adoring grandmother to Marcie Nadler (Simon), Debbie Falik (Adam), Leslie Levin (Marc) and Ross Feinstein; and loving great-grandmother to Allison, Emily, Rebecca, Gabrielle, Aaron, Eliza, Sophie and Max. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1920 to Freda and Morris Kramer, Mrs. Lucks was the sister of the late Norman Kramer and the late Bas-Ami Grodman. Mrs. Lucks graduated Erasmus Hall High School and New York University. As the matriarch of the family, she always put family first and was a role model who imparted the values of unconditional love and selflessness. A funeral service will be held on Friday, May 27, 2011 at 11:00am at Community Synagogue in Rye, N.Y.

TOKYO -- In Sony's 1993 comedy ''Groundhog Day,'' Bill Murray finds himself reliving the same dreary course of events, day after day. It is as good an analogy as any to Howard Stringer's stint as chief executive of Sony, the electronics and entertainment giant: upswing, stumble, repeat.

COWIN--Daniel. It has been 19 long years since you left us. Your good friends remember you with amazing clarity and admiration. Those who knew you best miss your kindness, encouragement, wisdom and aesthetic expertise. Would that you could return to us. Joyce, and family

GROOPMAN--Jacob, MD. The Astoria Center of Israel mourns the sudden death, and honors the life, of our respected and beloved co-president, Jacob Groopman, MD. His legacy of wisdom, leadership, and friendship will remain with us always. He is survived by his twin sister Cynthia, co-president of ACI, and we share her grief.

10 P.M. (MUN2) HARLISTAS: AN AMERICAN JOURNEY (2011) For more than 50 years they have proudly called themselves Harlistas: Harley-Davidson riders of Latin American ancestry. From the plains of South Dakota to the Oregon coast, with stops at the Grand Canyon and Monument Valley, Alfredo de Villa explores Latino motorcycling culture in the United States through four sets of men in search of adventure, camaraderie and the American dream. The subjects includes Danny Huerta, a Harley technician from Baldwin Park, Calif., who retraces his father's motorcycle journey through the Southwest; the four Rodriguez brothers from Queens, whose only sister was killed in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing; Carlos de Lorio, a Nicaraguan immigrant who uses a trip to bond with his 15-year-old son, Junior; and Lonnie Gallego, a bike-shop owner from Los Angeles who helps keep his stepson out of jail through their mutual passion. 10 A.M. (CUNY) DAY AT NIGHT: VINCENT PRICE This actor, who was known as the King of the Grand Guignol and the Merchant of Menace, would have turned 100 on Friday. In this interview recorded in Los Angeles on April 25, 1974, he speaks with James Day about the need for arts education in the United States, his graduation from Yale and art-history studies in London and his career-making turn as Prince Albert in ''Victoria Regina,'' which had its premiere on the West End before moving to Broadway. (The interview will be repeated at 3 and 8:30 p.m.)

NORDLINGER--Toby of Englewood Cliffs, NJ and Sand Key, FL died May 15, 2011 at home after a year long battle with cancer. She was 84. She was predeceased by her husband Hon. Richard E. Nordlinger. Also survived by sisters Roz Goral and Sarah Sylvan and brother Mendy Greenspan. She is survived by her sons Arthur, Robert, and Glenn, and her grandchildren Sam, Elizabeth, Alex, Brian, and Jonathan. Donations can be made in her honor to The Mount Sinai Medical Center, Tisch Cancer Institute.

Because of an editing error, the State of the Art column on Thursday, about DAR.fm, a Web site that allows users to record any American radio show, garbled a sentence in some editions. The sentence, about a drawback to the service, should have said, ''And of course, you have to program your recordings on the Web -- you can't do that from your physical Wi-Fi radio'' -- not ''The main one is that you can't do that from your physical Wi-Fi radio.''

WASHINGTON TIES In an effort to expand its influence in the nation's capital, Facebook has hired Joel Kaplan, an executive vice president at the Texas utility giant Energy Future Holdings, to head the company's office there. In the last few years, Facebook has started to fill its ranks with executives with deep ties to Washington. Its chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, above, was a former chief of staff to a Treasury secretary during the Clinton administration. EVELYN M. RUSLI

LIPPMAN--Bert J. You left us 30 years ago today. We think of you always and miss you, miss you, miss you. You are forever in our hearts. Your legacy continues with your great-granddaughter, Lucy Sam. With all our love, Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Bradley, Jessica

WALSH--Anne R. on May 26, 2011. Beloved mother of Carolyn Walsh Parry, Esq. Service Sunday 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to KittyKind www.kittykind.org.

1:59 p.m. | Updated Sarah Palin will begin a bus tour of the East Coast on Memorial Day weekend, the latest and most significant evidence that the former governor of Alaska is still seriously considering a run for the Republican presidential nomination this year. Ms. Palin will begin the series of high-profile public events in the Washington area, starting with the annual Rolling Thunder motorcycle rally and continuing on through the Northeast, according to a statement on her Web site.

For nearly 20 years, an East Village journalist named Bill Weinberg has been a familiar late-night voice on the left-leaning radio station WBAI-FM (99.5), ruminating about radical politics, global turmoil and life in New York City. In mid-March, however, the station canceled Mr. Weinberg's program, the Moorish Orthodox Radio Crusade, after he accused WBAI of promoting fringe right-wing commentators and conspiracy theories claiming that the United States government was behind the destruction of the World Trade Center.

SAMRA--Victor M. The entire Poly Prep Country Day School community--trustees, alumni, faculty, staff, and students--mourns the loss of Victor M. Samra, Jr., Class of '59. A trustee since 1976 and former chairman, Vic was a loyal and dedicated friend and alumnus whose wise counsel and generosity to our school will be greatly missed. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife, Alexandra, and his entire family. Vincent J. Vigorita, MD, Chairman David B. Harman, Headmaster

Francesca Zambello, a busy director of opera and theater and the artistic and executive director of the Glimmerglass Festival, has been appointed artistic adviser of the Washington National Opera - heralding a possible link between the institutions, officials said on Wednesday. The appointment is part of the Washington company's reorganization as it merges with the Kennedy Center, which was a response to the Washington opera's financial troubles. Placido Domingo, the company's general manager, is departing next month. Washington National Opera also announced that its chief operating officer, Michael L. Mael, had been named executive director. -Ms. Zambello had been a candidate to lead New York City Opera, which had a history of collaborating with Glimmerglass, in Cooperstown, N.Y. Now - at Glimmerglass herself - she made clear that the festival (it used to be Glimmerglass Opera) may forge ties with her new company. ''In terms of Glimmerglass, this appointment allows for me to continue my work in larger companies with reciprocal benefits for the festival,'' she said in a statement, ''such as the sharing of principal artists and programming, and placing our Glimmerglass young artists in other opera houses.''

WEINER--Eve Siegel, devoted wife of the late Louis and sister of Jean Dattner. Survived by caring nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY at 10am on Sunday.
A Return to 'The Normal Heart' Joe Mantello talks about returning to the stage in Larry Kramer's play.

Donald L. Johnson had a privileged role at the Nasdaq Stock Market. When companies that trade on Nasdaq wanted to understand how impending news would affect their share prices, they would consult with Mr. Johnson, who was a senior executive on the exchange's so-called market intelligence desk.

In 1995, some 8,000 Bosnian Muslim men and boys were massacred in the town of Srebrenica. It was the worst ethnically motivated mass murder in Europe since World War II. Now, finally, Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general who masterminded that butchery, is where he should be -- in custody, facing prosecution before the International Criminal Court and, we hope, a lifetime in prison. The arrest should be a warning to other butchers that they, too, will be caught and held to account, no matter how long it takes. It is also a reminder that sustained international pressure works. Europe's leaders made Mr. Mladic's capture and delivery to The Hague a condition for Serbia's admission to the European Union.

On the night that one Fox reality show, ''American Idol,'' was ending its season, another Fox reality show, ''The X Factor,'' was aswirl in tabloid-ready developments. TMZ and other Web sites reported on Wednesday night that Cheryl Cole, one of the four people signed to judge contestants on ''The X Factor,'' had been let go. The Web sites also said Nicole Scherzinger, who had been hired as one of the show's two hosts, had stepped in as a judge in Ms. Cole's place. That would leave the show with a single host, Steve Jones, just as ''Idol'' has one host.

Buster Posey ended last season by catching the final pitch of the World Series. He seems to have ended this season in a gruesome home-plate collision with Scott Cousins of Florida Marlins on Wednesday night. Posey, the National League rookie of the year last season for the San Francisco Giants, has a fractured left ankle and severely strained ligaments, according to the team.

A picture caption with an essay on Tuesday about the early days of the Apollo manned spaceflight program, using information provided by a photo agency, misstated the location and date of the image in which President John F. Kennedy and other officials reviewed scale models of booster rockets and missiles. The photo was taken in Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Sept. 11, 1962, not in Houston on Sept. 12, 1962.

The old news about the latest music sales: Adele is No. 1, yet again. The new news: Thanks to an aggressive marketing campaign and some apparently unsolicited promotion by Amazon, Lady Gaga is selling even better than expected. On this week's Billboard album chart, which tracks music sales for the seven days that ended on Sunday, Adele's ''21'' (XL) dominates with 138,000 copies sold in the United States. That puts her at No. 1 for a ninth time; in the 13 weeks since its release in this country, it has sold 1.8 million copies. (The album is an even bigger hit in Adele's native Britain, where it has sold more than two million copies.)

The game of musical chairs in casting male roles at American Ballet Theater continues. Johan Kobborg, a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet in London, will make his first appearance with Ballet Theater as a guest artist at Saturday's matinee of ''Giselle.'' Mr. Kobborg will dance the role of Albrecht, replacing Maxim Beloserkovsky, who is injured. This week, the company announced that Ivan Vasiliev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, would replace Herman Cornejo, who is also injured, in several performances. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LONDON - As new rules to regulate banks take shape around the world, the banks are increasingly seeking ways to soften the impact. UBS, one of Switzerland's biggest banks, is considering a switch to a holding structure, and then incorporating the investment banking business as a separate legal entity in London, two people with direct knowledge of the idea said on Thursday. They declined to be identified because no decision had been made.

STEWART--John M. With profound and abiding sadness, the staff, trustees and members of the corporation of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution mourn the death of friend and colleague John Stewart, a Life Trustee whose influence on our organization, as on so many others he served in a volunteer capacity, was fundamentally enhancing. John was a mentor and counselor who shared freely his time and the benefit of his long experience, broad perspective, and enormous intelligence. He considered thoughtfully every context, he listened carefully before expressing his view, and he offered invariably keen and creative insights tempered with a remarkable grace, natural humility, and gentle humor. John loved the ocean, was an accomplished sailor and aviator, and possessed the same need to explore, discover, understand, and share that drives our scientific mission. Like every organization he served, he made us better and helped us contribute to a greater good. We wish John Godspeed, and, with heavy hearts, we wish his wife Eliot and his entire family every consolation.
KINSTLINGER--Joe. 2/21/68-5/27/01. To his memory, example and love. Mom, Dad and Family

STEWART--John M. The partners of McKinsey & Co. mark with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, John Stewart, who served our clients and our firm with distinction for 37 years. John joined McKinsey in 1961, with degrees from Yale and the Harvard Business School, after serving in the U.S. Navy and working at TRW. He became a Partner of McKinsey in 1967 and retired as a Special Status Director in 1998. John was a revered and gracious presence and a beloved colleague. Possessing one of the most brilliant minds of his era, he relished the problem solving process and was known for his penetrating questions, imaginative thinking, and stunning insights. With a self-effacing style and a fondness for parables, he became a masterful counselor to CEOs, who cherished his wisdom, his great humanity, and his deep instinct to help. So did we. To John's wife, Eliot, his children, and the rest of his family, we offer our deepest condolences and join in mourning the loss of a great man.

FRELINGHUYSEN--Peter H.B.,Jr. The Board of Directors and staff of the Garden Conservancy are deeply saddened by the loss of Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen, Jr. A passionate gardener and dedicated advocate, Peter was a founding member of our Board, a Director Emeritus, and dear friend. His generosity and enthusiasm contributed greatly to the organization. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Thomas N. Armstrong III, Chairman Francis H. Cabot, Chairman Emeritus Benjamin F. Lenhardt, Jr, Vice-Chairman Antonia F. Adezio, President Morris Cheston, Jr., Vice-President

The Advertising column on Thursday, about a new commercial for Heineken beer, misidentified the performer of ''Jaan Pehechaan Ho,'' an Indian song from the 1960s that is heard in the commercial, because of inaccurate information supplied by the advertising agency that created the spot. The song is performed by the songwriter Mohammed Rafi, not by a band named the Serenades.

CAREY--Robert H.,on May 26th, age 79. Bob was born in Brooklyn, attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated from Niagara University. After serving in the U.S. Army he earned his law degree from St. John's University and embarked on a 50 year career as a municipal bond attorney starting with Caldwell, Trimble and Mitchell then merging with Nixon, Mudge, Rose Guthrie and Alexander. He was later Managing Partner of Sullivan, Donovan and was until his death of counsel to Nixon Peabody. Bob is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, Joan, four beloved children, Robert Jr., Suzanne Lavins, Gregory and William, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. His loving charm, kind sense of humor and dedication to family and friends will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Southampton Hospital or The Children's Academy in Manhattan. Visitation is May 31st at Thomas A. Glynn & Son in Rockville Centre with a Memorial Service on June 1st at 11am at St. Agnes Cathedral.

You'll never think of the phrase ''box office gross'' in the same way again: a pornographic 3-D movie that has already proved a hit in Asia is headed for a theatrical release in the United States. The movie, an erotic Hong Kong period drama called ''3D Sex and Zen: Extreme Ecstasy'' and directed by Christopher Sun, is a remake of a 1991 film called ''Sex and Zen,'' which in turn is adapted from a 17th-century work of Chinese erotic fiction known as ''The Carnal Prayer Mat.'' (Among its characters are a lascivious scholar, his virginal bride, a duke with an estimable harem and a horse.) Explaining his film to Reuters last summer, Mr. Sun said that if audiences are going to pay additional ticket costs for 3-D movies, they should ''get into a world they've never seen before.'' He added, ''It's not just erotica, they want some wow factor.''
A cornucopia of music festivals, parades, celebrations of art and food is around the corner, and most of it at small cost.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we get started today, I just want to take a moment to applaud my fellow constructors, particularly today’s, for their creativity and the ingenious lengths they go to in order to entertain us. I did most of the puzzle today with my mouth hanging open and I sincerely hope that when you discovered the gimmick, you were just as pleasantly surprised.

The federal Storm Prediction Center has released its latest tally of tornadoes and deaths for 2011, with the current count of 523 now making this the worst year since 1950.. [May 30, 11:45 p.m. | Updated This line and the headline have been adjusted to eliminate an error explained at the end of this post.]

My Sunday column argues that India is turning around and that its takeoff is gaining traction around the country, even in places like Bihar and West Bengal. I’ve been a bit wary of India in the past, previously noting that the tech sector accomplishments are real but have tiny employment and that solid chunks of India remain abysmally undeveloped. That’s still true, but my latest trip leaves me more optimistic. India is steadily evolving in the right direction — while in China there’s reason for more caution. Under President Hu Jintao, China’s evolution has paused, and there probably won’t be more movement until after the Communist Party Congress in late 2012 installs Xi Jinping as Hu’s successor. I still would never bet against China, but I think India may be able to narrow the gap in the coming years.

John Collins Rudolf has posted a thorough overview of the latest murder on the eroding perimeter of the Amazon rain forest in Brazil. There’s been enormous progress in efforts to bring governance to forest frontiers in Brazil since the late 1980s, when I spent months in the western Amazon reporting on the life and assassination of Chico Mendes for “The Burning Season,” my first book. But pistols and shotguns still sometimes blaze.

Animal Kingdom is the story today. The Kentucky Derby winner’s trainer, Graham Motion, announced, as definitely as one can two weeks before the race, that Animal Kingdom is headed for the Belmont Stakes. Motion was quoted by The Associated Press as sayng, “He bounced out of the Preakness very well and we are looking forward to running in the Belmont Stakes.”
The fitness guru Tony Horton says exercisers should focus on engaging their core muscles.

Part of Kevin Long’s job as the hitting coach for the Yankees is to build trust, to get his players to buy what he is selling. He has been far more successful doing that than he was at an off-season job in the minors, when he tried to sell Yugos in Phoenix.
Sony has finally agreed to testify before a Congressional hearing that will be held by Representative Mary Bono Mack, the chairwoman of the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade.

Steve Nash, the Phoenix Suns’ star point guard and noted soccer enthusiast, is hosting the fourth annual Showdown in Chinatown, a charity soccer match, on June 22 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Tony Parker, Grant Hill and Brandon Jennings are among the N.B.A. stars playing in the match, which is free and open to the public. Proceeds from an after-hours event will benefit the Steve Nash Foundation. Nash, who lives in Manhattan in the off-season, has recently become an advocate for gay rights and recently lent his voice to a same-sex marriage initiative in New York State.

One of the most celebrated aspects of Stanley Cup play is the pain players endure to make a contribution during the postseason. It is a point of professional pride that hockey players will dress for games with injuries that would sideline most other athletes.

For a pitcher with only a few months in the major leagues, Toronto’s Kyle Drabek is easy to identify. He is the son of Doug Drabek, the 1990 National League Cy Young Award winner; he was the Blue Jays’ centerpiece in the trade that sent Roy Halladay to Philadelphia; and he is the only pitcher in the majors with a single-digit uniform number.
Widespread approval greeted the news last week that the Los Angeles Lakers had chosen Mike Brown to replace the retiring legend Phil Jackson. And why not?
Coverage and live analysis of the UEFA Champions League final between Manchester United and Barcelona from Wembley Stadium in London.

Wheels will be taking a short break in observance of Memorial Day, but we’ll return on Tuesday, May 31, with our regular coverage. Whatever mode of transport conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Once you’ve solved this puzzle, you might think that Patrick Blindauer is a tad obsessed with the letter “H,” but in reading between the lines on this one, I’m wondering if it also serves as a love letter to his fiancee. Each of the theme entries is a phrase that has that double “H” going for it, and most of them are fairly romantic. Or maybe it’s a love letter to Henry Hook, what do I know?

In a six-game stretch from late April to mid-May, Joaquin Benoit of the Detroit Tigers allowed 12 earned runs, three more than he did all of last season for the Tampa Bay Rays. That short stretch of shaky pitching showed just how volatile a reliever’s results can be from year to year.
MONACO – Today’s track action in Monaco has been overshadowed by two bad accidents.

It’s not quite a year yet since Business Week ran a piece ridiculing my concerns about prolonged economic weakness, comparing it to the wisdom of John Paulson, who saw a boom — particularly in housing — just around the corner. Still, it seems worth revisiting.

PARIS — Mahesh Bhupathi and Leander Paes of India, the world’s third-ranked doubles team, tumbled out of the French Open Saturday in a straight set upset loss to Stephen Huss and Ashley Fisher of Australia, 7-6 (7), 6-4.

Some weeks ago, I started noticing nascent light-green buds on the branches of every city conifer I encountered from Central Park down to Staten Island. Unlike mature pine needle tea — a resiny, survivalist food at best — fresh, young evergreen tips are a citrusy surprise to the palate, and I couldn’t help nibbling on a choice few. At the College of Staten Island, I discovered a midsize, classic Christmas-tree-looking conifer, which friends at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden identified as a Colorado blue spruce. It had very lemony-tasting tips.

As I mentioned in an earlier post, the latest OECD Economic Outlook is a remarkable document — and I mean that in the worst way. I’ve already pointed to the report’s insistence that we must raise interest rates, because foofa grrzt bumble shazam — OK, that’s not quite what the report says, but it makes at least as much sense as the justification the report does offer.

Early last Tuesday, José Cláudio Ribeiro da Silva, a forest activist and tree nut harvester, and his wife, Maria do Espirito Santo, drove a motorcycle through Brazil’s northern Para State, in the Amazon rain forest. As they crossed a river bridge, gunmen lying in wait opened fire with a pistol and shotgun, killing them.
PARIS -– Andy Murray rolled on the red clay, his face a portrait in pain, after injuring his right ankle Saturday in his third round French Open match against Michael Berrer of Germany.

PARIS – Rafael Nadal of Spain used his potent forehand and a strong-arm backhand service return to move easily into the fourth round of the French Open Saturday. He defeated Antonio Veic of Croatia, the world’s 227th ranked player, 6-1, 6-3, 6-0.

I watched the first two sets of the Djokovic-Del Potro match searching for any sign of weakness in the tall Argentine’s game. I found none, and in fact felt that he had Djokovic on the defensive when the match was called in the waning light on Friday night. Despite a year’s absence from the tour, and a comeback interrupted by a slight tear high in the quadricep that put his return to Roland Garros in doubt, Del Potro served well, hit out with authority on his ground strokes, and competed fearlessly against the tour’s dominant player. Having Del Potro back in the mix in a Grand Slam adds excitement to the men’s game, and Saturday’s continuation of the match has tennis fans buzzing over the high quality of the first two sets.

In the wake of the NY-26 election, both Henry Olson and Jonathan Chait pointed out that the constituency most resistant to Paul Ryan’s Medicare reforms seems to be conservative-leaning blue collar voters — what the Pew Research Center, in a recent report, calls the “Disaffecteds.” (This is a cohort that I mentioned in my column on Mike Huckabee’s appeal, and it overlaps to some degree with the “Sam’s Club Republicans” that Reihan Salam and I spent a whole book talking about.) Chait calls this “the demographic group that should terrify Republicans,” because they’re a crucial constituency for the right-of-center coalition, but they’re also more resistant to cutting Medicare and Social Security than most Democratic-leaning groups.

Last Sunday, Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker and current Republican presidential candidate, told America that he was a small-business owner. Because of a production error, an article on Friday about the growing number of psychics practicing in Salem, Mass., omitted the last passage in some editions. It should have read: ''Now, talk has started about new regulations that would include a cap on the number of psychic businesses, but the grumbling has in no way reached the level of viciousness that occurred in 2007, when someone left the mutilated body of a raccoon outside Ms. Szafranski's shop and Mr. Day and Ms. Stathopoulos got into a fight. Ms. Szafranski says she plans to send the council an official complaint in June. This time, she has no prediction how it will turn out.''

Would you cast someone to play Anna Karenina in a film version of ''War and Peace''? Bring in Tom Joad to spruce up your ''Of Mice and Men'' movie? Or add Jack Pumpkinhead to the roster of ''The Wizard of Oz''? Probably not if you know what's good for you, but that hasn't discouraged Peter Jackson from risking the wrath of the literary-adaptation gods by announcing that he has added his ''Lord of the Rings'' star Orlando Bloom to the cast of his ''Hobbit'' movies, even though Mr. Bloom's character, the elf Legolas, doesn't appear in J. R. R. Tolkien's original ''Hobbit'' novel. In a Facebook post on Friday, Mr. Jackson wrote: ''Ten years ago, Orlando Bloom created an iconic character with his portrayal of Legolas. I'm excited to announce today that we'll be revisiting Middle Earth with him once more.'' Mr. Jackson, who is currently directing a two-movie adaptation of ''The Hobbit'' in New Zealand, gave Mr. Bloom his first major film roles by casting him as Legolas in his ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, helping raise the actor to stardom and other hit movies like the ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' series. (Since then, Mr. Jackson observed: ''Funny thing is, I look older - and he doesn't! I guess that's why he makes such a wonderful elf.'')

As if Don Draper didn't have enough on his plate already, with a new marriage, a daughter who's too grown up for her age, a son who's constantly being replaced by new actors, a struggling ad agency whose future all but rests on his shoulders and all that smoking and drinking he has to do, another responsibility has been added to his plate for the coming season of ''Mad Men.''Jon Hamm, the actor who plays Draper on that hit AMC period drama, will direct the first episode of the show's new season, the Web site tvline.com reported. Mr. Hamm, a multihyphenate who is also a producer of his companion Jennifer Westfeldt's coming film ''Friends With Kids'' and a star of the Kristen Wiig comedy ''Bridesmaids,'' said he had been contemplating a directing opportunity on ''Mad Men'' ever since John Slattery, a ''Mad Men'' co-star, directed an episode for the show's fourth season.

Having been successfully located on a hotel rooftop in ''The Hangover'' - and had the good sense to stay out of trouble in its sequel, ''The Hangover Part II'' - Justin Bartha will next turn up in Second Stage Theater's production of the Zach Braff play ''All New People,'' as part of a cast that also features Anna Camp, Krysten Ritter and David Wilson Barnes, the theater company said on Thursday. Second Stage Theater said in a news release that the play by Mr. Braff, the ''Scrubs'' and ''Garden State'' star, chronicles a heartbroken man (played by Mr. Bartha) who retreats to the resort community of Long Beach Island, N.J., in the middle of winter, only to have his solitude ''interrupted by a motley parade of misfits who show up and change his plans.'' His offbeat visitors are a local fireman (Mr. Barnes, of ''Becky Shaw'' and ''The Lieutenant of Inishmore''), a British real estate agent (Ms. Ritter, of television's ''Breaking Bad'' and the coming ABC series ''Apartment 23'') and a character the news release describes as a ''hired beauty'' (Ms. Camp, of ''True Blood'' and ''Mad Men'').

The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is in danger of becoming the latest victim of an international diplomatic battle that has led Russian museums to hold off making loans of state-owned art to the United States, after a federal judge in the District of Columbia ordered Russia to turn over a trove of religious books and manuscripts to members of Chabad-Lubavitch, the Hasidic group based in Brooklyn. -The Los Angeles Times reported that the loan dispute could mean the absence of 38 works of art from ''Gifts of the Sultan: The Arts of Giving at the Islamic Courts,'' a major show scheduled to open June 5. Barbara Pflaumer, a spokeswoman for the museum, told the newspaper that the situation was ''incredibly fragile and we are doing our very best not to make waves,'' in hopes that the situation can be remedied. But she added that the exhibition would take place with or without the pieces.

ABOARD PT-728, off Lower Manhattan - Capt. Tom Whyte issued only one order all morning, and there were very good reasons why that one order was not ''damn the torpedoes'' or ''lower the depth charge,'' but ''Timmy, cover your ears.'' Tim Ivory, the crewman, complied, and Captain Whyte sounded the surprisingly high whistle, an intriguing Irish tenor where a landlubber might have expected a basso profundo. Then Captain Whyte cut the engine and glided into a slip at the marina by Battery Park City.

A tumor on Gary Carter's brain is most likely malignant, according to preliminary results from a biopsy that was performed Friday morning. A statement from Carter's physicians said that once the final pathology report became available in several days, treatment options would be discussed with Carter and his family. Carter, the Hall of Fame catcher for the Mets and the Montreal Expos, was ''in excellent spirits and good physical condition,'' according to the statement from Dr. Allan H. Friedman and Dr. Henry S. Friedman, deputy directors at the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center at Duke University. The statement was released by the Mets.

Many readers made thoughtful comments in response to my post earlier this week, asking what they would take if they had to leave their home quickly in a disaster. Children, pets and sentimental keepsakes topped their lists, along with wallets and credit cards. No one talked about grabbing the cable television box. But apparently, that may be a good idea. The Consumerist reported Monday that the cable provider Charter Communications initially played hardball with some victims of the tornadoes that devastated parts of Alabama in April, telling them they would have to return their cable boxes or pay possible late fees or even replacement charges. The company then relented and said it wouldn't charge customers for lost or destroyed boxes.

Horse racing is halfway to a Triple Crown rubber match after the trainer of Animal Kingdom said Friday that the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom would come to New York for the Belmont Stakes. The trainer, Graham Motion, said that Animal Kingdom was none the worse for the wear after his late charge fell a half-length short to Shackleford in the Preakness Stakes last Saturday. Both Motion and Barry Irwin, the chief executive of Animal Kingdom's owner, Team Valor International, have pointed to the 3-year-old championship as a goal for Animal Kingdom and believe a victory in the Belmont is the way to the title.

A joint venture between MGM Resorts International and the daughter of a Hong Kong casino mogul raised $1.5 billion on Friday in its initial public offering, highlighting the strong appetite for stocks that have a large exposure to China. MGM China, whose main asset is a giant hotel and casino in the Chinese gambling hub of Macao, said in a statement Friday that it had priced its shares in the offering at 15.34 Hong Kong dollars ($1.97) -- at the top of a previously announced price range.

The sales estimates for Lady Gaga's new album keep going up and up. The latest projection: 1.15 million, according to the data-crunchers at Billboard magazine, which would make it the fastest-selling album in at least six years. A few weeks ago Billboard predicted that the album, ''Born This Way'' (Interscope), which was released on Monday, might net fewer than 750,000 sales in its first week, since some of its early singles had ''a less-than-spectacular reaction on the charts.''

In January 2009, roughly a month after Bernard L. Madoff's arrest, David Einhorn wrote an opinion article with Michael Lewis, the author who was then working on a book about the financial collapse of Wall Street. It was headlined ''The End of the Financial World as We Know It.'' In the article, published in The New York Times, Einhorn took note of how Harry Markopolos, an investment officer with a Boston financial firm, had spent nine years unsuccessfully trying to persuade the Securities and Exchange Commission that Madoff was up to no good.

Small museums don't often find themselves at the center of international investigations, but last year the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., did, when agents from the Department of Homeland Security tracked an altarpiece stolen in Italy in 1971 to the Speed's store rooms. The piece, a triptych featuring a Madonna and child that may date from as long ago as the 14th century, was stolen from a villa in Goito, southwest of Verona; two years later, the museum bought it from Newhouse Galleries in New York for $38,000. Under a settlement negotiated by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and announced on Monday, the Speed will soon turn over the work to Homeland Security, which will transfer it to Italian cultural authorities. (The collector who had owned it in 1971 has since died, and the authorities will be responsible for determining who is now entitled to the work.) Before that, however, the museum will show the painting, which it has not exhibited for at least a decade, from June 9 to July 3 as part of a small exhibit that will, according to the museum's director, Charles L. Venable, ''contextualize it in a larger world of provenance research and repatriation of works of art.'' In addition to the unsolved mystery of how the altarpiece got from Italy to the gallery in New York, there are other questions, including who painted it and whether it is actually a 14th-century work, as some scholars have argued, or a 19th-century painting in the style of a 14th-century one, as others have suggested. In part because of the uncertainties of attribution and dating, Mr. Venable said that the museum valued the painting today at $38,000 - the same price it paid in 1973.

9:30 P.M. (Cooking) FROM SPAIN WITH LOVE Annie Sibonney, above, eats her way through Spain on an odyssey that takes her from the beaches of Mallorca to the rugged Pyrenees, with stops in the fishing villages of Galicia and cosmopolitan Madrid. Her journey begins in Basque country, a fiercely independent region with an inventive cuisine and, she says, more cooks per capita than anywhere else in the world. In this series premiere, Ms. Sibonney breaks through barriers at a men's-only gastronomic society; samples cod kokotxas, her favorite Basque dish; partakes in a ''tapas crawl''; and cooks alongside the chef Juan Mari Arzak, considered the godfather of modern Basque cuisine. 10:30 A.M. Hyperbole is rarely in short supply on the eve of a major soccer final, but Manchester United Coach Alex Ferguson might have been on to something on Friday. In his final news conference before United faces Barcelona in Saturday's UEFA Champions League final, Ferguson predicted the matchup would produce the best game of the past 10 years. On paper, the matchup is mouthwatering: Barcelona's possession and passing and its pint-sized genius, Lionel Messi, against United's grit, its sustained excellence and its penchant for high drama.

MANDEL--Irwin D.,DDS. Professor Emeritus of Dental Medicine of the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on May 26, 2011. Dr. Irwin Mandel was born on April 9, 1922. He and his wife Charlotte, an award-winning poet and teacher, had two daughters, Nora and Carol, and a son, Richard. With the exception of two stints in the Navy Dental Corps (1945-1946 and 1952-1954), Dr. Mandel spent his entire career at Columbia, where he received his dental degree in 1945. Prior to that, Irwin graduated from the College of the City of New York in 1942. He began as a research assistant in 1946, and gave up his part-time private practice in 1968 to devote himself full-time to research and teaching. He founded and served as the director of the Division of Preventive Dentistry at Columbia, the first such department in the country, and also served as the founding director of the Center for Clinical Research in Dentistry, and as the Dental School's Associate Dean for Research before attaining emeritus status in 1992. A past president of the American Association for Dental Research, his many awards include the first Gold Medal Award for Excellence in Dental Research from the American Dental Association (1985). Other honors include the Award for Leadership in Periodontology from Tufts University (1971), the International Award from the University of Connecticut (1979), the Jarvie-Burkhardt International Award given by the New York State Dental Association (1990), and the Distinguished Service Award from the American Association of Public Health Dentistry (1991). Dr. Mandel received the honorary degree of Doctor of Science (honoris causa) from Columbia University in 1996. He also holds honorary degrees from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey (1981) and the University of Goteborg, Sweden (1994). As part of Columbia University's 250th anniversary celebration, Irwin was honored as one of the Columbians Ahead of Their Time and at a symposium held at the Dental School. Author of over 225 scientific articles and 18 books or book chapters, Dr. Mandel conducted pioneering research on the role of dental plaque in tooth decay and periodontal disease, and is also known for studies of salivary composition as it relates to dental disease and systemic disease. As a researcher, author, and teacher, Irwin D. Mandel played a major role in shifting the focus of dentistry from repair to prevention. Until recently, Dr. Mandel served as a consultant and research mentor on several projects. He was Chief Dental Advisor to Consumers Union and its publications, a position he held for nearly 50 years. He was also a consultant and spokesperson for the American Dental Association, Associate Editor of the Journal of Dental Research, and a grants reviewer for the National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research. He was an active writer and reviewer for the Surgeon General's Report on Oral Health (2000), and served as the preventive dentistry consultant to NASA's manned mission to Mars project. Irwin's influence on generations of dental students at Columbia was enormous. He emphasized the need to translate research findings into improved clinical care. Irwin will be remembered for his prodigious intellect, sharp wit, and his devotion to Columbia and the profession of dentistry. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Charlotte, his daughters Nora and Carol, his son Richard, and members of his family. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Mandel's family has requested that donations in his memory be sent to the College of Dental Medicine, Irwin D. Mandel Research Fund, 630 West 168 St., New York, NY 10032. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., Dean College of Dental Medicine Columbia University

Three of the nation's biggest banks introduced a service that will enable their customers to move money from their checking accounts using only an e-mail address or a mobile phone number. Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo already introduced the transfer service, called clearXchange, in Arizona, and it will roll out in more markets in coming months. It will be available nationwide within a year.

One of New York City Opera's key unions on Thursday charged the company with unfair labor practices and sought a court order blocking its proposed move out of Lincoln Center. The salvo from the American Guild of Musical Artists comes nearly a week after City Opera said it could no longer afford to stay at the arts complex. Opera officials have so far remained silent on what they will present next season or where. The Guild, which represents singers, chorus members, dancers, stage managers and directors, said City Opera was using the move to break its contractual obligations and had refused to negotiate or provide any information about it. The Guild filed its complaint with the National Labor Relations Board, and said it would ask the board to seek a federal court injunction barring the move. A departure would leave the performers' lives and careers ''irreparably damaged,'' said Alan S. Gordon, the Guild's executive director. The union also accused the company of violating the contract by failing to tell its members the number of guaranteed weeks they would have next season. City Opera did not immediately return a call seeking comment.

An article on Thursday about the announcement by Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister, that she would be a candidate for managing director of the International Monetary Fund erroneously attributed a distinction to Ms. Lagarde should she be appointed. She would be the first woman to head an international financial institution, not an international institution. (The World Health Organization, Unicef and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, among others, are or have been headed by women.)

“The blood of the first Martyr has flowed,” the Richmond Daily Dispatch announced on May 27, 1861. Three days earlier Confederate partisan James Jackson had been killed in Alexandria, Va., by a Union soldier after Jackson shot and killed Union Col. Elmer Ellsworth, who had charged into Jackson’s inn to remove a Confederate flag atop the building. Arguably the first casualties of the war, Jackson and Ellsworth became celebrated martyrs for the respective Confederate and Union causes.

A FIFA ethics panel on Sunday suspended two of the organization’s most powerful figures, Mohamed bin Hammam of Qatar and Jack Warner of Trinidad and Tobago, after they were accused of corruption. Two male playwrights consider the perks and perils of parenthood in new shows that recently opened in New York. Daniel Goldfarb’s “Cradle and All,” from the Manhattan Theater Club, is about two couples living in Brooklyn Heights, one considering having a baby and the other wondering whether or not to let their baby cry herself to sleep. In Jonathan Marc Sherman’s “Knickerbocker,” which closed on Sunday at the Public Theater, a 40-year-old man comes to terms with being a father for the first time.

The stakes were high late in the third set Sunday between Jelena Jankovic and the French Open defending champion, Francesca Schiavone. Both players had squandered opportunities to run away with the match, and neither was playing their best tennis. Schiavone had won converted just 4 of 19 break-point chances. Time and again, Schiavone set up the point, only to hit the final shot into the top of the net or just wide. For her part, Jankovic allowed her emotions to run away, especially at several critical junctures late in the match.

This has been a year of uprisings. The series of popular revolts, struggles and crackdowns by governments, which continue to this day, began in Tunisia when protesters demanded the removal of president Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.  The claims of the protesters were about the right to eat (the cost of food), political corruption, freedom of speech and basic political rights.  Then came Egypt, as thousands flocked to Tahrir Square in Cairo and elsewhere.  Their demands were similar to those in Tunisia. Both sets of protesters were successful: the leaders of both countries fled.  This was the first wave.  It was largely peaceful.

New York City’s alternative music scene will get a lift starting Wednesday, June 1, when WNYE-FM, the city-owned noncommercial station at 91.5 on the dial, begins broadcasting the indie music service “The Alternate Side” from 6 a.m. to noon. The program, started in 2008 by Fordham University’s public station WFUV-FM with support from the New York State Music Fund, has showcased artists like the Strokes and TV on the Radio as well as newer local groups like Freelance Whales.

FROM the recent string of crises at symphony orchestras you might conclude that orchestral business models are as outdated as the musicians' Victorian attire. The Philadelphia Orchestra filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in April; the Honolulu Symphony and the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra recently folded; and musicians of the Detroit Symphony had their pay cut after a six-month strike. In a turbulent economy that has carried a wide range of organizations, including arts groups, banks and newspapers, to the brink, orchestras are being forced to re-examine their missions and structures to accommodate a changing fiscal and social landscape. ''Music Makes a City,'' an engaging documentary from last year about the Louisville Orchestra that was just released on DVD, offers an inspiring and cautionary tale of creative chutzpah and financial mismanagement. The orchestra, which itself filed for bankruptcy in December, was founded shortly after the floods that crippled Louisville, Ky., in 1937.

It is as if pro athletes work behind some invisible cage. Fans can expect to abuse them without even the slightest recompense.

HIRSHFIELD--Bernard, age 90, died Wednesday, May 25, 2011. He was the devoted husband of Shirley of nearly 64 years; beloved father of Marsha and Morris Sobel, Dr. Carol Hirshfield, and Barbara and Marc Schwartz and proud of his grandchildren. He served his country in World War II in the Army Air Corps in the South Pacific from 1942-1945 for which he received medals. He owned and managed Hirshfield's Florsheim Shoes in Astoria, Queens and was very involved in the local community. A private graveside service was held. The family would like to thank the wonderful staff at the East Orange Veterans' Administration Hospital for their incredible care. Donations may be made in his memory to the charity of your choice.

NAKONECHNY--Donald S.,MD, July 13, 1944 - May 20, 2011. After a recent diagnosis of cancer, Donald S. Nakonechny, (Donny) a long-time Seattle pathologist, died peacefully at home in the company of his wife, Patti McCall, and son, Lyle Nakonechny. Don shared a memorable story with everyone he met and loved a good meal while learning about the lives and thoughts of his friends and family. The spectrum of his interests, studies, skills, and joys was shaped by the quality of people and the environment around him. He loved his family, his friends, his Cairn terriers, and the Pacific Northwest. Don had a wonderful 40-year career as a pathologist and was deeply committed to helping people up to the day of his death. Donny was proud to have been born into the cultural diversity of Manhattan, New York. Much of his childhood was spent with his grandmother, learning about his Ukrainian heritage and enjoying the borscht, chopped liver, potato latkes and other foods of his family's old-world traditions. As a young boy exploring in New York City, Donny found a snake at the edge of Central Park and brought it straight to the American Museum of Natural History. The snake had escaped from the Museum only days before and the research staff rewarded him with a special tour of the Museum that ignited a life-long love of science and the natural world. His love of science and nature grew to include the arts and literature when Don was given a scholarship to attend Regis High School in New York City. It was here he learned Homer's song of the sirens in ancient Greek, discovered his love for Bach and Mozart, and was introduced to the physics and art of optics and microscopy. Following Regis High School, Don attended New York University, Saint Louis University Medical School, and finally moved to Seattle for a pathology residency at the University of Washington Medical School. Following his UW residency, Don worked with Dr. Don Reay in the King County Medical Examiner's Office applying his skills of observation, science, and art to forensic pathology. These busy times of field and laboratory forensics were tempered with Herzog film festivals, Bob Marley concerts, academic lectures, and swimming. He also learned to scuba dive, forage for wild mushroom, and fish the local waters. Donny and his son, Lyle, spent many hours diving, fishing and rock hunting. Don's heart belonged to his family, his friends and his work. He took both great pleasure and pride in his West Seattle home and his home on the Washington Long Beach Peninsula. The curiosity and joy with which he approached life endeared him to nearly every life he touched and he will be deeply missed. On Saturday, June 4, 2011 from 12:30 to 3:30pm, the family has planned a celebration of Donny's life at Ray's Boathouse (The Northwest Room), at 6049 Seaview Avenue NW, Seattle, WA 98107. In lieu of flowers or gifts, Donny would have loved supporting the school that fostered his curiosity for life. Donations should be sent in memory of Donald S. Nakonechny, Class of '62: Regis High School, 55 East 84th Street, New York, NY 10028-0884.

For a pitcher with only a few months in the major leagues, Toronto's Kyle Drabek is easy to identify. He is the son of Doug Drabek, the 1990 National League Cy Young Award winner; he was the Blue Jays' centerpiece in the trade that sent Roy Halladay to Philadelphia; and he is the only pitcher in the majors with a single-digit uniform number. Drabek wears No. 4, which he wore as a high school wide receiver in suburban Houston. His baseball uniform was No. 1. When he got to pro ball, he was startled to see his uniform.

ROSENTHAL--Irvin H.,Manhattan attorney who practiced for sixty years. Proud member of the American Bar Association, New York County Lawyers Association, Bar Association of Nassau County, New York Women's Bar Association and former VP, American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. Proudly served US Army 1951-53. Admired and loved by sons Robert and Laurence, granddaughters Ariana and Veronica, his sisters and beloved wife Judy and her family.

GRABER--Frederick August, III, 93, of Los Altos Hills, CA passed away May 20, 2011. He was born in Terrytown, NY on May 18, 1918 to Mildred (McBride) and NY State Representative, Frederick Graber II. A graduate of Washington Irving High School, and Tome Prep School, it was during his senior year at Colgate University that he received his first taste of flying when a fellow student landed on Colgate's snow-covered football field and took him up for a ride. Fred received an appointment as a naval Air Force "student pilot" in July 1941. He was soon commissioned and joined the VF-11 "Sundowner" squadron. In March 1943, his squadron was sent to Guadalcanal, where he flew combat missions. In May 1944, he was sent to the aircraft carriers U.S.S. Enterprise and Saratoga. Fred joined Pan American World Airwavs where he flew throughout the world for the next 28 years. He was married for 48 years to Dorothy Myrick, before her passing in 2000. Together they raised three boys, Fred Jr., Randy, and Bill who have all married and survived him.

LEVERTE--Thomas J.,83, of La Quinta, CA died peacefully on May 23, 2011 after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Jean Mitchell Leverte, loving father of Kara Farley (Dan), Cristin Goldman (Ryan) and T.J. Leverte (Mikelynn) and grandfather of five. Tom attended Seton Hall and West Virginia and was an accomplished basketball player having played in multiple NIT tournaments held at MSG. After a successful multi-decade career as an executive in the pharmaceuticals industry with Chesebrough-Pond's and Bayer, Tom devoted his later years to his work as Board Member for Martha's Village and Kitchen in Indio, CA. A previous resident of New York, NY, Westhampton Beach, NY and Belvedere, CA before retiring to La Quinta, he was well and widely regarded as fair-minded, mentoring, and persistent in pursuit of noble causes, Tom will be missed by many. A memorial Mass will be held Tuesday, May 31, 2011, 11am, at St Francis of Assisi Church in La Quinta. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Martha's Village and Kitchen, 83791 Date Ave, Indio, CA 92201.

FOR some yoga practitioners, the body is a sacred vessel that should not be tainted. For others, the skin represents a blank, movable canvas for tattoos displaying thoughts, texts and deities that inspire and inform their practice. These works of art, stretched across shoulders, chests, arms and legs, may be tucked away during the workday. But when clothing comes off, as it often does in yoga studios, they are on display for all to see.

IT WAS JULY 12, 1995, and a cameraman from Bosnian Serb television was there, in the town of Srebrenica. United Nations forces had made it a safe haven for Bosnian Muslims, but Bosnian Serb forces had wrested it from them. The Serb commander approached a young Muslim boy and grinned like a doting grandfather. ''No one will be harmed,'' Gen. Ratko Mladic said, patting the boy's cheek. ''You have nothing to fear. You will all be evacuated.'' ''Thank you,'' refugees answered.

A chart on May 15 with an essay about how religion might affect financial destiny misstated the percentage of people identified as secular who graduated from college. It is 35 percent, not 45 percent.

PARK--Henry C. 1962 - May 17, 2011 of Somerville, MA and formerly Hopewell Junction, NY, passed away much too soon and unexpectedly from aortic rupture. A courageous champion of social justice, Henry was well known by Harvard classmates for political activism against apartheid, his involvement in the student assembly, founding of the Radical Academics group, and contributions to The Harvard Crimson where he worked to inform and create change for the better. Henry graduated cum laude from Harvard. Henry loved to swim, run, workout and play electric guitar, but his greatest passion was to research, read, write, and contribute to discussions on social and political issues. It directed his life. Henry managed staff and co-edited the opinion page of the Michigan Daily while earning his doctorate in sociology at the University of Michigan. Afterwards, Henry taught sociology at various universities in hopes of educating and inspiring students and pursuing research. He was a research scholar interested in China and Russia. He later worked as a statistical consultant while independently publishing, reading, researching, and attending lectures about social and political issues. His family and friends miss him very much. He is survived by his mother Margaret Park, his father K.C. Park, his brother Stuart Park, his sister Rosanne Park and a nephew and niece. A memorial service will be held at the MIT Chapel, 44 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA on July 10th at 1pm.

WASSERMANN--Felix E.,on May 22, 2011, age 86, at his home in New York City. Born in Bamberg, Germany, Professor of Microbiology at New York Medical College, fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine, and U.S. Army Veteran. Husband of Hannah Durlach Wassermann, survived by sons, Eric, Ross, and Joel. Donations to the Animal Shelter of Schoharie Valley, P.O. Box 40, 304 Howes Cave Rd., Howes Cave, NY 12092.

NUMBER OF attendees in 2011: 1,200 Price of admission: $25 consecutive years event has been sold out: 5 U.S. Sales of Fleetwood Mac's album ''Rumours'': more than 19 million U.S. sales of Stevie Nicks's solo albums: more than 16 million Stevie Nicks, the Fleetwood Mac vocalist, has always attracted blatant imitators and fervent admirers. For 21 years, the two camps have converged annually in New York City at the Night of 1,000 Stevies. With singers, dancers and other performers at the multimedia celebration at the Highline Ballroom earlier this month, Nicks (otherwise unaffiliated with the event) appeared in a video, promising to attend a future show and sing ''Edge of Seventeen.'' ''Should Stevie ever attend and perform,'' says Chi-Chi Valenti, the show's founding producer, ''it would be a mass of fans weeping, twirling, reaching out to touch her hand, singing along and making a mighty clatter of tambourines.'' Future attendees, be prepared: the Web site says it's strictly B.Y.O.B.T. -- Bring Your Own Bedecked Tambourine.

THE Insurance Institute for Highway Safety on Thursday released crash-test results for 13 small cars, with six earning top scores. That brings the total number of small cars named top safety picks by the institute to 22. The I.I.H.S., which is financed by the insurance industry, also released a list of the 10 small cars that had achieved top crash-test scores and had the highest fuel economy ratings in their class.

WATSON--Patricia, passed away May 23, 2011 at age 65. Born May 28, 1945 to Stanley and Edith (Horner) Rubin. She was a travel agent and Co-Founder of Watson and Watson Limited, a member of Virtuoso, and Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck. Survived by her beloved husband Robert E. Travers, cherished children Samantha (Michael) Shanken Baker, Allison (Adam) Cohen, Tracey (Andrew) Brody, Todd (Monica) Watson, adoring grandchildren Jake and Lauren Cohen, Marcia Brody, Alexandra and Daniel Watson, and loving sister Ronnie Rubin. Memorial Service to be held June 10, 2011 at 7pm at Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Susan King, Director, Special Events Center for Hearing and Communication, 50 Broadway, 6th Floor New York, New York 10004, Phone: 917-305-7804, Fax: 917-305-7821 www.chchearing.org

A picture caption on May 15 with a review of Henry Kissinger's ''On China'' misidentified an American official shown at a meeting with Kissinger, President Richard M. Nixon and Prime Minister Zhou Enlai during Nixon's trip to China in 1972. He was John H. Holdridge, a senior staff member of the National Security Council, not Secretary of State William P. Rogers, who also went on the trip.

Paris, Feb. 21, 2011 I traveled to Paris from Geneva, where I was studying abroad. I took this photograph on the first night I arrived, after I had ridden to the top of the Eiffel Tower and was walking back to my hotel. As I was heading back, I passed a young couple walking down the path leading up to the tower, and as I looked back at them, I was struck by the contrast between the beautifully lit tower and the dark and romantic silhouettes. Anna Tate, Ithaca, N.Y.

SELIGMAN--Adele Chase, on May 24. Beloved wife of the late Malcom, her soul mate from first grade on through their late 80s, who shared warmth, kindness and wit with everyone she encountered. Devoted mother of Pat Grant (Ron Litowitz), Lynne Vantriglia (Anthony Paolino), and the late Ellen Seligman; adored grandmother of Daniel, Eric, Owen, Douglas (Katie), Damian (Leah) and Charlotte; "GG" to Luke, Gus and Tatum; loving sister of Jimmy Chase and cherished cousin of Jean Heller and Lucille Samson. Memorial service Sunday, June 5, 10:30am, The Osborn, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to Greenwich Hospital for The Bendheim Cancer Center, 5 Perryridge Rd., Greenwich, CT 06830.
SILVERWATER--Arthur, 82, died May 27. Taught industrial arts in Harlem, NYC and Andres Hudde Junior High School, Brooklyn.

One of the most celebrated aspects of Stanley Cup play is the pain players endure to make a contribution during the postseason. It is a point of professional pride that hockey players will dress for games with injuries that would sideline most other athletes. Teams are reluctant to disclose injuries while they are still in contention, fearing that opponents will exploit their weaknesses or try to aggravate the conditions. But once a club is eliminated, stories emerge about the damage.

CAREY--Robert H.,on May 26th, age 79. Bob was born in Brooklyn, attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated from Niagara University. After serving in the U.S. Army he earned his law degree from St. John's University and embarked on a 50 year career as a municipal bond attorney starting with Caldwell, Trimble and Mitchell then merging with Nixon, Mudge, Rose Guthrie and Alexander. He was later Managing Partner of Sullivan, Donovan and was until his death of counsel to Nixon Peabody. Bob is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, Joan, four beloved children, Robert Jr., Suzanne Lavins, Gregory and William, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. His loving charm, kind sense of humor and dedication to family and friends will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Southampton Hospital or The Children's Academy in Manhattan. Visitation is May 31st at Thomas A. Glynn & Son in Rockville Centre with a Memorial Service on June 1st at 11am at St. Agnes Cathedral.
Art Randy Kennedy
NEWMAN--William L. Gone 25 years, but always in our hearts. We love and miss you. The Kids

JOE MANTELLO was a 22-year-old actor, trained in the classics and fresh to New York, when he set out for the Public Theater one snowy night in 1985 to see ''The Normal Heart,'' Larry Kramer's play about the first years of AIDS. Watching the protagonist Ned Weeks -- a blunt, opinionated gay man not unlike himself -- Mr. Mantello understood his need to take action in the face of death and denial, he recalled recently. If others found ''The Normal Heart'' a statistics-laden screed, Mr. Mantello felt a visceral recognition that Molière and Sophocles had never triggered. ''I tend to go toward things that make me afraid,'' Mr. Mantello said, ''so as a young gay man in New York at the beginning of the AIDS epidemic I had to go toward it. I'd never connected to a character so much before.''

When Derek Jeter stole second base in the third inning Saturday night against Seattle, he became the Yankees' franchise leader in stolen bases (327), passing Rickey Henderson (326). The title's changing hands twice since 1988 (when Henderson passed Willie Randolph) is unusual considering the fact that 11 teams have not had a change since 1925 or earlier. Current names of franchises are used below. Years indicate when the player took the franchise lead. Steal total is the current record.

HONIG--Edwin, 91, of Alzheimer's complications. Professor Emeritus at Brown, he was a renowned poet and scholar and knighted by the Spanish and Portuguese governments for his translations of Iberian poets and playwrights. He is survived by his sister, Lila Putnam, two sons, Jeremy and Daniel and his former wife, Margot Dennes.

WIENER--A. Walter, 99 years young, passed away on Friday, May 27 at home in Deal, NJ. Born in Long Branch, NJ on November 25, 1911, he grew up there before moving to Deal 60 years ago. He was the last surviving child of Russian immigrant parents Sarah and Charles Wiener, preceded by his sisters Sophie Goldwasser, Pat Schwartz-stein and Mildred Edelstein Isaacson, and brothers Jack and Murray. He is survived by his lifelong love and adored wife of more than 60 years, Virginia (nee Sternheimer of Richmond, VA); his three children, Barbara Wiener Fischhof and husband Richard of Atlanta, GA, Nancy Wiener of Little Silver, NJ, and Dr. David Wiener and wife Jennifer of Denver, CO; and darling grandchildren Adam, Daniel, Sarah, Sophia and William, to whom he was Pa and Popi. Some knew him as co-owner and president of Atlantic Plumbing Supply of Long Branch for more than 52 years; others knew him as an outdoorsman, adventurer and nature lover with the skill to fix or grow anything, and as a remarkably fit and energetic individual committed to whatever the challenge. But first in his life was his adoring family for he enriched their lives with his selfless spirit, giving heart and positive attitude. He was a caring sensitive man, a strong man, a loving man and a loyal friend in many ways a man ahead of his time and a dear person who will be greatly missed and never, never forgotten. He graduated from Long Branch High School and served in the US Army Signal Corps of Ft. Monmouth, NJ during World War II. He was a member of Jordan Masonic Lodge; Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ; Deal Borough Club; Hollywood Golf Club of Deal and Elberon Bathing Club. Private graveside service. Shiva observed May 30 at 5pm and May 31 at 7pm at his home. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Deal Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 56, Deal, NJ 07723 or a charity of your choice.
