While fashion has evolved from its rigid dictates, it's as true today as it ever was: after Memorial Day, white rules. (Although diehard New Yorkers will be back in all-black by next week.) The quest for the newest T-shirt is under way. A visiting Parisian, top, far right, sports a tee with ruffled shoulder pads and a low neckline edged with gauze; and a young man's, right, was baggy by design. White pops up on hats and on a bicycle helmet worn with matching glasses. Setting the season's monochromatic mood is a 44-foot-tall head by Jaume Plensa, dazzling against the emerald lawn of Madison Square Park.

HORN--Zenith Rosenberg, 96, of Tamarac FL, passed away quietly on Friday, May 27. Devoted wife of the late Sidney Horn, beloved mother of Nancy Pernick and Martin Horn, loving mother-in-law of Benjamin Pernick and Janis Horn, adoring grandmother of Jonathan Pernick, Gary Pernick, Alice Pernick, Joanna Horn and David Horn and proud great-grandmother of Michael and Joshua Pernick, Diana and Rachel Barry. She lived a full life of good deeds, surrounded by lifelong friends. Born in Brooklyn, she worked for many years as a fund raiser for the Jewish Hospital for Chronic Diseases and the Haym Solomon Home. Funeral Services Tuesday, May 31 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY; interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. The family will receive condolences at the home of Gary and Lynn Pernick, 209-45 18th Ave. Bayside, NY 11360 on Tuesday, May 31 from 3pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Hospice By the Sea 1531 Palmetto Park Rd. Boca Raton, FL 33486 or Rayus Hadassah 7960 Colony Circle North 5-306 Tamarac, FL 33321.

SMITH--Quentin I.,Jr., died peacefully on May 20, 2011 after a short illness. He was 83 years old and a resident of Kendal-on-Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY at the time of his death. Born in New York City, Quentin was the eldest son of Alice Lawson Smith and Quentin Irving Smith. He grew up in Edgemont, NY and graduated from Scarsdale High School, where he met his wife of sixty years, Beverly Pertsch. After a stint in the Army, Quentin graduated in 1950 from Yale University where, among other activities, he played on the varsity baseball team. He also graduated from the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School. Quentin began his business career at the Prudential Insurance Company. In 1957, he joined Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby Inc, later known as Towers Perrin and now part of Towers Watson, a leading international management consulting company. He rose through the ranks at TPF&C and, in 1971, at the age of 44, became the firm's President and Chief Executive Officer, a position he held until his retirement in 1987. During Quentin's tenure, TPF&C grew from a firm with annual revenues of $12 million and a few offices to a business with annual revenues of close to $500 million, thousands of employees and offices around the globe. He helped to engineer a series of strategic acquisitions that diversified the company's service offerings and transformed it into one of the largest, privately-held consulting firms in the world. Quentin's colleagues credited him with transitioning TPF&C from a loose coalition of individual practitioners into a focused, disciplined and integrated worldwide professional services firm, a leader in its field. Quentin was a tireless executive who valued greatly all the people he worked with regardless of position or title. During his career, Quentin also proudly served as a member of the Board of Directors of The Guardian Life Insurance Company, The J. Walter Thompson Company, Omnicom Group, UGI Corporation, and the Employee Benefit Research Institute. In retirement, Quentin lived in Sanibel Island and Boca Grande, FL, as well as East Orleans, MA. He was a fixture at his grandchildren's many sporting events, concerts, and plays. He also performed volunteer work for the United Nations. He continued his lifelong passion for baseball, always watching and rooting for the New York Yankees and personally playing softball well into his seventies in the Cape Cod Old Timers Softball League. He was an avid tennis player and occasional golfer. He was a long time member of the Eastward Ho Golf Club in Chatham, MA and Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, NY. Quentin was a wonderful man and leaves behind many adoring family members. In addition to his wife Beverly, Quentin is survived by two brothers, Peter L. Smith of Richland, Washington and Donald L. Smith of Rock Island, IL, his three children, Jeffrey Q. Smith of Purchase, NY, Lance A. Smith of Westport, CT, and Karen L. (Smith) Salinaro of Hastings on Hudson, NY, their spouses, seven grandchildren, and a host of extended family in Florida and elsewhere. When in the last several years his health deteriorated and his activities became much more limited, his spirit remained strong. Quentin always had a smile and wave for those he saw. He never stopped caring about his family, friends, and former colleagues. He will be greatly missed. Quentin was interred at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY following a private family ceremony. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held in New York City during June. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Quentin's name to support either research into the aging brain under the direction of Dr. Richard Mayeux, Department of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center, 710 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032, or Yale University, Ray Tompkins Associates, P.O. Box 1844, New Haven, CT, 06520.
At the New Coney Island Neil Genzlinger rides the four new attractions at Scream Zone located in Coney Island's Luna Park.

An article last Sunday about the brilliance of the soccer player Lionel Messi misstated to whom the British commentator Ray Hudson was referring when he said a player had ''chameleon eyes.'' It was Messi's teammate Xavi Hernandez, who goes by only his given name, not Messi himself.

GEOGHEGAN--William James, William James Geoghegan, 89, died at Sunrise Assisted Living in Westfield. He was born in Elizabeth, NJ and lived in Springfield since 1952. Bill was a veteran of World War II, serving in the Air Force, and received a Purple Heart after being wounded in France. Prior to the war he played semi-professional football. Following the war he attended Newark College of Engineering. Bill spent the better part of his 50-year career in construction with Morse Diesel International Inc. Bill's expertise and accomplishments spanned the gamut of commercial, industrial, and correctional facility construction. In his career, Bill guided a number of corporate America's major construction projects, including facilities for Phillip Morris, Coco Cola and Schering Plough. His work for Phillip Morris, in particular, included monumental projects in the late 1970s and early 80s such as the Park Avenue headquarters building near Grand Central Station and three huge tobacco manufacturing facilities in Richmond VA, Louisville, KY and Cabarrus County, NC in all, totaling about three million square feet. His projects for this client also encompassed major industrial manufacturing facilities and laboratories for General Foods and major breweries nationwide for Miller Brewing Company. Bill was also at one time perhaps the nation's foremost authority on construction of correctional facilities. His criminal justice projects included correctional treatment facilities in Washington, D.C., West Palm Beach, and Bradford, PA. He was also responsible for the rebuilding of the Manhattan House of Detention into a modern maximum security facility near Greenwich Village, and the expansion of the Otis Bantum Correctional Center on Rikers Island. He will always be remembered for his love of the New York Giants, the Arts, sailing, skiing, and especially for sharing these experiences with family and extended family. He leaves behind his wife of 69 years Liselotte Rendl Geoghegan of Springfield, NJ, his sons William Thomas Geoghegan of Las Vegas, NV and Michael Vincent Geoghegan of Moretown, VT, and daughter Margaret Geoghegan-Daly of Germansville, PA. He was a loving grandfather to Kasey Geoghegan, William Michael Geoghegan, Michael Luke Geoghegan, Amy Frostman, Kathryn Geoghegan, Daniel Daly, and Luke Daly; and the great-grandfather of six. Also surviving are siblings Ann Short, Marie Byrne, Margaret Macziejewski, Jane Burke, and Honore Monroe. Previously deceased is a brother Richard Geoghegan. A funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday, June 1 at St. James the Apostle, 45 South Springfield Ave., Springfield, NJ. Friends may call at the Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home, 415 Springfield Ave., Springfield, NJ on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. For more information or to send a condolence please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association, 400 Morris Ave., Suite 251 Denville, NJ 07834.

ROSE PETERSON: I was thinking that it was a lot harder to put the little flower on than I expected. I was also excited about the pictures being taken, because those are always the sweetest ones. Gabe is my best guy friend, and so we were like, ''We'll go to prom together!'' And I made him ask me in a cute way. In the photo, I think Gabe was a little bit scared that I'd stab him, but other than that he was fine. GABRIEL LUCIANO-CARSON: I wasn't nervous; if anything, I thought it was comedic. It's hard to pin a corsage on. What I was thinking was: ''This is going to be such a fun night.'' Last year I went to prom, and it wasn't that much fun.

Steve Nash, the Phoenix Suns' star point guard and noted soccer enthusiast, is hosting the fourth annual Showdown in Chinatown, a charity soccer match, on June 22 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Tony Parker, Grant Hill and Brandon Jennings are among the N.B.A. stars playing in the match, which is free and open to the public. Proceeds from an after-hours event will benefit the Steve Nash Foundation. Nash, who lives in Manhattan in the off-season, has recently become an advocate for gay rights and recently lent his voice to a same-sex marriage initiative in New York State. Q. We're used to seeing you still playing in May. What are you doing with the down time? Are you watching the playoffs?

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Born on Sideline, Cheering Clamors to Be Sport,'' May 23: The major purpose of any sport is competition. The major aim of cheerleading is performing at games. Cheerleaders' existence is based on performance art, no matter how competitive they are at other times.

STEWART--John MacKenzie, 79, died peacefully at home on May 19, 2011. Born in Glen Cove, NY, in 1932, he graduated from Yale University ('53) and Harvard Business School ('57). He served in the US Navy from 1953 - 1955 and as a program manager for TRW's Saturn missile project. In 1961 he joined McKinsey & Company where for 37 years, he dedicated himself to client service. In addition, he served on the Defense Science Board, Yale University Council, National Council on Economic Education and as Executive Director of the US National Commission on Productivity. Most recently, he was a trustee of NYU Medical Center, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and on the Dean's Advisory Council at Boston University School of Medicine. He also consulted with a Gates Foundation initiative to reduce HIV/AIDS in India. John's many civic commitments reflected his lifelong interest in the intersection of management with science and economics, and a deeply held belief in "giving back". Even his love of flying became a way to help others through Angel Flights. John was a great human being. He brought integrity, creativity and compassion to every endeavor with family, with friends and with professional colleagues. He had a unique way of guiding those around him to new and deeper insight. And he was a lot of fun to be around. He loved his family: his wife, Eliot; their four children: Diane Stewart, Sandi Stewart, Ian Highet and Eliot Patty; and nine grandchildren: Anna, Colin, Ali, Dash, Gil, Lisa, Andrew, Liam and Eliza. Services will be held at the Yale Club on Sunday, June 19 at 4:30pm, reception following. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: John Stewart Memorial Fund, Amyloid Research Program, Boston Univ. School Of Medicine, 72 E. Concord St., Boston, MA 02188 or Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Fenno House, Woods Hole, MA 02543.

Part of Kevin Long's job as the hitting coach for the Yankees is to build trust, to get his players to buy what he is selling. He has been far more successful doing that than he was at an off-season job in the minors, when he tried to sell Yugos in Phoenix. ''I made exactly one sale,'' Long writes in his new memoir, ''Cage Rat,'' a book that personifies him. It is illuminating and instructive, sprinkled with anecdotes, easy to understand and never controversial.

KAYNOR--William A. Bill Kaynor died on May 25, 2011, at the age of 88. Bill was a resident of Coconut Grove, Florida and Quogue, New York. He was born and raised in Waterbury, CT. He attended McTernan's School, the Taft School, Yale College and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he flew 35 missions as a B-24 Pilot in the European Theater of Operations. He was awarded the Air Medal with two OLC's, the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Purple Heart. After the war he attended Harvard Law School where he graduated cum laude and was an editor of the Law Review. He spent his entire professional career as a corporate lawyer at Davis Polk & Wardwell, in New York City, where he was a partner for over 30 years. He moved to Florida in 1996, but continued to summer in Quogue, NY, where he has summered for the last fifty years. He was a director of Americana Hotels & Realty Corp, Segue Software, Planned Parenthood of South Florida, and Community Partnership for the Homeless of Miami. Bill will be remembered as a wonderfully sweet man, always wearing a grin, whose kindness and generosity knew no bounds. He descended from the earliest settlers of the country on both sides of his family. His maternal ancestors included Thomas Hooker, the founder of Hartford, CT and Elihu Yale. His father's ancestors included two who fought in the Revolutionary War and the Battle of Brandywine and at the Battle of Plattsburg in the War of 1812. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Irene Moullin, his two sons William A., Jr. and Robert M., and four grandchildren, Dillon, Caroline, Charlie and Sophia. Services will be held on Sunday, May 29th at Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove at 3pm and on Saturday, June 4th at the Church of Atonement in Quogue, New York at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, please mail contributions to The Riverhead Hospital or East End Hospice.

IT promises to be the summer's biggest sequel: the High Line, Section 2. Friends of the High Line, the nonprofit group that with the New York City parks department maintains the elevated railway turned park by the Hudson River, has yet to announce an opening date for the second section, except to say it will be in June. The city is closely guarding that ribbon-cutting moment so that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can fling wide the gates.

Widespread approval greeted the news last week that the Los Angeles Lakers had chosen Mike Brown to replace the retiring legend Phil Jackson. And why not? Brown's coaching mantra is defense above everything, and defense is certainly not the Lakers' strong suit, as the longtime franchise icon Jerry West said during the season.

A classical music entry in the May 8 ''Summer Stages'' section misstated the opening date of the Olympic Music Festival, in Quilcene, Wash., on the Olympic Peninsula, which ends Sept. 4. It is June 25, not July 25. The entry also misstated the animals on the 55-acre farm. There are chickens, ducks and mares; there are no longer donkeys.

Hello Kitty plans to expand into China with a theme park. Sanrio Corporation, the Japanese company that created the popular mouthless cat in 1974, has announced it will build a Hello Kitty theme park in the rural town of Anji, several hours' drive from the major cities of Hangzhou and Shanghai.

8 P.M. (13, 49) NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT (2011) This annual tribute will honor those who lost their lives on 9/11, and the heroism of the firefighters and police officers who first responded that day. Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna (near right, with Mr. Sinise) team up for the sixth time as hosts of this live broadcast from the West Lawn of the United States Capitol. Forest Whitaker, Dianne Wiest, B. B. King, Jason Ritter, A. J. Cook, Pia Toscano, Hayley Westenra, Yolanda Adams, Kris Allen and Daniel Rodriguez will perform, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jack Everly. Gen. Colin L. Powell will send a special thank-you to troops in Iraq; another segment will honor World War II veterans 70 years after the attack on Pearl Harbor. Other participants include members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff as well as the United States Army Herald Trumpets, the United States Army Chorus, the Soldiers' Chorus of the United States Army Field Band, the United States Navy Sea Chanters and the United States Air Force Singing Sergeants, along with color guards and service flags from each branch of the armed services. 6 A.M. (TCM) MEMORIAL DAY WAR MARATHON A weekend-long programming block picks up with ''Hell to Eternity'' (1960), about a young man (Jeffrey Hunter) adopted by Japanese-Americans who becomes a hero in World War II, and continues at 8:30 with ''From Here to Eternity'' (1953), about the days leading up to Pearl Harbor -- and starring that immortal kiss between Burt Lancaster and Deborah Kerr. The prime-time segment begins at 8 p.m. with ''The Story of G.I. Joe'' (1945), in which Ernie Pyle, the Scripps-Howard war correspondent (played by Burgess Meredith), joins an Army platoon during World War II to learn what battle is really about. Reviewing the film, by William A. Wellman, in The New York Times, Thomas M. Pryor said, ''It is humorous, poignant and tragic, an earnestly human reflection of a stern life and the dignity of man.''

Erik Spande, the owner of the Amsterdam shop Chocolatl, may hail from Portland, Ore., but he has found a quintessentially Dutch solution to the problem of limited space. ''This is all custom-made,'' he said, pulling out a slab of shelf, one of many that are stacked to the ceiling with chocolate products both luxurious and fanciful. ''Space is at such a premium here.'' Amsterdam's Jordaan neighborhood is a microcosm of what visitors expect from the Netherlands: small in scale but ambitious, quaint but bustling. And the Hazenstraat, which runs through the lower part of the neighborhood, is the Jordaan in miniature. Gallery owners pace small showrooms with wooden floors, and hairdressers gab with clients while their neighbors sip tea at tables pulled out onto the sidewalk. JOEL WEICKGENANT

WEINTRAUB--Moses, died on May 24 at the age of 90. Beloved and adored husband of Marian for over 62 years. Devoted and loving father of Steven (Judy) Weintraub, Jeffrey (Judy) Weintraub, and Sharon (Michael) Dashow. Dear brother of Roslyn Besdine, the late Alfred Weintraub, and the late Esther Miller and adored grandfather of Wendy (Yehuda), Jenny, William, Erica, Jordan, and Allison, and adored great-grandfather. His devotion to the Jewish community was exemplified by his service as a founding member, former Chairman of the Board, and former Israeli bond Chairman of the Young Israel of Oceanside, in addition to his other philanthropic activities. He spent 31 years as an Assistant Attorney General with the New York State Department of Law and 21 of the 31 as a prosecuting attorney with the Special Prosecutions Bureau, now known as the Criminal Prosecutions Bureau. He had a private law practice for many years and was a Certified Public Accountant. He never had a bad word to say about anyone. His beautiful smile lit up the world. He was deeply loved, will always be remembered, and will be greatly missed. His passing leaves a void in our hearts.

In years past, hotel rooms offering outdoor showers in Manhattan were all the rage. This year, the latest in urban en plein air living is the outdoor bedroom. This month the AKA Central Park in New York began allowing guests who book the penthouse on the 17th floor of the 134-room hotel to request that staff members move the bed onto the terrace (above) before a wood-burning fireplace. A night in the suite, which features one indoor bedroom, costs $3,000 and includes a bottle of Champagne or vodka, chocolate-covered strawberries and the use of flashlights, an e-reader and a telescope for stargazing.

In a six-game stretch from late April to mid-May, Joaquin Benoit of the Detroit Tigers allowed 12 earned runs, three more than he did all of last season for the Tampa Bay Rays. That short stretch of shaky pitching showed just how volatile a reliever's results can be from year to year. The Tigers had hoped for better, after paying Benoit $16.5 million for three years in free agency, but they are not alone in their torment. The Yankees showered Rafael Soriano with $35 million and three years - against the wishes of General Manager Brian Cashman - and Soriano is out until midseason with elbow inflammation. Oakland's Brian Fuentes ($10.5 million, two years) has lost seven games, and his closer's role, while feuding with Manager Bob Geren.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel begins his trip around the Mediterranean with a stop at the Cabo de Gata-Níjar nature reserve (above) in southeastern Spain, where he finds idyllic beaches away from the tourist hordes that flock to the region. Help him plan the fourth stop on his journey by coming up with an itinerary for a fun-filled, smartly themed, low-budget, five-day trip to somewhere on the Italian coast.

The number of hotel rooms in New York City has increased by almost 24 percent in the last three years, a growth that has been driven in part by hotels in boroughs beyond Manhattan, according to NYC & Company, the official marketing, tourism and partnership organization for New York City. This year the trend continues, with about 40 percent of the new hotels in New York opening in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. That is a significant shift, said Bjorn Hanson, dean of the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Sports Management at New York University. Thirty years ago, he said, ''42nd Street was too far south, 59th Street was too far north, Lexington Avenue was too far east, and Sixth Avenue was too far west.''

FRELINGHUYSEN--Peter H. B.,loving husband of the late Beatrice P. Frelinghuysen and proud father, grandfather and great-grandfather to a grateful family. A man from a different era, he was modern in his outlook. He found his vocation in politics and was blessed with an inquisitive and critical mind. Passionate about plants of all kinds, he delighted in his gardens, collecting palm trees in Maui and his favorite daffodils in New Jersey. In conversation, he choose his words carefully, mixing wit with an occasional barb. He found wonderful companionship playing bridge, where he showed his competitive side. With his late wife Bea, he had beloved friends of all ages from every stage of his life. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, June 3 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 121 South Street, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Friends of The Great Swamp Wildlife Refuge 241 Pleasant Plains Road, Basking Ridge NJ 07920 or the Raptor Trust 1390 White Bridge Road, Millington, NJ 07946.

SKALAK--Anna Allison, 86, passed away peacefully on April 24, Easter morning. Anna was the loving wife of Richard Skalak (1923-1997), mother of Steven, Thomas, Martha, and Barbara Skalak, grandmother of Sarah Maffey, Leslie, Matthew, Zachary, Scott, and Linden Skalak, and great-grandmother of Thomas Maffey. She was close to brother Walter Leslie Allison, Jr. and sister Sara Jean Allison Van Horne. Anna was born in India, attended Woodstock School near the Himalayas, and left home alone at age 17 in 1942 to sail on a steamship to New York. Her father wrote, "She brought us seventeen years of pure joy." Anna received a B.A. from Wilson College, moved to New York City, and married Richard Skalak, a Professor at Columbia University and U.C.S.D. Anna lived with grace, optimism, and self-reliance, raised her family in Leonia, NJ, and later lived in San Diego. Public memorial service: June 20, 2pm at La Jolla Presbyterian Church, 7715 Draper Ave., La Jolla, CA.

AUBURN, Ind. -- Years before he gained fame, let alone a place in the Baseball Hall of Fame, Reggie Jackson, his five siblings and parents would sit on their front porch after dinner and play a game in which they received one point for identifying the make, model, year, official color and the license plate number of the cars that drove past. Those accrued points acted as currency redeemable for a bedtime snack, Mr. Jackson recalled during a panel discussion here at the spring car auction conducted by Auctions of America by RM. In addition to collecting 563 home runs during his major league career, Mr. Jackson has presided over a car collection that has, at times, exceeded 100 vehicles.

Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about ''The Convert,'' Deborah Baker's account of Maryam Jameelah, an American Jew who moved to Pakistan and became a noted Islamic writer, used the author's name erroneously in a sentence about the book's subject. It was Jameelah's parents who were concerned about her varying fixations on Middle Eastern issues, not Baker's.

THE Japanese photographer Rinko Kawauchi is finely tuned to what she likes to call the small voices in our world -- those that whisper. Her eyes, she says, naturally focus on small things. Illuminance, her show at the Hermès gallery and the title of a lush book published by Aperture, is resplendent in them. A tiny green frog perched on the palm of a seemingly enormous hand; a lighted cigarette, its ash a fiery orange, juts from the fingers of another. A slab of raw tuna takes on the monumentality of a landscape, while an image of goldfish packed to the gills in a plastic baggie brings to mind the Tokyo subway during rush hour. Illuminance was drawn from 15 years of work, and the journey is an epic one. And yet, Ms. Kawauchi chose to bookend it with images of an eclipse, leaving the impression that time has passed in the blink of an eye. Gallery at Hermès, 691 Madison Avenue. ALIX BROWNE

IT was a horse race for this week's biggest sale, with the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu paying $15.5 mil- lion for a town house in Mid- town and the prominent philanthropist Laurie M. Tisch closing on the sale of her co-op at the Brentmore on Central Park West for $15.15 million.But Mr. Slim, who paid $44 million last year for the Duke Semans mansion on Fifth Avenue, bought the house, once home to Elizabeth Taylor and her third husband, Michael Todd, for use as offices, ac- cording to the broker who handled the all-cash deal, Faith Hope Consolo of Prudential Douglas Elliman. The 11,700-square-foot unit, which had an asking price of $18 million, had commercial space in it, she said. (Mr. Slim is a creditor and a shareholder of the New York Times Company.)Ms. Tisch's apartment, then, a four-bedroom three-and-a- half-bath co-op most recently listed with Stribling and Associates for $17.25 million, comes in as the biggest residential sale of the week, according to transactions posted on Streeteasy.com and city property records. Ms. Tisch, the daughter of Preston Robert Tisch, a founder of the Loews Corporation, had listed two units at 88 Central Park West,near 69th Street, as a combination last Au- gust. The initial asking price was $25 million, for a total of eight bedrooms and five and a half baths. But in November she also listed the larger unit separately, for $18.25 million. In early December, The New York Observer reported that the actress Sarah Jessica Park- er and her husband, Matthew Broderick, had gone into con- tract on the combination, but both listings reappeared two weeks later, according to Stree- teasy. And city property records filed on May 20 show that residents of another apart- ment in the building, Jeffrey L. Gates, a hedge fund owner, and Richard M. Moran, bought the larger apartment for $15.15 mil- lion.The brokers who represent- ed Ms. Tisch did not respond to a request for comment, and the status of her smaller apart- ment was unclear.Records show that Ms. Tisch paid $29 million in 2009 for a co- op at 834 Fifth Avenue, a Rosa- rio Candela building.Big ticket includes closed sales from the previous week, ending Wednesday.SARAH KERSHAW

THE culture is headed for the curb, and The New York Times is on the story. Recent examples include a May 19 article (''With a Harsh Light on Two Men, Much of the Scrutiny Falls on the Women'') about the privacy-invading media coverage of the women in the Arnold Schwarzenegger and Dominique Strauss-Kahn cases, as well as a Sunday, May 22, investigation (''The Gossip Machine, Churning Out Cash'') into how pay-to-play tabloid journalism works in the digital age.

WORD of a scandal began to fly through New York society circles in 1898 when Henry T. Sloane, a wealthy carpet manufacturer who was furnishing the new mansions, hotels and clubs of the city, deeded a mansion on the Upper East Side to his wife. It was soon confirmed that Mr. Sloane's wife, Jessie, had taken up with another man, and she married him a mere five hours after divorcing Mr. Sloane. So Mr. Sloane set out to build himself a new mansion at 18 East 68th Street, off Fifth Avenue.

AS the real estate market in New York City shuffles toward recovery, two-bedroom apartments have been the last to rejoin the party. Sales of studios and one-bedrooms rebounded first after the market crashed in late 2008, followed by three-bedrooms, but it wasn't until mid-2010 that the two-bedroom market started its comeback. Now, brokers say that the demand for smaller apartments has ebbed and that two-bedroom apartments are all the rage, especially those priced at the lower end of the market.

PARMER--Leo G.,MD, 94, on May 22, 2011. Beloved husband of Miriam; loving brother of Rose Zelman; devoted father of Bill (Joan) and Laura (Andy) Skodol; adoring grandfather of Dan, Ali, Julia, and Ilana. He received his PhD and MD from Columbia University; was dedicated to the patients in his private practice of internal medicine in Fresh Meadows, Queens from 1951 to 1984; and was a founding physician of LIJ Hospital. We will miss his playful sense of humor, whimsical creativity, love of knowledge, and devotion to family. Donations may be made to the CCFA-Long Island, 585 Stewart Ave., Garden City, NY 11530.

STEWART--John M. The partners of McKinsey & Co. mark with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, John Stewart, who served our clients and our firm with distinction for 37 years. John joined McKinsey in 1961, with degrees from Yale and the Harvard Business School, after serving in the U.S. Navy and working at TRW. He became a Partner of McKinsey in 1967 and retired as a Special Status Director in 1998. John was a revered and gracious presence and a beloved colleague. Possessing one of the most brilliant minds of his era, he relished the problem solving process and was known for his penetrating questions, imaginative thinking, and stunning insights. With a self-effacing style and a fondness for parables, he became a masterful counselor to CEOs, who cherished his wisdom, his great humanity, and his deep instinct to help. So did we. To John's wife, Eliot, his children, and the rest of his family, we offer our deepest condolences and join in mourning the loss of a great man.

THE NEWS Kathy Hochul, the Democratic clerk of Erie County, N.Y., won a special election to the House in a district near Buffalo that had been solidly Republican for decades. BEHIND THE NEWS The G.O.P. candidate, Jane Corwin, saw her wide lead in the race evaporate after Ms. Hochul criticized her for backing her party's plan to scrap Medicare in its current form and replace it with subsidies for private health insurance. Elated Democrats saw the victory as a sign that the right-wing Republicans in the House had greatly overplayed their hand and would be vulnerable in 2012.

AXELRAD--Mireille Angel Guzelbahar, 97, passed away on May 26, 2011 after a valiant struggle with her last illness. Born in Istanbul, Turkey in 1914, she attended Robert college. In 1960 she came with husband Robert Guzelbahar to America joining daughters, Doli and Emel. She became a Turkish American matriarch, beloved and relied upon by her own large family and a multitude of friends who reaped spiritual and intellectual inspiration from her. A vibrant lady, a great bridge player and chef, she bestowed gifts of all kinds on those who knew her. A resident of Boca Raton, Florida for years, she kept close contacts with her family in New York, Paris and Istanbul. She was predeceased by her husband, Robert Guzelbahar, her daughter, Doli Cole and her granddaughter, Sally Rosen. She is survived by her daughter, Emel Glicksman Israel, her grandchildren, Robert and Amy Cole, Cynthia Touma, Nina Rosen, and her great-grandchildren, Danielle and Adam Cole, and Henry and Zoe Touma. The family will welcome friends at the home of Emel Glicksman Israel on June 20, from 6 to 9pm.

WITH Memorial Day upon us, and with it a summer driving season marked by high prices at the gas pump, it seems a fitting time to look at the electric car. How do the fuel and environmental costs of running one compare with the costs of a conventional car, or even the electricity to run appliances in your home? (Such details are on the minds of federal officials, who last week unveiled new fuel-economy stickers for vehicles, starting with the 2013 model year.) The figures on this page are only one way of crunching the numbers. They focus on the Nissan Leaf, among the first purely battery-powered electrics now on the market. (The much-publicized Chevrolet Volt is a plug-in electric-gas hybrid.) The comparisons reflect the immediate expense of running the cars or appliances shown -- the price incurred from pump or plug to car or device. They do not factor in manufacturing costs or purchase prices; maintenance expenses (like replacing an electric car's battery); the cost of the car's home charger; or even home electrical upgrades, if needed.

There are many reasons why people fail to reach college, including, of course, lack of access to quality primary and secondary schooling. But for millions of students who could succeed in college, the limiting factor is money.

After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championship characteristics in our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.” Based on similar research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might predict the winner of the Stanley Cup finals, which start Wednesday in Vancouver. Focusing on concepts of sports psychology, we looked at factors such as big-game experience, leadership on the ice and consistency. So important are these concepts to winning championships that they have proven to be common themes across all sports we have studied.

On May 31, 1861, Joseph Holt spoke out on behalf of the Union. The man who had been Secretary of War in early 1861 (and who has a role played by Danny Huston in Robert Redford’s current film, “The Conspirator”) saw that his native state of Kentucky dangled precariously in the balance. Its leading men had just resolved upon “strict neutrality” between the Federal government and the Confederacy. Holt would have none of it. Neutrality, he insisted, was a delusion. He would as soon think “of being neutral in a contest between an officer of justice and an incendiary arrested in an attempt to fire the dwelling over my head.”

“The Hangover Part II” has sold about $137.4 million in tickets since opening in North American theaters on Thursday, according to results compiled by Hollywood.com. That performance — the biggest debut for a live-action comedy and the strongest opening for an R-rated comedy — helped drive robust business for the Memorial Day weekend.Audiences for the top 12 films over the four-day weekend spent about $272.8 million on tickets, up 48 percent from the same period last year. (The figures were not adjusted for inflation or to account for 3-D and Imax ticket prices.)

A mild tremor of excitement ran through the New York City Ballet audience on Sunday afternoon as the cast of George Balanchine’s “Slaughter on Tenth Avenue” took a bow. The dark-suited and hatted dancer who had played the “Big Boss” in the delightful tale of murder and mayhem at the ballet, had just popped out of the wings, performed a quick, modest salute, and popped back in. It took a moment to realize that the Big Boss was in fact the Big Boss. Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of the company, had stepped in for an injured Ask la Cour the previous night, and reappeared at the matinee with no fanfare or announcement of the change in cast. Mr. Martins, who retired from dancing in 1983, hasn’t appeared onstage since dancing in a pas de deux with Suzanne Farrell at her farewell performance in 1989. But he clearly hasn’t forgotten the tricks of the trade, even jumping nimbly off a high table (those of us who had recognized him winced for his knees) and rolling on the floor as he fought Andrew Veyette as the Hoofer. The only concession Mr. Martins made to age and experience was to forgo wearing tights. We understand.

We've highlighted a few of the most entertaining here -- separated into domestic and international divisions -- but please go back and read all the contributions.

FISHEL--James W.,James W. Fishel, an advertising executive for more than 50 years and former president of Fairfax Advertising Agency, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. A native of New York City, Mr. Fishel attended the city's public schools. After graduating from Washington & Lee University in 1939, Mr. Fishel began his career at a small New York advertising agency, Jasper and Lynch. In 1949, he and his brother, the late Stanley I. Fishel, who was also a member of the firm, resigned and became principals of Fairfax. James Fishel served as president and CEO of the Fairfax agency from 1976 until 1983, when the company was acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi. Mr. Fishel remained as CEO of the division until 1989, when he retired. Mr. Fishel was a pioneer in the advertising mail order industry, introducing clients to the concept of television commercials by persuading well-known television stars such as Dave Garroway, Steve Allen, Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and Hugh Downs to do live commercials. This approach changed advertising strategy and helped turn unknown companies into household names, including Miracle-Gro and GNC. In addition, Mr. Fishel was a pioneer in the use of multi-page inserts in mass-circulation magazines featuring the products of leading mail-order companies. After his retirement from Saatchi & Saatchi, Mr. Fishel devoted his time to pro bono work. He served as advertising manager for "New Youth Connections," a city-wide news magazine written by New York City teenagers trained in journalism at the publication and delivered to more than 200,000 students in the city's high schools. Mr. Fishel served on the board of directors of the 92nd St. Y for 50 years. He was also a long-time member of the Harmonie Club and an accomplished player of tennis and squash. Mr. Fishel was an Army veteran of World War II and achieved the rank of Major. Mr. Fishel was married to the late Edith (Rubin) Fishel for more than 50 years. He is survived by his two daughters: the writer Elizabeth Fishel of Oakland, CA, as well as her husband, Robert Houghteling and their sons, Nate and Will; and Anne Fishel, a clinical psychologist and professor at Harvard Medical School, of Newton, MA, as well as her husband, Chris Daly, and their sons, Gabe and Joe. He is also survived by his companion, Catherine Kinsey of Sayville, NY. He was beloved by his family and his many friends for his kindness, his humor, his sense of fun, and his love of life. A funeral service will be held at 11:30am, Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Youth Communication 224 W. 29th St. New York, NY 10001.

While you theatergoing butterflies out there keep nattering on about the Tonys - who will win, who should win, and so on - I have been focused on an issue of far greater momentousness and urgency. That's the shameful squandering on Broadway of what our country would seem to believe is our most valued (and infinitely exploitable) natural resource: our celebrities. It has become a fact of cultural life in New York that a theater producer in search of big box office will seek out a famous person, regardless of his or her talents or credentials. Famous people of all stripes are returning the compliment by looking to Broadway to rejuvenate their careers, enhance their artistic credibility and pitch woo to audiences that may have ceased to believe in their existence.

New York City's alternative music scene will get a lift starting Wednesday, June 1, when WNYE-FM, the city-owned noncommercial station at 91.5 on the dial, begins broadcasting the indie music service ''The Alternate Side'' from 6 a.m. to noon. The program, started in 2008 by Fordham University's public station WFUV-FM with support from the New York State Music Fund, has showcased artists like the Strokes and TV on the Radio as well as newer local groups like Freelance Whales. Chuck Singleton, WFUV's program director, said that the show was created to fill a void by bringing together a music community but that had been primarily an online and HD radio service, with just a 10 p.m.-to-midnight broadcast on WFUV (90.7 FM). On WNYE, the local broadcast will replace two music shows produced by KEXP-FM in Seattle. Both KEXP and now WFUV pay the city for the time slot.

On Wednesday, the Thiel Foundation, funded by Mr. Thiel, announced the first group of Thiel Fellows, 24 people under 20 who have agreed to drop out of school in exchange for a $100,000 grant and mentorship to start a tech company.

The secret beating heart of a traveling circus, hidden behind the fluff and flounce of the center ring and the derring-do on the high trapeze, has always come down to the hard logical nut of getting everything and everybody from one place to another. And when the mode of the road is rail, as it still is for Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey, that logical problem can get boiled down further still, to the personal space. How, to cite just one example, does a family living in a narrow rail-car apartment make room for a piano and lessons for the children? For the Iversons -- Jonathan, ringmaster and father; Priscilla, performer and mother; Felipe, a budding musician and their son -- making it work is just another form of juggling. A piano in the kitchen? Why not?

Just as a deal came together late last week to keep PBS programming on the air in Orlando, Florida's public broadcasters suffered a financial blow when Gov. Rick Scott vetoed the state's nearly $4.8 million appropriation for public broadcasting. That figure had already been reduced by 30 percent from the amount broadcasters received last year. With the cuts, each of 13 public radio stations will lose $87,287 in state funds compared with last year, and each of the 13 public television stations will lose a subsidy of $434,837. Stations receive the same subsidy, regardless of size.

LEVITT--Mitzi. On May 28. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving and proud mother of Michael and the late Stacy. Mitzi leaves behind Maria, devoted friend and family member. A School secretary at the Rabbi Harry Halpern Day School of East Midwood Jewish Center. She was a supporter of charities and a treasured friend to many. Services Tuesday, 9:30am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Between Ave I and J). She will be dearly missed.

WIENER--A. Walter, 99 years young, passed away on Friday, May 27 at home in Deal, NJ. Born in Long Branch, NJ on November 25, 1911, he grew up there before moving to Deal 60 years ago. He was the last surviving child of Russian immigrant parents Sarah and Charles Wiener, preceded by his sisters Sophie Goldwasser, Pat Schwartz-stein and Mildred Edelstein Isaacson, and brothers Jack and Murray. He is survived by his lifelong love and adored wife of more than 60 years, Virginia (nee Sternheimer of Richmond, VA); his three children, Barbara Wiener Fischhof and husband Richard of Atlanta, GA, Nancy Wiener of Little Silver, NJ, and Dr. David Wiener and wife Jennifer of Denver, CO; and darling grandchildren Adam, Daniel, Sarah, Sophia and William, to whom he was Pa and Popi. Some knew him as co-owner and president of Atlantic Plumbing Supply of Long Branch for more than 52 years; others knew him as an outdoorsman, adventurer and nature lover with the skill to fix or grow anything, and as a remarkably fit and energetic individual committed to whatever the challenge. But first in his life was his adoring family for he enriched their lives with his selfless spirit, giving heart and positive attitude. He was a caring sensitive man, a strong man, a loving man and a loyal friend in many ways a man ahead of his time and a dear person who will be greatly missed and never, never forgotten. He graduated from Long Branch High School and served in the US Army Signal Corps of Ft. Monmouth, NJ during World War II. He was a member of Jordan Masonic Lodge; Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ; Deal Borough Club; Hollywood Golf Club of Deal and Elberon Bathing Club. Private graveside service. Shiva observed May 30 at 5pm and May 31 at 7pm at his home. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Deal Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 56, Deal, NJ 07723 or a charity of your choice.

HORN--Zenith Rosenberg, 96, of Tamarac FL, passed away quietly on Friday, May 27. Devoted wife of the late Sidney Horn, beloved mother of Nancy Pernick and Martin Horn, loving mother-in-law of Benjamin Pernick and Janis Horn, adoring grandmother of Jonathan Pernick, Gary Pernick, Alice Pernick, Joanna Horn and David Horn and proud great-grandmother of Michael and Joshua Pernick, Diana and Rachel Barry. She lived a full life of good deeds, surrounded by lifelong friends. Born in Brooklyn, she worked for many years as a fund raiser for the Jewish Hospital for Chronic Diseases and the Haym Solomon Home. Funeral Services Tuesday, May 31 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY; interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. The family will receive condolences at the home of Gary and Lynn Pernick, 209-45 18th Ave. Bayside, NY 11360 on Tuesday, May 31 from 3pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Hospice By the Sea 1531 Palmetto Park Rd. Boca Raton, FL 33486 or Rayus Hadassah 7960 Colony Circle North 5-306 Tamarac, FL 33321.

Arthur Goldreich, who helped lead the armed struggle against apartheid in South Africa and once posed as the operator of a farm where Nelson Mandela, masquerading as his houseboy, plotted revolt, died on Tuesday in Tel Aviv . He was 82. The Nelson Mandela Foundation announced his death.

When an idea gets hot in Silicon Valley, scores of entrepreneurs come up with me-too ideas to try to get some of the money sloshing around. Why else are there so many photo-sharing apps, geolocation services and social networks? Raptr might seem like one of those companies that has sliced the salami pretty thin. It is a social network for gamers, with about 8 million of them. The name lacks a few vowels, as those of so many Silicon Valley start-ups do. It has no visible source of revenue. And it has raised more than $27 million from venture capitalists, including some of the same folks who staked Facebook.

While this year’s final eight in the women’s draw at the French is filled with unfamiliar faces, there is just one man left on the men’s side who hasn’t previously made it to the final of a major. Few view Juan Ignacio Chela, a 31-year-old Argentine journeyman, as a threat to win the title. Those who derive pleasure from meticulously organizing things — in this case, an iTunes music collection — will be pleased to know that TuneUp, a provider of add-ons for Apple’s music-management software, has added “DeDuper” to its suite of wares.

“We first met in Toronto, friends of friends, met on the scene, you know?” says the designer Jeremy Laing, referring to the artist Scott Treleaven. Laing is no stranger to the artist collaboration — in past seasons he worked with Karen Azoulay and also the band Grizzly Bear. For his fall collection (hitting stores this month), he and Trevleavan generated two different prints — a flaming hand and a moon — that will come in the form of silk jersey T-shirt and a slinky silk crepe dress. “Jeremy was in a mood of luminance and transformation, which coincided perfectly,” says Treleaven. “We were both seeing these circle patterns and lunar imagery.” The rest of the collection is a more subtle riff on the theme with crater-etched sweaters, voluminous wide-leg trousers and a black velvet sheath dress – albeit in the same pagan, slightly macabre spirit. “I really appreciate the collaborative process; it’s a great way to keep engaged and grasp onto someone else’s creativity,” Laing says.
Call it life imitating art.

Broadway had another billion-dollar season between late May 2010 and Sunday, with shows grossing $1.08 billion — 5.9 percent more than the total for the 2009-10 season — and playing to more than 12.5 million people, according to the Broadway League, the trade group for theater owners and producers. That 2010-11 season attendance figure also reflects an increase of 5.4 percent over the previous season.

First baseman Ike Davis had a setback in his recovery from a bone bruise in his left ankle when a foot specialist told him Tuesday to wear a protective boot for another three weeks, meaning his return to the Mets is at least a month away.

Perhaps it’s the influence of all those story ballets, where love mostly triumphs (at least when no-one is dying young and becoming a Wili). American Ballet Theater seems to be experiencing an unusual rush of real romance, with three engagements over the last two weeks. On the opening night of the season, Ethan Stiefel proposed to his longtime girlfriend Gillian Murphy on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, moments after she and her partner David Hallberg had taken their curtain calls for the “Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux.” A few days later, the about-to-retire Cuban star Jose Manuel Carreño and corps de ballet dancer Melanie Hamrick announced their engagement. And on Friday, which happened to be the 30th birthday of the Royal Ballet guest artist Alina Cojocaru, her longtime on-and-offstage partner Johan Kobborg (who had arrived unexpectedly to fill in for the injured Maxim Beloserkovsky at the Saturday matinee of “Giselle”) popped the question.  Perhaps Alexei Ratmansky will choreograph a wedding dance.

After some delay, the first kiosk of Fatty at the Battery, as Zakary Pelaccio’s Fatty Crew company is calling their new stands in Battery Park near Castle Clinton, will open Wednesday Thursday (they had to delay it a day) from noon to 7 p.m., selling hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches. (After that it will be open 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily.) Called Fatty ‘Cue, it’s to the left of a planted area called the Battery Bosque, in what had been Will Goldfarb’s Picnick stands. Fatty Snack, with pastries and ice cream will follow in about a week, once the ice cream machine is installed, and it will be farther the castle. There is some seating around the kiosks. Internet dating is fertile territory for people who study social patterns. Belinda Robnett and Cynthia Feliciano studied racial exclusion patterns in the Journal Social Forces. They looked at over 6000 internet dating profiles and found that whites are least open to dating outside their group, with Asians and Latinos close behind. Asian males and black females are more highly excluded than their opposite sex counterparts.

A study by Jeffry Rudski, Lauren Bernstein and Joy Mitchell in the Archives of Sexual Behavior studied the link between the menstrual cycle and perception. Female research subjects were asked to react to various Georgia O'Keeffe paintings. Nearly a third of the women in the first half of their monthly cycle discerned sexual themes in her paintings, while only 6 percent of the women in the second half of their cycle did. Women who were taking oral contraceptives saw the paintings the same way throughout the month.

Our colleagues Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker report on President Obama’s nomination of Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the Army chief, to succeed Adm. Mike Mullen as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In a brief Rose Garden announcement in the midst of Memorial Day observances, Mr. Obama highlighted the dual roles that General Dempsey, who, as chairman, will be the country’s highest-ranking military officer, must fill as the United States brings its troops home from Iraq, begins withdrawing from Afghanistan and takes part in the NATO operation in Libya. As if to prove that there are no supernatural forces working against Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit” movies, for which that director has already contended with a labor dispute, the occasional explosion and emergency ulcer surgery, the studios have settled on some interesting release dates for the two-part fantasy epic. New Line Cinema, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said in a joint statement reported by The Associated Press that the first “Hobbit” movie would open on Dec. 14, 2012, when some scholars say is the 509th anniversary of the birth of Nostradamus, the French astrologer and soothsayer. (Historical spoilsports say he was born on Dec. 21.) And the concluding “Hobbit” film will be released on Dec. 13, 2013, a date that not only has two 13s but is also, wouldn’t you know it, Friday the 13th.

It’s a well-known fact that Vogue assistants often move on to become designers: Irini Arakas of Prova, Aimee Cho of Gryphon and Eviana Hartman of Bodkin. As I wrote in Sunday’s cover story, 4-year-old conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan seem — based on casual observation and (as yet unpublished) scientific research — to share some sensory perception. Their neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Children’s Hospital, believes that a neural bridge that links the thalamus of one girl to that of the other could explain why, for example, Tatiana would be able to see the stuffed animal Krista is holding, even when Tatiana’s eyes are closed.

Shackleford, the winner of the Preakness, arrived at Belmont Park Monday morning. He arrived after an overnight 15-hour van ride from Churchill Downs. The New York Daily News reported that “the 3-year-old colt is expected to gallop over Belmont’s main oval Wednesday, before having an official workout over the strip Saturday.” The Associated Press said that the trainer Dale Romans “wants to make sure the 3-year-old colt is in top condition before committing to the Belmont.”

Kamoinge, a group of mostly New York photographers who strive to capture the black experience, are creating an archive of their work. The group first assembled in 1963 and now has 24 members, with some focusing on documentary work, others on fine art. They are all driven by a similar passion: honest portrayal. “What we’re documenting isn’t just black history,” said Russell Frederick, one of Kamoinge’s newer members. “It’s American history; it’s global history. It’s something that everybody needs to see.” Read and see more on the Lens blog.

His creation, titled “Leviathan,” fills the large-scale venue with a giant sculpture — measuring about 775,000 square feet — that seems to push the walls of the building and, within its interior, drenches the viewer with a blood-red hue.

It’s hard for a first-round pick to move up significantly, but aside from Jose Bautista, Ryan Braun is probably the top hitter in fantasy baseball this year. While Braun’s 12 home runs and .588 slugging percentage through Sunday are improvements over last year’s rates, the number that jumps out most is his 13 steals in 14 attempts. Milwaukee’s new manager, Ron Roenicke, is more aggressive on the basepaths than his predecessor, Ken Macha: the Brewers are 14th in the majors in stolen bases this year, as opposed to 21st last year, and Braun in particular is getting the green light. At this pace, a 35-35 season is within reach, and with Braun, you’re virtually assured a good batting average. Only Carlos Gonzalez and maybe Matt Kemp offer the same speed-power-average upside, and Gonzalez is struggling this year.Jacoby Ellsbury’s 2010 was a lost season because of rib injuries, but as he is 27, his value has never been higher. The 19 stolen bases through Sunday put him on pace for close to 60 steals, and that’s not accounting for chilly early-season conditions that often slow the running game. Ellsbury also has 6 home runs and 16 doubles and is posting a .298/.368/.462 line in 208 at-bats while hitting leadoff in one of the league’s best lineups. In short, he’s what the Red Sox hoped Carl Crawford would be when they gave him $142 million. Crawford was a late first-round pick in most leagues, and Ellsbury must be considered similarly at this point.

JASSEM--Muriel (nee Weinstein), 94, passed away Saturday, May 28. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Beloved mother of Stanley, Ellen, the late Robert, Lynne and Julie. Adoring grandmother of Jena and John, Julie and Jeff, Corey and Michelle, Daniel and Kim. Proud great-grandmother of Jessica, Jillian, Jaclyn, Jacob, Grace, Piper, Crosby, Sasha, Mikayla, and Katya. Muriel lived a full, vibrant life and her ebullient personality touched everyone. Born in Brooklyn, she became a Rockette at 16, received an Accounting Degree from Queen's College, and served as Senior Tax Examiner for NYS Income Tax. Widowed at 56, she moved to Florida, started a successful tax practice, remarried twice, and remained vital always. Greatly missed, she will leave a void that will never be filled. Graveside service Wednesday, June 1, 1pm, at New Montefiore Jewish Cemetery, Wellwood Ave, Pinelawn, NY 631-249-7000

''The Hangover Part II'' has sold about $137.4 million in tickets since opening in North American theaters on Thursday, according to results compiled by Hollywood.com. That performance helped drive robust business for the Memorial Day weekend. Audiences for the top 12 films over the four-day weekend spent about $272.8 million on tickets, up 48 percent from the same period last year. (The figures were not adjusted for inflation or to account for 3-D and Imax ticket prices.) ''The Hangover Part II'' --a sequel from Warner Brothers to the 2009 hit starring Bradley Cooper (above), Ed Helms and Zach Galifianakis (who all returned for more trouble) -- ranks behind Disney's ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' as the year's second-biggest opening of 2011. ''Kung Fu Panda 2'' (Paramount) has taken in about $68 million since open- ing on Thursday, and it finished second for the weekend. ''On Stranger Tides'' fell 56 percent in its second week of release, with $50.4 million in sales over the holiday weekend, for third place; its domestic total is $164 million. ''Bridesmaids'' (Universal) was fourth, with $21 million through Monday, and ''Thor'' (Paramount) was fifth, with $12 million. Despite the strong weekend traffic at theaters, overall domestic attendance is down 9.7 percent from this point in 2010.

On a fall afternoon in 1988, Jon Sarkin, a 35-year-old Massachusetts chiropractor, was happily playing the eighth hole on a local golf course when he felt something ''twist'' in his brain. Three days later he began to hear a high-pitched screech, a siren that only grew louder with the passing weeks. Doctors shrugged; a brain scan suggested a vague abnormality near a nerve at the base of the brain that controls hearing and balance. Eight months later, driven to distraction by the unceasing noise, Dr. Sarkin underwent a controversial operation to ''decompress'' the small vessels surrounding the nerve. The day after surgery -- having woken up long enough to report that the noise had indeed stopped -- he was rushed back to the operating room with a major stroke.

Lots of questions have been asked about David Einhorn's purchase of a minority stake in the Mets: Will his investment shore up the Mets' finances? (Maybe.) Does the deal allow him to take majority control of the Mets? (Yes.) And will he eventually take over the team? (Probably.) But on Wall Street, a very different question is quietly being asked: Will Mr. Einhorn, one of the great value investors of his generation and an obsessive stock picker, take his eye off the ball? (Pun intended.) It is a question that invariably is raised whenever a wealthy financier seeks to live out his childhood fantasy by acquiring a professional sports team, a race horse or even a yacht.

STEWART--John MacKenzie, 79, died peacefully at home on May 19, 2011. Born in Glen Cove, NY, in 1932, he graduated from Yale University ('53) and Harvard Business School ('57). He served in the US Navy from 1953 - 1955 and as a program manager for TRW's Saturn missile project. In 1961 he joined McKinsey & Company where for 37 years, he dedicated himself to client service. In addition, he served on the Defense Science Board, Yale University Council, National Council on Economic Education and as Executive Director of the US National Commission on Productivity. Most recently, he was a trustee of NYU Medical Center, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and on the Dean's Advisory Council at Boston University School of Medicine. He also consulted with a Gates Foundation initiative to reduce HIV/AIDS in India. John's many civic commitments reflected his lifelong interest in the intersection of management with science and economics, and a deeply held belief in "giving back". Even his love of flying became a way to help others through Angel Flights. John was a great human being. He brought integrity, creativity and compassion to every endeavor with family, with friends and with professional colleagues. He had a unique way of guiding those around him to new and deeper insight. And he was a lot of fun to be around. He loved his family: his wife, Eliot; their four children: Diane Stewart, Sandi Stewart, Ian Highet and Eliot Patty; and nine grandchildren: Anna, Colin, Ali, Dash, Gil, Lisa, Andrew, Liam and Eliza. Services will be held at the Yale Club on Sunday, June 19 at 4:30pm, reception following. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: John Stewart Memorial Fund, Amyloid Research Program, Boston Univ. School Of Medicine, 72 E. Concord St., Boston, MA 02188 or Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Fenno House, Woods Hole, MA 02543.

A mild tremor of excitement ran through the New York City Ballet audience on Sunday afternoon as the cast of George Balanchine's ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue'' took a bow. The dark-suited and hatted dancer who had played the ''Big Boss'' in the delightful tale of murder and mayhem at the ballet, had just popped out of the wings, performed a quick, modest salute, and popped back in. It took a moment to realize that the Big Boss was in fact the Big Boss. Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of the company, had stepped in for an injured Ask la Cour the previous night, and reappeared at the matinee with no fanfare or announcement of the change in cast. Mr. Martins, who retired from dancing in 1983, hasn't appeared onstage since dancing in a pas de deux with Suzanne Farrell at her farewell performance in 1989. But he clearly hasn't forgotten the tricks of the trade, even jumping nimbly off a high table (those of us who had recognized him winced for his knees) and rolling on the floor as he fought Andrew Veyette as the Hoofer. The only concession Mr. Martins made to age and experience was to forgo wearing tights. We understand. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FISHEL--James W.,James W. Fishel, an advertising executive for more than 50 years and former president of Fairfax Advertising Agency, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. A native of New York City, Mr. Fishel attended the city's public schools. After graduating from Washington & Lee University in 1939, Mr. Fishel began his career at a small New York advertising agency, Jasper and Lynch. In 1949, he and his brother, the late Stanley I. Fishel, who was also a member of the firm, resigned and became principals of Fairfax. James Fishel served as president and CEO of the Fairfax agency from 1976 until 1983, when the company was acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi. Mr. Fishel remained as CEO of the division until 1989, when he retired. Mr. Fishel was a pioneer in the advertising mail order industry, introducing clients to the concept of television commercials by persuading well-known television stars such as Dave Garroway, Steve Allen, Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and Hugh Downs to do live commercials. This approach changed advertising strategy and helped turn unknown companies into household names, including Miracle-Gro and GNC. In addition, Mr. Fishel was a pioneer in the use of multi-page inserts in mass-circulation magazines featuring the products of leading mail-order companies. After his retirement from Saatchi & Saatchi, Mr. Fishel devoted his time to pro bono work. He served as advertising manager for "New Youth Connections," a city-wide news magazine written by New York City teenagers trained in journalism at the publication and delivered to more than 200,000 students in the city's high schools. Mr. Fishel served on the board of directors of the 92nd St. Y for 50 years. He was also a long-time member of the Harmonie Club and an accomplished player of tennis and squash. Mr. Fishel was an Army veteran of World War II and achieved the rank of Major. Mr. Fishel was married to the late Edith (Rubin) Fishel for more than 50 years. He is survived by his two daughters: the writer Elizabeth Fishel of Oakland, CA, as well as her husband, Robert Houghteling and their sons, Nate and Will; and Anne Fishel, a clinical psychologist and professor at Harvard Medical School, of Newton, MA, as well as her husband, Chris Daly, and their sons, Gabe and Joe. He is also survived by his companion, Catherine Kinsey of Sayville, NY. He was beloved by his family and his many friends for his kindness, his humor, his sense of fun, and his love of life. A funeral service will be held at 11:30am, Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Youth Communication 224 W. 29th St. New York, NY 10001.

Kevin Shapiro, a 20-year-old math and physics major at the University of Pennsylvania, first tried a hookah at a campus party. He liked the exotic water pipe so much that he chipped in to buy one for his fraternity house, where he says it makes a useful social lubricant at parties. Like many other students who are embracing hookahs on campuses nationwide, Mr. Shapiro believes that hookah smoke is less dangerous than cigarette smoke because it ''is filtered through water, so you get fewer solid particles.''

Tom Kerr of Pittsburgh will never forget the long-distance call from his elderly mother, who was in a hospital in the Cleveland area with a broken leg. She phoned her son, more than 100 miles away, because no one in the hospital was answering her call button.

BOSTON -- It has been a long time since so many Bostonians cared so much about the Bruins. In this city last weekend, from the North End to the South End and every place in between, it was all Bruins, all the time. The team's logo -- a spoked B -- was plastered in the windows of the dive bars in Haymarket, on the hockey sweaters of drunken late-night revelers in the financial district and on the caps of Boston-based Barcelona fans watching the European Champions League final in Hanover Street cafes.

After 33 years of marriage, Steven Simkin and Laura Blank divorced in 2006. They agreed to split their considerable wealth equally. She got the apartment on the Upper East Side; he got the house in Scarsdale, N.Y. Afterward, they spoke infrequently, mostly concerning their two grown sons.

KASHIMA, Japan -- When the Shimane nuclear plant was first proposed here more than 40 years ago, this rural port town put up such fierce resistance that the plant's would-be operator, Chugoku Electric, almost scrapped the project. Angry fishermen vowed to defend areas where they had fished and harvested seaweed for generations. Two decades later, when Chugoku Electric was considering whether to expand the plant with a third reactor, Kashima once again swung into action: this time, to rally in favor. Prodded by the local fishing cooperative, the town assembly voted 15 to 2 to make a public appeal for construction of the $4 billion reactor.

Verizon Wireless, which provides wireless broadband access across the country, has sued to block a federal rule requiring wireless broadband providers to offer data roaming on commercially reasonable terms. Verizon is entitled to its day in court, but this suit must not prevail. With text messages, e-mail and other forms of data overtaking voice as the main form of wireless communication, the rule issued in April will preserve competition in a vital communications network.

A man from a different era, he was modern in his outlook. He found his vocation in politics and was blessed with an inquisitive and critical mind. Passionate about plants of all kinds, he delighted in his gardens, collecting palm trees in Maui and his favorite daffodils in New Jersey. In conversation, he choose his words carefully, mixing wit with an occasional barb. He found wonderful companionship playing bridge, where he showed his competitive side. With his late wife Bea, he had beloved friends of all ages from every stage of his life. 8 P.M. (13) CARNEGIE HALL 120TH ANNIVERSARY CONCERT Alan Gilbert conducts the New York Philharmonic, above, in a commemoration of Carnegie Hall in this ''Great Performances'' presentation, taped on May 5. The program includes Beethoven's Triple Concerto in C (Op. 56), performed by the pianist Emanuel Ax, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the violinist Gil Shaham, as well as several works with connections to Carnegie Hall: ''Carnival,'' a concert overture by Dvorak, who conducted it with the Boston Symphony at the hall on Oct. 21, 1892; the Tony-winning singer and actress Audra McDonald in ''Solitude,'' ''Sophisticated Lady,'' ''On a Turquoise Cloud'' and ''It Don't Mean a Thing (If It Ain't Got That Swing)'' by Duke Ellington, who played his first concert at the hall on Jan. 23, 1943; and George Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' commissioned by the Philharmonic and conducted by Walter Damrosch at the hall in its New York premiere on Dec. 13, 1928. Carnegie Hall was home to the Philharmonic until the orchestra moved to Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center in 1962. 8 P.M. (ABC) JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! GAME NIGHT Mr. Kimmel ushers in the N.B.A. finals for a fourth season with a series of half-hour pregame shows featuring some of the court's biggest stars. ''N.B.A. Countdown'' offers news and analysis at 8:30. The Dallas Mavericks visit the Miami Heat for Game 1 of the finals at 9.

It was not billed as a three-hankie movie - it was a documentary, after all. But Editta Sherman started sobbing a few minutes after the lights went down, and not because of the way she looked on the screen. She did not mind that she was one of the people the camera kept coming back to in the film, ''Lost Bohemia.'' What had her crying was the subject matter. ''Lost Bohemia'' is a depressing goodbye to the apartments that used to be above Carnegie Hall and the people who lived in them, the rent-controlled or rent-stabilized tenants who were forced to vacate - quirky people in quirky apartments, or so it seemed from the film.

When FrontPoint Partners began in 2000, its founders envisioned the firm as a one-stop shop for multiple hedge funds, a distinctive strategy in an industry dominated at the time by single star managers. As FrontPoint fights to stay alive after an insider trading scandal, one of its co-founders, Philip Duff, who left in 2006, sits in a nondescript office less than a mile away from his former firm rethinking the pension business with his latest venture, Massif Partners.It is his second attempt.

Now that the Supreme Court has given California the choice of shrinking its prison population drastically or making sufficient room for the prisoners it has, attention has naturally turned to how the financially strapped state will respond. But that focus shouldn’t obscure the remarkable nature of what the court did last week when it upheld a lower court’s order requiring California to reduce its prison population to no more than 137.5 percent of capacity within two years to cure overcrowding so severe that it amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.

Gauti Eggertsson has a nice piece on the New York Fed blog about the great monetary/fiscal mistake of 1937, which sent the Great Depression into a second downward leg. As he notes, the underlying situation bore a significant resemblance to current events: unemployment still high (actually under 10 percent if measured by modern standards, so quite similar to now), but with rising prices thanks to commodity shocks.

“What’s Going On,” Marvin Gaye’s groundbreaking 1971 album whose socially sensitive subject matter Motown boss Berry Gordy Jr. initially believed would ruin Gaye’s career, is 40 years old this year. And as we all know now, the album, contrary to Gordy’s fears, became a critical and commercial success. More important, its message has remained timely and relevant over virtually its entire four decades of existence.

The reports of Rafael Nadal’s demise are exaggerated, as he showed in Wednesday’s straight-sets dismissal of Robin Soderling. With his level of play clearly rising, Nadal has swept into the semifinals at Roland Garros despite the negative buzz emanating from the press room and the locker room. Granted, Nadal has looked more vulnerable this spring than in any previous clay campaign, and, as the No. 1 player in the world, he knows that his every shot, and every utterance in news conferences, will be scrutinized, compared, assessed and commented upon.

At a recent Saint-Germain-des-Pres dinner party, the conversation turned to perfect destinations for a seaside weekend near Paris. A Los Angeles-based architect wondered aloud about Deauville, provoking a quorum of shaking heads, so our hostess set him straight. “Deauville, c’est trop bling-bling,” she told him. “Bling-bling?” “Flashy,” a fashion P.R. executive volunteered. Then someone suggested Cadaques, on Spain’s Costa Brava, which drew approving murmurs but was ultimately nixed because getting there requires a plane ride and a rental car. Belle Ile in Brittany got a heads up, too, but not for a weekend, since it’s too far away. Honfleur met with general approval, too, but it also requires a rental car. We all agreed that the perfect place would be only a train ride away.

The return of “America’s Got Talent” catapulted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 15 million viewers watched the two-hour sixth-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Up by more than 2.6 million over last year’s premiere (12.4 million), “America’s Got Talent” also lifted NBC’s ratings at 10 p.m., during which the network’s new reality competition “The Voice” attracted its largest audience to date, 14.4 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night, though reliable audience figures for its coverage of the N.B.A. finals were not immediately available. Preliminary overnight estimates were the highest for a Game 1 broadcast since 2004, slightly outperforming last year’s first game, which drew 14.1 million viewers. CBS was third with reruns of “NCIS” (11.1 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (9.9 million) and “The Good Wife” (6.2 million). Fox was fourth with a new episode of “Traffic Light” at 9:30 (2.2 million) after repeats of “Glee” and “Raising Hope.”

Summer is all about showing skin. But for those who aren’t into baring it all, one option is dipping into early fall offerings. Pared-down basics by the Los Angeles-based designer Raquel Allegra have long been favored by stars such as Halle Berry, Hanneli Mustaparta and Agyness Deyn. Although Allegra is best known for her supersoft cotton shredding technique, for her latest collection, which hits stores in July, she began thinking about leather. “I asked myself, What do I want to wear as a second skin?” The results include a dappled goatskin bouclé cardigan that is as pleasing to the touch as it is to the eye — and that still leaves enough to the imagination. There are also slimming thigh-high leather leggings that mold to one’s body, supple camel leather shirts and buttery black body-con dresses that look effortless and sensual, not overripe or overtly sexy. The collection, available July 31, ranges from $250 to $1,100 and can be purchased at barneys.com or netaporter.com.

VENICE — After the first day spent looking at most, but not all, of the national pavilions in the Giardini, this year’s Biennale has started to shape up as a knock-down, drag-out contest among immersive, environmental installation artworks. The battle is especially pitched on the little hillock dominated by the pavilions of Britain (Mike Nelson), Germany (Christoph Schlingensief) and France (Christian Boltanski), although the fray has also been joined by Switzerland (Thomas Hirshhorn) and the Czech Republic. At that pavilion, a little-known artist named Dominik Lang, barely 30 years old, has mounted a strangely affecting time-capsule-like installation featuring a great deal of generic postwar figurative sculpture by his father, Jiri Lang (1927-1996), who stopped making art years before his son was born. It serves as a sobering reminder of the obscurity that awaits most of the art produced at any given point in time, as well as the ability of art objects, being objects, to wait out different phases of neglect.
