There are three places one must never wear makeup: to the beach, to the gym and to bed. Reader, I did all of these things over the course of a day during Cannes. But at least let me explain. I was staying at the Hotel Martinez, which, for those unaware, becomes so brimming with celebrities (from Vanessa Hudgens to Sarah Jessica Parker) during the film festival that every paparazzo in the world, and possibly the entire population of the South of France, hold vigil outside, cameras pointed at the door until they realize you are not, in fact, Clemence Poesy (thanks, though!). So when sharing an elevator with Jude Law, whether coming from the seventh floor gym or la plage across the street, is a real possibility, being caught barefaced is a bit daunting. As for my sleeping in makeup, blame Olivier Zahm and his Purple party at Le Baron, an early flight and the lack of the will to painstakingly remove the waterproof makeup I agreed to test for The Moment. (Plus, my bottle of the famous only-available-in-France eye makeup remover, Bioderma, was too large to carry on.)

We all feel a bit disorganized and even overwhelmed at times. You know the feeling — crucial tasks are slipping between the cracks, you’re not sure what needs to be done next, you’re missing deadlines, other people aren’t coming through with their pieces of the project. If you’re feeling that way more than occasionally, you may need help from project-management and other task-organizing tools. Just as financial-management services like Mint or QuickBooks can help you keep your house in order when it comes to money, project- and task-oriented tools can help you plan, manage and coordinate activities.

We had barely finished giving well-deserved honor, respect and praise to the “little colored girl born in Kosciusko, Miss.,” when a video was posted on the Internet last week offering a preview of an upcoming documentary to be released later this year titled “Dark Girls.” Produced by Bill Duke, D. Channsin Berry and Bradinn French, “Dark Girls” takes a compelling look at the impact of colorism: a state of prejudice, conscious and unconscious, that causes both black people and white people to label as more beautiful or desirable or intelligent individuals with lighter shades of skin, particularly when it comes to black women. Few among people of color are unfamiliar with the saying: “If you are light, you are all right. If you are brown, you can stick around. If you are black, get back.” A writer in The Washington Post aptly described the phenomenon a few years ago as “the crazy aunt in the attic of racism.”

At the height of the housing boom, the 26th floor of Goldman Sachs's former headquarters on Broad Street in Lower Manhattan was the nerve center of Goldman's fast-growing mortgage trading business. Hundreds of employees worked closely in teams, devising mortgage-based securities -- billions of dollars' worth -- that were examined by lawyers, approved by management, then sold to investors like hedge funds, commercial banks and insurance companies.

She stepped delicately over damp logs and poison-ivy patches, a metal trash-grabber in one hand, a black trash bag in the other. Something caught her eye. ''Jackpot,'' she said.

SCHWARTZ--Robert N.,94, died on May 29, 2011. Robert served as president and C.E.O. of Manning, Selvage & Lee, one of New York's foremost public relations firms. Its specialties included health care and technology. In 1980, the firm merged with Benton & Bowles, one of the world's leading advertising agencies. Prior to his distinguished career in public relations, he was an accomplished journalist for the St. Louis Post Dispatch, The New York Times, the Chicago Sun and the International News Service. He is survived by his loving wife of 71 years, Judith, his brother Irvin, his daughter, Fran, and son, James, and his three grandchildren.

VENICE -- The weather may be picture-perfect, but the stars were not all aligned for the first day the giant Biennale was open to the art press and V.I.P.'s. A one-day water-bus strike has crippled this shimmering city. When asked the reason for the walkout, a concierge at the chic Hotel Danieli, shrugged and replied, ''Money, madame,'' like everywhere else. But without the public water buses, or vaporetti, it's like New York during a transit strike. People have donned their sneakers and are walking as fast as they can.

OAKLAND, Calif. - A common practice of sporting publications is undertaking surveys that rate players, hoping to provoke a response. The latest version appears in this week's Sports Illustrated, which asked 185 major leaguers to vote in the category of Most Overrated Player. Such surveys inevitably tend to focus on good players from big-market teams, and perhaps not surprisingly the Yankees dominated the list, filling the top three: Alex Rodriguez, Joba Chamberlain and Derek Jeter.
An article on Monday about a skull found in a Brooklyn backyard misstated the year in which the cornerstone was placed at the nearby Church of the Ascension. It was 1865, not 1853.

Expert network firms were once an obscure pocket of Wall Street, an elite service for aggressive money managers looking for an investment edge. Today, these businesses find themselves in the middle of the government's multiyear investigation into insider trading. And on Wednesday, they are expected to take center stage in a federal courtroom in Manhattan.

The spokesman, Ole W. Pedersen, said that the plan would essentially provide the same coverage, not that it would stop covering employees' spouses and children.

THE ASTOR ROOM 34-12 36th Street (35th Avenue), Astoria, Queens; (718) 255-1947; astorroom.com. This refurbished commissary of Kaufman Astoria Studios, a vast complex of sound stages near the Museum of the Moving Image, is an odd but rewarding new spot. The Astor Room's owner, Chris Vlacich, has made the ambitious decision to insert a Jazz Age-themed supper club, with live piano music (mercifully subdued), careful service and drinks named after the likes of Mary Pickford elegantly presented. The dinner menu, rather daringly for 2011, is devoted to old-school dishes like oysters Rockefeller and beef stroganoff that are nicely executed. The Astor Room's subterranean dining room can be gloomy, but the efforts of Mr. Vlacich (and his chef, John Doherty) deserve more recognition. (May 25) JULIA MOSKIN CHEF'S TABLE AT BROOKLYN FARE 200 Schermerhorn Street (Hoyt Street), downtown Brooklyn; (718) 243-0050; brooklynfare.com/chefs-table. César Ramirez, the chef here, stood like a ship's captain in front of the immense Molteni stove that is the centerpiece of his restaurant, framed by an immense collection of gleaming copper pots. Before him were 18 customers on stools set around a D-shaped stainless-steel bar. And before them would be placed 20 small courses over the evening. Mr. Ramirez worked for David Bouley, and he has some of that chef's precision and passion, his respect for pure ingredients. The mood in the restaurant thus swings from hushed to giddy. Everyone starts to compare notes, share insights, share wine. They celebrate the delicious. A meal at Chef's Table costs $185 a person, not including tip or the wine you take. That is either expensive or not, depending on your bank balance, but it is worth the money whatever your answer. (Reviewed April 27, ) SAM SIFTON COLONIE 127 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn Heights; (718) 855-7500; colonienyc.com. Long and lean beneath a rough-finished wooden ceiling, with a handsome bar and a wall garden of herbs leading to a brick-walled dining room and open kitchen in back, Colonie serves a mostly solid farm-to-table menu of haute American food to a building crowd. Alex Sorenson, the chef, who was at Mas (Farmhouse), serves a familiar menu of eggs and mushrooms and pork belly and scallops and beets. But his cooking does not seem overexposed or trendy. There is brightness to it, a clever happiness that often comes through on the plate. The kitchen can be inconsistent, though, and when the owners are not in, waiters, runners and bartenders alike appear to disappear. (May 4, ) SAM SIFTON GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL 12 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village; (212) 620-4020; gothambarandgrill.com. In a city obsessed with the shiny and novel, this is an outlier. Open since 1984, it celebrates stability and excellence, perhaps even opulence. It is all very civilized here. Gotham has an informality of service, though, that is purely American. And Alfred Portale, who came to this Greenwich Village restaurant the year after it opened, runs a kitchen that is committed to innovation even as it celebrates the past. His life must occasionally resemble those of perpetually touring rock stars who need every night to sing the songs they wrote as teenagers. But even after more than 20 years, new songs keep coming. At Gotham, there is no recitation of the provenance of the bacon, or explanation of the wild arugula's journey, before you eat. No one offers the name of the boat whose captain whispered the tuna aboard. A meal at Gotham is about you and your interests, not of those who made it. (May 18, ) SAM SIFTON JONES WOOD FOUNDRY 401 East 76th Street, Upper East Side; (212) 249-2700; joneswoodfoundry.com. Odds are you haven't tucked into a nice plate of bangers and mash lately, or a proper Victoria spongecake filled with raspberry jam. But with well-turned dishes like those, as well as crumpets and kedgeree, parsnip soup and meat pies, Jones Wood Foundry may persuade New Yorkers to take English food seriously. The restaurant is the very definition of a gastropub, where bar food with a bit of flair is more important than drink. Jason Hicks's menu is overlarge, and thus not everything is well cooked. And service is not as professional as could be, but the happy locals and assorted expat Britons who pack the place do not seem to mind. (Dining Briefs, May 4) JULIA MOSKIN SOUVLAKI GR 116 Stanton Street (Essex Street), Lower East Side; (212) 777-0116, souvlakigr.com. Bougainvillea spills over a blazing white wall. A cobblestone sidewalk is washed white, the doors an impossible Aegean blue. So the flowers are fake, the stones painted on, and the doors and shutters open to nowhere. Somehow it feels genuine. This is due to the ministrations of the host, Abby Sierros, an owner. There is little here beyond souvlaki. The pork and chicken are moist and tender. Spices and garnishes are minimal and effective. (Dining Briefs, May 18). LIGAYA MISHAN Restaurants reviewed in the $25 and Under column and the Dining Briefs do not get stars.

After a year of work, MCC Theater's stab at salvaging the musical ''Carrie'' from the Broadway flop hall of shame is far enough along that the company announced on Tuesday that it will produce the show next season, with preview performances set to begin Off Broadway on Jan. 31, 2012. An adaptation of the 1974 Stephen King novel about a bullied girl with telekinetic powers and her deeply religious, overprotective mother, ''Carrie'' will have a cast led by three-time Tony Award nominee Marin Mazzie (''Kiss Me, Kate,'' ''Next to Normal'') as the mother, Margaret White, and Molly Ranson (''Jerusalem,'' ''August: Osage County'') as the title character. Both actresses performed their respective parts in a 2009 reading that helped set the stage for this new production, which will be directed by Stafford Arima (''Altar Boyz'').
An obituary on May 24 about Joseph Brooks, a songwriter and filmmaker, misstated where he grew up. It was Lawrence, N.Y., on Long Island, not Lawrence, N.J.

Coachella is splitting in two. Next year the Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival, the rock festival in the Southern California desert that provides plenty of music fans with their first sunburn of the season, will be held on two consecutive weekends, with the same lineup each weekend. They will take place April 13 to 15 and April 20 to 22, at the Empire Polo Club in Indio, Calif. ''Same lineup, same art, same place, different people,'' organizers said in an announcement on Tuesday.

8 P.M. (13) JAMES LEVINE: AMERICA'S MAESTRO ''American Masters'' celebrates the 40-year association of Mr. Levine, above, with the Metropolitan Opera, touching on milestones since his conducting debut there in 1971, at 28, of Puccini's ''Tosca.'' This documentary, directed by Susan Froemke, also features scenes between Mr. Levine and his longtime collaborator Plácido Domingo as they prepare to mount Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra'' and with the Met Orchestra as Mr. Levine rehearses the ensemble for its first performance of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony at Carnegie Hall. ''Great Performances at the Met,'' at 9, presents the company's premiere production of John Adams's ''Nixon in China,'' conducted by Mr. Adams and staged by Peter Sellars. With a libretto by Alice Goodman, the opera is based on President Richard M. Nixon's visit to China in 1972. James Maddalena, in his Met debut, portrays Nixon, a role he created for the opera's world premiere in 1987. The cast includes Janis Kelly as the first lady, Pat Nixon; Richard Paul Fink (Henry Kissinger); Robert Brubaker (Mao Zedong); Kathleen Kim (Madame Mao); and Russell Braun (Zhou Enlai). 5 P.M. (Sundance) OF TIME AND THE CITY (2009) In his first documentary Terence Davies constructs a poetic essay about the Liverpool of his childhood -- and revisits the pain and pleasure of growing up gay and Roman Catholic in postwar Britain. He uses archival footage of the city from the 1940s to the '60s, musical excerpts and autobiographical recollections. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''a deeply personal piece of art that never descends into the confessional or the therapeutic, and a work of social and literary criticism that never lectures or hectors, but rather, with melancholy, tenderness and wit, manages to sing.''

BARASCH--Marvin. The Board of Governors and Members of Falls Golf & Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Marvin Barasch. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Phyllis and their family. Gerald Fineberg, President

A World Health Organization panel has concluded that cellphones are ''possibly carcinogenic,'' putting the popular devices in the same category as certain dry cleaning chemicals and pesticides, as a potential threat to human health. The finding, from the agency's International Agency for Research on Cancer, adds to concerns among a small but growing group of experts about the health effects of low levels of radiation emitted by cellphones. The panel, which consisted of 31 scientists from 14 countries, was led by Dr. Jonathan M. Samet, a physician and epidemiologist at the University of Southern California and a member of President Obama's National Cancer Advisory Board.

A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about antigovernment protests in Georgia misstated the charges facing the husband of Nino Burdzhanadze, a prominent opposition leader. The husband, Badri Bitsadze, was charged with creating paramilitary groups and organizing attacks on police officers during the protests, not with attempting a government takeover.

It doesn't hurt to be known as the Google of Russia. Shares of Yandex, the Russian search engine company, shot up more than 55 percent in their Nasdaq market debut last week. The stock's rise illustrates investors' voracious appetite for emerging-market investments and Internet initial public offerings. But Yandex is also a sign of another trend: investors are willing to ignore the special risks associated with foreign Internet companies in their hunger for riches.

An article on Thursday about the impact of the euro crisis on the agenda of the Group of 8 industrialized countries at its two-day summit in France misstated the effect of Greece's debt problems on the bonds of Spain and Italy, which are seen as increasingly risky. It is the yields on those bonds -- not the prices -- that are rising, as investors demand a greater return in exchange for the increased risk of owning them.

An article on Saturday about figures from the Paris arts scene in the 1920s who appear in the new Woody Allen movie, ''Midnight in Paris,'' including the filmmaker Luis Buñuel, misidentified a film by Buñuel that the Allen movie's protagonist urges him to make some day. It is ''The Exterminating Angel,'' from 1962, not ''The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie,'' released in 1972.

PUTTANESCA is a sauce that plies its trade all year round, heedless of the season. The ingredients -- pantry staples including canned tomatoes, capers, anchovies, garlic, red pepper flakes and olives -- are at the ready whenever the desire strikes. But I wanted a puttanesca dressed for spring, with the spicy pungency that makes the dish seductive freshened up with something lively, green and biting.

LAMB--Margaret (Mimi). Fordham English Professor. A memorial will be held on Saturday, June 4 at 2pm at St. Mary's Episcopal Church. 521 West 126th St. NYC.

As if to prove that there are no supernatural forces working against Peter Jackson's ''Hobbit'' movies, for which that director has already contended with a labor dispute, the occasional explosion and emergency ulcer surgery, the studios have settled on some interesting release dates for the two-part fantasy epic. New Line Cinema, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said in a joint statement reported by The Associated Press that the first ''Hobbit'' movie would open on Dec. 14, 2012, when some scholars say is the 509th anniversary of the birth of Nostradamus, the French astrologer and soothsayer. (Historical spoilsports say he was born on Dec. 21.) And the concluding ''Hobbit'' film will be released on Dec. 13, 2013, a date that not only has two 13s but is also, wouldn't you know it, Friday the 13th. The studios also announced the films' full titles: Part 1 will be called ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,'' and Part 2 will be ''The Hobbit: There and Back Again,'' neither of which is as interesting as the dates they open. Of course if you're among those who believe, as Nostradamus predicted, that a ''king of terror shall come from the sky'' in 2012 and possibly end the world, then it doesn't really matter, does it?

Reposing Redden's Funeral Home 325 West 14th St., New York City, Wednesday and Thursday 2:00 to 5:00 and 7:00 to 9:00pm. Mass of Christian burial Friday 10am Guardian Angel Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

An article on April 27 about so-called super-injunctions -- stringent British legal measures that prevent the media from publishing reports on certain topics -- misstated the job title at the BBC of Andrew Marr, who had used such an injunction to keep secret an extramarital affair. He is host of ''The Andrew Marr Show'' on BBC One, not the BBC's political editor, a position he has not held since August 2005. This correction was delayed for research.

HOLLERITH--Charles. Music-Theatre Group Board members, artists, and colleagues are saddened by the passing of our esteemed former chair Chuck Hollerith. He led us faithfully and loved the theatre deeply. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family. Bill Clark, Diane Wondisford, Rosita Sarnoff

HOLLERITH--Charles, Jr. The Actors' Fund of America mourns the death of Charles Hollerith, Jr., who served as a Trustee from 1979 to 2010. During those 31 years, Chuck served as Secretary of the Board, and on the Executive and Human Services Committees. A Theatrical Producer, he was recruited to the Board by Nedda Harrigan Logan, The Fund's President from 1979 to 1989. He graduated from St. Albans School and Williams College, and served in the Navy in World War II. He was passionate about The Fund and played a leading role in strengthening and expanding its services. For his service, he was awarded the Actors Fund Medal of Honor at the 2010 Annual Meeting. We extend our condolences to his two children and four grandchildren. Services will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, off Fifth Avenue, on Thursday, June 2nd at 3:30pm. Brian Stokes Mitchell, Chairman of the Board Joseph Benincasa, President, The Actors Fund

With a big smile and a warm handshake, Fred Wilpon, the Mets' principal owner, told starting pitcher Mike Pelfrey that he loved Pelfrey's recent playful dig at him. Somehow, through all his troubles last week, Wilpon was able to smile and laugh. On May 23, the day word broke that Wilpon had been critical of his team as a whole and some of his players specifically in an article in The New Yorker, Pelfrey joked that Wilpon would benefit from the media training that the team mandates its players go through each spring training.

There was a rally on May 12, when seasoned protesters convened by the thousands near City Hall to stake their claim against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget. There were gatherings at subway stations organized by the city's public advocate, Bill de Blasio, at which hundreds of parents recorded messages and signed petitions against cuts to their children's schools. Then there were these lower-profile efforts to join in the debate over whether laying off 4,100 teachers was really the best way to balance the city's books: handwritten messages to the mayor taped to a big dollar sign outside a school in the Mount Eden section of the Bronx; postcards to City Council members signed at a foldout table in a school in Hell's Kitchen, parents clustered on a sidewalk in Park Slope, Brooklyn, chanting, ''Save our teachers,'' even though no one was around to hear it but parents themselves.

KAYNOR--William A. Bill Kaynor died on May 25, 2011, at the age of 88. Bill was a resident of Coconut Grove, Florida and Quogue, New York. He was born and raised in Waterbury, CT. He attended McTernan's School, the Taft School, Yale College and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he flew 35 missions as a B-24 Pilot in the European Theater of Operations. He was awarded the Air Medal with two OLC's, the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Purple Heart. After the war he attended Harvard Law School where he graduated cum laude and was an editor of the Law Review. He spent his entire professional career as a corporate lawyer at Davis Polk & Wardwell, in New York City, where he was a partner for over 30 years. He moved to Florida in 1996, but continued to summer in Quogue, NY, where he has summered for the last fifty years. He was a director of Americana Hotels & Realty Corp, Segue Software, Planned Parenthood of South Florida, and Community Partnership for the Homeless of Miami. Bill will be remembered as a wonderfully sweet man, always wearing a grin, whose kindness and generosity knew no bounds. He descended from the earliest settlers of the country on both sides of his family. His maternal ancestors included Thomas Hooker, the founder of Hartford, CT and Elihu Yale. His father's ancestors included two who fought in the Revolutionary War and the Battle of Brandywine and at the Battle of Plattsburg in the War of 1812. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Irene Moullin, his two sons William A., Jr. and Robert M., and four grandchildren, Dillon, Caroline, Charlie and Sophia. Services will be held on Sunday, May 29th at Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove at 3pm and on Saturday, June 4th at the Church of Atonement in Quogue, New York at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, please mail contributions to The Riverhead Hospital or East End Hospice.

WIENER--A. Walter. The Board of Governors and members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our longtime dear friend and our oldest active member, A. Walter Wiener. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Ginny, Nancy, and the entire family. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

Francesca Schiavone played smart tennis in the wind to defeat Marion Bartoli in straight sets in a French Open semifinal Thursday at Roland Garros. The defending champion defended grittily, sliding on the clay to make Bartoli hit one more ball.

Every afternoon except Tuesday, when this Upper West Side temple to alternative pets - jungle birds, desert reptiles and all things aquatic - is closed, Bob Myles and his Norfolk terrier, Bruno, pop through the front door and make a beeline for the spectacular glassed-in aviary at the back. There, Bruno plants himself on his haunches, nose to glass, and stares at the parrots in free flight on the other side. Mr. Myles, who lives in the neighborhood, is a regular at the shop, Fauna, but not a customer. "Bruno leads me here, and the people who run the store are very gracious about it," he said. "They know we're just here to look. The little green parrots are his favorites."

I spent the second day of press previews for the Venice Biennale in the Arsenale, a narrow gauntlet of art compared to the Giardini, with its discreet national pavilions and semblance of order. Here “ILLUMInations,” as the Biennale exhibition is called — having started in the spacious galleries of the Giardini’s Central Pavilion — becomes a kind of extended scrum, spliced with additional national pavilions. The impossible enormity of the Biennale beast begins to sink in. With all the additional pavilions scattered about town and the independent exhibitions that are out there, too, Venice currently has more contemporary art on offer than any one person can see, even without the usual considerations of time, money and eye-strain.

Organizers for the Tonys said on Thursday that this “Company” cast will perform at the awards telecast on June 12. Neil Patrick Harris, who played the lonely bachelor Robert in that production, wasn’t hard to pin down, since he’s hosting the Tonys; he’ll be joined in this performance by Stephen Colbert, Jon Cryer, Christina Hendricks, Patti LuPone and Martha Plimpton, as well as Jill Paice, Anika Noni Rose, Jennifer Laura Thompson, Jim Walton, Chryssie Whitehead, Katie Finneran and Aaron Lazar. A statement from the Tony organizers did not indicate which number(s) the “Company” cast will perform (so can we put our thumb on the scale now for “Side by Side by Side/What Would We Do Without You?”). The Tonys will be held this year at the Beacon Theater and broadcast on CBS. An HD film version of the Philharmonic’s “Company” will also be shown in movie theaters starting June 15.

In his lush new how-to book, “Makeup Your Mind: Express Yourself,” the makeup artist François Nars uses real women as muses. Showcasing an incredible array of faces — there are all different ethnicities, ages and even a sprinkling of men — the dense tome contains “before” and “after” photos (shot by Nars himself) of each subject. A transparent overlay between the two shots shows you how and where to apply makeup, which is very effective. Seeing the outline of the shape you are trying to create helps you apply product in a more accurate, efficient way. Because you have a clear view of the “before” face, which is completely bare, you can see how a primer or a sheer glow or matte foundation changes skin quality, and how a simple application of makeup can bring a feature to life or downplay it. The book challenges you to take risks, and even the most seasoned makeup wearer will be enlightened. It brought me back to my teen years, when I delighted in playing with different, even extreme, looks. Building confidence and conveying a variety of moods through makeup, Nars inspires you to be playful, passionate, imaginative and, as he says, “have an open spirit, and believe in your own beauty.” Nars’s picks from his own line of cosmetics: the Multiple, All About Eve Eyeshadow Duo, EFA Night Infusion and the AquaGel Hydrator.

Deborah Voigt, the renowned soprano, has sold her autobiography to HarperCollins, the publisher announced. The book, tentatively titled ''True Confessions of a Down to Earth Diva,'' is scheduled for publication in 2013. The memoir will detail Ms. Voigt's dramatic ups and downs throughout her career, including her famous battles with her weight. Ms. Voigt, 50, said in a statement, ''It's time for me to step up and share my story because I know there are lots of other people, especially women, who are out there suffering in silence.'' Jonathan Burnham, the publisher of HarperCollins, called the book an ''unbelievably honest narrative of a woman caught in a dangerous cycle of addiction and illness who overcame her demons in an utterly triumphant way.'' Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Korean grocers have not only populated New York's neighborhoods in recent decades, they have also popped up in its culture, lore and literature. 1976: An article in The New York Times about the city's ''sudden profusion of Korean fruit and vegetable shops'' quotes a produce supplier: ''When I first came into this business -- that was before the war -- to do business here you had to know some Jewish phrases. Then some years later you had to pick up a few Italian words to make it. Now I'm trying for all the Korean words I can.''

AUSTIN--Barbara Forester, 76, of New York City, died peacefully at home on May 26, 2011 after an extended illness. Daughter of Helen Foss Forester and Henry William Forester, now deceased, she will be missed by her brother, Sturtevant Hobbs of Westwood, MA; by three generations of nieces and nephews; and by her cat, Mr. Darcy. Elegant and colorful, she was a voracious reader and conversationalist, but her passion was music. She was an enthusiastic supporter of Young Concert Artists, and lived across the street from Carnegie Hall. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Young Concert Artists (250 West 57th Street, NYC 10107), which can be contacted for information about the memorial celebration to be held on June 9th.

A report last Thursday in the Currents column erroneously attributed a distinction to Matthew Carter, a type designer who is being honored with the 2011 National Design Award for lifetime achievement. Charles Bigelow, not Mr. Carter, is the first type designer to receive a MacArthur Foundation fellowship. Mr. Bigelow received his in 1982, Mr. Carter in 2010.

JENNINGS--John Prentice (Jack) of Mill Neck, NY, and Vinalhaven, ME died May 30 at 81. The son of B. Brewster Jennings, President of Mobil Oil Corp. and Kate Prentice Jennings. Graduated from Fountain Valley School Colorado. Left UVA to join the Marines and fought in Korean War as Master Sergeant. He broke Camp Lejeune sharp shooter record. He worked for Grumman Aerospace as assistant to the President. He was involved in the Apollo program which built the Lunar Module and put Astronauts on the moon. In 1970, he and Nina hosted a celebration for the safe return of the Astronauts of Apollo 13. When the mission went awry the Grumman LM returned them safely to earth; a task for which it was never designed. He founded Hunters Africa, a safari outfit in Botswana. Occasionally he was the safari guide. He served his community in many capacities including, Trustee and Police Commissioner of Mill Neck, on board of North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary, and board member at Glen Cove Hospital. His charm and wit were legendary and he will be deeply missed. Survived by his wife, Cornelia (Nina) Clark Jennings, daughters Debra Gillette, Wendy Hall, Leigh Judson, Edith McElroy, Katharine Cushing, Lee DiPietro, Nini Marceca, son Brewster Jennings and 18 grandchildren. Daughter, Ames Tollefson, predeceased him. His family has planned a celebration of his life at Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, Thursday, June 9th., 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fountain Valley School, 6155 Fountain Valley School Road. Colorado Springs, CO 80911.

Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st) Thursday 3-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Libby's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105

The government-run developer of Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi announced that it had hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to monitor conditions for foreign laborers building the new branches of the Louvre and Guggenheim museums there. A 2009 report by Human Rights Watch raised alarms about working conditions on the island, in particular the practice of workers having to pay hefty fees to recruiters in their home countries, putting them in debt before they even start to work. Earlier this year a group of prominent Middle Eastern artists said it would boycott the new Guggenheim unless conditions were improved. In a telephone interview on Tuesday, Sarah Leah Whitson, the director of the Middle East and North Africa division at Human Rights Watch, said the appointment of an independent monitor was ''a very welcome and positive development.'' But she added that her organization still had some concerns, including the fact that the law in the United Arab Emirates, which includes Abu Dhabi, prohibits workers from forming unions or going on strike. She also called on the Guggenheim and the developer, the Tourism Development and Investment Company, to pledge to reimburse workers if their employers were found not to have covered their recruitment fees.

BANDEL--Judith. On May 31, 2011. Beloved daughter of the late Esther and Nathaniel Bandel. She is survived by many dear friends and colleagues. Services Thursday 3pm at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation.

AT Cannes last month, the paparazzi gave Gwen Stefani (above) the royal treatment when she accessorized her 1970s-inspired Stella McCartney sequin jumpsuit with an equally glamorous disco mane. The look, side-parted with voluminous soft curls, is a ringer for the one the hairstylist and Redken creative consultant Guido Palau created for the spring shows at Sonia Rykiel (right) and Marc Jacobs -- and, according to the stylist, is simple to recreate for summer. If your hair is curly (women with God-given ringlets, stop complaining!), just tame your locks with a leave-in conditioner and use a curling iron to define more pieces throughout your hair. ''This will create even more bounce,'' Mr. Palau said. For straight hair, ''apply a light mist of a heat protector -- I use Redken Hot Sets 22 Thermal Setting Mist -- before drying hair and using a curling iron.'' If you have time, do as he did for the runway and set your curls with pins, then finger comb with a finishing gel for extra pizazz.

LEVIN--Jonathan Charles, died May 11, 2011 in South Burlington, Vermont of complications following renal biopsy. He was 44 years old. Mr. Levin was born in Japan and adopted as an infant by his parents who were then serving at the American Embassy in Tokyo. He attended schools in Tanzania, Sri Lanka, India and Washington, DC and graduated from the Edmund Burke School in Washington and Champlain College in Burlington. The Levin family home is in Calais, Vermont. Mr. Levin was an enthusiastic chess player, bowler, computer user and an innovative cook. His mother, the late Cornelia Rose Levin, died July, 2010. Immediate survivors are his sister, Martha Levin of Hong Kong, and his father, Herbert Levin of New York City. His family and friends mourn the loss of this kind and gentle man. Donations in his honor may be made to: Kidney Transplant Fund Development 4610H4, Fletcher Allan Health Care, 111 Colchester Ave., Burlington, Vermont 05401.

BROWN--Doris Loebenberg, 88, of Atlanta, Ga.,formerly of Valhalla, White Plains and Utica, NY., died at home on May 31, 2011, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. She was the beloved and devoted wife of Raymond, mother of Alison Lukacsko and Diane Treuman and grandmother of Jeffrey and Michael Lukacsko and Emily and Daniel Treuman. Doris is also survived by an adoring son-in-law, Stanton Treuman, sister-in-law Barbara Brown, and several nephews and a niece. Doris was the glue in an unusually close knit family and was like a second mother to nephews Peter and Jim Freedman. She will be terribly missed. Doris was a graduate of The Dalton School in Manhattan and Pembroke College and was a founding member, sisterhood President and teacher at Temple Emanuel in Utica, NY. She was a lifelong advocate of public education. Doris was a public school psychologist and visionary in developing programs for learning disabled children; after a 30 year career, Doris retired and volunteered in the Gift Shop at White Plains Hospital. She loved traveling with her family, doing the New York Times crossword and was an expert and avid bridge player. Doris was always refined and a role model of unconditional love. She will be remembered for her optimism, energy for life, loyalty to friends and family and boundless grace. The family requests donations to American Cancer Society. Services by the Cremation Society of Georgia, 404-355-7627

MEEKS--Thomas Orestes, Jr.,83, of Brooklyn, NY died May 28, 2011 at the Hopkins Center for Rehabilitation & Health Care. A graduate of MIT, Yale and Polytechnic University of New York Thomas Meeks, PhD, was an Associate Professor of Physics at Kingsborough Community College (CUNY) until his retirement. His life is highlighted by his humble beginnings to his outstanding academic achievements. He is survived by a sister, Elaine (Meeks) Wallace-Colbert and his devoted niece, Linda M. Wallace. A memorial service followed by a fellowship hour will be held at First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn at 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY on Saturday, June 4 at 11am. Contributions in his memory may be directed to MIT, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02139 or to First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn's Health Ministry Committee.

MIGDEN--Jules, 88, a World War II Veteran served in the South Pacific in the Signal Corp Division of the U.S. Army, and a long time (54 year) resident of East Hills, NY passed away, May 31st 2011 due to complications related from Lymphoma and Diabetes. IT turns out that last week's sun was not just a cruel tease, so you'll need a cute cover-up for those first beach weekends. Kelley Culp, the ''Full Frontal Fashion'' editor, likes caftans for the beach, so much so that she has brought 15 of them back from her travels to Morocco and India. ''They give you the freedom of a robe but are crafted to be appropriate in public,'' she said. If a caftan is too much cover-up, an airy caftan-inspired style, short with batwing sleeves and perhaps front smocking, is flirty and comfortable, and a splashy print ensures that it's not too see-through. An article on Friday about attractions on Governors Island misidentified the sponsor of an exhibition of sculpture there by Mark di Suvero. While the exhibition was organized by the Storm King Art Center, the sponsors who provided financing include many individuals, foundations and corporations. The art center is not a sponsor.

BARASCH--Marvin, 88, of Manhattan and Palm Beach, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, passed peacefully in his home surrounded by loving family on May 30. Devoted husband of 20 years to Phyllis (nee Putter). Broadway had another billion-dollar season between late May 2010 and Sunday, with shows grossing $1.08 billion - 5.9 percent more than the total for the 2009-10 season - and playing to more than 12.5 million people, according to the Broadway League, the trade group for theater owners and producers. That 2010-11 season attendance figure also reflects an increase of 5.4 percent over the previous season. Musicals and plays on Broadway have proved to be hardy perennials on the economic landscape for the entertainment industry, with shows steadily filling the sector's 40 theaters in Manhattan. While commercial hits are something of a rarity - only 25 to 30 percent of new shows usually turn a profit - long-running blockbusters like ''Wicked'' and ''The Lion King'' have become reliable money-makers even in bad weeks for other shows, and new additions like ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' and ''The Book of Mormon'' have been selling strongly.

WEISBERG--Richard Edward, 67, a lifetime resident of New York City, passed away Wednesday, May 25, 2011. He was predeceased by his parents, Nathan and Pearl Rebak Weisberg. He is survived by his beloved wife, Kathryn Annette Clark; a brother, Steven Weisberg (Amie); nephews, Ira (Laura) (son, Noah) Weisberg and Bryan (Debra Bass) Weisberg ; and the Clark and Azar families. Richard inspired extraordinary, deep, and passionate love and was deeply loved by everyone who met and associated with him. Among his many contributions to what is the most beautiful, he created and was the Principal of The Cobble Hill school of American Studies. Richard had a profound impact on each of his students, their parents, his teachers, and all who worked with him. His capacity to see the good in every person and every situation, his incomparable capacity for love, compassion, devotion, and always doing the right thing are unrivaled. Richard we miss you terribly already. You are in our hearts and our lives forever. You changed our lives. What you added to each of our lives --- we will always be at a loss to express. Funeral services will be held at Leak Memory Chapel at 11:00am on Thursday, June 2, 2011. Burial will follow in St. Margaret's Cemetery in Montgomery, AL. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the IMUS Cattle Ranch for Kids with Cancer, www.imusranchfoods.com Ribera, NM 87560.

An article last Thursday about the songwriter Allee Willis misstated her age. She is 63, not 64. The article also misstated the location of the high school she attended. Mumford High School is in Detroit, not Mumford, Mich., which does not exist. The article also misstated the approximate age of the Del Rubio Triplets, a singing group, when Ms. Willis discovered them. They were in their 70s, not middle-aged.

An article last Thursday about Maria Sharapova misidentified the basketball team for which her fiancé, Sasha Vujacic, plays. It is the Los Angeles Lakers -- not the New Jersey Nets, for whom he did play.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about Manhattan law firms that are moving to the West Side misstated the affiliation of Robert Goodman of Colliers International. He is an executive managing director and a member of the company's Tri-State Law Firm Services Group, which represented Holland & Knight in its move to West 52nd Street; he is not affiliated with Holland & Knight. The article also misspelled the name of a law firm that joined with other lawyers to form Buckley Sandler. It was Buckley Kolar, not Buckley Coler.

It has been noted repeatedly that almost no top bankers have faced serious consequences for their actions in the financial crisis. But there is a Wall Street corollary that might be even more pernicious: good guys are punished. Whistle-blowers, truth-tellers and fraud-spotters pay a miserable price on Wall Street. They are vilified. They are fired. Sometimes they are even sued. Instead of being sought after, they become persona non grata.

Too bad Sandy Koufax is not pitching anymore. Major League Baseball said Wednesday that a team from Israel would participate in the World Baseball Classic in 2013. The event will be expanded to 28 teams from 16. In a new format, 16 teams, including those from Brazil, Britain, Israel and Thailand, will play in a double-elimination qualifying round in late 2012.

How's this for rags to riches: The Queens-born tenor and son of a grocer Anthony Dominick Benedetto - you might know him better as the enduring pop crooner Tony Bennett - will make his debut on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House at a concert in September, the Met said on Wednesday. The concert, scheduled for Sept. 18, will celebrate Mr. Bennett's 85th birthday (which officially arrives on Aug. 3) and promote his coming album ''Duets II,'' which is planned for release on Sept. 20. The Met said in a news release that Mr. Bennett would perform with Lee Musiker (piano), Gray Sargent (guitar), Harold Jones (drums), and Marshall Wood (bass), and plans a lineup of ''pop standards from the Great American Songbook, many of which Bennett has introduced and recorded to critical and popular acclaim that led to a string of greatest hits over his 60-year career.'' Mr. Bennett said in a very groovy statement that he had ''been practicing my whole life to perform on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House,'' adding: ''It's a dream come true.'' Tickets for the concert are $50 to $350 and will go on sale at metopera.org on Sunday.

One was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. Another was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. The third is the spouse of the two-term governor of Indiana, who, until a few weeks ago, was considered by many as a leading candidate for the Republican Party's presidential nomination. But what does Cheri Daniels have in common with Elizabeth Taylor and Natalie Wood? Like them, she divorced one husband to marry another, only later to remarry the first husband. That marital roundelay, though almost never discussed by the couple, was largely considered one reason Governor Daniels decided against a White House run. As he explained last month: ''I find myself caught between two duties. I love my country. I love my family more.''

Shaquille O'Neal's final walk down an N.B.A. corridor was painful to witness, but it came with an appropriate dose of joyful happenstance. The Celtics had just been eliminated by the Heat in a playoff series that O'Neal never got the chance to affect. His right Achilles' was inflamed, his gait crimped. His final postseason was ruined, along with the Celtics' title hopes.

10 P.M. (NBC) LOVE BITES Three loosely connected stories about dating, sex, love and marriage are presented each week in this new series, which stars Becki Newton (above) as Annie, a single New Yorker looking for ''Mr. Right Now,'' and Constance Zimmer and Greg Grunberg as Colleen and Judd Rouscher, a happy married couple in Venice Beach, Calif. In this premiere episode, filled with guest stars, Cassie (Krysten Ritter), becomes jealous of all the attention bestowed on Annie, who is pregnant, carrying a child for her sister. Not to be outdone, Cassie masquerades as a virgin to get a man. Elsewhere an accountant (Kyle Howard) is fired and returns home early to find his fiancée (Lindsay Price) in bed with a gift from her bachelorette party. And Judd ends up sitting next to Jennifer Love Hewitt on a cross-country flight. She happens to be on his ''celebrity exemption list,'' which means he is allowed to sleep with her without marital consequences. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY In a live broadcast from St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Matt Lauer and Al Roker have an audience with Pope Benedict XVI. Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York gives Mr. Lauer and Mr. Roker a private tour of the Basilica, including a look at John Paul II's newly installed tomb; the occasion is being billed as the first such peek for an American broadcast. Anne Thompson examines how the church has embraced social media.

Colin Campbell will step down after 13 years as the N.H.L.'s chief disciplinarian, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Brendan Shanahan will take over the job, and Campbell will stay on as the league's vice president in charge of hockey operations. Shanahan retired from a 22-season N.H.L. playing career in 2009 and has since been a league vice president heavily involved in rule changes. Shanahan will also head a new department of player safety. More at nytimes.com/slapshot.

6:28 p.m. | Updated Lenovo, the Chinese computer maker that bought I.B.M.'s PC division six years ago, said Wednesday that it planned to take control of a German consumer electronics manufacturer, Medion, in a deal valuing the company at $909 million.

You probably didn't get in on LinkedIn's initial public stock offering last week, but the company can still get you something more stable than an investment in an Internet stock- a job. But there are three things a lot of LinkedIn users don't seem to know that can help raise your chances of being recruited. Post a photo - A few years ago, people who posted photos of themselves to the Internet seemed self centered. In the Facebook, era, though, an account page without a picture seems like the work of someone who didn't put much effort into it. It doesn't need to be a professional headshot. Just stand against a white wall in business attire (or, if you're a software engineer, a Rush t-shirt) and have someone take a cellphone photo of your face and shoulders. To upload your photo, choose the option Profile -> Edit Profile at the top of your LinkedIn page, and look for the Add Photo link.

Saturday night seemed like a perfect one for a baseball game: 70 degrees and breezy, with the workweek, because of the Memorial Day holiday, still more than 60 hours away. The National League's best team and the Mets' longtime rivals, the Phillies, were in town at Citi Field. I expected quite a few New Yorkers to have made the same calculation, and was resigned to having to pay a slight premium to buy tickets at StubHub. But just a few hours before gametime, there were still plenty of good seats available at Mets.com in virtually every section of the ballpark.

The news came via Zenyatta.com, her Web site, which is maintained by Dottie Ingordo-Shirreffs, the racing manager for Zenyatta's owners, Jerry and Ann Moss, as well as the wife of the mare's trainer, John Shirreffs.

SCHEUER--Bernard I.,DDS, passed away on May 31, 2011 at 90 at his home in Hackensack, NJ. Born on March 16, 1921 in Brooklyn. He was the son of William and Ann, and the brother of Henrietta and Mildred. He was beloved husband of Caroline (nee Feller) for close to 67 years. He was the dear father of Lynette (Bruce), Wanda (Steven) and Brian, adoring grandfather of Rachel (Ken), Lisa (Dave) Heather, Erin (Ariel) and Brad (Jenn). He was proud great-grandfather of Zachary, Ryan, Alex and Lauren. Dr. Scheuer was an esteemed dentist who practiced for 40 years in Manhattan. He graduated from Boy's High School (1936), NYU Heights (1939) and NYU School Of Dentistry (1943). He was past president of New York State Dental Society of Anesthesiology. Dr. Scheuer served as an Army Lieutenant in WWII where he flew gliders in the 101st Airborne Division. Dr. Scheuer will be remembered by family, peers, and those who knew him as a decent, loving gentleman. Funeral services will be held on June 2, 12pm, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

WAYNE, N.J. - A New Jersey technology company that had been a major contractor on the Bloomberg administration's troubled CityTime payroll project abruptly halted operations and terminated its employees amid a widening city and federal investigation, according to a company memorandum sent out this week. The top two executives of the company, TechnoDyne L.L.C., have returned to their native India, according to people familiar with the case who were not authorized to speak publicly because the investigation was continuing.

KAS, TURKEY - I sit on this peaceful peninsula marveling at how long it's been since Odysseus sailed the eastern Mediterranean. Then I realize that those millennia are nothing compared with how long our species might take to adapt to the inexorable spread of the American diet. Once, we had to combine hunting skills and luck to eat meat, which could supply then-rare nutrients in large quantities. This progressed - or at least moved on - to a stage where a family could raise an annual pig and maybe keep a cow and some chickens. Quite suddenly (this development is no more than 50 years old, even in America), we can drive to our nearest burger shop and scarf down a patty - or two! - at will.

Immigration authorities announced on Wednesday that they will drop their case against Mohammed G. Azam, a young Bangladeshi man who had been fighting deportation since 2003, when he registered with a special post-9/11 program for Muslims. In April, the government ended the ''special registration'' program, which critics had said amounted to racial profiling, but Mr. Azam was one of perhaps hundreds still caught in its net.

WARRIORS OF RADNESS, the Los Angeles men's-wear brand known for its surf-inspired beachwear, is showing Opening Ceremony how to beach-party right this summer. In its latest collaboration, Opening Ceremony teamed up with the Warriors founder, the California street-style vet Rick Klotz, on a capsule collection of swim trunks, tanks, shirts and soft pullover sweatshirts in washed-out pastels that recall Frankie and Annette frugging on the beach. All of the pieces are branded with a ''Beach Crew!'' logo Mr. Klotz designed as a reminder, he said, of ''beach style when it actually represented fun times.'' Warriors of Radness x OC Beach Crew! sweatshirts ($105) and shorts ($95) at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street; (212) 219-2688; openingceremonyus.com.

THODE--Irving of Stamford, CT, (age 80) died June 1, 2011 of heart failure. Born in Loup City, NE he graduated from the University of Nebraska. He served on the Vista Board of the Chase Manhattan Bank after a management career at IBM, Control Data and Quotron Systems. A long time resident of Greenwich, Thode was president of the Greenwich World Hunger and served on the Vestry of Christ Church Greenwich. He is survived by his wife Nancy Thode of Stamford, a son Scott Thode of New York City, a daughter Tari Sherry, step children Anne Every Cuddy and John Everly and their spouses and eight grandchildren. A service will be held at Christ Church Greenwich on Saturday, June 4, 2011 at 11:30am.

Word got out this week that Twitpic, the most popular service used by Twitter users to upload and post photos, had struck an exclusive partnership with World Entertainment News Network, a news and photo agency that specializes in celebrity stories and pictures. The deal allows the agency to sell images posted on Twitpic for publication elsewhere. (Flickr, by contrast, expressly forbids the reuse of its members' photos without their personal permission or a special copyright designation that allows commercial use.)
LAMB--Margaret (Mimi). Fordham English Professor. A memorial will be held on Saturday, June 4 at 2pm at St. Mary's Episcopal Church. 521 West 126th St. NYC.

What rhymes with ''Yo, Adrian!''? The answer may lie with Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty, a Tony Award-winning songwriting team (''Ragtime''), who along with the book writer Thomas Meehan are deep into a stage musical adaptation of the boxing-cum-romantic drama ''Rocky,'' the winner of the 1976 Academy Award for best picture.

Gov. Andrew M. Cuomosaid on Wednesday that he was suspending New York's participation in a federal immigration enforcement plan that has drawn fire from immigrant advocates, civil liberties lawyers and elected officials in the state and around the country. A statement from Mr. Cuomo's office said there was ''mounting evidence'' that the program, called Secure Communities, had not only failed to meet its goal of deporting the most serious immigrant criminals but was also undermining law enforcement and compromising public safety.

Those who derive pleasure from meticulously organizing things - in this case, an iTunes music collection - will be pleased to know that TuneUp, a provider of add-ons for Apple's music-management software, has added ''DeDuper'' to its suite of wares. Say you own a copy of ''Hot on the Tracks,'' the 1976 release by the funk and soul band the Commodores. That would mean that you own ''Just to Be Close to You,'' a track on that album. But let's say you also own 1977's ''Commodores Live!,'' as well as the Commodores' 1979 release, ''Greatest Hits,'' and 1984's Commodores compilation, ''All the Great Love Songs.''

SHEA--Kevin Patrick, of Hoboken, NJ formerly of New Rochelle, NY suddenly passed away on May 30, 2011 at the age of 37 years old. Born September 7, 1973. Loving son to Jack and Jane Shea. He was a graduate of Iona Prep, Villanova University and earned a Masters Degree from Iona College in New Rochelle. He was a Vice President at Navigators Management Company Inc. and member of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters, New York, NY and the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, NY. He is survived by his parents Jack and Jane Shea of Pleasantville, NY formerly of New Rochelle, and beloved brother of John Shea of Hoboken, NJ, Brian Shea (Stacey) of Brooklyn, NY, Peter Shea (Inna) of Jersey City, NJ. Also proud uncle of Sophie and Gabrielle. Visitation is on Thursday from 7-9pm and Friday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, NY. Funeral mass will be celebrated 10am on Saturday at Sts. John & Paul R.C. Church, Larchmont, NY. Burial will be private.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether trades in health care stocks by the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors as recently as last year were made using inside information, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday. The investigation comes as SAC, one of the most prominent hedge funds in the world with $12 billion in assets under management, has become something of a focal point for authorities. Two former SAC portfolio managers have pleaded guilty to criminal charges of using inside information to trade technology stocks.

FITZMAURICE--Elizabeth. The Board of Governors and staff of The Little Orchestra Society extend our condolences to the family of our Board Co-Chair, Carol Schaefer, at the passing of her daughter, Betsy, a great friend and supporter of the Little Orchestra. We join with the family in remembering her life and express our deepest sympathies. William Ohlemeyer Board Co-Chair Joanne Bernstein-Cohen Executive Director

In its brief, half-decade history, the Bushwick Open Studios festival has earned a reputation as an eclectic, unpredictable entree into the underground Brooklyn arts scene, replete with cabarets, outre costumes, and free exhibitions from hundreds of local artists. The festival has also become known for something else: poor subway service.

KANE--Ronald S.,72, on May 30, 2011. Survived by sister Louise Trotman and nephews Adrian and Julian. He was a certified appraiser for antiques and real estate, an alumnus of Columbia College and a philanthropist.

SMALL VICTORY Even when a criminal defendant wins a case before the United States Supreme Court, there is no guarantee that the person will avoid a conviction and escape serving time in a federal prison, according to White Collar Watch. Two former chief executives, Conrad M. Black and Jeffrey K. Skilling, have learned that lesson the hard way because of an important legal doctrine called harmless error, which is frequently invoked to uphold convictions in jury trials. PETER J. HENNING

High fashion and money have always gone together, and for the next few weeks, they will do so in the museum world as well as on the racks. The Metropolitan Museum of Art said Tuesday that its Alexander McQueen show, which it recently extended by a week to accommodate the overflow crowds, will be opened during special viewing hours on Mondays, when the Met is usually closed, for patrons willing to buy $50 tickets.-Since the show opened on May 4, more than 150,000 people have gone to see it, making for long lines and waits. The tickets, which will go on sale in early June at the museum and online at metmuseum.org/alexandermcqueen, will allow entries on Mondays on the half hour, from 9:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. beginning June 6. (The show continues through Aug. 7; tickets for Monday viewing will not be available for July 4, when the museum is open to the public as part of a special holiday program.) The McQueen show will continue to be available during the museum's regular hours with no additional charge above the Met's $20 suggested admission price. In the last several decades the museum has rarely instituted special ticket charges for exhibitions. In 2003 and 2004 it opened the museum on Mondays in the same way it is doing for the McQueen show, charging $50 per ticket for special access to the exhibitions ''Manet/Velazquez: The French Taste for Spanish Painting'' and ''El Greco.'' In the 1970s and 1980s it sometimes instituted ticket charges above the regular admission price for some shows, like King Tut in 1978 and for the work of Degas and Georgia O'Keeffe in 1988.

SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Not that it’s about me, but the first thing that struck me about today’s puzzle was the appalling number of adult beverages it would take to get me up on stage at a KARAOKE BAR. I’m not a shy person by any stretch, but for some reason the thought of getting up and singing by myself in front of other people terrifies me. The last Christmas party I attended for Bust Magazine (disclosure: I construct their X Games crossword puzzle) was held at a karaoke bar here in New York City, and although I had immense fun with my fellow Busties, you would not have been able to get me up on stage if you tried. NO SIREE BOB. I will gladly applaud and cheer wildly for others, though.

Yesterday’s column on the weak historical relationship between the unemployment rate and presidential performance generated a mostly favorable reaction. But I also got a few replies wondering how to reconcile these findings against the claims, made with some frequency by political scientists, that presidential elections can be forecast with pinpoint accuracy provided that you know the economic fundamentals.
But I can promise you a panel discussion on Charlie Rose, tonight. Me, Jared Bernstein, Ken Rogoff, David Walker.

MG Siegler at the Techcrunch blog lays out the evidence that the computer mouse is dead. He says Apple is leading the way, but his argument gains strength (despite a mixed metaphor) when he points out what Microsoft is doing with its next Windows release.
As my colleagues Liam Stack and Katherine Zoepf report, Syria’s government apparently tried to stifle the flow of information on the protest movement with a nationwide Internet shutdown Friday.

After a series of spills, the United States Department of Transportation has ordered the TransCanada Corporation to suspend operation of its one-year-old Keystone 1 pipeline, which carries oil extracted from oil sands in the Canadian province of Alberta to the United States. The order was issued by the department’s Pipelines and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.
President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner are taking their budget negotiations to a place where a lot of deals get done in the business world: the golf course.

When it began nearly 30 years ago, Tetris quickly became one of the most popular video games sold. Now, the Tetris Company, which owns the Tetris brand, says it plans to expand beyond videogames and soon hopes to introduce dozens of new Tetris-themed products. These will include Tetris branded T-shirts, Halloween costumes, tabletop games, chocolates, candy, waffles, furniture that nests together, and even Tetris soup.

At the Dot Earth blog, Andy Revkin asked climate researchers to weigh in on the recent spate of tornadoes, seeking insights on the mix of factors that can transform merely turbulent weather into “a catastrophic outbreak of funnel clouds.” He received some interesting responses that shed light on scientists’ knowledge gaps.

BEIJING — Millions of Chinese who have never swung a racket or seen a live tennis match will cheer on Li Na on Saturday as she plays in the French Open final and tries to become the first Asian player to win a major.

Most people do not realize the intense relationship between modern agriculture and water quality. In an article in Friday’s paper, I write about a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico near the mouth of the Mississippi River and how it has been linked to runoff from farms, largely from chemicals used as fertilizers.

A couple of months ago, when we started putting credits and email addresses for the editors of feature stories on the magazine’s table of contents, Jack Shafer, media critic for Slate, felt inspired to not only mock the plan, but to impugn the editing profession generally. “Try complimenting an editor sometime about a good piece in his publication,” Jack wrote, “and you’re certain to get this eye-rolling response: ‘You shoulda seen it when it came in!'”

Whether you’re simply organized or mildy compulsive, a list can provide the structure for the everyday. However, when the to-do list is compiled by such artistic luminaries as Pablo Picasso, Alexander Calder and Franz Kline, it transcends its ostensible purpose and provides insights into the life and times of its maker. This is obvious from a new show — “To-dos, Ilustrated Inventories, Collected Thoughts, and Other Artists’ Enumerations,” curated by Liza Kirwin from the Smithsonian’s Archives of American Art — that opened today at the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan. For example, Pablo Picasso’s recommendations for inclusion in the 1913 Armory Show, the first international exhibition of modern art in the United States, astutely foresaw the historical importance of Marcel Duchamp, Fernand Leger and Juan Gris. Franz Kline’s shopping list for booze for his 1960 New Year’s party was evidence of his financial success (it was a hefty bill for the time) as well as his social nature. The artist Adolf Konrad illustrated his 1962 packing list: Khaki trench. Check. Six pairs of socks. Check. Sunglasses. Check. Two lemons. Check. Ah, the beauty of the artfully organized.
Twenty ways to use one of spring’s quintessential vegetables.
The old-school graffiti writer and Keith Haring collaborator known as LA II plans to wield his paint cans only in legal settings from now on.
Experts at the World Science Festival mused on individualized therapies, global involvement in clinical trials and the potential of genetic research to find a cure. Hint: It could take a while.

The Bahrain Grand Prix, the Formula One race that was postponed in February after widespread civil unrest broke out in the Gulf emirate, was reinstated on Friday by the race series’ governing body, the F.I.A.

Brian Johnson, singer for the long-lived, platinum-selling rock band AC/DC, will turn 64 this October. Rock stars of that vintage typically trace their transformative childhood moment to hearing an Elvis Presley or Little Richard record for the first time, or seeing the Beatles perform.

My favorite odd detail in Jon Caramanica’s profile of Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon in Sunday’s magazine — in an article stuffed with odd details — is Vernon’s description of the tattoo he has of the state of Wisconsin, with the six counties he knows best outlined. The specificity struck me with such force: the six counties? I mean, not to be parochial, but as far as homogeneous states go — well, let’s just say I had preconceptions about Wisconsin.

Gil Scott-Heron died last week. A pioneering artist and progenitor of rap and hip-hop, Scott-Heron, who battled substance abuse for decades, experienced a resurgence in popularity last year after a new album reminded audiences of his thought-provoking lyrical prowess.

For much of 2010, the slumping economy was affecting white-collar, highly educated workers almost as much as it was affecting less educated and blue-collar workers. That’s no longer the case. In recent months, the economy has once again been easier on college graduates than it has on everyone else, much as it was during nearly all of 2008 and 2009.

LOS ANGELES — The dust-up around Ben Shapiro’s book, “Prime Time Propaganda: The True Hollywood Story of How the Left Took Over Your TV,” has taken a toll on a values-oriented Hollywood organization that prides itself on reaching across partisan lines. That is the Caucus for Producers, Writers and Directors, whose members include Tom Hanks, Dick Wolf, Garry Marshall and some of the more prominent creative types in television.

The fledgling Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, with few contributions on the horizon and facing rising costs, is suspending operations, its chairman said on Friday. The orchestra, based in New York, was founded in 2004 by Alondra de la Parra, a rising young Mexican conductor, and made a specialty of Latin American music. It toured in Mexico recently in honor of the country’s bicentennial and gave three or four concerts a year in New York. Ms. de la Parra and the orchestra also released a recording of Latin American works last year.
Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who was scratched the day before the Kentucky Derby, has been diagnosed with a liver disease called cholangiohepatitis.

Women writers are “quite different,” said V.S. Naipaul in an interview at the Royal Geographic Society, picked up by The Guardian. “I read a piece of writing, and within a paragraph or two I know whether it is by a woman or not. I think [it is] unequal to me.” (To see if you have the master’s knack for sexing literature, go to what New York magazine calls “Guess the Sex of the Authors on the V.S. Naipaul Test” on the Guardian’s Web site.) He goes on to explain that, in part, women fall short because they aren’t the boss at home. “She is not a complete master of a house, so that comes over in her writing too.” Maybe Virginia Woolf should have asked for more real estate.

New York City Opera, as part of its resuscitation plan, will lay off 11 of its 48 administrative employees and eliminate four open positions, according to a company memorandum obtained on Friday. The layoffs are part of a reorganization approved at a May 19 board meeting when the company formally decided to leave its home, the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The memorandum did not identify the jobs and City Opera officials had no comment.

The United States added just 54,000 nonfarm payroll jobs over all in May, the Labor Department reported Friday, after having added an average of 220,000 in each of the three prior months. The May jobs report showed the slowest private-sector hiring in a year.

Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about a type of stock that had fallen into disfavor over the last couple of decades because it had none of the go-go appeal of a technology start-up — the dividend-paying kind. Paul speaks to several financial advisers who say they are now promoting dividend-paying stocks to people who still have money in cash or low-yielding bonds.

A few months ago, Barry Bearak called. Barry lives in Johannesburg, where he and his wife, Celia Dugger, have been our bureau chiefs for southern Africa for the past three and a half years. He called to describe a video he had recently seen of a mob that was beating and killing a man. Barry’s response was immediate: he had seen something terrible, something terribly wrong, and he had to understand why it had happened. Barry won a Pulitzer in 2002 for his coverage of life in war-torn Afghanistan; in 2005, he recreated the day the tsunami wiped out much of Banda Aceh, Indonesia, telling the stories of six survivors. Suffice it to say that he works tirelessly to get the details that convey the truth of the matter, which he does in this most recent piece, a powerful, disturbing story, “Death by a Thousand Blows,” that appears in this Sunday’s magazine.

Kitty Kelley got scads of attention for her 1991 book, “Nancy Reagan: The Unauthorized Biography,” by alleging that Frank Sinatra and Nancy Reagan carried on an affair for years, even during Reagan’s years in the White House. In Kelley’s book, Old Blue Eyes and Old Adolfo Suits would supposedly disappear “for three-or four-hour ‘private luncheons'” in the family quarters. At the time, some disputed the claim in print.

UBS said on Friday that it had hired Yusuf Nahmiyas as a managing director for its technology, media and telecommunications mergers team. Mr. Nahmiyas was most recently at Deutsche Bank and was previously at JPMorgan Chase. He is the Swiss bank’s latest hire amid a series of high-profile defections.

“Waiting for trade” is a common refrain from comic book fans. Rather than pick up the monthly issues of a comic book series, many fans haveopted to wait (sometimes patiently) for the collected edition of the title to arrive months later. It’s a risky proposition – if the monthly sales of a book sink, the chances of a collected edition may decrease dramatically. While softcover and hardcover editions have proved popular with fans, there’s been a growing number of deluxe, Absolute, Martini and Omnibus editions that have been catching fire.

Updated | 2:49 p.m. Hours after Bahrain’s security forces again fired tear gas at protesters on Friday, the World Motor Sport Council unanimously approved a decision to hold the Bahrain Grand Prix in October. In a surprising twist, the Knicks announced late Friday morning that Donnie Walsh would be leaving his post as team president when his contract expires at the end of this month. The team characterized Walsh’s exit as by mutual agreement between him and the team’s principal owner, James L. Dolan.

The first time I saw Cirque du Soleil was in Washington in the early 1990s and it was like no circus I had ever seen. There were no lumbering animals or clown cars. These performers were whimsical, the mood oddly dreamlike and, in between the death-defying acrobatics, there were moments of minor-key theatrical grace.I loved it.
PARIS -– Roger Federer defeated Novak Dokovic, 7-6, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, to reach the finals of the French Open Friday and snap Djokovic’s winning streak of 43 consecutive matches dating to last year.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, facing what it calls a “number of daunting, ongoing budgetary challenges,” has decided to raise its suggested admission fee to $25, from $20, where it has been set for the last five years. The change takes effect July 1.

Jonathan Chait thinks Paul Ryan will run for president, and that he might well be the Republican nominee. Interesting point. On the surface, it seems crazy: Ryan’s budget plan is, after all, both spectacularly bad policy and spectacularly bad politics. But Ryan may have a secret weapon: despite everything, much of the punditocracy (myself obviously not included) still has a crush on him.

Make no mistake: The higher the unemployment rate in November 2012, the less likely President Obama is to win a second term. But we should be careful about asserting that there is any particular threshold at which Mr. Obama would go from favorite to underdog, or any magic number at which his re-election would either become impossible or a fait accompli. Historically, the relationship between the unemployment rate and a president’s performance at the next election is complicated and tenuous. Read more »

The Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile, the ruling body of the Formula One race series, voted Friday to reschedule the Bahrain Grand Prix for Oct. 30. The move bumps the Indian Grand Prix to the season finale spot, though a date has yet to be announced. Originally scheduled for March, the Bahrain G.P. was postponed following civil unrest in the Gulf emirate. Read more »

Rothschild said on Friday that it had hired Steve Patrick, the former vice chairman of Colgate-Palmolive, as a senior adviser. Mr. Patrick, who was previously Colgate-Palmolive's chief financial officer, will counsel the investment bank's mergers and financing advisory teams, especially on consumer and retail companies. It’s official: After cutting its interest rate for the third time in nearly nine months, SmartyPig’s rates are no longer the most attractive in the land of online savings accounts. The spectacled Pig is merely average.

I didn’t care much for Mitt Romney’s speech yesterday announcing his presidential bid. It struck me as vintage Romney, by which I mean it resembled a somewhat tin-eared consultant’s idea of the kind of political speech right-wing primary voters want to hear. (Okay, now the anti-European boilerplate: “The President seems to take his inspiration not from the small towns and villages of New Hampshire but from the capitals of Europe.” Now the hyperbole: “We are only inches away from ceasing to be a free market economy.”  Now the completely non-specific promises to cut spending: “I will cap federal spending at 20% or less of the GDP and finally, finally balance the budget.” Now the clunky one-liner: “You know, if you want to create jobs, it helps to have had a job.” Now wait for the applause …)
Stuart Grant, one of the name partners of the law firm Grant & Eisenhofer, is mad.

Do you have a question about an upcoming trip? Looking for information on where to go? You’ve come to the right place. For our regular Q&A column, which appears both on this blog and in our print section, we want your questions about travel. Post them below, or e-mail them to travmail@nytimes.com. (A tip: be specific, but not too specific. And ask ahead of time — if you are hoping to travel next week, it’s probably too late.)

More than two years have passed since the big debate over the effect of budget deficits on interest rates in a liquidity trap. The original argument of the anti-stimulus types was that large-scale government borrowing would drive up interest rates even in the face of high unemployment, and that this would hurt the economy. At that time the argument was framed in terms of simple crowding out, not solvency. And I argued that the whole thing represented a failure to understand basic macroeconomics.
As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, on Thursday Qatar forcibly deported a Libyan woman whose mistreatment by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi made her a symbol of its brutality.

From Goldman Sachs, an estimate of the federal budget impact on growth. The gray line shows the direct impact, the blue line includes the induced "multiplier" effects. Notice that this shows the rate of change, not the level effects. I explained the difference a while back.

By Republican tradition, it should be Mitt Romney’s turn as the nominee. The party has a long history of picking a politician who has paid his dues on the campaign trail — losing, learning lessons and then running again. But Mr. Romney’s potential Republican challengers have no intention of letting him anoint himself the party’s nominee. That fact was made starkly clear on Thursday by sharp-edged comments from Sarah Palin and Rudolph W. Giuliani — both of whom are still mulling presidential runs — even as Mr. Romney was making his candidacy official. Read more »

It’s big news when the Swedish import Johan Lindeberg, former C.E.O. of Diesel and creator of the popular J. Lindeberg label, celebrates a new project. Five years ago, the first edition of “The Maturing of America,” a report undertaken by the National Association of Area Agencies on Aging with groups representing local governments and city planners, found that most communities hadn’t begun to plan for the tidal shifts of the coming years. The proportion of people older than 65 is expected to swell from 13 percent of the nation’s population today to nearly 20 percent by 2030.
