I remember the day I reached my limit with the retail coffee and espresso business that my husband and I started in 2003. When we started our little food service venture, it was supposed to be a fun project that would eventually run itself and act as an additional source of income for our household. But after three years, two locations and countless hours, it became evident that our plan was easier said than done.

When the city of New York built a band shell near the southern end of Tompkins Square Park in 1966, it was quickly embraced by people who began using it for concerts, rallies and poetry readings. Twenty-five years later, after police and protesters battled during a Memorial Day concert in the park, city officials closed it for renovations that lasted more than a year and included the destruction of the band shell.

Need to find a certain open window on your desktop — but you cannot fully see it in the clutter of other open windows on the screen? Both Windows 7 and Mac OS X include features that help you focus quickly on the one window you need to find.

When Based in Berlin, an art festival running June 8 to July 24 at a handful of venues around the city, was first announced at the end of last year, it was dubbed a Leistungsschau — “an exhibit of achievement” — for young Berlin artists, complete with a citywide open call. The city had allotted about 1.4 million euros (about $2 million) to the exhibition.

The summer collector-car season is off to a clutch-dropping burnout of a start. At a Mecum auction in Indianapolis two weeks ago, $50 million in muscle cars changed hands. While there won’t be any Hemi ‘Cudas ripping up the pristine lawns at the Greenwich Concours d’Élégance this weekend, plenty of Chrysler Hemi power and other examples of Detroit V-8 muscle will be present, as the concours prominently features postwar European cars with American engines.

Not an ounce of energy has drained from “Back in the Days,” Jamel Shabazz‘s photo chronicle of the early days of hip-hop style, since it was published in 2001. They sold 35,000 copies the first time.)

8 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS: ROAD TO THE SHOWDOWN After the destruction of the Ady Gil and the detainment of its captain, Pete Bethune, in a Tokyo prison last season, the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, under the leadership of Capt. Paul Watson, returns to the Antarctic to keep Japanese whaling ships in its sights. The latest campaign is Operation No Compromises, with a mission to end whaling once and for all. This hourlong special looks back at memorable moments from Season 3, before the 9 p.m. premiere of Season 4, in which the Sea Shepherds (above, a crew member) head south with a new vessel, the Gojira, in its fleet and discover two Japanese harpoon ships that have yet to kill a whale. 5 P.M. An article on May 27 about the capture of Ratko Mladic, the fugitive former Bosnian Serb general accused of responsibility for some of the worst atrocities committed during the 1990's Balkans conflict, misstated the number of children killed among the 10,000 victims of the siege of Sarajevo. It is 1,500, not 3,500.

QUIGG--Philip W.,died May 23, at age 90. Philip was a writer and editor in the fields of international politics and environmental issues. He was managing editor of Foreign Affairs magazine for 15 years.

The White House counsel, Robert F. Bauer, will return to private practice at the end of June and resume his role as lawyer for the Democratic Party and Mr. Obama's re-election campaign, President Obama announced on Thursday. Mr. Bauer will replaced by the deputy presidential counsel, Kathryn Ruemmler. ''Bob was a critical member of the White House team,'' Mr. Obama said in a statement. ''He has exceptional judgment, wisdom and intellect, and he will continue to be one of my close advisers.''

It is often said that teams and players can never really be complete without winning a championship. The participants in this year's N.B.A. finals would know. The Dallas Mavericks are looking to win their first title in 30 years of existence, a drought that their owner, Mark Cuban, has spent 11 seasons desperately trying to end. Since the 2001 season, only the Knicks have spent more on salaries than Cuban's Mavericks. Some $911,844,217 later, Cuban has two finals appearances and no titles - but that could all change this month.

JOLTIN--Lillian, 95, passed away on Tuesday, May 31, 2011 in Richmond, VA. Formerly of Forest Hills, NY, she is survived by her nieces, Judith Kowler (Dan), and Carol Ziff (Robert) and their families. A graveside service will be held at the Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY, on Friday, June 3, at 11:30am.

The artist Richard Serra, whose massive steel sculptures have been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and elsewhere around the world, has installed his first public artwork in the Middle East, in a sculpture park under construction in Doha, Qatar, adjacent to the Museum of Islamic Art, designed by I.M. Pei. Mr. Serra's sculpture is nearly 80 feet tall and has three vertical openings that frame views of Mr. Pei's building. The effect ''actually brings the museum right into the sculpture,'' Mr. Serra said. When the park is completed later this year the sculpture will stand on the end of a pier jutting into Doha Bay. Qatar is engaged in something of a museum arms race with the nearby emirate of Abu Dhabi. Asked if he had received any commissions for the new Guggenheim museum there, Mr. Serra, who has eight works on permanent display at the Guggenheim Bilbao, said, ''Not as of yet.''

The New York City Opera has suffered a staff departure at a critical time. Edward C. Yim, the director of artistic planning, is resigning to serve as a consultant at the New York Philharmonic. The financially strapped opera company announced two weeks ago that it was leaving its Lincoln Center home to save money, without saying where it was going or what operas it would perform for the season starting in October. Mr. Yim said he was ''hugely supportive'' of City Opera and George Steel, its general manager and artistic director, and that his departure had ''nothing to do with any doubt that the company is going to reinvent itself and thrive.'' Mr. Yim was one of several key figures brought in by Mr. Steel, who was named to take over the company in 2009. Mr. Steel called Mr. Yim a ''sensational colleague'' and wished him success. He did provide any information about a successor.

If the recent spinoff of the ''Sweet Valley High'' young-adult series wasn't enough for nostalgic fans, there is another revival in the works. St. Martin's Press said on Thursday that it would publish a follow-up to ''Sweet Valley Confidential,'' the novel by Francine Pascal that caught up with Elizabeth and Jessica Wakefield in their 20s and landed on the best-seller list in April. The new follow-up, tentatively titled ''The Sweet Life,'' will be published as a digital-only serial beginning next spring. It will be released in monthly installments published online, mimicking the original cliff-hanger form of the original series. St. Martin's expects that the installments, which will run approximately 20,000 words each, will especially be read on mobile phones. ''It's really e-mass market,'' said Dan Weiss, the publisher at large at St. Martin's, part of Macmillan.

Hans Keilson, a German-born psychoanalyst who won literary fame at the very end of his long life when two of his long-forgotten works of fiction, set in Nazi-occupied Europe, were republished to great acclaim, died on Tuesday in Hilversum, the Netherlands. He was 101. His death was announced by his longtime German publisher, S. Fischer Verlag.

An article on Thursday about an unusual alliance between community and civil rights groups and mortgage lenders in opposition to proposed tighter regulations on home mortgage loans misspelled the surname of a United States Senator from North Carolina who signed a letter opposing the regulations. She is Kay R. Hagan, not Hagen.

JONES--Gordon L.,Jr. A former director and senior executive of Hearst Corporation, died April 20, 2011, at home in New Canaan, CT., after a long illness. He was 85. Jones, who retired from Hearst Corporation in 1995 and served on the Corporation's Board of Directors beginning in 1982, joined Hearst in 1979 and was instrumental in building Hearst's book and business publishing businesses. Most recently, he was a vice president of Hearst Corporation and group head of Hearst Books/Business Publishing. During his tenure, Hearst acquired William Morrow & Company and added it to Avon and Hearst Books to significantly expand its book-publishing activities. After his retirement, Jones served as a consultant to Hearst Corporation. "Gordon was a very important participant in the dramatic growth of Hearst Corporation during the 1980s and 1990s," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. "He was instrumental in building what today are our business media operations. We will indeed miss Gordon." Jones also played a role in the acquisition, from Cox Enterprises, of United Technical Publishing Co., a portfolio of trade publications, technical manuals and marketing data. Diversion magazine and its related activities were also acquired and added to the Group in the mid-1980s. Prior to Hearst, Jones was president of McGraw-Hill Publications Company. During his more than 26 years with McGraw-Hill, he served in numerous positions, including publisher of Electronics magazine; general manager, new products, for BusinessWeek; and senior vice president-marketing of McGraw-Hill Publications. From 1948 to 1950, Jones played professional baseball for the Cleveland Indians. A native of Los Angeles, he received his bachelor's from the University of Southern California. He is survived by his wife, the former Marilyn Holter, and their five children and 14 grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, June 4, 2011, at 11am, at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Jones' name to The ALS Association or the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

SCHEUER--Bernard I.,DDS, passed away on May 31, 2011 at 90 at his home in Hackensack, NJ. Born on March 16, 1921 in Brooklyn. Tickets to the Broadway musical ''Sister Act'' usually top out at $200 for the best orchestra seats, but they'll zoom to $10,000 for the June 23 performance - because the price includes a photo shoot with President Obama, whose re-election campaign has chosen the production for his first major Broadway fundraiser for the 2012 cycle. One of the musical's lead producers, the actress Whoopi Goldberg, who starred in the original ''Sister Act'' movies, is a political supporter of Mr. Obama's and will host the evening's events at the Broadway Theater. Mr. Obama drew solid financial support from many Broadway producers and other theater executives in 2008, even during the Democratic primaries when he was running against a hometown candidate, then-Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. And he cast a spotlight on Broadway early in his presidency by flying to New York with his wife Michelle for a date night that included the revival of ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' in 2009; Mrs. Obama and the couple's daughters subsequently saw the Broadway musicals ''Memphis'' and ''The Addams Family.''

Gates said Thursday. A book review on Tuesday of ''Shadows Bright as Glass,'' by Amy Ellis Nutt, about Jon Sarkin, a chiropractor who became an artist after a brain operation that led to a major stroke, misstated the timing of the births of Dr. Sarkin's three children. Two of them were born after his stroke, not all of them. And the article incorrectly described the narrative viewpoint of the book. It is told from the perspective of Dr. Sarkin and his wife, not from his perspective alone.

MEKAS--Adolfas. The entire Bard College community mourns the passing of Adolfas Mekas, beloved long-time faculty member and founder of Bard's film department. With his brother Jonas he founded the seminal magazine "Film Culture," as well as the Filmmakers' Cooperative. Mekas was associated with the Fluxus art movement, and also made several short films that showed his essentially comic and anarchic spirit, culminating in the feature "Hallelujah the Hills," in 1963, which played at the Cannes Film Festival that year, is now considered a classic of American film, and established his reputation as a key member of the New American Cinema of the 1960s. Mekas taught at Bard from 1971 until his retirement from active teaching in 2004, when he received the Bardian Award. From 1983 to 1989, he was also the director of the Milton Avery Graduate School of the Arts. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Pola Chapelle, their son, Sean, and his entire extended family. He touched many Bard students with his wit, charm, and vision. He will be sorely missed. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair

Advocacy groups are condemning a new Rihanna video that depicts the singer exacting violent revenge on a man who sexually assaulted her. They have called on the television network BET to stop showing the video, saying it sends a dangerous message to real-life assault victims. In the opening of the video for her song ''Man Down,'' Rihanna is seen shooting and killing a man in a train station, and a later scene reveals that the man once assaulted her in a back alley. Rihanna sings in the song that she ''just shot a man dead'' and has ''never been so proud,'' and in messages posted on her Twitter account to alert fans to the video, the singer warned other women that ''sometimes our innocence can cause us to be naive.'' She added, ''We always think it could NEVER be us, but in reality, it can happen to ANY of us!''

BECKER--Dr. Norwin H.,a renowned pathologist, who served Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine for nearly half a century, died on May 30 at his home in New City, New York. He was 81. A gifted clinician, educator, and researcher, Dr. Becker was Professor and head of anatomical pathology. He loved music as much as science, and may best be remembered for his brilliance, his sense of humor, his caring, and his compassion for others. The Department of Pathology extends heartfelt condolences to his wife, Isabel, and his entire family.

As a consultant for an expert network, Winifred Jiau stood at the nexus of a scheme to leak the valuable secrets of companies to hedge funds for a sizable profit, a federal prosecutor said Thursday during opening statements at her trial on insider trading charges. She wheedled inside information from sources she referred to in code as ''cooks,'' passed their ''recipes,'' or tips on to her hedge fund clients, then waited for the ''sugar,'' or money, the prosecutor, David Leibowitz, told a jury in a packed United States District Court room in Lower Manhattan.

PARIS -- Nine years ago, Anne Mansouret dissuaded her daughter from filing a legal complaint for attempted rape against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a prominent member of the Socialist Party in France and the former husband of one of her best friends. But now she is speaking out about what happened and what other Socialist leaders knew. And some Socialists -- deeply embarrassed by the accusations against the wealthy man who was likely to be their presidential candidate next year -- have called for her expulsion from the party.

YALOW--Rosalyn, PhD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Rosalyn Yalow, PhD, Distinguished Service Professor at Mount Sinai School of Medicine and recipient of the 1977 Nobel Prize. She was the second woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Dr. Yalow was the first physics major at Hunter College and later became the sole woman at the University of Illinois College of Engineering, earning both her master's and PhD degrees there. She was an investigator at the Radioisotope Unit at the Bronx VA Hospital, a Mount Sinai affiliate, from 1947 until 1980, and she served as Senior Medical Investigator there starting in 1972. In 1968, she was also appointed Research Professor in the Department of Medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital and later she became the Solomon Berson Distinguished Professor at Large, a position she held until her death. Together with Solomon Berson, MD, who was also an outstanding clinician-scientist at Mount Sinai, Dr. Yalow postulated the presence of, and went on to demonstrate, insulin-binding antibodies in insulin-treated patients. The collaborators then revolutionized medical science, especially endocrinology and metabolism, by developing the radioimmunoassay in 1959, first of insulin and later of growth hormone, ACTH, parathormone, and gastrin. It is this body of work that led to the Nobel Prize. Dr. Berson died in 1972. During her distinguished career, Dr. Yalow also received many other honors, including the AMA Scientific Achievement Award, the Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research, and the National Medal of Science. The Mount Sinai community extends its condolences to Dr. Yalow's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz, Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs at The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Either Jane Lynch or her snide alter ego, Sue Sylvester of ''Glee,'' will host this year's Prime Time Emmy Awards, the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences said Thursday. The Sept. 18 telecast will be shown on Fox, the network of ''Glee,'' which delights in the Sue Sylvester character, a cheerleading coach who relentlessly bullies students and other teachers and coaches. Everywhere Ms. Lynch appears these days she seems to channel Sylvester, and although it is unclear whether she will do so at the Emmys, she dropped a hint to that effect, saying in a statement, ''I'm looking forward to singing, dancing and sporting my finest tracksuit.''

A hacker group calling itself LulzSec claimed responsibility on Thursday for breaking into a Sony Web site and stealing personal information of about 52,000 customers. The group, which claimed this week to have hacked sites belonging to PBS, said it had used a ''simple'' attack on a ''primitive'' security hole that gave it full access to the Sony Pictures internal database.

In a Manhattan courtroom last week, federal prosecutors played for a jury a secretly recorded telephone conversation between two Wall Street traders exchanging stock tips. Rafael Nadal looks to win his sixth French Open Sunday as he faces his longtime friend and rival Roger Federer in the finals of the French Open. Nadal has beaten Federer four times here at Roland Garros, in the semifinals in ’05, and in consecutive finals in ’06, ’07, and ’08. Federer won here two years ago, defeating the only man to ever beat Nadal at Roland Garros, Robin Soderling, in the final. Federer advanced to the final with his upset win on Friday over Novak Djokovic, in a stirring match that will be remembered for its high level of play.

ANAHEIM, Calif. — On a sun-splashed June afternoon in Southern California, it felt like early March in Florida for Phil Hughes. His second spring training continued Saturday, when he threw 22 pitches to hitters from the mound at Angel Stadium, where he moved ever closer to an eventual return. Hughes remains at least a month away, according to Manager Joe Girardi, but his progress has allowed him to start looking ahead.

Justin Gillis is taking reader questions on the potential effects of climate change on the global food supply and will respond this week on the Green blog.

On a warming planet, humanity faces a great challenge in feeding itself at reasonable cost in the coming century, as I explain in Sunday’s paper. An issue I raise only in passing in the article is that agriculture itself is one of the earth’s greatest environmental threats.

My Sunday column perhaps contains a hint of bile: it reflects my distress at where the economic debate in this country is going, and at the rising levels of economic inequality. I’m afraid that efforts to address the budget mess — a serious challenge, but a medium- to long-term one — will aggravate the inequality and reduce opportunity in this country. In short, I worry that Republican or Tea Party budget policies will make America look more like…well, that’s the point of the column.

Our current economic discourse is pervaded by fatalism. Leave aside the people who insist that somehow Obama has destroyed capitalist incentives by passing Mitt Romney’s health care plan and threatening to raise tax rates to Clinton-era levels. 8 P.M. (HBO) KNIGHT AND DAY (2010) Cameron Diaz plays June Havens, a collection ''of alternately appealing and exasperating traits,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''thrown together to satisfy market research data suggesting that audiences go for women who are tough but not aggressive, flaky but not nuts, sexy but not actually having sex, and willing to fall for a certain kind of guy without entirely losing their heads.'' Tom Cruise is that guy: Roy Miller, a C.I.A. superassassin who collides with June at the airport in Wichita, Kan. The result is a cross-country action-comedy in which Ms. Diaz and Mr. Cruise, above, portray ''a pair of hastily sketched cartoon characters hurtling from plane crash to car chase to further car, helicopter and motorcycle chases, one involving stampeding bulls.'' Still, Mr. Scott added, ''It is just possible that 'Knight and Day' will earn some admiration because it is not a sequel or a spinoff and employs two stars who refuse to act like or resemble teenagers.'' 8 P.M. DRAPER--Jackman Strawn. Actor, writer, director Jackman Strawn Draper, passed away May 11, surrounded by family and friends after bravely living his last three years with ALS/Lou Gehrig's. Donations may be made to the ALS Assoc of Greater NY www.als-ny.org.

TOZZI--Giorgio. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of bass Giorgio Tozzi, one of the most versatile principal artists of the last century. In his 20 years with the company beginning in 1955, he sang leading roles in all parts of the repertory German, French, Italian, and Russian for a total of 528 performances. In addition to his beautiful voice and distinguished artistry, we will remember him for his consummate professionalism and exceptional popularity within the company. We offer our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

New York City Opera, as part of its resuscitation plan, will lay off 11 of its 48 administrative employees and eliminate four open positions, according to a company memorandum obtained on Friday. The layoffs are part of a reorganization approved at a May 19 board meeting when the company formally decided to leave its home, the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The memorandum did not identify the jobs and City Opera officials had no comment. On Thursday the director of artistic planning, Edward C. Yim, said he was leaving, without a replacement being named. City Opera said the laid-off workers could receive up to eight weeks' severance pay and medical coverage through July. In addition, one full-time job will be downgraded to part time. The opera said two weeks ago that it would slash its budget, which was $31 million this season, but has not revealed what it expects to spend or where it will perform.

When the city of New York built a band shell near the southern end of Tompkins Square Park in 1966, it was quickly embraced by people who began using it for concerts, rallies and poetry readings. Twenty-five years later, after police and protesters battled during a Memorial Day concert in the park, city officials closed it for renovations that lasted more than a year and included the destruction of the band shell. The band shell was never rebuilt.

Rihanna defended the video for her song ''Man Down'' on Thursday night during a telephone interview on the BET program ''106 & Park,'' saying that she did not intend to cause controversy but wanted to create ''art with a message.'' The video, which has been shown on BET, depicts Rihanna shooting and killing a man who is revealed to have sexually assaulted her. It has been criticized by advocacy groups including the Parents Television Council, which have said that the video sends a dangerous message to assault victims and have called on BET to stop playing it.

KREMENEZKY--John Paul, 88, passed peacefully at home surrounded by loving family on June 1. Beloved husband of 50 years of Margret (nee Meisegades). Adored father of Susan (Dominick Silvestri), Tina (Robert Smith) and Karen (Andrew Koines). Dear grandfather of Sophie, Alexander, Dominika, Julia and Erika. Born in Vienna, Austria, he proudly served during WWII with the Jewish brigade in North Africa and Italy, and later enjoyed a successful career in real estate. He will be remembered as a wonderfully sweet, decent and fine gentleman. After a private burial Friday, June 3, the family will greet friends at home in Mamaroneck between 5:00-9:00pm.

An article in some editions on May 28 about the Mets' 6-4 loss to Philadelphia a day earlier misstated the circumstances of the play that led to the Phillies' go-ahead run in the ninth inning. A ground ball by Domonic Brown went under the glove of Mets first baseman Daniel Murphy to drive in the run; Murphy was not charged with an error by the official scorer. The article also misstated the surname of a Mets third baseman in some editions. He is Justin Turner, not Tuner.

In the Talk interview in the Magazine this weekend, Barbara Sinatra, Frank Sinatra's fourth wife, disputes an account by Gay Talese in a 1966 Esquire article, in which he described Sinatra's toupees and the woman who cared for them. In taking issue with those details, Barbara Sinatra said her husband always employed men to care for his hair, and added, ''Right there you know that's a lie.'' In fairness, that characterization should not have been included in the interview without any corroboration or any response from Mr. Talese. He stands by his original account.

Paul Theroux has described his onetime mentor, the Nobel laureate V. S. Naipaul, as ''a grouch, a skinflint, tantrum-prone, with race on the brain.'' Mr. Theroux and Mr. Naipaul may have reconciled at a literary festival in Britain this week, but other critics are using new derogatory adjectives -- like ''arrogant'' and ''sexist'' -- to describe Mr. Naipaul after he declared that no female writer was his literary equal. In an interview at the Royal Geographic Society on Tuesday, Mr. Naipaul, 78, derided Jane Austen, saying he ''couldn't possibly share her sentimental ambitions, her sentimental sense of the world,'' according to the Guardian. The reason was that ''inevitably for a woman, she is not a complete master of a house, so that comes over in her writing too.'' He claimed that after reading a couple of paragraphs he could instantly discern whether the writer was a woman or man.

A chart on May 23 with an article about winners of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes who have faced each other in the Belmont Stakes misstated the year in which the Derby winner Cannonade met the Preakness winner Little Current. It was 1974, not 1973. (In 1973, Secretariat won the Triple Crown.)

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, facing what it calls a ''number of daunting, ongoing budgetary challenges,'' has decided to raise its suggested admission fee to $25, from $20, where it has been set for the last five years. The change takes effect July 1. -The move, said Thomas P. Campbell, the museum's director, was made because income from the Met's $2.3 billion endowment has flattened as the economy has continued to sputter and because the average amount paid by visitors - who can decide to contribute as little as a penny if they want - has been lower recently. ''Since the average cost to the museum of each visitor is $40 we believe it is fair, and above all necessary, to increase recommended admission levels at this time,'' Mr. Campbell said in a statement.

An article in some copies on Wednesday about the Miami Heat's victory over Dallas in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals misstated the half in which the Mavericks' Jason Terry scored his 12 points. It was in the first half, not the second.
An essay this weekend on Page 11, about crackpot conspiracy theories, misspells the given name of the French president. It is Nicolas Sarkozy, not Nicholas.

Yesterday's column on the weak historical relationship between the unemployment rate and presidential performance generated a mostly favorable reaction. But I also got a few replies wondering how to reconcile these findings against the claims, made with some frequency by political scientists, that presidential elections can be forecast with pinpoint accuracy provided that you know the economic fundamentals. Might it be that the unemployment rate is the ''wrong'' variable? It has a couple of flaws. It tends to be more a lagging than a leading indicator. It affects a relatively small number of voters (although underemployment is another matter). There is ample room to critique the way that it is calculated, such as by excluding ''discouraged workers'' from the calculation, and it's subject to reasonably large measurement errors.

Mark Pierpont used to be an important figure in the evangelical Christian effort to help “cure” gay people of their homosexual desires. He started out just printing up tracts and handing them out in gay bars, but his ministry grew over time, and eventually he was traveling the world and speaking to crowds that sometimes numbered in the thousands. There was just one problem. Mark Pierpont himself was gay. He continued to feel sexual desires toward other men and was constantly engaged in an effort to suppress them. In the documentary film “Protagonist,” Pierpont movingly describes his inner conflict, saying that he sometimes felt an almost physical revulsion at his own desires and would then think: “Good. I hate this.  I hate sin, just like God hates sin.”

One of the year’s best-reviewed wide-release movies, “X-Men: First Class,” took in a solid $56 million at the North American box office over the weekend — easily enough for No. 1 and to help reboot a sagging franchise. Facing audience and critical rebellion over the last two “X-Men” installments, Tom Rothman, co-chairman of 20th Century Fox, took creative risks with “First Class” that appeared to pay off, including casting a cadre of untested young actors and approving a screenplay that includes Russian, French, German and Spanish dialogue — highly unusual for a summer blockbuster. In partial release overseas, the film took in an additional $64 million. “The Hangover Part II,” the raunchy buddy comedy from Warner Brothers, was second with an estimated $32.4 million for a two-week total of $187 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Kung Fu Panda 2” (DreamWorks Animation via Paramount) was third with about $24.3 million, sending its two-week total past $100 million. “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” showed continued life in fourth place, taking in about $18 million for a three-week total of $190.3 million. The crude comedy “Bridesmaids” (Universal) was fifth with about $12 million for a four-week total of $107.3 million.

THINK of New Orleans, and you just might think of jazz. Which is what ''Treme,'' HBO's drama about loss and renewal post-Katrina, built its reputation on in its inaugural season, with stories about struggling musicians and a radio D.J., and lengthy interludes showcasing some of the city's performers. But increasingly cuisine has ventured out of the background, with pivotal scenes set in coffee shops and cafes, where plates run over with po' boys, gumbo and beignets.

FISCHER--Sadie, 95, passed away on June 3, 2011. Beloved mother of Rae-Ann, cherished cousin, aunt and friend. She will always be remembered for her wisdom, understanding, style and elegance.

WINOKUR--Virginia Cudahy, wife to Joseph Winokur, aunt to six of her sisters children, died peacefully Friday, June 3 of complications of Parkinson's. She fought the disease for several years uncomplainingly. It was my privilege as her husband to have known her and loved her for 43 years. For me and for everyone who knew her, her memory will ring like crystal. Warm, intelligent, wise, loving, funny and sweet wife-we will miss you beyond words. A memorial service and its location will be published in The New York Times as soon as it can be arranged.

Rafting outfitters in the West expect higher water and a longer river-running season because of above-average snowpack and a cool, wet spring. In Idaho's Sawtooth Mountains, little has melted above 6,000 feet yet, said Steve Lentz, owner of Far and Away Adventures, who expects later and more sustained melting to feed the Middle Fork of the Salmon River. Given the faster water, Far and Away is introducing shorter two- and three-night trips there.
AIN--Dorothy. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. David J. Nathan Parnas

ON campuses in the South, camouflage is replacing Kelly green as the prepster's color of choice. K. Cooper Ray, the blogger and sometime designer based in Charleston, S.C., noticed how the local dandies were bow-tied one minute, and in camo, to go duck hunting the next. An accessories collection Mr. Ray designed for Brooks Brothers capitalizes on the trend with this reversible bow tie: a green camouflage print with a pink repp stripe. The rustic fops who would wear it call themselves ''Prep-necks.'' $65. brooksbrothers.com. BRUCE PASK

STOCKHOLMERS revel in the long days of summer when the sun rises as early as 3:30 a.m. and doesn't set until after 10 p.m. Many locals escape to their country houses, but those who remain in the city spend as much time as possible outdoors -- an easy feat since water and parkland make up almost two-thirds of Stockholm. Situated on the Baltic at the mouth of Lake Malaren, Stockholm is built on 14 islands connected by bridges. On sunny days, waterside bars and cafes are packed with people wolfing down summer favorites like herring (served in a variety of ways) and toast Skagen (shrimp in mayonnaise with lemon and dill served with rye bread). Everywhere, visitors will find establishments -- new and venerable -- celebrating Nordic design, cuisine and culture. Friday

BRAKA--Pauline, 91, passed away peacefully on May 30. Daughter of the late Isaac and Sarina Perez. She is survived by her loving husband, David. They were married for 75 years this May 7. Devoted mother of, Jeannette Bogart (Fred), Ivor Braka (Robin) and Robert Braka (Linda). Treasured by her eight grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. She is survived by her sister, Tilda Husney and her brother, Edward Perez. Pauline resided many years in New York City before permanently moving to Aventura, Florida. Her passions included the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Central Park, music and flowers. As a child her family were members of Shearith Israel - Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue and during her lifetime she continued to support the Synagogue. Pauline's philanthropy extended not only to Hadassah but along with her husband David they were Founders of the ISEF Foundation and the Edmond J. Safra Synagogue of Aventura, Florida. She was an extraordinarily beautiful woman, whose grace and elegance will be missed by all who knew her.

THE NEWS The Chinese economy showed signs of slowing after two years of torrid growth, as manufacturers' backlogs shortened and auto sales unexpectedly stalled. BEHIND THE NEWS Beijing, worried about inflation, has been tapping the monetary-policy brakes in recent months, so a little slowdown could be seen as a good thing. But any loss of momentum in the world economy poses a danger to Europe and the United States, where jobs, not prices, are the main concern. Some analysts say China may not be able to resume such rapid growth once inflation is tamed.

THROPE--Zeena Sugarman, 84. Beloved wife of Irwin M. Thrope for 61 years and business partner in Sugarman & Thrope, PC (CPAs) for many years, proud mother of David (Arlene), Jeff (Gail) and Bess Goldring (Stuart), adoring grandmother of Peter, Glenn, Jonathan, Jason, Emily and Lily Thrope, Michelle, Douglas, Richard and Laura Goldring, graduate of CCNY (Baruch) Class of 1947. Funeral Services will be held on Thursday, June 2, 2011 at 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. Burial will follow at Old Montefiore Cemetery.

AQUINO--Maite. The lawyers and staff of Sullivan & Cromwell LLP mourn the loss of our partner Maite Aquino. Maite was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009 and died in New York, NY on June 4. She was 42 years old. We will miss her very much. Her husband, Nick Rudenstine, and her beautiful daughters, Ines and Aurelia, will always be members of our family. Maite spent her entire career at Sullivan & Cromwell, beginning as a summer associate in 1993 and joining the firm as a first year associate in 1994 following her graduation from New York University School of Law. She was elected to the partnership in the Fall of 2002. A leading member of our litigation group, she built a remarkable career, spanning from complex disputes involving antitrust claims to bet-the-company intellectual property trials. In the wake of the recent financial crisis, Maite, a recognized star in securities litigation, carved a unique practice representing international financial institutions facing global scrutiny before the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Department of Justice, the Financial Services Authority and the United States Congress. Maite's ability to see the big-picture and navigate through complex, interlocking investigations, regulatory proceedings and related civil litigation led to superlatives from dedicated clients who described her in industry review publications as a "terrific, tireless lawyer who gets right to the heart of an issue" with her "excellent instincts and persuasive arguments." Maite also devoted thousands of hours to pro bono service to persons in need, receiving a Thurgood Marshall Award for her substantial contributions of time and legal expertise. We are blessed to have shared the past eighteen years with Maite. A consummate lawyer, to us, she has been so very much more. A loyal and giving friend, a trailblazer, a touchstone, a role model and a mentor, she endowed us with her style, her grace, her compassion and her wit. We share our profound loss with the many and diverse communities that loved and respected her.
INFAMOUS PLAYERS A Tale of Movies, the Mob (and Sex)

PHOTOGRAPHY gave Jamel Shabazz direction in life -- straight to the young men and women he saw every day in parks, on stoops and on streets. When he started in the mid-1970s in Brooklyn's Red Hook projects, his camera led him to what would become a remarkable chronicle of the early years of hip-hop style, complete with swaggering B-boys rocking shell-toe Adidas sneakers, fuzzy Kangol caps and thick black Cazal eyeglasses. Many of those iconic images are included in ''Back in the Days Remix,'' the 10th anniversary edition of the book that earned him widespread notice. ''It started for fun, but progressed into making people feel good about themselves,'' Mr. Shabazz said of his portraiture. ''I'd approach them and say 'Excuse me, brother. My name is Jamel Shabazz and I'm a photographer. When I see you, I see greatness. I see the future.' '' He saw himself as a ''street teacher,'' offering insights from his life, which took him from graffiti to the military and later to a career as a corrections officer. To him, his pictures are a diary of those conversations -- some fleeting, others continuing.

IRVINE--Keith. Scottish-born interior designer Keith Irvine, 82, died May 31st. He is survived by wife Chippy, daughters Emma, Jassy and grandchild Caleigh. A private memorial celebration will take place June 12th.

The 36 Hours column on May 15, about San Francisco, misstated the location there of the original Burning Man arts festival. It is Baker Beach, not Ocean Beach. The column also misstated the merchandise carried by Sprout San Francisco, a children's boutique on Union Street. It carries natural and organic clothing, toys, furniture and books; it does not carry only locally manufactured, and recycled, plastic toys.

AQUINO--Maite, 42, of Manhattan and Quogue, New York, at home on June 4, 2011, of complications after a long and brave fight against breast cancer. She will be missed profoundly by all who were fortunate enough to share her life. Survived by her devoted husband, Nicholas Rudenstine; her two beautiful and cherished girls, Ines and Aurelia; her beloved parents, Armando and Raquel Aquino; her loving sister Theresa Aquino and brother-in-law Joshua Ballinger; and many aunts, uncles, cousins, nephews, nieces, friends and colleagues. Brought up amid a large, extended family on Staten Island, Maite graduated from SUNY Binghamton in 1991 before receiving her law degree from New York University School of Law in 1994. Following graduation from law school, Maite joined Sullivan & Cromwell, and was elected to the partnership in 2002 and became a partner of the firm on January 1, 2003. Maite was a member of the firm's litigation group, where she played a leading role in representing many of the firm's financial institution clients. She was an accomplished and gifted lawyer, recognized as a leading practitioner in her field, and was involved in many of the most significant corporate and securities cases of the past 15 years. Although Maite's personal and professional accomplishments were always impressive, her greatest impact on those around her came from her personal qualities. She was deeply devoted to her family and her friends and she brought to those relationships a unique combination of qualities-gentle, strong, determined, and loving. She was graceful and elegant but always relaxed and approachable. She wore her beauty easily, a beauty that was present to her last day, and she had a keen intellect, an unusually generous heart, and a smile and laugh that attracted everyone. She read widely and traveled frequently but she was, at heart, a local New Yorker who loved her home town and her family around her. Maite's daughters Ines and Aurelia were the greatest joy of her life and she fought with fierce courage and tremendous grace for each and every day that she was blessed to be with them. There will be a private funeral service for family members. A memorial will be held in the near future, details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to breast cancer research that is relevant to the cause of Maite's death, and details on those programs will also be released shortly.
ABRAMS--Lew (Died 6/06) Dad/m, we love you and miss you so. Jessa, Katie, Elly

BARASCH--Marvin. The Silver's send their fond wishes and love to the family of Marvin Barasch. Marvin's humor and fun loving nature will make us smile through eternity. Our relationship with Phyllis has been life changing. She is a role model for all. Our sincere condolences.

The Chess column last Sunday, about Boris Gelfand's winning the World Championship Candidates Matches to become the challenger for the World Chess Championship, misstated the year in which he first qualified for the matches to select a challenger. It was 1990, not 1993.

The cover article on May 22, about a drive along the music trail known as the Crooked Road in Virginia, misspelled the name of a town on the trail. It is Abingdon, as shown on the map and referred to elsewhere in the piece, not Abington. A picture caption with the article misstated the location of another town on the trail, Mouth of Wilson. It is in southwestern Virginia, not northern Virginia. The article also misstated the location of a Carroll County shooting in 1912 that people still talk about. It was in the county courthouse, not the jail.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports for May 27 to June 2. 1. BADMINTON DRESS CODE FOR WOMEN CRITICIZED AS SEXIST The Badminton World Federation says women playing at the elite level must wear dresses or skirts to create a more ''attractive presentation.''

SUZANNAH WAINHOUSE makes sense of the world through her hands, linking the visual with the tactile. She uses them to carve brass and silver into intricate jewelry worn by the likes of Heidi Klum and to sculpture thick impastos of paint on canvas. ''I identify and respond to a very untrained and primitive eye,'' said Ms. Wainhouse, a Brooklyn-based artist. Indeed, her rough-hewn bracelets and amulets are more akin to mystical talismans than decorative ornaments. But then again, what urban warrior could not use a lucky charm? Suzannah Wainhouse bracelets, starting at $600, will be at Barneys New York later this month. For her paintings, e-mail suzannahwainhouse@gmail.com. KAVITHA SURANA

I GREW up on a 100-acre farm in Michigan with almost every farm animal imaginable, including horses, peacocks, pigs, sheep and chickens. At age 6 or 7, I'd watch my father butcher the cows and I'd help pick the feathers off the chickens after they were slaughtered. I wouldn't have the stomach for that today. I demonstrated management skills early. At 13, I got a job detasseling corn on another farm. The next year, I became a team leader over six other teenagers, and at 15 I was appointed supervisor of a group of 40 other students.

PRIVITERE--Louis Philip, 85, passed away peacefully at home on May 22, 2011 after a brief, valiant battle with lung cancer. He was a loving and devoted husband, father, grandfather and loyal friend and believed in living life to the fullest with no regrets. Born August 12, 1925, in New York, NY he enlisted in the US Army before he turned eighteen in 1943. He proudly served his country until 1946 in China-Burma-India during WWII. On returning to New York, he enrolled in NYU and studied Business Administration there before transferring to The University of Miami where he earned his degree in Economics. Lou (as he liked to be called by everyone) held executive positions with several pharmaceutical firms but it would be at Merck Sharp & Dohme International where he was hired in 1964 as managing director of Venezuela that he would make his mark during a twenty five year career. In 1967 he was transferred to Italy as managing director there. Merck's business was in an early stage and thanks to his leadership and energy together with the efforts of his successors a pattern of long term growth began with Italy becoming one of the biggest and most successful subsidiaries. He returned to the US in 1969 as vice president of Latin America and assumed broader responsibilities as vice president for the Western Hemisphere in 1974. In 1977 he was elected senior vice president responsible for the division's activities in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, the far East (excluding Japan) the Middle East, India, Pakistan and Latin America. Before retiring in 1995, he was named senior vice president of Europe, thus completing many years at senior levels in a period of significant innovation and growth with the firm. Lou was a dynamic and resourceful executive whose greatest strengths were rooted in his ability to motivate and develop employees. He had a good eye for people's potential and was unafraid to delegate and empower his staff. Affable and direct, unceremonious in style, he was able to inspire his organizations to give their best. Happily retired in Naples, FL for the past sixteen years, he enjoyed cooking and playing golf, tennis and poker with his small circle of friends. In addition to his devoted wife, Jacqui, left to cherish his memory are his children, Paula Verner of Naples, FL, Andrea (Edward) Evans and Philip Privitere both of Montclair, NJ, his six grandchildren, David Verner, Todd Berquist, Chris Langfield, Tom Evans, Cayla and Cole Privitere and his stepson Alex O'Neal Caffrey. He will always be remembered with great love and respect.

A picture on Friday with an article about farm chemicals and waste that are carried south by the surging Mississippi and that are expected to result in the largest dead zone ever in the Gulf of Mexico was published in error. The picture showed volunteers sandbagging a farm south of Oslo, Minn., along the flooding Red River in April. The Red River, which flows north into Canada, is not part of the Mississippi River watershed.

AFTER ''Blonde Venus'' flopped in 1932, Paramount decided to break up the powerful creative alliance between the director Josef von Sternberg and the actress Marlene Dietrich, whom he had discovered in Germany and brought to Hollywood. While Sternberg, who was Jewish, entertained bizarre fantasies of returning to Germany to work for the state-controlled studio Ufa (he thought the Germans would treat him as the great artist he was), Dietrich was hustled directly into ''The Song of Songs,'' which has recently surfaced as half of a ''Pre-Code Double Feature'' available exclusively through the TCM Web site. (The other film is ''This Is the Night.'') Dietrich was still a valuable property, and the studio was probably trying to do its best by her by assigning ''The Song of Songs'' (1933) to Rouben Mamoulian, a prominent Broadway director who occasionally condescended to make moving pictures. The results are pretty appalling, but the film remains an instructive illustration of the culture war that then existed between the principled intellectuals of New York and the rampaging lowbrows of Los Angeles. Though the New Yorkers were triumphant at the time, history has largely reversed that judgment.

Hotels have used scent, art and of course food to set themselves apart. Now is using indie musicians as a way to define itself. The musicians can be found on playlists created for several Morgans hotels that stream on the Morgans Web site and are available as free downloads. Selected by Morgans' management and the online music distributor RCRD LBL, the playlists are meant to match emerging independent bands with each of its 12 hotels. On the playlist for the Delano in Miami, for example, Morgans aimed for sexy and sophisticated, choosing tracks by Matthew Dear and Freelance Whales. For the more energetic Mondrian hotels, including the new one in SoHo in New York, the Ting Tings and Chilly Gonzales made the list.

THE heritage hotel revival in London has reached another peak with the opening of the St. Pancras Renaissance Hotel. It took 12 years for Marriott to restore, salvage and update the Victorian behemoth in King's Cross. It's something close to a miracle that anything was left of Sir Gilbert Scott's 1873 building. Over the years, it was twice bombed and left to decay, hideously retrofitted in the 1960s as office space, then threatened with demolition. With the design firm Manhattan Loft Corporation, and the designer David Collins, who did the restaurant, Marriott has pulled off a feat of historical preservation. The Grand Stairway alone is worth the trip. ROCKY CASALE St. Pancras Renaissance Hotel, Euston Road, London NW1 3AU; (44 20) 7841 3540; stpancrasrenaissance

The Tampa Bay Rays had to make a decision before last season. They could field a team with several potential free agents and try to win a championship, or they could trade those players for prospects. They chose the first path, won the American League East and let every free agent go. Now the Rays are ready for their reward. Their free-agent losses resulted in 10 extra picks before the end of the second round in this week's draft, including first-rounders from the division-rival Yankees (for signing Rafael Soriano) and Boston Red Sox (for signing Carl Crawford).

NELSON OBUS is on no one's list of Wall Street titans. He is just another guy who chased that golden dream: catch the morning train into Manhattan, run a small but prosperous hedge fund, catch the evening train out, back to a leafy island of suburban wealth. But on the morning of July 11, 2002, a FedEx package from Washington arrived at his Midtown office, and his world collapsed beneath him.

HALLETT--Fred R.,Sr. died peacefully on the morning of June 2, 2011, after a long and courageous battle with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The visitation and reception will be held from 10:00am to 1:00pm on Saturday, June 11, 2011 at the Lodi Historical Society Building, 8394 Main Street, Lodi, NY. A memorial service officiated by Pastor Diane Walker, with full military honors will then be held at 1:00pm on Saturday at the Historical Society. Prayers of committal will be held privately at the West Lodi Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, kindly consider a donation in Fred's memory to: Lodi Historical Society PO Box 279, Lodi Volunteer Fire Company, PO Box 299, Lodi, NY 14860 or the Ovid Federated Church, PO Box 340, Ovid, NY 14521. Fred was born July 15, 1936 in Ludlowville, NY, a son of the late Ulysses S. Grant and Katie L. (Garnsey) Hallett, and at a young age his family moved to Lodi, NY. Upon graduation from South Seneca High School at the age of 16, he took advantage of the opportunity to study at New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance while working full time in the insurance industry. After obtaining his business degree in Accounting, Class of '57, Fred served proudly in the United States Marine Corps and in the Lebanon Crisis of 1958. In 1970 he became President of D.J. Colby Co., Inc. Under his leadership, the company grew into one of the premier insurance underwriting agencies in the nation. He loved the business and continued working until shortly before his passing. In 1992, he returned to the town he loved, Lodi, NY. He referred to the area as "God's Country." He was an active member of the community and was staunchly dedicated to maintaining, restoring and improving the town, where he served as Trustee. He was a strong supporter of the Lodi Volunteer Fire Company and long time advocate of education. He established scholarships for Lodi students looking to go to college, and with the assistance of Jay Dey, a scholarship was founded to support students interested in careers in agriculture. He loved spending time with his family and two dachshunds. He enjoyed meticulously maintaining his property, the beautiful countryside surrounding Seneca Lake, hunting and fishing. He is survived by Joan, his wife of nearly 45 years, five children and their spouses, Joan and John Meagle, Fred and Patricia Hallett, Todd and Liz Hallett, John and Maryl Hallett, and Judd Hallett and Emily Hill and is the beloved grandfather of eight including Colby, John, Kathryn, Freddie, Bridgett, Mack, Arden and Shelter; a brother Bill and Donna Hallett, Fred was preceded in death by his brothers, David Colby and John Hallett. For additional information, please contact Covert Funeral Home at 1-877-828-3411 or visit www.covertfuneralhome.com.

BARASCH--Marvin, 88, of Manhattan and Palm Beach, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, passed peacefully in his home surrounded by loving family on May 30. Devoted husband of 20 years to Phyllis (nee Putter). Loving brother of the late Norman. Adored father of Claudia (Shelly Hirshon) and Michael (Candy Carmel) and dear grandfather of Ariel, Yaniv, Jessica, Robert and Julia. Graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and NYU. Proudly served during WWII in U.S. Army's 100th division. Life long insurance executive. To the Sports Editor:

CO-OP at Harperley Hall, a 1911 Arts and Crafts-style building at 41 Central Park West, was the biggest sale of the week, closing for $11.75 million, according to city prop- erty records.(Streeteasy.com posted the sale of a $12.75 million condop at 445 Lafayette Street in NoHo, but brokers with Prudential Douglas Elliman who handled the listing declined to comment on the final sale price.)The Harperley Hall apartment was sold by Geraldine and Kit Laybourne. Ms. Laybourne ran Nickelodeon before founding Oxygen, a channel directed at women. The four-bedroom three-bath unit was originally listed with Brown Harris Stevens in April 2010 for $14.5 million. The price was reduced to $11.75 million in September; the unit went into contract in February, according to Streeteasy.The sale appeared in city records on May 26.E-mail: bigdeal@nytimes.com The buyers were listed as Stephen B. Burke, the chief executive of NBC Universal, and his wife, Gretchen.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the pre- vious week, ending Wednesday.

COLMAN--David R.,Ph.D., Director of the Montreal Neurological Institute and Hospital (The Neuro) of McGill University and the McGill University Health Centre, passed away suddenly on June 1, 2011. Beloved husband of Elizabeth, devoted father to Monica and Miranda, and brother of Carol Colman (Michael Gerber) and uncle to Joshua Gerber. David Colman was a true renaissance man. He was passionate about his family, science, art, cooking, heritage plants, old movies and so much more. His intelligence, entrepreneurial spirit and wonderful sense of humor will be deeply missed. Born in New York, he received his BSc from NYU (1970), and his PhD from the State University of New York (1977). He held faculty positions at NYU School of Medicine and The Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. In 1993, he became the Annenberg Professor of Molecular Biology and Neuroscience, the Vice-Chairman for Research in the Department of Neurology, and the Scientific Director of The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis of The Mount Sinai School of Medicine. In September 2002, Dave moved with his family to Montreal to become Director of The Neuro, one of five institutions supported by the Killam Trusts. He was deeply committed to Wilder Penfield's original vision of an integrated research and clinical institution. Through his championship of The Neuro and all the people who work there, he drew people in, captivating them with the promise of a new neuroscience. Under his visionary leadership, The Neuro launched a $40-million campaign and was named one of the first Canadian Centres of Excellence in Research and Commercialization. Dave approached science with a strong conviction in basic, curiosity-driven research and he believed in approaching problems from every angle. This commitment led to the multidisciplinary Neuroengineering Program, an innovative Neuropalliative Care program, and a major expansion in brain imaging. Dave was a mentor to many. He encouraged young students to be curious about the world around them. He championed the Integrated Program in Neuroscience and was spearheading a collaborative project with the NFB of Canada to create an educational 3-D IMAX film about neuroscience. He was a world-renowned scientist, who focused on problems related to myelination, spinal cord injury and nerve cell development and regeneration. His laboratory made major contributions to our understanding of how nerves are protected and nurtured by the myelin sheath in the brain and in the peripheral nervous system, and how nerve cells communicate with each other across the synapse. He was on the editorial boards of Neuron and Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience, and a member of the Medical Advisory Committee for the Gairdner Foundation, and authored more than 110 scientific publications in top tier journals. Dave had a meaningful impact on all who had the fortune of knowing him and his legacy as a visionary leader and an extraordinary person will live on forever. A private funeral will take place in New York. A memorial tribute will be held in Montreal at a future date. In lieu of flowers or gifts, please send donations to the David Colman Memorial Fund, Montreal Neurological Institute, 3801 University St., Montreal, Quebec, Canada, H3A 2B4.

WINTER--Martin, survivor of Lodz Ghetto and Auschwitz, dies at 81. Born Martin Kujawski on June 26, 1929 in Lodz, Poland, Martin was the sole survivor of his family of seven. In 1946, a cousin, Benjamin Winter, helped sponsor Martin to emigrate to New York. His career was spent setting the sales foundation for what would later become the Jones Apparel Group. Known as the Chief and for his beautiful tenor voice, he died on April 29th. A memorial service was held on May 2nd, 2011, Yom Hashoah Holocaust Remembrance Day. Survived by wife of 57 years, Charlotte, their four kids and eight grandchildren. Donations can be made to: The Museum of Jewish Heritage where Martin's Shoah Foundation testimony is archived www.mjhnyc.org; American Liver Foundation - www.liverfoundation.org; and Congregation Gesher Shalom 1449 Anderson Ave., Fort Lee, NJ 07024.

In their 50-season history, the Mets have retired only one number for one of their players: Tom Seaver's No. 41. Such restraint is admirable, perhaps, compared with the Yankees. But what about Gary Carter's No. 8? The Mets have had a complicated relationship with Carter, who managed successfully in their low minors in 2005 and 2006, then quit when he was offered the job at Class AA Binghamton, only one step up the organizational ladder. Then, in 2008, Carter contacted the Mets about their major league job before Willie Randolph was fired.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

THE summer collector-car season is off to a clutch-dropping burnout of a start. At a Mecum auction in Indianapolis two weeks ago, $50 million in muscle cars changed hands. While there won't be any Hemi 'Cudas ripping up the pristine lawns at the Greenwich Concours d'Élégance this weekend, plenty of Chrysler Hemi power and other examples of Detroit V-8 muscle will be present. These transatlantic cars were known in the collector car world as hybrids long before manufacturers appropriated the term to describe their gasoline-electric powertrains.

FORD--Harry E.,III, M.D., of Boston died on May 23, 2011 from Multiple Myeloma. Dr. Ford was a psychiatrist known for his hard work, kind heart, and generous spirit. Harry was born in Richmond, Virginia. He attended Lincoln University in Pennsylvania where he was President of his Senior Class, graduating in 1967 with a B.A. Harry then attended Temple University in Philadelphia and received an M.Ed. Harry taught high school in Philadelphia between 1967 and 1974. He was a Master Teacher in the Program for Dropouts from 1971-1972. Harry was admitted to Howard Medical School in Washington, D.C. and was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha Honors Medical Society. He was awarded his M.D. in 1978. Dr. Ford did his Family Medicine residency at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. He then worked as a Family Doctor at the Morris Heights Health Center in the Bronx. The clinic provided comprehensive health care to an indigent population. Harry once recalled that while working there, his patients talked not only about their medical problems, but also about the vicissitudes of life, prompting his interest in psychiatry. Dr. Ford was accepted at the Mass. General Hospital Residency in Psychiatry Program. Between 1981 and 1986 he completed his residency and a Clinical Fellowship in Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School. Dr. Ford held many positions as a staff psychiatrist, Unit Director, Associate Medical Director, and Medical Director, working with inpatients and outpatients, in Philadelphia, Boston, Fall River and Brockton, MA. He also taught Residents throughout his career, having been appointed as an Instructor in Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and a Clinical Assistant Professor at Boston University Medical School. He received many awards including two Outstanding Teacher Awards from the MGH Psychiatric Residents as well as the Harvard South Shore Program Outstanding Teacher Award. He received the Black Achievers Award presented by the Greater Boston YMCA and the Mass. Psychiatric Society's Outstanding Psychiatrist Award for Public Sector Service. That award states that as a "family physician and psychiatrist, you devoted your professional life to providing care for the seriously ill and under served, with special emphasis on improving services for minority populations, and are beloved by patients, families, trainees and colleagues for your steadfast devotion to disadvantaged persons with mental disorders." He is survived by his loving partner, Margaret N. Henehan, beloved daughter Christine R. (Ford) Rooney, son-in-law Stephen V. Rooney, grandchildren Felix, Catherine (Coco), Peyton, Vivian, Harry and John of Darien, Connecticut, brother Keith Ford of Vermont, sister Janice Hardy of Michigan, and many other relatives and friends. Donations in Harry's honor may be made to The Harry Ford Endowed Grand Rounds Lectureship Fund, MGH Department of Psychiatry, or to The MGH Multiple Myeloma Research Fund, each c/o The Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114. On line guest book at www.brownandhickey.com

GERTLER--Maynard. At 94, Emmanuel Maynard Gertler, devoted husband, father of five, scholar and university teacher, publisher, farmer, defender of Canadian unity, public servant, civil libertarian, peace and human rights advocate, environmentalist, and athlete, passed away in Montreal on April 19, 2011. He leaves behind his saddened and proud family: his wife of 68 years, Ann Straus Gertler (a granddaughter of Nathan Straus, philanthropist, public servant and merchant, who was co-owner of R.H. Macy & Company, and of the Abraham and Straus department store -- and grandniece of famed New York photographer and advocate of modern art, Alfred Stieglitz), his sons Michael, Alfred, Franklin, Edward, and their spouses, nine grandchildren, one great-grandson and many beloved nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. He was predeceased by his son, Jeffrey Lee Gertler (died 2005), by his sister Anna Berger and his brother Leonard Gertler, and by his parents Hyman and Gertrude (Slover) Gertler. Maynard was Research Director and then President of the New York documentary film company, The World Today, and taught economics at NYU. He served in the U.S. Army and in several wartime intelligence and economic warfare agencies under the Roosevelt Administration. Maynard and Ann were owner-operators of farms in Little Washington, VA, and Lancaster County, PA. Later, in the mid-1950s, he taught American government and economic history at Cambridge University, England. Returning to his home city of Montreal in 1958, with Ann he founded and ran Harvest House Publishers for nearly 40 years, bringing out books that celebrated thinkers such as Thoreau, Zola, Marcuse, and Myrdal, blazed new trails in planning and environmental conservation, built bridges of understanding between Canada's many peoples and debunked racial myths and narrow readings of history. At the same time, the family pursued pure seed production on farms in Picton and Williamstown, Ontario. He served as president of Amnesty International Canada, as vice-president of PEN Canada; and as a board member of the Raoul Wallenberg International Movement for Humanity. In 2002, his achievements were recognized with the Order of Canada (Canada's highest civilian honor) and the Queen's University Alumni Achievement Award. Private funeral and Interment were at Mount Royal Cemetery.

FROHLINGER--Helen. Our deepest sympathies go out to Joseph Frohlinger, partner and friend, and his dear family, as they mourn the loss of their beloved mother, Helen Frohlinger. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

FOR years, the main commercial section of the Mount Airy neighborhood, which runs along historic Germantown Avenue in northwest Philadelphia, has been overlooked in favor of the shopping and cultural offerings that mark the avenue's terminus in bordering Chestnut Hill. But in recent years, this enclave has benefited from an influx of business owners who have come to embrace the diverse population that distinguishes it from its more affluent and monochromatic neighbor. Buoyed by reasonable housing costs and relatively safe streets, Mount Airy is in the midst of a cultural revival, replete with new and old businesses, which have come to reflect its residents' socially conscious and progressive lifestyle. ZACH PONTZ
TSEKOURA--Lynda, 68, of East 13th St.,Manhattan, passed away February 2011. May she rest in peace.

Heather Young, 28: I was afraid that it was all going to be taken away at the last moment. This was shot in October 2009. I had just been handed my daughter after being released from La Vista women's prison after a year for meth possession. I was getting out with nothing. I didn't have anywhere to live, I didn't have a job and she didn't really know me as her mom. That was scary. I knew that every choice I was going to make from then on would affect her, and I just wasn't prepared for it. But I've gotten everything pretty much straightened out since then. We have our own place, and I work full time as a waitress. I change her diapers, I stay up all night when she's fussy and I bathe her. At some point, I'm going to have to tell her that I've made mistakes, and I don't quite know how I'll go about having that conversation yet. I think I'll just keep trying to move on from where I'm at.

RAND--John. John Rand, of Bridgehampton and New York City, died from complications of Parkinson's Disease and pneumonia on May 25, at age 90. Born in Chicago, in 1921, John graduated from the Chicago Latin School, Phillips Exeter Academy and Harvard. He acted with the famed Provincetown Players. In WWII, he was as a Captain in the anti-aircraft artillery and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Fluent in French, John served as Special Service Officer at Camp Top Hat, in Antwerp, where he directed theater productions and other entertainments. John was named "Young Man of the Year" by the Junior Chamber of Commerce, and married Judith Lane of St. Paul Minnesota. The couple wrote and directed a satirical revue, "Quick Changes," which had a highly successful run in Chicago and New York. John worked as a copywriter at Foote Cone and Belding in Chicago, then as a Senior VP and Creative Director at Ogilvy and Mather in New York City. He wrote award-winning campaigns for Hallmark, Kleenex, Sears, S.C. Johnson and Mattel, among others. While at Ogilvy, John directed the agency's philanthropic effort, sponsoring a block in East Harlem under the auspices of the Upper Park Avenue Community Association. John retired to Bridgehampton, where he was an active member of the Citizen's Advisory Committee. He wrote a column for the Southampton Press, highlighting the lives of vibrant seniors on the East End. John was an avid equestrian. John won scores of friends and admirers for his true joie de vivre-his over-the-top humor, rare graciousness and infectious optimism. His wife, Judy, a writer, died of cancer at age 64. He is survived by his daughters, Hilary Adams and Eliza Damiecki, and five grandchildren, Natalie, Genevieve, Griffin, Nina and Ellie. A private memorial will be held in July. To honor John, donations can be made to The Children's Storefront School in East Harlem: 212- 427-7900 or visit: thechildrensstorefront.org

WE had come a long way for a hog killing, but the butcher had chosen that day of all days to have a meltdown. Nobody at La Grande Boucherie des Cajuns -- an annual festival in St. Martinville, La., celebrating the Cajun tradition of boucherie, or the communal butchering of hogs -- knew what had set him off. It might have been the thunderstorm that had hit town that morning, blowing tents from the festival grounds and drenching vendors. Or maybe it was the unseasonably cool air; a cold chopping block could make for unpleasant butchering. Whatever it was, he had packed up his apron and butchering tackle, locked the hog in the trailer, and sped off -- presumably to the hog's relief. We stuck around for a while, hoping he might change his mind and return. My girlfriend, Emily, even got him on the phone, explaining how we'd traveled all the way from New York, so wouldn't he come back and, please, slaughter a hog? He did not accede. If we wanted to see a hog killing so badly, he said, we could come to his house the next day and he'd do one special, just for us.
Theater Jason Zinoman

LEWIS--Stephen Alexander, died peacefully on May 26 at his home in Oakland, CA after a nearly three-year battle with colorectal cancer. Born February 5, 1941 in New York to David and Muriel Lewis, raised in Riverdale. Graduated from the Fieldston School, 1959, then Yale University, 1963. Received his PhD with Honors from Yale in Physics in 1969. Steve's vocation was the development of mission-critical systems in accelerator control and physics data acquisition. He was one of the world's EPICS (Experimental Physics and Industrial Control System) gurus. Major contributions were to the Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab for Superhilac, Bevatron, Gammasphere, BaBar, and Spallation Neutron Source, Lawrence Livermore National Lab for the National Ignition Facility, and finally at the Stanford Linear Accelerator working on the Linac Coherent Light Source (LCLS) until the time of his passing. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He was a pilot, sailor, soccer and auto racing fan, world traveler, and an avid cyclist. Dearly missed by his wife Suzanna Lewis, brothers Dan and Robert Lewis, children Rachel, Aaron and Sam Lewis and Paul and Christy Geiger, and grandsons Alex and Zach Lewis, Henry Dalzell and Kiran Gangadharan. Donations in his name should be made to the Parkinson Foundation of the National Capital Area

The nonchalant look prevails at the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturdays. A bunch of poppies plopped in a bucket were not arranged by a designer, and yet they had an appeal that would attract an artist's eye. The same is true with the shoppers' attire. It's New York at its most relaxed style moment, excluding the kids, who looked like summer butterflies in their print dresses and shade hats. The new Andy Warhol statue, a few yards from his former Factory, peers over the square from its column perched in a seating area north of the park. It wasn't long before Campbell's soup cans were decorating the pedestal, some holding flowers.

The year 1980 was one in which economic forecasting models were in agreement that the economy had slumped too significantly to allow President Jimmy Carter to win re-election. Unemployment was at 7.5 percent and inflation was at 9.7 percent. Per-capita GDP and disposable income growth, adjusted for inflation, had been negative over the course of Mr. Carter’s term. The economy was officially in recession for much of the election year.

Last week, Fred Hayman, the “Godfather of Rodeo Drive,” was welcomed into an elite club (Giorgio Armani, Tom Ford, Donatella Versace, etc.),  when he received a Rodeo Drive Walk of Style award at the age of 86. The deluge of contemporary art that is the Venice Biennale is, on many levels, an unforgiving contest between the memorable and the forgettable. Why some things stick with you and others don’t is not always easily explained, and that mystery is a sign of one of life’s great gifts: aesthetic response is ungovernable. Your taste will surprise and betray you; that’s how it grows and adds to wisdom. The works that will be appearing in this feature — there will be a new one each weekday for the next two weeks — are among those that stuck with me, for reasons good and bad, as I waded through the Biennale and its collateral exhibitions. Whether I liked them or not may be beside the point, but they all raised intriguing questions, some of which I’ve tried to pose. Take a look, see what you think and add your own minireview to the mix.

Twitter has been expanding its services. The company recently announced improvements to search on Twitter.com, so that photos and video links appear next to relevant posts, and it has started a photo-sharing feature, shown above in a Twitter promotional video). During April, Singapore had the largest percentage of its Internet users go to Twitter.com. China's version of Twitter, Sina Micro, drew a high percentage, too, but the number of Internet users in China is a smaller percentage of its total population than in countries like the United States or Canada.

For AARP, 50 is the new 65. And as the company begins a new advertising campaign this week, it wants media buyers and advertisers to keep that in mind. AARP's new marketing effort will promote the baby boom generation, as it ages, as a viable consumer target for advertisers. The campaign, which includes print and digital ads, will run in trade publications like Advertising Age starting Monday.

Johanna Fiedler, a publicist who wrote tell-all books about the Metropolitan Opera and about growing up as the daughter of Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops, died on May 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 65. She had been ill for some time, her sister, Deborah Stiles, said.
