JERUSALEM -- Israeli forces fired at pro-Palestinian protesters on the Syrian frontier on Sunday as they tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks, reflecting a new mode of popular struggle and deadly confrontation fueled by turmoil in the Arab world and the vacuum of stalled peace talks. Wave after wave of protesters, mainly Palestinians from refugee camps in Syria, approached the frontier with the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights. Israeli soldiers opened fire on those who crossed a new trench and tried to attack the border fence near the towns of Majdal Shams in the Golan Heights and Quneitra in Syria.

LOS ANGELES - Many young companies are trying to seize on the intersection of social media, personalization and celebrity, but StarGreetz.com has something most do not: a pack of prominent Hollywood backers. StarGreetz, which is only a few months old, has two primary businesses. The simple one is a line of personalized video e-cards, invitations, ringtones and greetings priced at 99 cents to $2.99. Animated characters (Cinderella), athletes (Joe Namath) and other celebrities (Reba McEntire) speak directly to the recipient by name. Sample: ''Michael, hey this is Reba!''

Earlier this year, my colleague Claire Cain Miller and I reported on the fierce recruiting wars among tech companies as they competed to hire and retain talented software developers and engineers. We wrote about some of the perks that start-ups were offering to potential employees to convince them to join their companies, including free meals, haircuts and even iPads. Now, Hipster, a start-up in San Francisco that lets people post queries and answers to others in their geographic area using the Web and a mobile phone, is trying to attract fresh faces to its company with a particularly attention-getting offer -- $10,000 and a year's supply of beer. The company is also offering a bicycle, pair of oversized glasses, skinny jeans, a bowtie, mustache-grooming services and a pair of boots. The prize was designed to resonate with the company's name. The beer, of course, is PBR (Pabst Blue Ribbon, for those who are not hip).

7:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) LETTERS TO JULIET (2010) Sophie, a magazine fact checker played by Amanda Seyfried, arrives in Verona, Italy, on a prenuptial honeymoon of sorts with her restaurateur fiancé, Victor (Gael García Bernal, above with Ms. Seyfried). Then they go their separate ways. He hunts down culinary delicacies. She happens upon a group of Italian women known as Juliet's secretaries, who gather letters written by lovelorn ladies tucked between the stones of a wall beneath the most famous balcony in Verona. One day Sophie happens upon a note written decades earlier by Claire (Vanessa Redgrave), a British exchange student who ran back to England with cold feet after breaking her promise to meet a local beau. Soon, lured by Sophie's response, Claire returns to Verona with her romance-averse grandson, Charlie (Christopher Egan), whose immediate dislike of Sophie could well spell love. The film ''represents an interesting paradox: It is a movie that is very nearly perfect without being especially good,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Still, he praised Ms. Redgrave's Claire as ''effortlessly marvelous,'' adding that she ''imparts grace, authenticity and a sense of emotional gravity to a movie desperate for all of those things and unsure just how to manufacture them.'' Of Ms. Seyfried, he wrote that the movie ''is likely to consolidate her position as a certified movie star.'' 9:20 A.M. (Fox Business Network) RED INK WEEK Five days are dedicated to an analysis of government spending, the debt ceiling, and the auto and bank bailouts.

SISKIND--Elliott, died at home June 5, after a battle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Diana, father of Amy, stepfather of John, Vali and Tony, grandfather of Laura, father-in-law of Elaine, brother of Leonard, uncle of Linda and Jerry. His son Paul suffered a tragic death at age 29. Elliott will be remembered as a man of exceptional kindness, sharp intelligence and modesty. He was generous, full of life a wonderful friend and a person of deep insight. He was a World War II Veteran who earned the Purple Cross at age nineteen. He became a CPA who spent the last 26 years of his career at the Van Heusen Company where he rose to Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Services will be held Tuesday, 1pm, Plaza Chapel 212-769-4400.

Golf fitness is a hot topic because so many professional golfers have bought into the concept that fitter means farther and straighter ball flights. And there is little doubt that overall fitness is good for your overall game. One of the most useful golf books on this topic is ''Yoga for Golfers'' (McGraw-Hill) by Katherine Roberts. What I like most about the book is the simple, straightforward yet golf-specific yoga postures from Roberts, a golf fitness expert. The book is not new and Roberts has other good fitness offerings, but the yoga and golf connection remains my favorite.

BOSTON - The Vancouver Canucks won the first two games of the Stanley Cup finals at home by the narrowest margin possible, but each time, they prevailed by being the more energetic team in the final minutes. It bodes ill for the Bruins, who also looked tired at the end of some games in the Eastern Conference finals against Tampa Bay. On Sunday, some of them said they were not sure what to do about it going into Monday's Game 3, which they cannot afford to lose.

One of the year's best-reviewed wide-release movies, ''X-Men: First Class,'' took in a solid $56 million at the North American box office over the weekend - easily enough for No. 1 and to help reboot a sagging franchise. Facing audience and critical rebellion over the last two ''X-Men'' installments, Tom Rothman, co-chairman of 20th Century Fox, took creative risks with ''First Class'' that appeared to pay off, including casting a cadre of untested young actors and approving a screenplay that includes Russian, French, German and Spanish dialogue - highly unusual for a summer blockbuster. In partial release overseas, the film took in an additional $64 million. ''The Hangover Part II,'' the raunchy buddy comedy from Warner Brothers, was second with an estimated $32.4 million for a two-week total of $187 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. ''Kung Fu Panda 2'' (DreamWorks Animation via Paramount) was third with about $24.3 million, sending its two-week total past $100 million. ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' showed continued life in fourth place, taking in about $18 million for a three-week total of $190.3 million. The crude comedy ''Bridesmaids'' (Universal) was fifth with about $12 million for a four-week total of $107.3 million. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PARIS -- Unseeded Bjorn Fratangelo of the United States defeated Dominic Thiem of Austria, 3-6, 6-3, 8-6, on Sunday to win the French Open boys' singles championship. He is the first American junior to claim the title since John McEnroe won in 1977. He was named for Bjorn Borg, the winner of six French Open men's singles titles.

Jonas Bevacqua, a designer and entrepreneur who helped form the LRG brand, selling hip-hoppers and skateboarders clothing and other merchandise as expressions of ''ridiculous swagger,'' as the company puts it, was found dead on Tuesday in his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 33. There were no signs of foul play, Jim Amormino , a spokesman for the Orange County sheriff's office, told The A.P. An autopsy on Wednesday failed to determine the cause of death, but toxicological tests must still be completed, Mr. Amormino said.

For a few hours on Sunday, Governors Island became something of a Hamptons satellite, dotted with people in Nantucket reds, linen suits, Lilly Pulitzer pinks and sunhats that seemed as wide as a city block. They came for an exhibition polo match put on with the intention, according to the organizers, of bringing the elite sport down from on high. But the thousands of spectators, who sipped Champagne costumed in high Hamptons style, seemed intent on just the opposite.

POTTER--Rev. William A.,on May 29, 2011. Husband to Cynthia, brother to Joseph, father to Bancroft, Whitney, and Catherine. Memorial Monday, June 13, 2011, at 6pm, at St. Luke's Church, Hope, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please donate to: HavenOfHopeForKids.org.

KATZ--Harvey L.,age 86, died on June 4, 2011 at the Glen Arden Health Care Center in Goshen, New York after a courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was a well respected businessman whose career took him throughout the world. From 1949 until 1958 he worked as a reporter for several daily and weekly newspapers. In 1958 he became the director of corporate public relations for Pan American Airlines. While he worked for Pan American he accompanied their wheel chair basketball team to Israel and Italy where they had an audience with Pope John XXIII. In 1973 he became the Vice President of the New York City Convention and Visitor's Bureau a position he held until his retirement in 1992. A veteran of World War II, he received the Purple Heart and bronze star after being wounded in the Battle of the Bulge. He then attended Syracuse University, graduating in 1949 from the School of Journalism. There he met Glory Weisberger who he had been married to for 62 years at the time of his death. They had two children, Susan and Arne. Throughout his life he was devoted to his family, friends, Syracuse University and the New York Jets, Giants and Mets. He is survived by his devoted wife, Glory, of Goshen, New York, his loving son Arne Katz and daughter Susan K. Miller and her husband Stephen, his niece Pamela Brier and many other nieces, nephews, cousins and a great-great-nephew. Funeral services will be on June 6, 2010 at 1pm at Garlick's funeral home in Monticello, NY.

Rather than open on Broadway in the fall as producers originally hoped, the musical adaptation of the 2006 Dublin-set indie film ''Once'' will receive a downtown production at New York Theater Workshop in November, with Broadway a possibility after that, according to executives involved with the show. The musicians Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, who played the lead characters in the film and won an Academy Award for one of its original songs, ''Falling Slowly,'' have written the music and lyrics for the stage production, and the playwright Enda Walsh (''Penelope'') has written the book. The Off Broadway production will be directed by John Tiffany, best known in New York for the Iraq war play ''Black Watch'' at St. Ann's Warehouse, and choreographed by Steven Hoggett (''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' ''American Idiot'').

Our condolences to his family. James McConnaughy The NAADAA Inc.

A little more than three weeks ago, K. J. Choi of South Korea won the Players Championship. Five days after Choi hoisted the crystal trophy that comes with that near-major victory, Titleist and Foot Joy - two of the biggest brand names in the golf industry - were sold to a group led by the sporting-goods maker Fila Korea. Though the Titleist and Foot Joy headquarters will remain in Massachusetts, the sale underscores where golf's most visible expansion will be taking place. South Korea, with a population of nearly 48 million, already has about 1,200 driving ranges and 400 golf courses. One study reported that 15 percent of South Koreans more than 15 years old consider themselves golfers. In 2009, Y. E. Yang of South Korea became the first man from Asian to claim a major golf title, overtaking Tiger Woods to win the P.G.A. Championship. In the most recent Rolex women's world golf rankings, 6 of the top 15 players are South Korean.

CASSIDY--James R.,Hypoluxo, FL, age 88, died on Friday, May 27, 2011 at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and moved to Hazlet in 1957 where he lived for 45 years before moving to Florida. Prior to his retirement in 1987, he worked for The New York Times for 40 years as an Executive in the Accounting Pension Department. Mr. Cassidy was a member of St. Benedict's R.C. Church in Holmdel for 45 years. He was a kind, loving man who loved his family. He loved reading, writing and the beach, especially swimming. Mr. Cassidy is predeceased by his wife, Mildred Cassidy in 2007 and by 11 siblings. Surviving are his sons, James Cassidy, John Cassidy and his wife, Cathy; his daughters, Nancy Klose and her husband, Michael and Karen Cassidy. He is also survived by his 11 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held Tuesday, May 31, 2011. Memorial contributions may be made to the Susan G. Komen for the Cure, Attn: Donor Services, P.O. Box 650309, Dallas, TX 75265-0309. To send condolences, visit: www.higginsfuneralhome.com

CHICAGO -- Two new drugs have been found to prolong the lives of people with advanced melanoma, representing what researchers say is notable progress against the deadly skin cancer after decades of futility. The drugs represent success in two new approaches to combating cancer: one by attacking a specific genetic mutation that accelerates tumor growth; the other by unleashing the body's immune system to fight the disease

4:59 p.m. | Updated to add comment from Paul Ceglia's lawyer. Facebook on Thursday sharpened its attack on Paul Ceglia, a New York man who says that a 2003 work-for-hire contract with Mark Zuckerberg, the company's founder, entitles him to half of Mr. Zuckerberg's stake in the social media giant. In a legal motion filed in federal court in Buffalo, Facebook provided details and expert testimony to support its claims that the contract at the center of Mr. Ceglia's lawsuit was doctored and that a series of purported e-mails between the two men was fabricated. In addition, Facebook said Mr. Zuckerberg has sworn under oath that he neither signed the contract put forward by Mr. Ceglia, nor sent or received the purported e-mails that Mr. Ceglia has presented as evidence.

One hundred thousand E. coli can dance on the head of a pin; it may only take 50 to make you sick enough to die. Benign E. coli are everywhere, even in your own pink gut right now, and all E. coli can live on (or in) things as different as sprouts, burgers and water. But if you were able to trace back far enough, their reservoir is most likely the gut of mammal: a goat, a sheep, a deer, even a majestic elk or a dog. They’re most often associated with cows.

The New York Philharmonic is taking a break from its normal early-summer concerts in New York City parks, adding performances in September instead. The orchestra will perform with the tenor Andrea Bocelli on Sept. 15 on Central Park’s Great Lawn, a special event outside its usual parks series. Two days later at Avery Fisher Hall, it will play William Walton’s music from the movie “Henry V,” narrated by Christopher Plummer, and music from Shakespeare’s time. The concert had originally been planned for the spring but was moved because of a conflict with Mr. Plummer’s schedule, said the orchestra’s spokesman, Eric Latzky.

My in-house Japanese-culture consultant turned to me Sunday night and said, “Do you remember when Muhammad Ali fought the Japanese wrestler in the 1970s?” I assumed this was a gross misinterpretation of something. Maybe a cartoon she saw once. But no. On June 26, 1976, Ali met Antonio Inoki, a professional wrestler, in the ring in Tokyo (at Budokan!). Inoki, for reasons best known to him, which is not to rule out terror given his prominent chin, spent most of the match on his back, trying to kick Ali. It ended in a draw.

In the back of Brian Donnelly’s studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, behind three wheeled, wooden work tables and neatly organized racks containing bottles of brightly colored acrylic paint, past an array of painted canvases in different shapes and sizes, hides a four-foot-tall sculpture of Mickey Mouse. Mickey has seen better days, apparently. He’s gray. And his eyes are x-ed out, as if he just drank from a bottle labeled “Poison.” Donnelly, 36, who is better known by his alias, KAWS, is getting ready to haul a 16-foot-tall version of this mouse, titled “Companion (Passing Through),” from the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., to the Standard hotel in New York. A graffiti artist, illustrator, toymaker, sculptor and painter, Donnelly first collaborated with the hotel earlier this year, with a series of blue, red and green light bulbs that sold out in a matter of days. For all of his visibility in the worlds of fashion and art, Donnelly remains an unassuming, self-proclaimed “blusher” from New Jersey. T caught up with him on the eve of the unveiling at The Standard to talk about art, life and why his large “companion” looks so darned shy.

My shelves are filled with parenting books. A good percentage of them are there because parenting is now my beat — new ones arrive in the mail every day and they are now piled everywhere. But my collection began long before Motherlode. Even before I was pregnant I figured that if I gathered enough of these volumes I would find the answers. Part of me still believes this, and an archaeologist could easily see what I was looking for over time by excavating down through the piles. “What to Expect When You’re Expecting,” “Your Baby and Child,” “Operating Instructions,” “Siblings Without Rivalry,” “The iConnected Parent,” “Parenting Your Adult Child.”

Section 2 of the High Line, which opens to the public tomorrow, passes just beyond Frank Gehry’s IAC building and Jean Nouvel’s 100 11th Avenue Residences one block to the west. With the installation of Sarah Sze’s “Still Life with Landscape (Model for a Habitat),” some of the more modest denizens of the neighborhood will have a piece of starchitecture to call their own. The sculpture, a dynamic steel and wood complex of bird, ladybug and butterfly condos, sits between 20th and 21st Streets, and serves as a sort of gateway onto the High Line microclimate known as the Chelsea Thicket. Among its noteworthy amenities are feeding trays that will be regularly restocked with seeds and nectar, and miniature troughs designed to catch rainwater. But as with any luxury real estate development — even one with a boldfaced name attached to it — its occupancy rate is not a guarantee. “It’s really an experiment,” says Lauren Ross, the curator and director of arts programs at Friends of the High Line, adding that Sze consulted various urban birding groups but received conflicting predictions. “It functions first and foremost as sculpture. We are not sure how wildlife will respond to it.”

Q.

At a lunchtime conversation yesterday, just before Anthony Weiner used a tearstained press conference to confess to being both a serial Twitterer of tasteless amateur photography and an exceptionally ineffective liar, a colleague of mine made the case for forgiveness in such cases. His point, at least as I understood it, was that most politicians are raging narcissists of one stripe or another, walking a tightrope between flagrant egotism and true pathology. But public figures who pass through the fire of a major scandal-driven humiliation have a rare chance to come to terms with that narcissism’s catastrophic consequences, and as a result many of them probably come out of these kind of self-inflicted disasters as better people — and perhaps, by implication, better public servants — than your typical Joe Q. Politician.

Q.

Recently, The Paris Review blog ran a Q. and A. with Oliver Broudy about his forthcoming book, “The Saint.” And in that Q. and A., Broudy responded to a question about his relationship with New York, and he answered (for himself) the much larger New York question: What does it mean to live in New York, to be challenged in New York, to work like a New Yorker works, and how does one move beyond New York, if ever? And like all New Yorkers, I am drawn to anything that helps me to understand what it means to live in this city. This paragraph deserved to be saved, reread and questioned by other New Yorkers.

Noel Coward once said, ''The only thing that really saddens me over my demise is that I shall not be here to read the nonsense that will be written about me and my works and my motives.'' The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center promises to display both sense and nonsense about the composer, director and playwright at a new exhibition devoted to Coward that is scheduled for next spring. ''Star Quality: The World of Noel Coward'' will run from March 12 to June 9 in the Donald and Mary Oenslager Gallery and include photographs, programs, scripts, costumes, personal effects, memorabilia, and other objects, as well as audio and video components. There will also be a series of public and educational programs around the city related to the exhibition.

Last season's statistical line for Austin da Luz, selected 14th over all by the Red Bulls in the 2010 Major League Soccer draft, is stark: a long series of zeros. That changed last Saturday night, when the club found itself without six players who were away with their national teams. Coach Hans Backe, arm firmly twisted behind his back, gave da Luz, a San Diego native, his first start in league play. Da Luz acquitted himself well by keeping it simple and keeping it solid.

Tyler, 6 feet 11 inches and 260 pounds, is projected as a second-round pick by DraftExpress.com. The service rates him as the 16th-best big man in the draft, which will be held June 23 in Newark.

Marv Albert will call N.F.L. games for CBS Sports starting this season, if there is one, but will give up announcing games for the Nets on the YES Network. Albert said the initial offer to call the games for CBS came during the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, which he was calling for CBS and Turner Sports, his primary employer for N.B.A. broadcasts on TNT.

To stay warm in Antarctica's bitterly cold conditions, emperor penguins are known to form tight huddles. Researchers now report that while in these huddles, the penguins move in a coordinated periodic wave. This allows every penguin a chance to move from the colder outer region of the huddle into the warmer inner region. Penguins form such tight huddles that it would be impossible for an individual to make an isolated movement, said Daniel P. Zitterbart, a physicist from the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg and the study's first author.

If you found it hard to get a livery cab on Monday morning, there was a good reason: Nearly 2,000 drivers skipped work to rally outside City Hall against a city proposal to create a separate class of taxis that would pick up street hails outside of most of Manhattan. The drivers gathered along the west side of City Hall Park, waved posters and chanted ''Si Se Puede'' or ''Yes We Can,'' as several City Council members and State Assembly members spoke at a news conference.

Also his stepdaughters Susan, Robin, Leslee and Penni, and sister Clair Baer. He was the Bishop of The Friars Club, a National Director of ADL and Director of The National Liberty Museum. He was a bright light and a lion to the end. Services 10am on Thursday at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St.

Right now, Spanish soccer is at a level no one can match.

RAUSNITZ--Egon. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our uncle Egon. Our deepest sympathies to Lee; Linda and Michael; Diane and Ira; his grandchildren and great- grandchildren. All our love, Vera, Gerry, Susi and the Rausnitz & Strauss Families

Josephine Hart, an Irish-born novelist whose best-selling tale of erotic obsession, ''Damage,'' inspired the 1992 feature film of that name starring Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche, died on Thursday in London. Ms. Hart had long been circumspect about her age but was believed to have been in her late 60s. The cause was cancer, a spokeswoman for her husband, the advertising mogul Maurice Saatchi, told The Press Association, the British news service. Ms. Hart, who was active on the London arts scene as a producer of plays and poetry readings, was known formally as Lady Saatchi: her husband was named a life peer in 1996.

An article on Saturday about problems with a proposed bike-sharing program in New York City misidentified the company that had financial problems with a similar operation in Montreal. It was Public Bike System Company, the equipment provider for Alta Bicycle Share, which is a finalist to run New York's program, not Alta itself. The error was repeated in a front-page summary of the article. The article also misstated the Spanish cities where another company, Cemusa, which decided not to bid for New York's program, operates bike-share programs. They are Pamplona and San Sebastian, not Madrid and Barcelona.

DORSEN--Harriette K.,was born on August 26, 1942 in Newark, NJ, and died on June 5, 2011 in Salisbury, CT., peaceably and with her family at her side. She was the daughter of the late Sondra and Joseph Koffler. She married Norman Dorsen on November 25, 1965. In addition to her devoted husband, she is survived by three daughters, Jennifer, Caroline and Annie, and three grandchildren, Claudia, Tanya and Mateo, all of whom cherished and will never forget their "Mimi." She also leaves her brother-in-law, David Dorsen, his wife Kenna, and countless friends in New York, Cornwall, CT, Sanibel, FL, and elsewhere. She was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and New York University School of Law. After taking time to raise her children, she joined the law firm of Lankenau, Kovner and Bickford, where she rose to be managing partner. She left LKB to become general counsel of Bantam Doubleday Dell publishers and, after a merger, general counsel of Random House, where she was one of the country's most forward-looking and influential publishing lawyers. She then became an executive at Plaza Construction Company. After retiring, she concentrated on her many interests, including photography, crossword puzzles, NIA dancing, bird-watching, Yoga, and above all her children and grandchildren. Throughout her life she was an accomplished and eclectic cook. She was at various times a member of the boards of Planned Parenthood New York, the Cornwall Association and the Cornwall Consolidated School Fund for Excellence. Active in politics; she was elected chair of the Cornwall Democratic Town Committee and chair of the Northwest Connecticut Democratic Coalition. There are no words adequate to describe the lovely person Harriette was, the good that she did, the support she provided, or the depth of feeling with which she will be missed. Contributions in her name may be made to the Women's Cancer Center at NYU Cancer Institute, 160 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016. Burial will be private. The date of a memorial in Cornwall will be announced.

Do bears feel grief? On Friday, workers at the Central Park Zoo euthanized one of its most popular and beloved residents: Ida, a 25-year-old polar bear who had suffered from liver disease. It was a painful moment for her keepers, who were given time with her before she was put down.

After years of weighing in on issues like secondhand tobacco smoke and radon exposure, Dr. Jonathan Samet is accustomed to controversy. And last week, Dr. Samet, a University of Southern California physician and epidemiologist, found himself at the center of debate again as chairman of a World Health Organization committee ruling on the health effects of cellphone use. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, which consisted of 31 scientists from 14 countries, concluded that cellphones are ''possibly carcinogenic,'' putting the devices in the same category as about 260 chemicals, pesticides and other substances, including coffee, that might lead to certain cancers.

Dijon James, 17, and Jo Doodle, 17, showed up for their prom on Friday night looking as if they had just come from a skate park. Both teenagers, who attend high school in Harlem, wore dressed-down skateboarder chic, in skinny jeans and sneakers. They munched on food from McDonald's and leaned against the tall marble columns in front of the New York Public Library's main branch, at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street in Manhattan.

RAUSNITZ--Egon, beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died peacefully today at home with his wife and daughters. Born in Gablonz, Sudeten, then part of Czechoslovakia, in 1925, Egon's education was cut short by the advancing Nazi armies. This unfortunately ended his dreams of following his father, Julius, into the practice of medicine. He fled with his parents and two brothers into Eurasia eventually reaching as far as Tashkent. He served with distinction during World War II with the Czech division of the Red Army for which he has since been awarded several medals by the Czech government. After the War, Egon returned to Gablonz but fled to avoid the Communist takeover. He emigrated, again with his parents and brothers, to New York City. There he met and married the love of his life, Lee Peck, in 1954. They have two daughters, Diana and Linda. His family was the most important part of his life. He leaves behind his bride, Lee; daughters, Diana Rausnitz Riklis and Linda Rausnitz Jesselson; six grandchildren, Jordana, Talia, Samuel, Roni, Jonathan and Maya, and five great- grandchildren, Ayelet, Leora, Elan, Zachary and Avi. Egon, with great strength of purpose, roused himself just two weeks ago to travel to Philadelphia for the Bris of his youngest great grandson, Avi. His family, including his brother, Paul, sister-in-law, Vera, cousin, Steve Israeler, sons-in-law, Ira D. Riklis and Michael Jesselson, and grandsons-in-law, Dr. Benjamin Cooperberg and Andrew Day, all deeply feel his loss. The funeral will be held Tuesday, June 7th, at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th Street, at 9:30am.

In its quest to win approval of its $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA, AT&T just got a lot of help from its friends. Eight technology giants, including Facebook and Microsoft, and 10 venture capital firms, filed letters supporting the acquisition late on Monday. The letters, filed with the Federal Communications Commission, lent their support to AT&T's argument that the T-Mobile deal will help the company extend its next-generation data network across the country, helping to meet the growing need for wireless broadband services.

FRANKFURT, Germany -- In 1919, a soldier in Munich discovered that he could galvanize small groups of fellow trench warfare veterans with virulently anti-Semitic diatribes. A superior officer, impressed with the soldier's oratorical skills, asked him to commit his ideas to paper. Out of that came the first written record of Adolf Hitler's obsessive hostility toward Jews, an embryonic form of the worldview that would later lead to the Holocaust and millions of deaths. Now, the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles has acquired what may be the original version of the document, known as the Gemlich Letter. In July, the center plans to put it on public view for the first time, at its Museum of Tolerance, making the letter the centerpiece of its Holocaust exhibit.

UJA-Federation of New York mourns with great sadness the passing of our dear friend Egon Rausnitz, beloved father of Linda Jesselson and Diana Riklis and father-in-law of Michael Jesselson and Ira Riklis, leaders in the Jewish community whose commitment to philanthropy has helped us strengthen the Jewish people in New York, in Israel, and around the world. Egon's legacy will be remembered through the generosity and kindness of his children, grandchildren, and extended family, to whom we offer our sincerest condolences. May his memory be a comfort and a blessing. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

When Chad Etzel and Paul Stamatiou began to raise additional money for their technology start-up in the fall of 2010, they were preparing for an investment frenzy. The young entrepreneurs, who had already raised $200,000 for Notifo, their mobile notifications platform for businesses, used their contacts from the start-up incubator Y Combinator, along with the investor matchmaking site AngelList, to arrange nearly 40 meetings with venture capitalists, including some of the best-known investors in Silicon Valley. They set a goal at $300,000, later increasing the number to $500,000.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of their long-time beloved friend and esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. John Tomsky, President.
GROSS--Herman. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns his loss and extends sympathy to his wife Gertrude and family.

An article on May 15 about efforts to build a battalion of foreign mercenary troops in the United Arab Emirates referred imprecisely to the role played by Erik Prince, the founder of the security firm Blackwater Worldwide. He worked to oversee the effort and recruit troops. But Mr. Prince does not run or own the company Reflex Responses, which has a contract with the government of the U.A.E. to train and deliver the troops, according to the company president, Michael Roumi. An article on May 16 repeated the error.

FISCHER--Dr. Murry G.,died on June 5, 2011 at age 91. He was a surgeon at Beth Israel Medical Center for over 60 years. He was a beloved husband to Jean, father to Mindy and Richard, grandfather to David, Sarah, and Daniel, brother to Lester, and educator to hundreds of budding surgeons. Services: Tuesday, 10:45, Plaza Chapel.

A music review on Thursday about a program at the Stone, in the East Village, misspelled the surname of the composer of a piece played by the Prism Quartet, ''Straight Up.'' He is James Primosch, not Primrosch.

MARX--Herbert L. Jr. Herbert L. Marx Jr.,89, on May 31, 2011. His was a life well-lived, well-savored, and well-loved. Arbitrator, writer, editor, teacher, leader, father and grandfather. His thirst for knowledge, ease with people, respect for a variety of perspectives and ability to express reasoned opinion found welcome audience in all parts of his life. He was very proud his career continued into his eighty-ninth year. He passed on his love of literature, arts and a collector's passion for playbills, tea tins, and most of all, dictionaries, to more than one generation. His family grieves his loss. Children: Jonathan, Timothy and Alison Marx; daughters-in-law Johanna Lackner Marx, and Nan Simons Marx; grandchildren: Alyssa Marx Gray, Ariel Marx, Sophie Marx; Benjamin Marx; grandson-in-law David Gray; Benjamin Lackner Marx; and Joshua Lackner Marx. Stepdaughter Tedra Schneider and her children Gregory, Andrew and Hilary; Benjamin and Samuel Levine, children of the late Michael Levine, stepson; Stepdaughter-in-law Ellen Levine and her children Victoria and Robert. His first marriage was to Hilda Fisher Marx who survives him. He later wed the late Dorothy Sachs Marx. Herbert was an esteemed arbitrator for 37 years, serving six Presidential Emergency Boards; founding President National Association Railroad Referees; VP, Chair and Parliamentarian Nat'l Academy of Arbitrators; Member American Arbitration Association, Federal Mediation Conciliation Service, National Mediation Board; and countless national and regional panels. He was author, editor and contributor to noteworthy publications on labor, bargaining and religion. He served as adjunct faculty Cornell, Pace and Rutgers Universities; lecturer at Stanford University and Worcester College, Oxford, UK. Prior, he was VP, General Cable Corporation for 23 years. His career began as editor Scholastic Magazines; editor "The Dartmouth", Dartmouth College ('43). During WWII, he served the OSS in London/Paris. Truly a splendid life. Contributions may be made to Reach Out and Read, in honor of Herbert's lifelong love of literature. Memorial to be held later this summer.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the loss of Leo Greenland, a friend and generous supporter for more than 50 years. He established the ADL Rita and Leo Greenland Library and Research Center, which today houses one of the world's largest digital collections of extremist publications. Leo was an Honorary Life Member of ADL's National Executive Committee and National Commission, Vice President of the ADL Foundation and a longtime member of the New York Regional Board. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Eileen, his sons, Seth and Andrew, and the entire family. Robert G. Sugarman, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

Ever since Charles Gwathmey died in 2009 people in the architecture world have wondered what would become of his partner, Robert Siegel, and the firm they founded in 1968, Gwathmey Siegel & Associates Architects. Now the answer is clear: the architect Gene Kaufman has acquired a majority share and the firm will become Gwathmey Siegel Kaufman & Associates. Mr. Kaufman's own firm will retain its name, Gene Kaufman Architect (GKA). In addition to serving as the principal of the new Gwathmey Siegel, Mr. Kaufman will serve as the chief executive of both firms. Mr. Siegel will continue in a leadership role at the firm. ''We wanted to increase the body of new work,'' Mr. Siegel said. ''Our design expertise combined with his development expertise will make projects more likely to happen economically but also be much more exciting from an architectural point of view.''

9 P.M. (USA) WHITE COLLAR Matt Bomer, above, returns as Neal Caffrey, a bond forger escaped from prison who teams up with Peter Burke (Tim DeKay), the agent who put him there, after being forced to choose between cooperating with the enemy or ending up back behind bars. In this Season 3 opener, these bickering buddies must put aside their differences to track down the con who robbed the Federal Reserve. In the second-season premiere of ''Covert Affairs,'' at 10, Piper Perabo picks up as Annie Walker, a C.I.A. operative with exceptional linguistic skills striving to balance her ''pseudo-normal'' life with her high-drama adventures -- in this case, protecting a Russian tennis player. 4:30 P.M. (HBO) THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE (2009) In this adaptation of the Audrey Niffenegger best seller, Eric Bana plays Henry, a Chicago librarian and unwilling time traveler who flits -- naked -- in and out of the life of his true love, Clare (Rachel McAdams), only to return each time with increasingly disconcerting information about her future. ''The director Robert Schwentke lays a heavy hand on every nuance and has made a dirge about love instead of an ode,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

Visiting hours will be held from 5 to 8pm on Wednesday, June 8th at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York, NY. Service, Thursday at 10am at the funeral home, followed by interment in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. Relatives and friends are invited to attend.

A book by the French Resistance hero Stephane Hessel that has sold more than 3 million copies in Europe since its publication in October will be published in the United States this fall. Twelve, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, said on Monday that it would release ''Time for Outrage,'' which has been translated from the French by Marion Duvert, in September. The slim pamphlet-like book, only 29 pages long when it was published as ''Indignez-Vous!'' in France, urges people to adopt the principles of the French Resistance in response to issues of immigration, social policy, welfare and Israel's treatment of Palestinians.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our cherished friend and benefactor Leo Greenland. We are fortunate to have known this dynamic and generous-hearted gentleman whose warmth, intelligence, and humor embraced us all. Like everyone who knew Leo, we felt a close bond of friendship the first time we met him. With his beloved wife, Eileen Ludwig Greenland, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council, he championed the efforts of Rockefeller scientists working at the frontiers of biomedicine. Leo will be remembered for his keen mind and impassioned commitment to the many causes and institutions that engaged him through his life. We celebrate a life remarkably well lived, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Eileen; and to the entire Greenland family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Jeffrey Ravetch, Theresa and Eugene M. Lang Professor Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

She was Mr. Sisulu's deceased sister, not Mrs. Sisulu's.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Officers and Directors for the Friars Foundation deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed former President Leo Greenland. FISCHER--Murry, G.,MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center community acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Murry G. Fischer, MD, Associate Chairman of the Department of Surgery. A member of the Beth Israel family for over 60 years, Dr. Fischer also served for over 30 years as Director of Surgical Education, overseeing the post-graduate education of thousands of surgeons in training. In recognition of his exemplary commitment to medical education, Dr. Fischer was honored by Beth Israel in 2000 with the establishment of the Murry G. Fischer, MD, Distinguished Educator Award, presented annually to a member of the Beth Israel Attending staff who exemplifies Dr. Fischer's commitment to surgical post-graduate education and training. Dr. Fischer also was a well-respected and prodigious general surgeon, with particular expertise in a wide variety of gastrointestinal sub-specialties, and held the academic title of Professor of Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He also supported the hospital in other capacities, including his many years of service on the Medical Board. He will be greatly missed. To his beloved wife, Jean, his son, Richard, his daughter, Mindy, the entire Fischer family, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Steve Hochberg Chairman, Board of Trustees; Harris M. Nagler, MD President; Sheldon Simon, MD President, Medical Board; Martin S. Karpeh, Jr., MD Chairman of Surgery

MACK--Kay, of Lawrence, NY, passed away on May 25, 2011. Beloved wife of Sheldon Mack, loving mother of Larry (Lisa) and Alyssa Kuhn (Matt). New York theatrical flops consuming $2 million to $3 million usually occur on Broadway, where plays cost that much and musicals are easily twice as expensive. Such debacles are rarer Off Broadway, but the lead producer and investors in the Nashville-themed musical ''Lucky Guy'' lost at least that much money when the show closed on May 29, 10 days after opening night, according to two theater producers with knowledge of the musical's capitalization. Money aside, long-held dreams were also dashed: The show's lead producer, L. Glenn Poppleton, who had been developing ''Lucky Guy'' for years, had been aiming to transfer the musical to a Broadway house in the fall, according to an e-mail message that he sent to potential investors and that was shared with the Times. He was scrambling to raise an extra $500,000 to cover shortfalls in the days before the show closed, according to the e-mail.

''The X Factor'' will go forward in the United States without the British singer and model Cheryl Cole, one of the judges that Simon Cowell had recruited for the talent competition. Fox and the production companies behind the show, FremantleMedia North America and Syco TV, confirmed on Monday that the singer and dancer Nicole Scherzinger would replace Ms. Cole on the judges' panel for the show, which is holding auditions in advance of a September premiere.

MARCUS--Harold, age 82, of Butler, New Jersey, died June 4, 2011. He was predeceased by his parents, Dorothy Kittle Marcus and Max Marcus; his stepmother, Shirley Marcus, and his companion of more than 30 years, Darys Harrison. He is survived by numerous cousins and close neighborhood friends. Harold was a graduate of Rhodes School and earned Bachelor of Science and Master of Science Degrees from Columbia University. He served with the United States Army during the Korean War in Pusan, Korea. Initially, he was a chemist at Memorial Hospital, New York City and then worked Physiology Laboratory at the Institute for Muscle Disease in New York. Thereafter, he was employed at the Albert Einstein Medical Center for 24 years completing his career as a Senior Associate in the Physics Department and as the radioactive and radiographic materials at their facilities. Following his retirement in 1990, he continued his life long study of scientific subjects with Botany curses at the New York Botanical Gardens, building a small botanical laboratory in his home and becoming a very active home gardener after moving to Butler, NJ in 1992. He was a member of the American Association of Physicists in Medicine and the Health Physics Society. Graveside services will be held at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ on Tuesday, June 7, 2011 at 11:15am. Services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

The debate about cellphone safety was reignited yet again last week when a panel of the World Heath Organization declared that it was ''possible'' the phones could cause cancer. This is the first time a major health organization has suggested such a link, and it was promptly disputed by many scientists, who have been saying for years that there is scant evidence cellphones cause cancer and that it is biologically implausible to think they could.

THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Solvers frequently comment on a constructor’s use of the “rare” letters seen in crossword puzzles, particularly J, Q, X and Z. In fact, this usage has even been given a nickname. A puzzle with a plethora of these letters is described as “Scrabbly.” I have to confess that I enjoy a Scrabbly puzzle as much as the next person, although I am in the camp that believes that you shouldn’t endanger a perfectly good theme or sector just to get those letters into the grid.

The recent events swirling about the ex-next-president of France, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, have revived old tropes about how culture affects sex, including sexual violence. Before this scandal, many continued to believe that Americans are still infected by their Puritan past in matters sexuel, while the French are just chauds lapins: hot rabbits. The supposed difference consisted of not only a heightened sexual activity but an altered set of conventions about where to draw the line between benign sexual interaction and harassment. The French, many believed, drew that line differently.

Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She’s confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

Chloë Sevigny’s resort collection for Opening Ceremony, shown yesterday evening at the St. Patrick Youth Center in SoHo, exuded a nostalgic, teenage spirit — and even included pieces made in collaboration with the storied skate brand Vision Street Wear. “It’s hard to encapsulate my inspiration because there are so many different looks, but I think it’s just like, sexy girl you see walking down the street in a cool outfit,” Sevigny said. “A lot of eyelet, a lot of leather, playing with the hard and the soft, the good and bad inside of us all.” The hairstylist Thomas Dunkin, who used Sebastian Potion 9 for a “soft, natural, ’80s skater girl vibe,” spared the models’ hair from heat tools (good thing, as the center was not air-conditioned). The makeup artist Lottie Stannard applied M.A.C. Coffee Eyeliner “haphazardly” — topped off with loads of black mascara — and M.A.C. Blush Cream in Laid Back. “I’m really into a blush on the eyelid and on the high of the cheek,” Sevigny said. “The singer of Cocteau Twins used to do that — really pink eyelids. It added a little romance to the hard kind of street-edge clothes.”

There is much speculation about whether Representative Anthony D. Weiner will remain in Congress or resign his seat. But there is a politically expedient solution for Democrats if they want to show him the door: Neuter his district in the redistricting process, which will require New York to lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House of Representatives.

The Knicks announced an affiliation partnership with the Erie (Pa.) Bayhawks of the N.B.A. Development League on Wednesday, with Allan Houston to serve as the team’s general manager as well as continuing his role as assistant general manger of the Knicks.

Sorry, Queens, but you’ve had plenty of opportunities to feature the Cute Beatle, now it’s time to let the Bronx host him for an evening: Paul McCartney will play his first concert ever at Yankee Stadium on July 15, Live Nation Entertainment said on Wednesday. Mr. McCartney, the pop musician whose work in Wings is perennially overshadowed by his time with another popular British rock outfit, has some familiarity with New York ballparks, having served as the inaugural performer at Citi Field as in 2009, and as a surprise guest when Billy Joel closed down Shea Stadium in 2008; Mr. McCartney also played at Shea Stadium in 1965 as part of that beloved band whose name momentarily escapes us. (No, not the Rolling Stones, the other guys.) A statement from Live Nation said Mr. McCartney’s performance at Yankee Stadium “can safely be predicted to feature some nearly three hours of the world’s best loved and most known music, with hits, deep cuts and surprises spanning his unrivaled career,” including the 2008 album “Electric Arguments” that he released under the name the Fireman. With a top ticket price of $279.50 for this show, Mr. McCartney will hopefully throw in “Band on the Run” or “Let It Be,” too.

California has been having a lot of problems lately, but despite the budget, gas prices and the fear of earthquakes, the Golden State can still conjure romantic notions of endless summer: surfing in the Pacific, camping in Redwood, taking the archetypal road trip down a coastal highway. Driving is a large part of California’s culture, and typographically speaking, the bold red script on the state’s license plate seemingly embraces the happily casual and free-spirited notions commonly associated with the West Coast.

Reed Krakoff used the term “warm minimalism” to describe the changes — actually, improvements — offered in his resort line. Mr. Krakoff, trying to establish a look with his still-new signature label, makes progress with a more feminine-looking bunch of clothes that plays on rounded edges, easy volumes and intense colors offset by fleshy beige tones. Those colors — ultraviolet blue and green, coral and cinnamon — are his strength. They’re sharp and specific, with a modern art reference that he likes. See a green panel on a sleeveless wrap dress in an abstract blue python print, and you think, as intended, Rothko. It’s not all highfalutin: Mr. Krakoff also showed a well-done blazer in beige lightweight wool with a double lapel, a nice way to suggest layering. He paired the jacket with soft red trousers. Also strong were a leather shift, pounded thin like a cutlet, and an electric blue python skirt with pleating at one side.

LEBHAR--Blanche ("B") Eleanor, died peacefully in her sleep, age 93, May 19, 2011, at Vicar's Landing, Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida, her residence since 1994 after sixty-one years of living in Westport, Connecticut. Eldest daughter of Capt. Haswell C. Herbert, American Expeditionary Force, attached to the famous Lafayette Escadrille squadron, and of the Paris-born Ana's-Madeleine Haase, both of Scarsdale, New York. In 1933 the family moved to Westport. B graduated from Staples High School, Class of 1935, with a brilliant record both scholastic (Valedictorian) and athletic (basketball and tennis which became her lifetime sport. She attended Vassar College, Class of 1939. A great loss in March 1944, at the of 26, was her high-school sweetheart and then husband, Thomas R. Finnegan, 1st Lieut., US Army Air Force, giving his life for his country as pilot in a B-25 Mitchell bomber raid over the Imperial Japanese Army bases on the north shore of New Guinea. In 1950 B married widower Dr. Neil F. Lebhar, a Westport pediatrician, son of Dr. Norman and Ada Gedney Lebhar of New York. Predeceased by her two husbands and by her sister Mary "Babs" Patterson of Pompton Lakes, New Jersey, B is survived by her sons: Richard H. Finnegan, New York; the Rt. Rev. Neil G. Lebhar (Marcia), Jacksonville, Florida; Brett H. Lebhar (Marilyn), Cincinnati; Clay G. Lebhar (Natasha), Coral Springs, Florida. She is also survived by her sister Mrs. Kathleen E. Todd of Westport, seven grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren in whom she particularly delighted, as well as numerous nieces and nephews from three families and their offspring. A funeral service will be held Saturday, June 11th, 2pm, at the Church of the Redeemer (Anglican). 4815 Executive Park Court, Building 200, Suite 201, Jacksonville, FL 32216. In lieu of flowers, kindly make a memorial contribution in her name to your charity of choice or to: the Church of the Redeemer (Anglican), Earthplace (The Nature Discovery Center), 10 Woodside Lane, PO Box 165, Westport, CT, 06881; or Christ & Holy Trinity Church, 75 Church Lane, Westport, CT, 06880. Services are under the direction of Hardage-Giddens Funeral Home, 1701 Beach Blvd., Jacksonville Beach, FL.

Dr. Leo Rangell, a leading psychoanalyst during the heyday of classical Freudian talk therapy in the 1960s and '70s, and a relentless advocate for the slow approach to treating emotional distress even as antidepressants and managed care made short-term treatment the norm, died on May 28 in Los Angeles. He was 97. His family said the cause was complications of a surgical procedure the day before at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

SABSHIN--Melvin, M.D. The American Psychiatric Association has marked the passing of one of the most prominent psychiatrists in the second half of the 20th Century, Melvin Sabshin, M.D. Dr. Sabshin led the APA for nearly a quarter century from 1974 to 1997. He passed away on Saturday at the age of 85. Sabshin's accomplishments during his tenure at APA were numerous and far-reaching. His years at APA included publication of new editions of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders; creation of the American Psychiatric Press, Inc.; the development of practice guidelines; and the strengthening of research, advocacy, education, and public affairs. Sabshin also increased the organization's international involvement by working with the World Psychiatric Association and others to help end the use of psychiatry to suppress political dissent in the Soviet Union and other parts of the world. "Dr. Sabshin was an esteemed leader, an intellectual catalyst, and a consummate diplomat who was central to the evolution of modern American psychiatry," said APA President John M. Oldham, M.D. "As medical director of the American Psychiatric Association from 1974 to 1997, Dr. Sabshin understood that psychiatry, as a profession, needed a new direction, resolved to be part of the change, and succeeded." Sabshin completed high school at age 14 and undergraduate study at the age of 17. After brief service in the U.S. Army, he completed medical school and residency at Tulane University. He then took a position at the Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago and in 1961 became the head of the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Illinois College Medicine. During this time, he became active in the APA and was elected to the Board of Trustees; and in 1974 he became the medical director of the APA. Upon his retirement from APA, he took a position as clinical professor of psychiatry with the University of Maryland and lived much of the year in London with his British wife, where he was an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists. He remained active in the APA, attending Annual Meetings throughout his retirement. Sabshin was an author of dozens of scientific articles and author or co-author of seven books, including his latest in 2008, Changing American Psychiatry: a Personal Perspective, in which he describes changes in psychiatry in the post WWII era and later and offers his insights into the process. Dr. Sabshin is survived by his wife, Marion Bennathan, his son, James Sabshin, M.D., and four granddaughters.

An obituary on Friday about Hans Keilson, the German-born psychoanalyst who wrote about life in Nazi-occupied Europe, misstated at one point the name of a novella he wrote. As correctly reported elsewhere in the obituary, it is ''Comedy in a Minor Key,'' not ''Comedy in a Modern Key.'' The obituary also misidentified the translator of Dr. Keilson's novel ''The Death of the Adversary,'' which was reissued in English in 2010. It was translated into English by Ivo Jarosy in 1962, not by Damion Searls, who began campaigning to return Dr. Keilson's works to print in 2007 and later translated ''Comedy in a Minor Key,'' which had not been published in English.

O'CONNELL--Agnes N. PhD passed away on Monday after a long battle with cancer. Dr. O'Connell was a psychology professor at Montclair State University for over 25 years. She was an expert and pioneer in the area of women in psychology. She was honored during her career at Montclair with the Distinguished Scholar award and received Emeriti status upon retirement. She had numerous scholarly publications including an award winning series of books, Models of Achievement: Reflections of Eminent Women in Psychology. She chaired Eight National Task Forces for the American Psychological Association-Society for the Psychology of Women. Additionally, she founded the Montclair State University Emeriti Association and served as their President. Agnes is survived by her daughter, Mary Anne O'Connell Rush and son, Brian T. O'Connell. In addition to her two children, she has four grandchildren, Ryan, Marissa, Brendan, and Lauren. Visitation will be held Thursday from 7:00 to 9:00pm at the Holmdel Funeral Home 26 South Holmdel Road, Holmdel. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered Friday 10:00am at St. Benedict R.C. Church, Holmdel. Interment will be in the Holmdel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, a contribution can be made to the American Cancer Society 6725 Lyons Avenue, P.O. Box 7, East Syracuse, NY 13057. For directions or to send an online condolence please visit www.holmdelfuneralhome. com

The State Department will provide financial and logistical support to Merce Cunningham Dance Company's first set of performances in Russia as part of efforts by the Obama administration to improve ties with that country, the Cunningham Dance Foundation announced on Monday night. The performances will be presented June 14-16 by the International Chekhov Festival in Moscow. The dance company will also sponsor a weeklong film series and line-up of educational programs for Russian audiences about the work of Mr. Cunningham, the renowned New York choreographer who enjoyed an international reputation as a pioneer of modern dance and dance theater by the time of his death in 2009. Members of the Cunningham repertory will also teach a workshop on the choreographer's technique to dancers in Moscow.

ASPARAGUS and eggs have an affinity for each other. The voluptuous yolk softens and smoothes the grassy sharpness of the vegetable, while the asparagus brightens up the dull richness of the egg. The pair's most classic expression is asparagus hollandaise, a dish I adore. But it's fussy and time-consuming, and you end up with a side dish rather than dinner.
VALENTI--Salvatore. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Salvatore Valenti, associated with The New York Times from August 30, 1966 until retiring on May 1, 2006.

An article in some editions on Monday about the findings of a confidential New York State ethics panel that a health care consultant with ties to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not violate state lobbying regulations misidentified the boroughs where two hospitals that have been his clients are located. Maimonides Medical Center is in Brooklyn, not the Bronx. Montefiore Medical Center is in the Bronx, not Brooklyn.

NEGRIN--David. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Honorary Board Member and benefactor, David Negrin, "A Proud Greek". His dedication, kindness, generosity and genuine concern for the well-being of the residents of the Sephardic Home will always be cherished. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Rhea, children, Neil, Douglas and Beth, grandchildren and great grandchild. Officers and Board of Directors of the Sephardic Nursing & Rehabilitation Center Michael New, Executive Director Laurie Kamhi, President James Caspi, Ch. Of the Bd.

LOS ANGELES - No more than two minutes before the lights went down to begin Sony's media briefing at the E3 video game convention here late Monday afternoon, I was debating with a senior game executive seated beside me whether Sony would address the elephant in the room. That, of course, would be the horrendous network break-ins the company has suffered recently, which led to the possible disclosure of tens of millions of customers' personal information. As soon as Jack Tretton, head of Sony's American game business, got onstage to open the two-hour presentation, he used that exact pachydermic turn of phrase. And then he did the right thing. Forthright and humble, he acknowledged the problem and apologized to developers, retailers and most important, the public.

Devoted mother of Shane O'Neil, his wife Karen Frieman, Liam O'Neil, his wife June Ma, Kelly O'Neil Levy and her husband Harlan Levy. Cherished grandmother of Jamie, Max, Gavin, Caitlin and Emily. A listing of credits with a television review on Saturday about ''Teen Wolf'' on MTV, using information from an outdated news release, omitted two executive producers and misidentified the role of one of them. In addition to Jeff Davis, Marty Adelstein, Michael Thorn and René Echevarria, Tony DiSanto and Liz Gateley are executive producers of the show; Ms. Gateley is not an executive in charge of production for MTV. The listing also misspelled the surname of an executive in charge of production for MTV. He is Justin Levy, not Levi.

Ron Suskind, the author and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, will offer a new account of the financial crisis and its aftermath in ''Confidence Men,'' a book to be released by HarperCollins in September, the publisher said on Tuesday. ''This is a book that shows how the financial collapse did virtually nothing to change the culture of Wall Street,'' Tim Duggan, a vice president and executive editor of Harper, said in an e-mail. Mr. Suskind, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, is the author of ''The One Percent Doctrine,'' ''The Way of the World'' and ''The Price of Loyalty.''

Are we just being anthropomorphic? Or does that bay colt in Slide 13 look awfully surprised? If so, he wasn't the only one at the Belmont Stakes 40 years ago who couldn't believe what had just happened. For the colt was Pass Catcher, a 34-1 shot, who denied the bid by Canonero II of Venezuela to become the first 3-year-old to win the Triple Crown since Citation in 1948.

WECHSLER--Arnold. With heartfelt sadness, Wechsler Ross & Partners mourns the loss of our founder, chairman, CEO and inspiration, Arnold Wechsler. Arnold was a creative visionary who transformed the field of investment marketing. He was not just our leader but a great friend and mentor to all of us. Arnold defined the words life force and it is impossible to imagine a world without his vigor, warmth, humor, generosity and infectious laughter. Our own world certainly will never be the same. We offer our sincerest condolences to his loving family. May his memory continue to inspire love and creativity in all who have been touched by his presence.

10 P.M. (ABC) REALITY RULE$: WHEN TV GETS REAL In this special edition of ''20/20,'' Chris Connelly delves into the underbelly of reality television and the bad behavior that fuels profits. He also examines the impact of cable reality shows on network programming and introduces four creators of top-rated series: Andy Cohen (Bravo's ''Real Housewives'' franchise), J D Roth (NBC's ''Biggest Loser'' and ABC's ''Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition''), Michael Hirschorn (VH1's ''Celebrity Rehab'') and SallyAnn Salsano, who grants ''20/20'' access to the control room of MTV's ''Jersey Shore,'' now on location in Florence, Italy, above. In other segments Deborah Roberts explores why the ''Real Housewives'' are so nasty through interviews with Mr. Cohen, Kyle Richards of Beverly Hills and Caroline Manzo of New Jersey. And Mr. Connelly reports on the postshow success of reality stars like Bethenny Frankel, Kim Kardashian and Mike Sorrentino and Nicole Polizzi (the last two being better known as the Situation and Snooki). Mr. Connelly also traces the trajectory of Bret Michaels from rocker to reality-television brand name, while Ms. Roberts looks at shows like ''Cake Boss'' and ''Project Runway,'' in which talent is necessary to win. Last, Ms. Roberts also goes behind the scenes at a casting call in Los Angeles for a new series. 1 P.M. (MSNBC) ANDREA MITCHELL REPORTS As part of NBC News's Education Nation On-the-Road tour, Ms. Mitchell takes her program to Philadelphia. Her guests include Schools Superintendent Arlene C. Ackerman and Representative Chaka Fattah, Democrat of Pennsylvania. The discussion continues on ''Hardball With Chris Matthews,'' at 5, with Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia and his wife, Lisa Nutter, president of Philadelphia Academies, whose mission is to expand opportunities for public school students through a career-focused curriculum.

A federal judge on Tuesday denied a request by prosecutors to reconsider his ruling last month striking down a ban on direct contributions from corporations to political candidates, setting into motion what could be a pivotal court battle over one of the biggest legal and political issues of the day. In his ruling, Judge James C. Cacheris of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia stuck by the reasoning he used in late May: that the Supreme Court's logic in last year's Citizens United decision, which struck down limits on independent spending by corporations in election campaigns, should also apply to campaign contributions by corporations.

DALLAS - Donnie Walsh figured it was only a matter of time and place. Someone would do what he didn't do and make Mark Jackson a head coach in the N.B.A. ''He's a leader, that's the biggest attribute,'' Walsh said Tuesday on the morning after Jackson, his old point man in Indiana and a current ABC analyst, was named coach of the Golden State Warriors.

On a sunny morning about three weeks ago, I found myself sitting across a table from Representative Anthony D. Weiner at Coffee Shop, in Union Square, chatting about Twitter. I had asked for an interview after my editor noticed that Mr. Weiner's Twitter feed was punchier and more candid than that of the average elected official, and that he sometimes seemed just 140 characters away from a career-bungling mistake. So we decided to do an article on his use of social media, and he was happy to cooperate.

MCCORMACK--Joseph Charles, 86, of Highland Beach, FL., formerly of Baldwin on June 5th. Beloved husband of Eileen, loving father of Michael (Susan), Robert (Carol), John, Suzanne (Michael Cleven) and Joseph (Ruthanne). Cherished grandfather of Joseph, Peter, Timothy, Kathleen, Christopher, Connor, Brian, Colin and Sarah. Brother of John Robert (deceased). Graduate of Columbia University. Proud veteran of the US Navy, having served in WWII and the Korean Conflict. A long and distinguished career as a Senior VP with Tishman Realty and Construction, during which he played an integral part in the building of many of New York City's major landmarks including The World Trade Center, Madison Square Garden, The Olympic Tower, The City Spire, and The Four Seasons, as well as 1986's major renovation of Carnegie Hall. Joe proudly worked with many charity organizations, attaining the rank of 3rd degree within the Knights of Columbus, a Knight of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher and a former President of the Friends of Mercy. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice. Visitation will be help on Thursday June 9th from 2:00-4:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm at Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre. Funeral Mass, Friday, June 10th, 9:30am, at St Joachim's Church, Cedarhurst.

Memorable dishes sometimes come out of nowhere. One recent evening in Tarragona, just south of Barcelona, I wandered past a number of cafes and tapas bars. Txantxangorri, a Basque place serving rice dishes -- not paellas -- was the only one that had seats. The rice with rabbit, served in a terra cotta casserole, was simple, satisfying and, unlike the Michelin-starred dishes I had elsewhere in Spain, something I could try at home. With reds from Roussillon, a region that is practically in Catalonia anyway, I had my chance. If you do not have an earthenware casserole, you can make the whole thing, from stovetop to oven, in enameled cast iron. FLORENCE FABRICANT

When a preservationist in Greenwich Village learned last week that Panchito's Mexican Restaurant had painted over the faded lettering reading ''Fat Black Pussycat Theatre'' above its entrance, he was outraged by what he viewed as the destruction of a link to a musical milestone. ''This was a tangible connection to the Village's great history as a place where musicians and artists changed the world,'' said the preservationist, Andrew Berman, executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. And in his view the theater certainly qualified as just such a place.

At its corporate headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., the Ford Motor Company announced Thursday that it would introduce its C-Max small crossover vehicle in 2012 as the foundation of a dedicated line of parallel hybrid and plug-in hybrid vehicles. The strategy closely resembles that of the Toyota Prius, the hybrid sedan that soon will be offered also as a plug-in hybrid, as well as in a wagon body style and potentially a compact hatchback.

Stock research has long been considered a big money loser on Wall Street. It costs millions to produce and most investors are unwilling to pay hard cash for it. But in 2006 Goldman Sachs came up with a plan to leverage its equity research, funneling short-term stock tips to its biggest trading clients.

There’s a rhythm, slightly irritating to television critics, to the rollout of the new fall shows on the major television networks. After the upfront presentations in May, DVDs are mailed or online screeners are posted with warnings that the shows in question are works in progress, and that credits and effects — or even actors and entire plot lines — may change. Later in the summer the final screeners are provided (meaning that the conscientious or curious critic could end up watching every new pilot twice).

Two weeks ago, “CBS Sunday Morning” aired my story about the end of the Space Shuttle program. It was a story dear to my heart, one I’d hoped to do for years. It took me three trips to Kennedy Space Center to finally film the liftoff (because the final liftoff of the shuttle Endeavour kept being delayed).

There are a bunch of brothers and sisters who have reached the pinnacles of their respective fields. Standouts include the late Bruce Wasserstein, the star investment banker, and his late sister, Wendy Wasserstein, the renowned playwright. There is Maryanne Trump Barry, a federal judge in New Jersey, and her brother, The Donald. And most famously these days, we have the Emanuels: Rahm, the mayor of Chicago; Ari, the Hollywood super agent; and Zeke, a health care expert.

On Monday, The New York Times published a second article in a series examining the treatment of the developmentally disabled in New York State. In his investigation, Danny Hakim of The Times reviewed thousands of state records and court documents and interviewed current and former employees at nine state-run institutions that house the developmentally disabled. He found that supervisors at these institutions have tolerated physical and psychological abuse, knowingly hired unqualified workers, ignored complaints by whistle-blowers and failed to investigate credibly cases of abuse and neglect.

The Dresden Staatskapelle will replace the Berlin Philharmonic as the resident orchestra of the Salzburg Easter Festival starting in 2013, officials have announced. The Berliners wanted to increase their performances at the Easter festival but were rebuffed for lack of money, so they announced a plan to move to Baden-Baden’s festival hall after next year.

Citigroup’s discovery of a security breach that occurred last month, affecting 200,000 credit card accounts in North America, underscores corporate vulnerability to Internet attacks. In this video interview, CNBC asks a cybersecurity expert if a tipping point has been reached in the battle to keep secure networks safe.

Newt Gingrich’s campaign manager and a half-dozen senior advisers resigned on Thursday, two aides said, dealing a significant setback to his bid for the Republican presidential nomination and severely complicating his hopes for a political comeback.

On May 1 — almost seven weeks ago, or several eons in Internet time — the magazine published a Riff by Dan Kois titled “Reaching For Culture That Remains Stubbornly Above My Grasp.” The shorter online headline is “Eating Your Cultural Vegetables.” The tonal distinction between these two headlines may be crucial, for reasons explored below.

With their refined silk embroidery and unironic butterfly and heart shapes, Sophia 203 belts, necklaces and flower-child headbands feel very Yves Saint Laurent by way of Williamsburg. Sophia Edstrand, the designer behind the label, is from Sweden but her C.V. has a very French accent: she studied fashion design in Paris, worked as a salesgirl at Colette — “It was supposed to be for pocket money while I was a student, but I spent it all on shoes,” she says gleefully — then did a 10-year stint as the creative assistant to the Parisian jeweler Marie-Hélène de Taillac. Edstrand now splits her time between Paris and Jaipur, India, where she moved six years ago and where her one-year-old line is produced by traditional craftsmen. “The embroidery that’s done here is unbelievable,” Edstrand says. “When I showed one of my pieces to Manish Arora” — the New Delhi designer who’s known as the John Galliano of India — “he couldn’t believe it. And people here are not afraid of color.” Neither is Edstrand, who named the line for her favorite Pantone shade, a bright fuchsia. Lampshades, children’s wear and bridal pieces are coming up next, and Edstrand is happy to undertake custom orders. She claims she had no thoughts of YSL when she was designing her pieces but is happy to report that Stefano Pilati has already bought one of her heart belts. “I’m inspired by happiness and lightness,” she says. “That’s really where the collection is coming from.”

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has released “The Future of Natural Gas,” the latest in its valuable series of reports examining global energy choices. The report lays out a path for exploiting this abundant and relatively clean source of energy in ways that could limit environmental concerns and give the biggest near-term boost to efforts to trim emissions of carbon dioxide.

FiveThirtyEight, a blog devoted to helping readers of The New York Times cut through the clutter of this data-rich world, decided to find out.

Minimalism never takes a holiday at Calvin Klein, not even when Resort rolls around. But a side-effect of all that modesty is that small details like the slit in the front of an ivory shift or, in the case of this look, a deeply cut racer back, become quite unexpectedly erotic.

As the earth’s forests and other natural resources face growing peril, humans are affected in many unexpected ways. In recent years, musicians have found themselves organizing to save the pernambuco, a medium-size tropical tree native to Brazil and known for its unique red wood. Francisco Costa’s modest resort collection for Calvin Klein flowed easily from his fall line, with a fluid fit, an abundance of long-sleeved looks, and not too many surprises until the very end of the show. One difference is length; on Wednesday, in the Calvin Klein showroom, Mr. Costa’s hemlines were below the knee. Most styles, including a dark navy coat dress in crepe de chine and a collarless jacket in wool shown with a matching georgette skirt, came with a thin belt. For women looking for a break from the scuba and urban-surfer looks on the runways, Mr. Costa is your answer. He didn’t show any color, which is perhaps too bad. His evening looks were exceptional — a distraction of sexy halter and tank dresses in black or white silk suspended on sterling silver bands.

New work from the National Theater of Scotland, John Malkovich in the role of director and Simon Callow appearing in drag are just a few highlights coming this summer to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the enormous arts festival that annually takes over the Scottish capital. Festival organizers announced on Thursday that the festival, the biggest to date, would comprise a record 2,542 events in 258 sites (up from 2,453 shows last year). More than 600 productions will be offered for no charge during the festival, which runs Aug. 5-29. The revamped Web site www.edfringe.com will be available later Thursday and tickets go on sale Friday morning.
