This is the second in an occasional series on how business owners are succeeding and struggling with their technology needs. The business: Cannonball Wine (the name will be changing to Cannonball Winery), based in Healdsburg, Calif., is a five-person virtual winemaker. Rather than owning vineyards and processing facilities, the company contracts with various larger companies that provide grapes (mostly from Sonoma and Mendocino counties), as well as fermentation, aging, finishing, bottling and warehousing services, all to Cannonball's specifications. Founded four years ago with financing from the partners and their families and friends, as well as a Small Business Administration loan, the company is now shipping 35,000 cases of its Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot a year to wine stores and wholesalers.

WEISS--Paul E.,age 82, passed away Sunday, June 5th, 2011 at his home in Fleetwood, NY. Paul was born on July 20, 1928 in Ridgewood, NY to Paul and Emilie Weiss. He married Lynne McLean on April 26, 1958 and they went on to settle in Bronxville, NY. Paul is survived by his wife; his son and daughter in law, Kurt and (Serena) Weiss of New York, NY; his daughter, Karen Weiss of Greenwich, CT and his beloved German Shepherd, Madge. Paul was a nationally ranked roller skater in pairs, doubles and fours. He attended the University of Michigan, served in the US Marine Corp and graduated with an Engineering degree from New York University in 1956. He retired as Quality Chairman of IBM World Trade Corporation. Paul's love of life coupled with an incredible medical team once led by Dr. Robert Gomprecht and carried on by Dr. Stephen Warshafsky; prove medical miracles are possible. Private cremation and interment services were held on Wednesday, June 8 and in lieu of gifts, Paul would want you to take a moment and brighten someone's life today.

On Tuesday, Manager Joe Girardi watched Mark Teixeira writhe in such pain after being struck by a pitch that he thought Teixeira broke his right kneecap. On Wednesday, Teixeira seemed one of the healthier players in the Yankees' clubhouse. No sooner had Teixeira surprised himself by recovering so quickly than two of his teammates - relieverJoba Chamberlain and catcher Russell Martin - sustained injuries. Chamberlain was placed on the disabled list and will miss at least the next three weeks because of a strained flexor muscle in his right arm. Soreness in that area, in the forearm, near the inside of the elbow, can portend a more serious ailment, but Chamberlain and Girardi did not sound concerned.

The New York Philharmonic is taking a break from its normal early-summer concerts in New York City parks, adding performances in September instead. The orchestra will perform with the tenor Andrea Bocelli on Sept. 15 on Central Park's Great Lawn, a special event outside its usual parks series. Two days later at Avery Fisher Hall, it will play William Walton's music from the movie ''Henry V,'' narrated by Christopher Plummer, and music from Shakespeare's time. The concert had originally been planned for the spring but was moved because of a conflict with Mr. Plummer's schedule, said the orchestra's spokesman, Eric Latzky. Two other concerts are planned for September, although Mr. Latzky did not immediately release details. Mr. Latzky said the Philharmonic chose to replace the normal parks concerts with the September performances after the Bocelli concert came up. The regular parks concerts are expected to return in 2012.

MAURO--Kenneth, 63, founding partner of the appellate law practice of Mauro Lilling Naparty, LLP died on Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, NY after a lengthy illness. He is survived by his loving and devoted family; wife Marsha, daughter Morgan, sister Karen and sister-in-law Lynn.

While a handful of initial public offerings are hitting the market with a pop, many are landing with a thud. Following the frenzied debuts of LinkedIn, Yandex and other new Internet shares, it's easy to forget that dozens of other I.P.O.'s this year are falling below size expectations or not producing double-digit price gains. Investors just don't have the same fervor for nontechnology offerings, which in the United States have raised $22 billion so far this year, or roughly 80 percent of the total I.P.O. volume.

Q.Is it true you can get a virus from Google Images? A.Security researchers have found thousands of photos from searches within the Google Images site that have been infected with malicious code. In many cases, clicking on one of these poisoned images triggers a script that makes it seem like the computer has become infected with viruses. Another Web site pops up trying to wheedle your credit-card number in exchange for fake antivirus software.

In Week 2 Lady Gaga's album sales have come down to earth. But she's still No. 1. Her album, ''Born This Way'' (Interscope), was released on May 23, and in its first week it sold 1.1 million copies, thanks in part to a surprise 99-cent promotion by Amazon. In its second week out the album sold 174,000 copies, an 84 percent drop, according to data from Nielsen SoundScan. Its strongest competition on the Billboard chart this week is Adele's ''21'' (XL), which sold 121,000 copies in its 15th week in stores, bringing the album's total sales past two million, the first title this year to cross that benchmark.

Greenpoint, at the northernmost tip of Brooklyn, accessible to Manhattan by subway transfer to the G train, can seem physically removed from the rest of the city. Maybe mentally removed, too - the waterfront neighborhood feels a bit apart from Manhattan's hustle. Even so, it might seem surprising that on Friday afternoon, when a package arrived at Dandelion Wine addressed to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, no one there had heard of him. Not the mailman, who asked ''Is there a Dominique here?'' Not the three workers in the store. One of them, Tom Athans, accepted the package anyway; he had a ex-girlfriend in France and thought it might be a practical joke. There is a an explanation of sorts for why the package arrived at the wine shop. It shares the same address - 153 Franklin Street - as the $14 million TriBeCa town house where Mr. Strauss-Kahn is confined while he faces charges that he sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper.

I recently visited a business owner's facility. As our meeting ended, she turned to me and said, ''Wouldn't it be great if you could run a business without employees?'' There were no employees around. I smiled and gave the perfunctory head nod -- but it was a lying perfunctory head nod, if there is such a thing. I know that many people have commented on this very blog that they prefer, or would prefer, to run their businesses without employees. I don't feel that way, but let me state the obvious: employees can be a liability. Whether they are causing problems with customers, stealing, breaking things, suing you or doing something that gets you in trouble with a regulatory agency, employees can be trouble. And when trouble rears its ugly head, the owner cannot say, ''I was only taking orders!''

After a series of setbacks, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy organization whose victory in a historic lawsuit brought billions of additional dollars to poor school districts in New York State, has run out of money to sustain itself, the organization said. The organization's last remaining employee, Helaine K. Doran, will leave the group's Lower Manhattan office this month and, essentially, lock the door behind her.

Susan Stroman, the Tony Award-winning director and choreographer (''The Producers'') who was nominated for both jobs on ''The Scottsboro Boys'' in this Sunday's Tonys competition, has her next Broadway project: A musical adaptation of the film and novel ''Big Fish,'' aiming to open in spring 2012, the producers announced on Wednesday. A father-son story that weaves deathbed flashbacks with fantastical tall tales, ''Big Fish'' has music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa (''The Addams Family,'' ''The Wild Party'') and a book by John August, who also wrote the screenplay for the movie version. That 2003 picture was directed by Tim Burton and starred Ewan McGregor, Albert Finney, and Billy Crudup. Its producers were Dan Jinks and Bruce Cohen, who are also producing ''Big Fish'' for Broadway and who won the Academy Award for best picture in 2000 for ''American Beauty.''

WITH the iPhone now available through two networks, a profusion of Android phones hitting the market and an abundance of apps for every phone, you might think it would be easier than ever to find the right phone to give as a gift. But the vast number of choices makes it harder than ever. I mean, what is HSPA+, anyway? Here is an effort to walk you through the shopping process and to demystify some of the more important features.

An article last Thursday about online shelter magazines misstated the professional background of Katie Armour, a founder of one such magazine, Matchbook. She worked for three years for interior design firms; Michelle Adams, who started another of the magazines, Lonny, is not the only founder of an online shelter magazine with experience in interior design. The article also misstated the publication schedule of the online magazine Trad Home. It will be published again in October; it was not a one-time project.

SALNY--Alan S.,age 83, of West Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts died on Sunday, June 5, 2011 while hospitalized in Florida. Mr. Salny was the son of the late Samuel M. Salny, the prominent New England labor attorney and labor relations specialist and his widow, Rae Salny Brown. Alan is survived by his loving family; June G.(Freedman) Salny, his wife of over 60 years, daughter Susan and her husband Dean Trilling, son Stephen, two grandsons, Scott and his wife Meghan Trilling and Andrew Trilling and great-grandchildren, Elsie Rose and Adam Trilling. Mr. Salny was born in Boston and raised in Fitchburg, Massachusetts. He graduated from Worcester Academy in 1945 at the age of 17 and attended Williams College until his studies were interrupted by his service in the Military Intelligence Division of General MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo. After his honorable discharge from the army, Mr. Salny completed his studies at Boston University where, in succession to his father, he was a second-generation member of Tau Epsilon Phi. He graduated from BU in 1951. Mr. Salny was President of the Alan Salny Real Estate Company which manages the residential real estate portfolio developed in Baltimore, Maryland during the 1940s and the 1950s by his father. Mr. Salny has overseen the business collaboratively with his son since 1977. Alan Salny served on the Board of Directors of the Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation, a public company under the aegis of Martin S. Ackerman, the financier and President and Chairman of the Board of that company which was engaged in film processing and the mail-order sales of drugs and vitamins through United Whelan Corporation, a drugstore chain; Hudson National Inc., a mail-order firm; and Equality Plastics Inc., a consumer-products-distribution company. Mr. Salny was active with Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston (CJP), serving as Advance Gifts chairman for the organization's 1967 Newton, Massachusetts Appeal and Israel Emergency Fund. He also chaired CJP's Newton Appeal and Israel Emergency Fund campaigns in 1968 and 1969 and was appreciably involved with the organization's longstanding Real Estate Team and Business Men's Council. An avid tennis player who won many interclub tournaments, Mr. Salny played the game all-year-round in Florida, in Boston and also in the Negev during his and his wife's first visit to Israel in 1966, less than one year before the Six-Day War. He and his wife even attended Wimbledon on their honeymoon in 1950. Mr. Salny was also an enthusiast of sports (he held season's tickets to the Baltimore Orioles for over 50 years), politics, travel and jazz and classical music, especially the performances of the Boston Pops, Tanglewood and the by-gone Palm Beach Festival. Services will be held at the Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, June 12 at 11am. Burial will follow at Sharon Memorial Park in Sharon, MA. Memorial observance at his late residence following the burial on Sunday until 8pm and Monday and Tuesday 1-4pm and 7-9pm. Contributions in Mr. Salny's memory may be made to the Samuel and Rae Salny Endowed Fellowship, c/o Brandeis University, Mailstop 122, P.O. Box 549110, Waltham, Massachusetts 02454-9110, or to the charity of your choice.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Board of Directors of Queens Plaza and Electric Realty Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of the husband of our esteemed Board Member Eileen Greenland. We would like to extend our sympathy to her family.

After two days and nine hours of nego- tiations, the only point of agree- ment between N.B.A. owners and players is that a huge gulf still separates them on the key ele- ments of a new labor deal and that time is running short. Negotiators gathered here with a sense of guarded opti- mism, based on a willingness to talk and exchange ideas. By the time they parted Wednesday, the sunny sentiments were gone. ''We remain very far apart,'' said Commissioner David Stern, whose words were echoed an hour later, nearly word for word, by Derek Fisher, the players un- ion president.

The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday announced new safety restrictions on high-dose simvastatin, also known as Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug taken by an estimated 2.1 million Americans. The agency said the 80-milligram dose caused a potentially severe muscle disease, called myopathy, especially in the first year of taking the medication.

NO one knows who designed the iconic sunglasses Audrey Hepburn wore in ''Breakfast at Tiffany's.'' Speculated to be any one of a number of brands, they were most likely provided by the venerable British eyewear company Oliver Goldsmith, which made all the frames the actress wore in ''Charade,'' ''How to Steal a Million,'' ''Roman Holiday'' and ''Two for the Road.'' The company, which dates from 1926, was brought back to life in 2005 (it closed in 1985) by Mr. Goldsmith's great-granddaughter, Claire Goldsmith, who has now created a replica of the oversize Holly Golightly frames to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the film. She called upon craftsmen who worked with the company for generations and studied 40 stills to recreate the shape. (An original drawing never turned up.) Ms. Goldsmith likes to recall a passage from her grandfather's memoirs: ''He said: 'Today I met a delightful young lady called Audrey Hepburn. They tell me she is going to be a big star.' '' Oliver Goldsmith sunglasses, $370 at Artsee Eyewear, 259 Avenue of the Americas, (212) 414-0900.

After two seasons, Laurence Fishburne is leaving the cast of ''CSI,'' one of the longest-running series on prime-time television. CBS declined to comment Wednesday on many news reports about his departure, but network executives, speaking on condition of anonymity because CBS has not commented, acknowledged that they expected him to depart after the 11th season of the show, which ended in May. The network expects a new character to replace Mr. Fishburne's Dr. Raymond Langston for the 12th season, which will start in the fall.

I remember the day I reached my limit with the retail coffee and espresso business that my husband and I started in 2003. When we started our little food service venture, it was supposed to be a fun project that would eventually run itself and act as an additional source of income for our household. But after three years, two locations and countless hours, it became evident that our plan was easier said than done. I had felt the day coming. There are some things you just know about your business. We were fast asleep one cold, February morning in 2005 when Chris's cellphone rang at 4:15. It was the lead barista at our north location calling to say she wouldn't be able to work her shift. That gave one of us 15 minutes to jump out of bed, get dressed and fly into Bentonville, Ark., to open our flagship store in time for the morning rush. This was not the first time this had happened, but it ended up being a wake-up call in more ways than one. In my business-owner bones, I knew things had to change. I also knew that there was something fundamentally wrong with my business: me.

DALLAS - Dirk Nowitzki's sniffles and fever were essentially gone Wednesday, after a long shower, soup, tea, some food and a good night's sleep - rest made easier by the Dallas Mavericks' 86-83 victory over the Miami Heat. Nowitzki was limited to noncontact work at practice and said his illness should not be an issue for Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday at American Airlines Center. He is also playing with a torn tendon in his left middle finger, an injury to his nonshooting hand sustained in Game 1 that requires a protective splint.

Our case study last week examined the efforts of a bicycle shop owner in Princeton, N.J., to secure a loan. Charles Kuhn, who runs Kopp's Cycle, had sought $1 million to refinance the mortgage on the shop, pay down debt, and obtain working capital. Unfortunately for Mr. Kuhn, the recession has hurt both his business and, apparently, the value of his real estate, undermining its potential as loan collateral. But the lenders and other advisers we consulted suggested that Mr. Kuhn's inability to get a loan has more to do with how he has managed his business than the economic climate or the reluctance of bankers to make loans. ''The first impression is we are trying to treat the symptom and not the cause,'' said Lorraine Allen, regional director of the Small Business Development Center at the College of New Jersey in nearby Ewing. ''If the banks tell us we have a problem with cash flow, we have to trace through the lines of operation to see where the challenges are and address them, and not just for the sake of the loan.'' You're The Boss readers agreed.

8 P.M. (TCM) DRIVE-IN DOUBLE FEATURES Park yourself on the sofa and prepare to fall into the safe arms of your companion during this lineup of creature features aimed at atomic-age teenagers. The thrills begin with ''Them!'' (1954), about federal agents on a mission to destroy a colony of giant mutant ants and starring Edmund Gwenn and Joan Weldon (above, with, from left, Sean McClory, Fess Parker and James Arness). ''Cosmic Monsters'' (1958), at 9:45, involves a monomaniacal doctor (Alec Mango) who experiments with intense magnetic fields and ends up luring big, mean bugs from another dimension after accidentally blowing a hole in the ionosphere. ''Tarantula'' (1955), in which a scientist (Leo G. Carroll) creates a huge tarantula while trying to cure hunger, follows in its TCM premiere at 11:15. Other offerings include ''The Black Scorpion'' (1957), Edward Ludwig's film about prehistoric arachnids that terrorize the Mexican countryside after some unusual volcanic eruptions, at 12:45 a.m.; ''The Giant Claw'' (1957), directed by Fred F. Sears and starring a bird the size of a battleship and made from antimatter, at 2:30; and ''The Wasp Woman'' (1959), Roger Corman's cautionary tale about an executive (Susan Cabot) whose search for eternal beauty turns her into a monster, at 4. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR In collaboration with the Economist Film Project, the program presents a segment from ''Up in Smoke,'' Adam Wakeling's documentary about Mike Hands, a British tropical ecologist who, after working as a surveyor in Honduras and witnessing the decimation of the rainforest through slash-and-burn agricultural techniques that rendered the soil useless in three years, has made it his mission to find an affordable, nonindustrial solution to the problem.
WOHL--David. Happy Birthday David. You are always in my heart. Love, Nina

THE Indian fashion invasion continues apace, now on the Bowery, where Misha Nicole has established permanent digs following pop-ups in the neighborhood. At this roomy store, Misha Nicole Shivdasani, once a buyer at Bergdorf Goodman, wants to introduce sophisticated New York women to modern Indian design. You'll find plenty of silk and sequins in candy-bright colors. We like Manish Arora's baroque shapes, Namrata Joshipura's short-sleeve sequin shirts and Payal Singhal's tweaks on traditional garb. Alongside are covetable things from familiar brands, including Norma Kamali swimsuits, Paige denim and Sachin + Babi long summer dresses. Go for the jewelry: vintage pieces to spice up your summer look.

The crossword puzzle on Friday provided an erroneous clue for 30-Across, seeking the answer ''Ute.'' The clue should have read, ''Subject of a museum in western Colorado,'' not ''Subject of a museum in eastern Colorado.''
Hedge fund managers have been called plenty of names. Now, they can add another: local banker.

Listen up, Hulkamaniacs: Are you an aspiring young actor or journeyman performer looking for advice, inspiration and insider anecdotes from a seasoned show-business veteran? Would you be interested in attending an hour-and-a-half lecture by Terry Gene Bollea, a seasoned actor, musician and athlete? Not sure? How about a 90-minute, no-holds-barred stage production starring Hulk Hogan, the pointing, preening, all-American professional wrestler? Whichever sounds more appealing, you'll have your chance to pose questions to and receive wisdom from Mr. Hogan, the body-slamming alter ego of Mr. Bollea, on a tour that the wrestler is planning for next year and which his agency is envisioning as a Hulk-ified version of ''Inside the Actors Studio'' (with perhaps more Atomic Leg Drops than James Lipton's incarnation). The Agency Group said on Wednesday that it had signed up Mr. Hogan for the production, called ''In Conversation: Outside the Ring with Hulk Hogan,'' which will start with a few dates in the fall before commencing a worldwide tour next year. Nick Meinema of the Agency Group said Wednesday that the specific contents of the stage show were still being worked out, but would likely include ''about an hour of semi-scripted stories and behind-the-scenes stuff, synced up with video and pictures, stuff that he wants to share with his fans and will be exciting for them to hear from him -- personal stories, stories about matches and his career.'' The presentation will then conclude with a Q. and A. where audience members can ask the Hulkster about his life and work. But can they ask him to demonstrate the big boot on them? ''I doubt that highly, for insurance reasons,'' Mr. Meinema said. ''But maybe he can tell a story about how that finishing move came about.''
An obituary on Wednesday by The Associated Press, about the theater producer Tommy Brent, misspelled his family surname. It is Cheseldine, not Chesaldine.

FLORAL shorts on the spring runways made quite an impression on Glamour magazine's editors. In last month's issue, the three cover subjects -- Freida Pinto, Ashley Greene and Emma Stone -- were styled in a selection that included hot pants from D & G, retro high-waist shorts from Erdem and Peter Som, and boxing-style shorts from Lela Rose. In her spring collection, Michelle Smith, the designer of Milly, sent out a sporty pair (far right) in an unexpectedly feminine floral print. ''I'd like to say they are great for the office,'' Ms. Smith said, ''but that only really applies if you work in fashion.'' Still, in a workplace where miniskirts are office-approved, shorts can be a practical alternative to a mini. Matched with a nautical knit cardigan or a trim blazer, it could be your new work look. If that's still too risqué, there's always the weekend. Right, from top: Pleated pansy-print shorts, $70 at Topshop, 478 Broadway; (212) 966-9555;

JADE LAI, who owns Creatures of Comfort in NoLIta, stumbled upon the German label Hui-Hui during a shopping outing in Paris. The line, created by the sisters Katharina and Johanna Trudzinski and their friend Anne Schwätzler, is known for blurring their fine art and textile backgrounds with crafty fashion. Their playful summer collection, called Die Gerade und die Krumme, which, according to Johanna Trudzinski, ''translates to something like 'the straight and the bend,' '' includes quirky fabric paper bags that can be folded over to make a clutch; silk scarves digitally printed with images from Katharina's sculptural installations; and necklaces, like this one, that are handmade from cut wood, then honed and painted. Hui-Hui painted wood medallions on a sterling silver chain, $200 at Creatures of Comfort, 205 Mulberry Street; (212) 925-1005; creaturesofcomfort.us/.

OPENINGS Too late for the ''Sex and the City'' girls, KIEHL'S is opening its latest New York branch in the meatpacking district later this month. It will feature not only a full range of Kiehl's skin products but also a neon art installation and a photo booth for customers who feel like posting their pictures on the store's walls. The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom was made the 2-1 morning-line favorite to become the 12th horse to win both the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes on Saturday in the 143rd running of the Triple Crown's oldest and longest leg. He will break from the No. 9 post, and his trainer, Graham Motion, expects jockey John Velazquez to keep Animal Kingdom much closer to the front of the pack in the mile-and-a-half race than he was in the Preakness Stakes.

HIGH-SPEED METAPHOR Bart Chilton, below, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, fears that cheetahs are running wild on Wall Street. Mr. Chilton was referring to high-frequency traders, a group he nicknamed cheetahs because of their speed and fearless nature. ''We need to do a better job of keeping up with the cheetahs and the ramifications of technology in the financial sector in general,'' he told a conference of high-frequency traders in Amsterdam on Wednesday. Q.Ever since I upgraded to Internet Explorer 9, I have been having trouble printing Web pages, which come out looking different than what's on screen. What's wrong?A.To speed up its handling of Web pages, Internet Explorer 9 shifts the workload from the computer's main processor to the graphics processor. If your computer's video card does not support this type of hardware acceleration, your Web pages may print incorrectly. Update your printer's driver software to make sure outdated software is not the culprit. You can download the latest files for your printer model from the Support area of the manufacturer's Web site.

CHU--Jeffrey Chuan, beloved husband of Loretta Yung Chu, passed away at his home in Lincoln, MA on June 6, 2011, at the age of 91. Known as Chuan to family and friends, he was born into a family of scholars in Tienjin, China. He received his BS from the University of Minnesota and his MS from the Moore School at the University of Pennsylvania. Chuan was a core member of the engineering team that designed the first electronic computer, ENIAC, in 1946. As a Senior Scientist at Argonne National Laboratory, he helped design several improved versions of large-scale computers, until the 1950's when he became Chief Engineer at Univac for the LARC project, one of the earliest all-transistor computers. He continued to be a leading figure in the computer and electronics industry as microchip technology allowed computing devices to become smaller and more personal, becoming Director of Engineering and Vice President of Honeywell Information Systems, Senior Vice President at Wang Laboratories, and Chairman and CEO of Sanders Technology (Santec). He also served as Senior Advisor at Stanford Research Institute (SRI) and at Data Resources, Inc. (DRI). Most recently, he held the position of Senior Advisor and was a member of the Board at BTU International. In the 1970's, Chuan returned to China for the first time in nearly 40 years and discovered the cause that would become his passionate mission for the rest of his life. He became an active participant in the effort to modernize China. Meeting with Deng Xiao Ping and serving on various State boards, he brought his technological expertise and knowledge of Western business practices to China, and advised American companies seeking to do business in China. As a lifelong scholar himself, it was his greatest pleasure to serve as visiting professor at several universities in China. He personally established a scholarship for Chinese students to study English at Shanghai Jiao Tong University, and he facilitated the establishment of a partnership between Jiao Tong University and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Inspired by his years of living in the U.S., Chuan promoted the idea of public service as being an essential ingredient of a successful modern society. It was his self-appointed mission to inspire individuals to help those less fortunate, and to serve a cause beyond themselves. He advocated this ideal in his many public speeches in China, and he established a Campus Civility Award for public service at Jiao Tong University. However, he taught best by his own example. A man of tremendous vigor and vision, he spent his long public life in service to both his countries. Chuan is survived by his wife Loretta of Lincoln, MA; his brother Zhu Chuan-yi of Beijing, China; his sister Zhu Chuan-yi of Tianjin, China; his daughter Lynnet and husband Noel McDermott of Santa Cruz, CA; daughter Bambi and husband Michael Rae of Naples, Italy; daughter Diedre and husband Fanul (Bodhi) Kocica of Miami Beach, FL; and stepson Van Tsai and his wife Paula of Hanover, NH. He leaves eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by four sisters, Zhu Tao-le, Zhu Shang-rou, Zhu Chuan-xun, and Zhu Chuan-rong, and by his granddaughter Lauren Tsai. A celebration of Chuan's life will be held on Saturday, July 16, 11:00am, at the First Parish Church in Weston, MA. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery in NY is private. Donations in memory of Jeffrey Chuan Chu may be made to the Wharton-Penn China Center Fund by contacting Jeffrey Sheehan, jsheehan@wharton.upenn.edu. To view a full obituary, leave a condolence, or share a memory please visit www.jcchu.com or www.concordfuneral.com.

An article on May 26 about the songwriter Allee Willis misstated her work on the soundtrack for the film ''Beverly Hills Cop.'' She was a co-writer of two songs; she did not write the entire soundtrack.

HENNING--Eleanor Bloss, of Glen Cove, New York, formerly of Garden City, passed away peacefully after a long series of illnesses at the age of 93. She was surrounded by her family and devoted caregivers. She was the devoted wife to Robert and mother to Robert Jr. (Jean Smith), Margaret Minnick (Jeffrey), Richard (Eileen Kelly), Patricia Cochran (David), Douglas and Eleanor Clark (Walton). In addition she had seventeen grandchildren and five great grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister, Patricia Taylor of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. "Ellie" loved her family and her friends, and she had a true joie de vivre. Until the end, she insisted on being a central part of the lives of all of them. She always had a special effect on everyone because of her enthusiasm and interest in their accomplishments. Her patriotic spirit made her proud of her long time association with the Daughters of the American Revolution. Eleanor has been an enormous presence in the lives of everyone she touched. We will all miss her but know that her devoted husband, Robert, is welcoming her with open arms. Visitation will take place at the Fairchild Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, New York on Friday, June 10, 2011 from 5-8pm. Services will be at the Garden City Community Church on Saturday, June 11, 2011 at 10am. with a private burial at the Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Central Moravian Church, 73 West Church Street, Bethlehem, Pennsylvania 18018 or to any charity of your choice.

Trackers of the artist Edward Hopper tirelessly pursue the true settings of his city tableaux, so tinged with Gotham loneliness. Was the night-shrouded ''Drug Store'' modeled from the Waverly Place shop in Greenwich Village currently occupied by a corner bookstore? The artist offered them little help. ''What I wanted to do was to paint sunlight on the side of a house,'' was his typically terse clue about his work. City searchers would be wise to go 20 miles up the Hudson River to Nyack, a rustic backwater when Hopper grew up there in the 1880s. His home on North Broadway has been preserved as the Edward Hopper House Art Center.

WATSON--Donald James, of East Brunswick, died Tuesday, June 7, 2011 at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, New Brunswick. He was 57. Born in Manhattan, NY, he resided in Cranford before moving to East Brunswick 21 years ago. He worked as a mailer for the New York Times, Manhattan, NY, where he worked for 40 years and ran their activities and recreation center. He also worked part time as a sales assistant in Lowe's in Old Bridge. He was a very dedicated worker and had strong work ethics. Mr. Watson was a communicant of St. Bartholomew RC Church, East Brunswick. A sports enthusiast, he was a baseball coach for the East Brunswick little league and an avid New York Yankees and Giants fan. He played centerfield at Cranford High School when they won the State Championship, and played football there as well. While at Kean University he played baseball. He was recruited by the California Angels. He was very active in the Boy Scouts of America and was a Troop Leader. He loved to be on the beach at the Manasquan Inlet. Surviving are his wife of 21 years, Diane Giffin Watson; his three children: Kyle James, Colleen Elizabeth and Claire Alice, all at home; two brothers: Larry Watson and his wife Andrea of Cream Ridge and Richard Watson and his wife Marsha of Hammondsport, NY: two sisters: Ellen Watson of New York City, NY and Jayne Millering and her husband Scott of Matawan. Funeral services will be held on Saturday at 8:15am in The Brunswick Memorial Home, 454 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick, followed by a 9:00am. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Bartholomew Church, East Brunswick. Interment will follow at Holy Cross Burial Park, East Brunswick. Friends may call at the funeral home on Friday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. For directions, please visit www. brunswickmemorialhome.com Memorial contributions may be made to The Watson Family Foundation. Information will be available at the funeral home.

The work of Martha Graham, the legendary choreographer who redefined modern American dance, has been performed all over the world before and since her death in 1991 -- with the exception of Russia. That will change on June 23 at a gala celebrating the acclaimed career of Diana Vishneva at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Janet Eilber, artistic director of the Martha Graham Company, said Wednesday. Ms. Vishneva, a 34-year-old prima ballerina with both Mariinsky (formerly the Kirov Ballet) and American Ballet Theater, will perform ''Errand Into the Maze'' with Benjamin Robert Schultz, a member of the Graham company. Created in 1947, ''Maze'' is one of the 13 Graham masterpieces based on ancient Greek myths. ''It's kind of astounding because we've been everywhere else in the world,'' Ms. Eilber said of the performance. ''We're really excited. We're hoping that Diana Vishneva will whet their appetite for more Graham.''

KIM--Dr. Wan Hee. Dr. Wan Hee Kim, known as the father of the Korean electronics industry and a recipient of the U.S. Bronze Star Medal, died on May 24 in New York City. Dr. Kim was also the first Korean and youngest person (in 1963) to be granted tenure as a full professor at Columbia University. Over the past fifty years, Dr. Kim laid the foundation for, and was the key figure in the development and promotion of, the Korean electronics industry, from its infancy to a world leader. Public condolences from President Lee of Korea and other prominent politicians and business persons were conveyed to his family. Born in Osan, South Korea, Dr. Kim graduated from Seoul National University in 1950 and earned his Ph.D in electrical engineering at the University of Utah. Dr. Kim joined the faculty of Columbia University as a professor of electrical engineering and computer science in 1957 and taught electrical engineering and computer science for 21 years. His academic achievements include authoring numerous scientific articles in leading publications and two graduate level text books. His honors include John Simon Guggenheim and National Science Foundation fellowship. At the request of President Park Chung Hee, Dr. Kim left a tenured professorship at Columbia to assist the Korean government in the development of the electronics industry. Dr. Kim authored the fundamental national policies for the Korean government and economy relating to the development of the electronics industry. He is responsible for establishing the Korean R&D Institute and the Electronic Times publication. Due to their historical significance, many of his letters from President Park were donated by Dr. Kim to the Presidential Archives. In addition to the Chairmanship of the Electronic Industries Association of Korea and Korea Electronics Industries Cooperative, Dr. Kim has held numerous prominent positions relating to the electronics industry in Korea and in Asia, including Chairman of the Korean National Institute of Electronic Technology and President of the Asian Electronic Union formed by 14 Pacific Rim countries. He is a recipient of the U.S.-Asia Institute Achievement Medal awarded to outstanding individuals of Asian background who have made a significant contribution to the U.S.-Asia relationship. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Chung Sook, a daughter, Millie, son, Richard, daughter-in-law, Terri, and grandchildren, Brandon, Marisa, Isabelle and Pierce.

IN its Platonic ideal, a bathing suit removes you momentarily from yourself, and perhaps unleashes heretofore dormant aspects of your personality. Wriggle into a great-looking suit that's black and snug and tailored, and suddenly you're ready for an underwater cocktail party; rock a pair of floral Hawaiian board shorts and suddenly you're convinced that the only way to spell ''dude'' is with two o's. My annual quest for such a garment got its kick-start in late May when a friend e-mailed me a link to a site called Socialite Life, which featured a folio of 23 photos breathlessly headlined ''Jude Law: Shirtless in Cannes!'' Squinting rakishly in the brilliant Mediterranean light, Jude looked worldly, post-coital, regnant.

David Ortiz strolled to the plate in the first inning awash in a lusty chorus of boos. He was perceived to have slighted the Yankees on Tuesday night - a bat-tossing incident that brewed overnight in the caldron that is the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry - and their fans craved retribution. It never came Wednesday night, and Ortiz bristled after Boston's 11-6 victory when asked if he was ever worried it would.

On June 10, 1861, Confederate and Union forces met in what was arguably the first land battle of the Civil War. And while the Battle of Bethel is relatively forgotten, little more than a footnote in Civil War history and dwarfed by later engagements that were far more ambitious, costly and consequential, it is significant for leaving us one of the earliest and most detailed battlefield maps of the conflict.

Those of us who quip that the perfect soccer match is a 0-0 draw can point to 13 such Major League Soccer matches this year, and 25 1-1 games. Basic math says I have a 32.7 percent chance of seeing a sporting event with minimal scoring and no clear resolution when watching an M.L.S. game; the odds are higher for the Red Bulls, who have tied 7 of their 13 games, including their last four. My desire to see frequent (hourly, at least) scores and clear victors may make me a short-attention-span philistine who demands to be constantly entertained, but I think those are perfectly reasonable demands to make of my entertainment.

If you’re doing your job as a magazine editor, there’s a lot of wonderful stuff readers never get to see — because there isn’t room. This applies especially to photography. The editing process can break your heart. For a single feature, we’ll sometimes look at hundreds of pictures, leaving many great ones on the cutting-room floor. So for this editor’s note on an issue filled with spectacular pictures, I asked the photography department to pick a few images they loved that did not make the print edition of our “Voyages in America” special issue. If you click on the headline, it’ll take you to the story.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — A woman has been found dead at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, as the Associated Press reported, and was confirmed by the festival’s organizers. The Coffee County Sheriff’s office confirmed the death of a 32-year-old women from the Pittsburgh area this morning, and according to Sheriff Stephen M. Graves, the woman was found dead at her camp site by friends at 11 p.m. on Thursday, the opening night of the four-day festival. The state medical examiner will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death, according to the A.P. report. Her name has been withheld pending notification of her family.

I became hooked on cold-brew coffee after working a construction job in New Orleans more than 10 years ago. It was strictly a regional thing then, everywhere in the Big Easy and nearly impossible to find elsewhere — you could find cold-brew concentrate in the supermarket, but most of the people I knew were given mayo jars full of the dark, dense liquid by an aunt or a grandmother. In the following years, I became a proselytizer for cold-brew coffee, gaining converts for a steep-and-strain method that seemed counterintuitive until you tried it.

It should surprise no one that Helmut Lang’s resort collection was dominated by macabre hues of gray and black. The asymmetrical lines of this silk dress follow the natural curvature of the body; it takes its inspiration from Jan Kempenaers’s photographs of the Yugoslavian monuments known as Spomeniks. How silk can be modeled after concrete is as much a triumph of drapery as it is of ideological sculpture.

In a setback for the guardians of Frida Kahlo’s work, the Mexican attorney general’s office has declined to bring charges against two art dealers who say they have an enormous collection of paintings, keepsakes and letters that belonged to the artist. Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, takes note of the women who received Representative Anthony Weiner’s texts to make the point that their names will be forever linked to his in any online search. Yes, this is a high-profile example, but Paul says that all sorts of people can be negatively branded on the Web, even if they did nothing wrong.

Elegance seemed to go viral in the photographs of George Hoyningen-Huene. A Russian émigré in Paris in the 1920s, and a baron at that, Huene produced an exquisite quality of longing — or was it remoteness? — in the pages of French Vogue, where he was chief photographer in the most glamorous of 20th-century decades. You might say that Huene (pronounced HEW-neh) sealed the deal between modern-thinking couturiers and photographers, seducing us with light and classical forms. Afterward, nothing seemed the same. In her review of a 2001 exhibition that brought together Huene and his great friend Horst, the critic Vicki Goldberg noted “the two H’s influenced almost everyone else.”

Friday, Steph asked to hear from parents who regretted having children. Most of you assured her that parents rarely regret the children they have, but sprinkled amid the many comments were a few that were starkly sad. Most of those were from mothers, and they were about the added price women seem to pay — in sleep, income, ambition, time, status — when they have children.

Dana Spiotta joins Sebastião Salgado and J. J. Sullivan in this week’s issue. In her review of Spiotta’s novel “Eat the Document,” about two radicals on the lam, Michiko Kakutani credited her with erecting “an elliptical narrative filled with musical leitmotifs and searing, strobe-lighted images of contemporary life — a narrative that immerses us, headfirst, in the chaos and incongruities of the American scene while goading us into a melancholy contemplation of the country’s penchant for discarding the past.”

Ulm, a small German city on the Danube, entered the contemporary photography scene with last year’s opening of the Walther Collection, a small museum founded by Artur Walther, a native of Ulm and former Wall Street banker. Mr. Walther’s collection of about 1,100 works from the late 19th to the early 21st centuries is noteworthy for its Chinese and African photographs.

The word on the street is that no one ever leaves Macao Trading Co. sober. The restaurant cum lounge is a haven for all manner of cool kids and gourmet-food chasers, and the management loves to get the customers sauced and smiling. As a no-holds-barred celebration of this mentality, the lounge, in collaboration with a performer who goes by the name Calamity Chang, hosts an annual Drunken Dragon Festival, where for five hours a completely free open bar and passed hors d’oeuvres menu attract a cast of hundreds costumed in either 1940s colonial or Chinese attire. At the most recent incarnation of the event, several burlesque performers took over the main room, which was packed with revelers and covered in a blanket of confetti. And yes, the snake is real. A smaller version of the madness, Drunken Dragon Nights, is held weekly, downstairs at Macao, and features live burlesque performances. Go to macaonyc.com.

The Big Apple Barbecue Block Party will have 16 pit masters from across the country at Madison Square Park (Madison Avenue between 23rd and 26th Streets) once again this Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Plates of food are $8. There will be live music and cooking demonstrations throughout the two-day event. One note: go early, since some vendors often run out of food. On Friday, a preview party at the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues), from 6 to 8 p.m., includes food, drinks and films. Tickets for that party are $100 online. If you’d rather watch the pit masters setting up and smoking meats between 7 and 9 p.m., Blue Smoke will serve some food and drinks during a V.I.P. party that costs $250 per person but includes a FastPass for two allowing access to an express lane (those passes are sold out otherwise) and $100 for food and drinks. Proceeds from the event benefit the Madison Square Park Conservancy.

During the swine-flu crisis of 2009, I was living in Germany. I remember bicycling to work down Friedrichstrasse, one of Berlin’s main arteries, passing all the newsstands lined up outside convenience stores. The headlines of Bild, Germany’s best-read and most hysterical tabloid, were printed in such large type that I could take in the day’s news as I biked by. Often I would see one rather ugly word: SCHWEINEGRIPPE!!!

The Broadway stagehands’ union will not have a picket line by the red carpet at the Tony Awards on Sunday evening, after reaching an agreement on Friday morning with the managers of the awards festivities to allow union workers to stage the carpet, according to representatives of both sides. The union and the Tony ceremony managers had been in a public standoff over the last 36 hours, with the clock ticking to set up the red carpet.

On Saturday night, Texas Motor Speedway will host the Firestone Twin 275s, the first IndyCar doubleheader since June 28, 1981, when Rick Mears swept two 125-mile races at Atlanta. Beginning on Saturday the two manuscript parts of the unfinished and unpublished Jane Austen novel known as “The Watsons” will not be reunited, exactly, but will be closer they’ve been in almost 100 years — just 35 blocks or so from each other. The first part of the manuscript, some 12 pages, was sold during World War I to benefit the Red Cross, and now belongs to the Morgan Library & Museum. The rest, 68 pages which had been in private hands in England until recently, is going on display for a week at Sotheby’s before being shipped back to London, where it will be auctioned off in mid-July.

DIETZ--David. A career journalist who found his calling in public service investigative reporting, died June 1 in his home in Healdsburg, CA. He was 70. The cause was cancer. Mr. Dietz was a senior writer for Bloomberg Markets magazine and had been part of the Bloomberg News operation since 2001. His last in-depth story for the magazine, in March, revealed ways in which some corporations have cheated the public by taking federal tax credits intended to reduce poverty and using them instead for development of luxury hotels and office buildings. His follow-up article in April reported that the U.S. Treasury Department has pledged to reform the program. Mr. Dietz's career spanned more than four decades and included long stints at two San Francisco newspapers, the Examiner, where he met his wife of 24 years, journalist Joanne Derbort, and the Chronicle, where he was special-projects editor for investigative reporting. Before joining Bloomberg, he wrote and edited at TheStreet.com. A past board president of Investigative Reporters and Editors, an international organization of 4,600 journalists, Mr. Dietz received the IRE's Lifetime Achievement Award in 2010. His probes into civic malfeasance, judicial misconduct and corporate fraud won more than 25 national and regional awards, changed laws and reformed public policy. David Stanley Dietz was born April 30, 1941 in Syracuse, NY, grew up in New York City and Westfield, NJ and studied history at Rider University. His affinity for journalism began with visits as a child to the Newark Star Ledger, where his father, Joe Dietz, worked. He landed early reporting jobs at the Asbury Park Press and the Jersey Journal, then moved to the San Francisco Bay Area in the late 1960s, first working as a reporter and city editor at the Marin Independent-Journal. During his newspaper career, he completed a journalism fellowship at the University of Missouri. Mr. Dietz is survived by Ms. Derbort of Healdsburg, CA, two sons, Robert of San Jose, CA, and William of Tahoe City, CA, and their wives; four grandchildren, and a sister, Debby Dietz Davis, of the Hudson Valley in New York. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to any of the following organizations: Investigative Reporters and Editors (IRE), the San Francisco Opera, or the Sonoma County non-profit Worth Our Weight, a culinary apprenticeship program for underserved young people.

An article on June 3 about an Asia regional security conference in Singapore attended by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates referred imprecisely to the official American government policy toward Taiwan, which China considers a renegade province. The policy says the United States supports a ''peaceful resolution'' of the China-Taiwan dispute, without specifying whether the outcome includes the possibility of reunification. The policy does not assert that the United States supports a ''peaceful, negotiated reunification.''

HELLER--Dorothee, 88, died peacefully in Delray Beach, Fla., June 8. A Brooklyn native and NYU graduate, she is survived by her sons Jonathan, Joshua, Robert and Billy; daughters-in-law Mary, Beth and Jennifer; eight grandchildren; and her sister Annette Slotnick. She was married to Milton Heller, her teenage sweetheart, for 65 years, until his death in January. Services at noon on Sunday at Gutterman's in Woodbury, LI. We love you, Mom.

If you could meet any historical figure, who would it be and why? If it's former President Bill Clinton, you might just get your chance. For the second time, Mr. Clinton is raffling off his time to help pay down the debt on the 2008 presidential campaign of his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

When the Boston Red Sox paid $103 million, including a $51 million fee to his team in Japan, to sign Daisuke Matsuzaka in November 2006 and the Yankees followed two weeks later by paying Kei Igawa $46 million, including a $26 million team fee, little did the two American League rivals know that they were consigning themselves to two of the most expensive major league contracts ever signed for pitchers. The often-injured Matsuzaka may never pitch for Boston again; the overmatched Igawa has hardly ever pitched for the Yankees. Their cost per inning has been mind-boggling. Here are baseball's 10 most expensive contracts per inning pitched. The figures are for completed contracts, except for those of Oliver Perez, Carlos Silva, Matsuzaka and Igawa, all of whom are unlikely to reappear in the majors before their deals expire. 1. Jason Schmidt, Dodgers; Years:2007-9; Innings: 43 1/3; Cost/IP: $ 1,084,615

ADELMAN--Burton K.,of Tenafly, NJ passed away on June 9, 2011. Beloved husband of Bunny Adelman, loving father of Jill Glenn and Ron. Devoted grandfather to Sophie and Christopher. Having earned a B.A, in business from NYU, Burt started in the stockroom of M.H. Lamston and rose through the ranks of the company to President and CEO. He touched the lives of many people - family, friends, co-workers. He had a great sense of humor, was unbelievably thoughtful and extremely loyal to those he loved. To the day he died, he urged all of us to take care and drive carefully! He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Englewood Hospital.

2:04 p.m. | Updated Just when the ''Spider-Man'' musical was about to make its much-delayed opening date on Broadway without any further drama, along came a dispute over royalties involving the musical's original director, Julie Taymor.

Tea Obreht won the Orange Prize for Fiction on Wednesday for her debut novel, ''The Tiger's Wife,'' making her at 25 the youngest person to win the award. The winner, chosen by a panel of five judges, was announced in London. The award is given annually for the best novel written in English by a woman and comes with a prize of about $49,000. Bettany Hughes, the chairwoman of the judges, said in a statement: ''Obreht's powers of observation and her understanding of the world are remarkable. By skilfully spinning a series of magical tales she has managed to bring the tragedy of chronic Balkan conflict thumping into our front rooms with a bittersweet vivacity.'' The other finalists were Emma Donoghue, Aminatta Forna, Emma Henderson, Nicole Krauss and Kathleen Winter.

With time growing shorter, lawmakers and White House officials involved in budget talks tied to the debt limit said on Thursday that they would meet at least three times next week to try to close in on an agreement. ''There's a commitment for next week that we will be engaging, once again, in a robust series of meetings to see if we can achieve a result,'' said Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader and one of two Republican lawmakers taking part in the talks.

New work from the National Theater of Scotland, John Malkovich in the role of director and Simon Callow appearing in drag are just a few highlights coming this summer to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the enormous arts festival that annually takes over the Scottish capital. Festival organizers announced on Thursday that the festival, the biggest to date, would comprise a record 2,542 events in 258 sites (up from 2,453 shows last year). More than 600 productions will be offered for no charge during the festival, which runs Aug. 5-29. The revamped Web site www.edfringe.com will be available later Thursday and tickets go on sale Friday morning. The Traverse Theater, which annually offers some of the most exciting new work of the summer, will present two productions by the National Theater of Scotland, best known for the acclaimed Iraq war play ''Black Watch.'' They are ''The Wheel,'' by Zinnie Harris, and ''The Strange Undoing of Prudencia Hart,'' an eerie ballad by David Greig to be presented in a pub.

(SPIKE TV) GUYS CHOICE 2011 Jennifer Aniston was honored with the Decade of Hotness award at this ceremony, taped on Saturday at the Sony Pictures Studios in Los Angeles, celebrating things that appeal to men. (IFC) MONTY PYTHON LIVE AT THE HOLLYWOOD BOWL (1982) The troupe -- John Cleese, Graham Chapman, Eric Idle, Terry Jones, Terry Gilliam and Michael Palin -- presents some now classic sketches: a cranky Pope Julius II objecting to Michelangelo's ''improvement'' to ''The Last Supper'' by adding two extra Jesus figures and no fewer than 28 disciples; a furious one-man wrestling match, in which a hold known as ''the double Eydie Gorme'' is demonstrated; a song about the drinking habits of the great philosophers ('' 'I drink,' says Descartes, 'therefore I am' ''); and ''The Ministry of Silly Walks,'' in which Mr. Cleese demonstrates why a would-be applicant will never qualify for a government grant. The result is ''Python lunacy of a purer grade,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. ''I don't know about you, but I wouldn't miss it.''

GREENLAND--Leo. Ralph and Gary Goffner would like to extend their deepest heartfelt sympathy to their cousin Eileen Greenland and her entire family for the passing of her beloved husband Leo Greenland.

Sorry, Queens, but you've had plenty of opportunities to feature the Cute Beatle, now it's time to let the Bronx host him for an evening: Paul McCartney will play his first concert ever at Yankee Stadium on July 15, Live Nation Entertainment said on Wednesday. Mr. McCartney, the pop musician whose work in Wings is perennially overshadowed by his time with another popular British rock outfit, has some familiarity with New York ballparks, having served as the inaugural performer at Citi Field as in 2009, and as a surprise guest when Billy Joel closed down Shea Stadium in 2008; Mr. McCartney also played at Shea Stadium in 1965 as part of that beloved band whose name momentarily escapes us. (No, not the Rolling Stones, the other guys.) A statement from Live Nation said Mr. McCartney's performance at Yankee Stadium ''can safely be predicted to feature some nearly three hours of the world's best loved and most known music, with hits, deep cuts and surprises spanning his unrivaled career,'' including the 2008 album ''Electric Arguments'' that he released under the name the Fireman. With a top ticket price of $279.50 for this show, Mr. McCartney will hopefully throw in ''Band on the Run'' or ''Let It Be,'' too. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article in some editions on May 25 about the Yankees' 5-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays misstated the type of weather-related damage recently sustained by Tuscaloosa, the hometown of the Yankees reliever Dave Robertson. It was caused by tornadoes, not a hurricane.

With Derek Jeter's membership in the 3,000-hit club imminent (he needed 11 hits entering Thursday's games), the baseball world can soon turn its attention to the players who could follow him on the path to 3,000. At first blush, the most logical place to look would be at the active players on the career hits leader board, which has Ivan Rodriguez (2,835 through Wednesday) and Omar Vizquel (2,821) right behind Jeter. But both are getting on in age (Rodriguez is 39 and Vizquel is 44) and their trajectories as hitters do not say much for their chances (neither is on a pace for 60 hits in 2011). Even for a great hitter like Ichiro Suzuki, the trends are pointing down. He ranks 11th among active players, but he is 37, needs 690 hits to reach 3,000 and has fallen off this season.

GREENLAND--Leo. The Board of Directors of Queens Plaza and Electric Realty Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of the husband of our esteemed Board Member Eileen Greenland. We would like to extend our sympathy to her family.

Egg Rolls & Egg Creams Festival (Sunday) If you're up for a quick trip to China and Eastern Europe this weekend, you need only head to the Lower East Side for the Museum at Eldridge Street's annual festival of Chinese and Jewish culture. From noon to 4 p.m. Chinese acrobats will mix it up, rain or shine, with klezmer musicians on the street outside the museum, as Chinese and Torah scribes demonstrate their art nearby. (Above, an acrobat last year with the Qi Shu Fang Peking Opera, which will appear again on Sunday.) There will also be workshops in making dumplings and challah rolls -- with the ready-to-be-cooked goodies wrapped up to take home -- as well as games of mah-jongg and lessons in Yiddish and Mandarin. Events will also be under way inside the museum, with tours scheduled throughout the day. It's all free, with the exception of a $5 cross-cultural treat of one vegetable egg roll and one egg cream (both kosher); 12 Eldridge Street, between Canal and Division Streets, (212) 219-0888; eldridgestreet.org. We know an egg cream contains no egg or cream, but the egg in an egg roll? It's sometimes in the wrap. (Anne Mancuso)

SHANGHAI - Carson C. Block makes even Wall Street cringe. Last week, the founder of the investment firm Muddy Waters Research issued a scathing report on a Chinese forestry company, calling it a ''pump and dump'' scheme that has been ''aggressively committing fraud.''

The Advertising column on Thursday, about the Microsoft search engine Bing's sponsorship of a reality competition to find a cast member for the show ''Glee,'' misstated, because of incorrect information from a Microsoft executive, which agency came up with the sponsorship idea. It was Universal McCann, part of the Mediabrands unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; it was not Starcom, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Publicis Groupe.

Stock research has long been considered a big money loser on Wall Street. It costs millions to produce and most investors are unwilling to pay hard cash for it. But in 2006 Goldman Sachs came up with a plan to leverage its equity research, funneling short-term stock tips to its biggest trading clients. On Thursday, Massachusetts regulators fined Goldman Sachs $10 million for this practice, calling it ''a dishonest and unethical violation'' of the state's securities act.

MINKOFF--Harry, 97, respected innovative group worker and retired CEO of several social service agencies, died peacefully at home on June 4. His wife, noted lyricist Fran Minkoff, predeceased him. He is survived by a daughter, Susan Feingold.
The New Music column on Tuesday, about new albums including ''Forever,'' featuring Chick Corea, misstated the year when part of that album was recorded. It was during a tour in 2009, not 2008.

STRONG DEBUT Shares of Fusion-io ended more than 18 percent higher on their New York Stock Exchange debut on Thursday, the latest technology offering to be met with strong investor demand. Fusion-io, which uses flash memory for data hardware and software, priced its initial public offering at $19. The stock opened at $25 and traded higher before retreating to close at $22.5. Fusion-io, founded in 2005, may be best known for its chief scientist, Steve Wozniak, above, 60, an Apple co-founder.

MAURO--Kenneth, 63, founding partner of the appellate law practice of Mauro Lilling Naparty, LLP died on Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, NY after a lengthy illness. He is survived by his loving and devoted family; wife Marsha, daughter Morgan, sister Karen and sister-in-law Lynn.

7:32 p.m. | Updated Coupons.com, a network for online and printable coupons, has raised $200 million from several institutional investors, the company said Thursday. The deal values the company at about $1 billion, according to two people close to Coupons.com who were not authorized to speak publicly.

Stormy weather forced the cancellation of a concert by the Black Eyed Peas that was to take place on the Central Park Great Lawn on Thursday night for an expected audience of 60,000. The concert's pre-show was canceled, and the main show's starting time was delayed twice due to the storms moving across the city, stranding thousands of fans on the streets of the Upper West Side. The gates were finally opened at 7:45 p.m., but about half an hour later, as lightning continued to streak across the sky and a light rain spattered the lawn, the concert was shut down.

An article on Tuesday about the increased danger of attacks against United States military forces as they begin the process of final withdrawal from Iraq misstated the number of American service members killed on Monday by a rocket attack on a military base in eastern Baghdad. It was five, not six.

LOS ANGELES - One of Hollywood's top film financiers and producers is making a big push into China. Legendary Entertainment, which is affiliated with Warner Brothers and has backed hits like ''The Dark Knight'' and ''The Hangover,'' completed a deal on Thursday with the Huayi Brothers Media Corporation of Beijing to form a new movie and television company. Their ambitious goal is to make English-language films and TV shows in China that can be exported to the rest of the world.

Storm clouds swirled above and the wind proved too strong for their candles, but that did not stop a group of grieving families from holding a vigil on Long Island on Saturday for women who worked as prostitutes and are believed to be the victims of a serial killer. The remains of some of them have turned up in recent months on a desolate stretch of the beach in Suffolk County, near where the vigil was held.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Day 3 of Bonnaroo: dust, dust and ice. Thousands of bags of ice, trucked all over the enormous site, used as soon as the bags got opened. People sunburned and zombified, spilling around most of the stages, even the film tent, even the comedy tent. The drowning feeling set in today.
Longshot Ruler on Ice edged out Stay Thirsty at a muddy and wet Belmont Park.

One point frequently raised in the coverage of Representative Anthony D. Weiner is that David Vitter, the Lousiana Senator who in 2007 acknowledged that he was a longtime client of a Washington-based prostitution service, did not resign his seat. In fact, Mr. Vitter won re-election with 56.6 percent of the vote last November.

PITTSBURGH — Mets Manager Terry Collins made four possible lineups for Saturday night’s game against the Pirates, including one that had Jason Bay batting second and another with Daniel Murphy there. Instead, he chose Ruben Tejada, the 21-year-old infielder who went into the game hitting .329.

Terry Collins clearly did not appreciate comments made by the former hitting instructor Howard Johnson, who told The New York Post that it was “ridiculous” to bench Jason Bay for two days while he is struggling.
A look back at the achievements and setbacks of the former congressman.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — If you talk to enough people about crossword puzzle solving, you eventually see that there is a pervasive misconception that the Sunday New York Times crossword is the mother brain buster of the week, the puzzle that is for the truly suicidal. Most people know that the puzzles increase in relative difficulty throughout the week, so they naturally assume that the puzzle on the last day of the week must be the hardest. Then there’s the sheer size of it. Not only does Will Shortz want us to break our brains, they reason, he wants us to suffer. This might be the puzzle we have to leave to our children in our wills.
Opponents of a new garbage-transfer station on the Upper East Side gathered Saturday afternoon hoping to thwart it.
Ruler on Ice, ridden by Jose Valdivia Jr., shocked in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, holding off Stay Thirsty by three-quarters of a length on a sloppy track. Brilliant Speed finished third.

My Sunday column looks at food safety and, in particular, the way the agribusiness lobby has blocked some basic reforms — not least the banning of routine feeding of antibiotics to health livestock, for growth promotion. That’s just unconscionable, given the risks of developing antibiotic resistance.

As the new pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets’ rookie-level team in the New York-Penn League, Frank Viola will have few pupils who were born in the 1980s, when he starred for the Minnesota Twins. But his pitchers will discover who he is.

A few weekends ago, while rushing through Central Park toward a breakfast date, I spied a giant cluster of scaly brown mushrooms that resembled a bird’s plumage, partially hidden under some weeds. Closer inspection revealed a cacophony of fungi spread out across an old tree stump — one mushroom growing singly like a shelf, others in trumpet-shaped clusters, and a few as large as pancakes. Each had that lovely speckled pattern fanning out across the cap.

A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Feherty’s half-interview, half-improv weekly show, “Feherty,” will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Feherty’s 2002 novel, “A Nasty Bit of Rough.” Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.

Not about the usual: this article in the Times, Regretting Move, Bank May Return to Manhattan is up my old alley -- the stuff I got the Swedish thingie for. And it should make Ed Glaeser happy. Together with Jess Gaspar, Ed wrote a paper 15 years ago arguing that contrary to what many people were saying, the Internet and all that wouldn't undermine the agglomeration forces that support places like Manhattan; if anything, agglomeration would increase. Actually, I wrote about that back in my "looking backward from the year 2096" piece, written about the same time.

As my colleague Marc Lacey reports, an enormous wildfire that has ripped through 408,000 acres in Arizona continued to burn on Saturday. Officials were bracing for high winds, projected to pick up in the afternoon, that would test the containment efforts after a two-day reprieve from harsh weather.

MONTREAL — Sebastian Vettel scored pole position in his Red Bull in Montreal today, but since he has done that at most of the races this year, I’d rather talk about other things.

Baseball fans had reason to be envious of the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. last week. Each sport’s championship series stood at 2-2 after four games. The World Series has not been tied 2-2 since 2003, when the Yankees played the Florida Marlins.
European officials have finally identified bean sprouts as the likely culprit in a deadly outbreak of E. coli poisoning, the latest in a series of outbreaks traced back to tainted sprouts.

The Yankees were convinced that the Cleveland right-hander Fausto Carmona intentionally hit Mark Teixeira in the second inning of Friday night’s game, an 11-7 Yankees victory. Carmona left Yankee Stadium without speaking to the news media, and on Saturday morning he offered his account of the pitch that sparked a benches-clearing incident and a shouting match between the managers.

When The Times began posting nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday, we asked readers poring over them to highlight noteworthy and interesting messages. When the San Francisco Giants needed a player to speak to the crowd before their game with the Los Angeles Dodgers on April 11, the choice was obvious. It would not be a star, but a journeyman left-handed middle reliever. It had to be Jeremy Affeldt.

Two new Web sites aim to make traveling a more social event. Both sites — triptrotting.com and igottaguide.com — combine travel with elements of social media, connecting members based on common interests.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — A reader asked me the other day about different methods for solving, and today’s Spiral puzzle by Will Shortz made me wonder: Do you start from the inside, working out, or do you start from the exterior of the spiral? Do you fall into the “a little of both” camp, as the instructions suggest? How about blindfolded, just to set yourself an extra challenge?

In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since. That is when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

News organizations that pored over nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday focused on her selection as Senator John McCain’s running mate in 2008, her relationship with the media and her style of governing.

With Tim Pawlenty — who was supposed to be a sensible Republican — going all-in for high voodoo, I thought it’s worth pointing out that at the moment there’s a pretty good case that there is a kind of Laffer curve in which more is less and less is more. Namely, there’s a good case that fiscal stimulus right now would actually improve the long-run fiscal situation, while fiscal austerity makes it worse.

Molly Jo Rosen has been involved with thoroughbred racing from coast to coast: from Churchill Downs to TVG to Smarty Jones’s personal assistant to managing a major New York racing operation. She now runs Community Communications at GradeOneRacing, finds future superstars at 2yoSales.com, and serves her blend of pony punditry on her blog, Focused Filly.

Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the top Republican on the Senate Small Business Committee, finally got the vote she sought for legislation that would make sweeping changes to federal rule making by requiring more deference to small-business interests. She lost, largely on party lines.
Today’s Times

“This is what I came here for, right here,” said a college boy next to me. It was a little after 2 a.m., and Lil Wayne had just cued the beginning of “I’m Single,” his narcotic, spectral slow jam from last year. The fan rapped every word loudly, twice as loud as Lil Wayne did, but with the exact inflections. Dozens of college boys around him were doing the same thing. They all looked different, but had the same purpose.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Live, with its simple song forms blown up to cathedral dimensions, the Kentucky band My Morning Jacket can suggest so many different sources that at least in print it looks ridiculous: Pink Floyd (in all eras), Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Rolling Stones, the Grateful Dead, Television, Prince, the early Paul McCartney solo records and Bob Dylan’s “Nashville Skyline,” which more than any other source seems to have given Jim James, the band’s singer, his voice. That voice is soft and big and throaty; tonight at Bonnaroo, in a two-hour set that just ended (I write this at 10:15 on Friday night), he stuck his tongue halfway out on the loudest and highest falsetto notes.

An article about a shopper's unsuccessful search for a swimsuit like one worn by Jude Law in a picture on the Web site Socialite Life misidentified the manufacturer of the swimsuit. It is Vilebrequin, not Dsquared2. The article also misstated the price of the swimsuit. It costs $180 at Vilebrequin's Las Vegas store, not $268, as stated on the Web site.

After weeks of back-and-forth debate and heavy lobbying by banks and retailers, the Senate voted Wednesday against delaying a cap on the swipe fees that stores must pay for the processing of debit card purchases. The vote means that the Federal Reserve Board will move ahead to complete the cap on the charges, formally known as ''interchange'' fees, by July 21. The board has proposed rules that would limit the fees charged by banks to 12 cents per transaction, down from the current average of 44 cents per transaction.

HUTNER--Joseph L.,78, died after a brave 20 year struggle with Parkinson's. Joe is survived by his wife Willa, daughters Laura (Harry Hummel), Susan and Amy, brother Martin and grandchildren, Erica, Alexandra and Gabriel. Joe graduated from Yale (Phi Beta Kappa, Summa Cum Laude). After graduating from Harvard Law School, Joe practiced law at Singer Hutner, Levine and Seeman and until his death, at Epstein, Becker and Green. He ran for New York State Assembly in 1964 and for US Congress in 1966. He loved sports, reading and people. The family will sit Shiva at 200 East 66th St. on Sunday and Monday from 2-6pm.

An article on Wednesday about the Stanley Cup finals, between the Vancouver Canucks and the Boston Bruins, misidentified the team designation for Ben Eager, who was not suspended after he checked the Canucks' Daniel Sedin into the boards in an earlier playoff round this year. It is the San Jose Sharks, not the Chicago Blackhawks, for whom he played last season. The article also misstated that earlier playoff round. It was the third, not the first.

Owners of a house in Florida have engineered a reverse foreclosure against a bank. That makes two so far this year. Just one more, and it's officially a trend, right?
