With its initial public offering near, Pandora Media put up a bigger price tag on Friday. The online music service increased its target price range to $10 to $12 a share, above its previous range of $7 to $9, according to its latest filing.

O'NEIL--Jack (John), on June 9, 2011 at age 76. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee Kinsella). Loving brother-in-law of Maureen Coleman and Peggy Kinsella Warshaw. Cherished uncle of Denis (Maggie), Michael (Joann), Anne (Doug), Richard (Suzanne) and Christopher (Biliana). Great-uncle of six. Lifelong friend of David Beisel. A life lived with great dignity and incredible humor. A celebration of this life well lived will be held Sunday 12pm-2:30pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to ALS Association of Greater New York, 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, New York, NY 10004.

That's not quite all for the motion-picture career of the Looney Tunes, or for Mel Blanc, the versatile voice artist and comedian who helped bring to life the animated antics of Daffy Duck and Tweety Bird. Those speech-impeded cartoon characters, along with Sylvester the Cat, Elmer Fudd, Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner are set to return in a new series of 3-D computer generated shorts that will use some vocals previously recorded by Blanc, and which will begin appearing with Warner Brothers movies in the fall, the studio's animation division said. The first of these shorts, ''Daffy's Rhapsody,'' will find Elmer Fudd pursuing Daffy Duck during a musical performance and will include Mr. Blanc's version of the song ''Daffy Duck's Rhapsody.'' That cartoon is to make its debut on Nov. 18 with the Warner Brothers animated feature ''Happy Feet 2.''

9 P.M. (STARZ) THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE (2010) Balthazar Blake (Nicolas Cage) -- a thousand-year-old master wizard in modern-day Manhattan -- takes on a reluctant protégé. The young man is Dave Stutler (Jay Baruchel, above left, with Mr. Cage), a physics major at New York University who tinkers with a giant Tesla coil in a basement lab while yearning for his childhood crush (Teresa Palmer). The wizard, however, decides that Dave is the Prime Merlinian. That means that he's the only person who can save the world from Balthazar's arch nemesis, Maxim Horvath (Alfred Molina), and the cataclysm that will be unleashed by the ancient spells of wizards, including the mean Morgana (Alice Krige) and the gorgeous Veronica (Monica Bellucci), if they are released from a Russian doll in which they were hidden centuries before. ''While Mr. Molina and Mr. Cage supply a measure of well-compensated eccentricity, their labors ultimately serve to emphasize the grinding mediocrity of the enterprise,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Why would Balthazar and Maxim -- magicians who can fly, change shape and conjure force fields, fireballs and just about anything else they want -- need to climb into cars and chase each other through the streets of New York? I put that question to a colleague, who condescendingly replied, 'because it's a Jerry Bruckheimer movie.' Duh. But still. It's stupid.'' 5 P.M. And Shackleford, fourth at the Derby and the winner of the Preakness, is rated 9-2.

An article on Thursday about the start of a federal campaign against fraudulent immigration lawyers misidentified the New York prosecutors who handled the case against Wilmer Melendez Rivera, who was convicted of posing as an immigration lawyer. They were from the Manhattan District Attorney's office, not New York State.

HELLER--Dorothee, 88, died peacefully in Delray Beach, Fla., June 8. A Brooklyn native and NYU graduate, she is survived by her sons Jonathan, Joshua, Robert and Billy; daughters-in-law Mary, Beth and Jennifer; eight grandchildren; and her sister Annette Slotnick. She was married to Milton Heller, her teenage sweetheart, for 65 years, until his death in January. Services at noon on Sunday at Gutterman's in Woodbury, LI. We love you, Mom.

An art review on Friday about exhibitions of work by the painter Amelie von Wulffen at the Greene Naftali gallery in Chelsea and the Alex Zachary gallery on the Upper East Side misstated the number of her paintings on view at Greene Naftali. It is 11, not 10. (Some of her drawings are also shown.)

HEART disease remains the No. 1 cause of death in the United States, killing more than 800,000 people each year, and accounting for one in three of all deaths. It is no wonder, then, that screening for heart disease is a routine part of just about every physical exam given in this country. The number of these tests has increased significantly over the last 20 to 30 years, and these days screening may involve any of a dozen procedures -- some as simple as taking a patient's blood pressure, some as complicated as CT angiography, an expensive, controversial test that may carry health risks.

A picture caption with an article on Page 10 this weekend about the actor Ryan Reynolds misidentifies the actress shown with him in a scene from the film ''Green Hornet.'' She is Blake Lively, not Carol Ferris, the character she plays in the movie.

GARTNER--Louis J.,longtime resident of Palm Beach and decorative arts consultant for Sotheby's, died Sunday, June 5, 2011 after an extended illness. Lou was an inquisitive soul, who had a resourceful and creative mind and a passion for the decorative arts.

Beware the fury of a first grader scorched. For a class of students at Public School 1 in Manhattan, this week's heat wave was a lesson in what it meant to be a have-not. Their peers across the hall had air-conditioning; they did not.

A Sports of The Times column on June 3 about the traditional matchup in this year's Stanley Cup finals, between the Vancouver Canucks and the Boston Bruins, misstated the type of vandalism that occurred in Montreal after the Canadiens beat the Los Angeles Kings to win the Stanley Cup in 1993. Fires were set and cars were destroyed; trolley cars were not overturned. (They had been taken out of service years before.)
BIRNBAUM--Norman. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Always in our hearts.

The Broadway stagehands' union will not have a picket line by the red carpet at the Tony Awards on Sunday evening, after reaching an agreement on Friday morning with the managers of the awards festivities to allow union workers to stage the carpet, according to representatives of both sides. The union and the Tony ceremony managers had been in a public standoff over the last 36 hours, with the clock ticking to set up the red carpet. A statement jointly released on Friday afternoon by James J. Claffey Jr., president of Local 1, and Allan Williams, general manager of Tony Award Productions, said, ''The Tony Awards and Local One I.A.T.S.E. are very pleased that, together, we were able to reach an agreement, to produce the Tony Awards red carpet on Sunday evening.'' Neither side would publicly disclose the terms and conditions of the agreement.

TOWBIN--Irene Kathleen June 10, 2011. A unique person, independent mother, artist, and friend. A citizen of Ireland and the USA, Irene was born in Brooklyn, attended catholic schools and became a graduate nurse from the Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing. She married and had three children; Minna, whose husband, Ned Pinger and children Belmont, Dash, and Zyla mourn her passing; Bram and his wife Erica, and Zachary and his wife Hannah and their children; Harry, Phoebe and Cayetana all share the tragedy of losing a mother and grandmother, as she approached her 75th year. She will also be mourned by her brother, Dan Lyons and his wife Judy and their children; Cathlin, and husband Eric, and their two children, Daniel and his wife Donna, and their two children, and Matthew Lyons. Finally, she will be missed by her former husband and friend Robert Towbin, who admired her unique understanding of good and bad and her willingness, to express her strong opinions. Irene was an accomplished artist who worked many years in her SoHo studio which she shared with her dear friend and fellow artist Kiki Kogelnik. Irene was more than a painter and maker of unique constructions, be it amusing statements of undeniable truths, or photos of things that would surely lose their glamour and moments of popular appeal. Her photos in the Dublin, Ireland, eatery, the Temple Bar, capture the SoHo of New York in the 1980's that no longer exists. Her growing interest in what governments are obligated to do for their citizens which started during the McCarthy era of the 1950s and translated, over the years, to a fierce defense of women's rights and disenfranchised people everywhere on this earth characterized her incisive strong and brave attitude to life. A growing distaste for the movement in her home country by right wing politicians infuriated her and as President George W. Bush became the favorite to win a second term, she decided to leave America and live in Ireland. She chose Galway as her home and created a unique spot in which to live. As she settled in, she began to travel and returned to Budapest, Hungary where Kiki had had a show years earlier, and bought an apartment there, on the river, and made her home both in Ireland and Budapest, entertaining her friends in both places in the ensuing years. Irene will be missed by friends in Ireland, Hungary and Staten Island where she bought two flats when the Staten Island Yankees came to town and sold one. The Yankees have not done as well. A memorial service will be held in New York City and details will be announced soon.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. -- A woman has been found dead at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, as the Associated Press reported, and was confirmed by the festival's organizers. The Coffee County Sheriff's office confirmed the death of a 32-year-old women from the Pittsburgh area this morning, and according to Sheriff Stephen M. Graves, the woman was found dead at her camp site by friends at 11 p.m. on Thursday, the opening night of the four-day festival. The state medical examiner will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death, according to the A.P. report. Her name has been withheld pending notification of her family. It's 92 degrees today here at Bonnaroo, a 700-acre farm about 60 miles southeast of Nashville, and it was hotter yesterday. There are 80,000 attendees this year. Last year, David Sloan, a 29-year old from Wilmington, N.C., died of heat stroke at the festival; it was reported that he had a core body temperature of 108 degrees. The Pittsburgh woman is the ninth person to die in the 10-year history of Bonnaroo - some from drug overdoses, two in moving-vehicle accidents.

How accurate is the all-important data in your credit report? It depends on whom you ask. Previous estimates of credit reports with serious errors vary widely, anywhere from 3 to 25 percent. But according to a recent study paid for by the Consumer Data Industry Association, the trade group for the credit bureaus that assemble and sell credit reports, that rate is much lower. Consumer advocates, meanwhile, were skeptical of those results.

In a setback for the guardians of Frida Kahlo's work, the Mexican attorney general's office has declined to bring charges against two art dealers who say they have an enormous collection of paintings, keepsakes and letters that belonged to the artist. The Mexican trust that owns the copyright to Kahlo's work says that the works are fakes and last year asked prosecutors to investigate. The attorney general's decision was issued last summer but not publicized by the dealers, Carlos Noyola and his wife, Leticia Fernandez, until this week. ''They have proven our innocence in this,'' Ms. Fernandez said.

Beginning on Saturday the two manuscript parts of the unfinished and unpublished Jane Austen novel known as ''The Watsons'' will not be reunited, exactly, but will be closer they've been in almost 100 years -- just 35 blocks or so from each other. The first part of the manuscript, some 12 pages, was sold during World War I to benefit the Red Cross, and now belongs to the Morgan Library & Museum. The rest, 68 pages which had been in private hands in England until recently, is going on display for a week at Sotheby's before being shipped back to London, where it will be auctioned off in mid-July. One of very few surviving Austen manuscripts, ''The Watsons'' is interesting for being extensively revised and corrected in her tiny, precise handwriting -- evidence of Austen's painstaking writing habits. You can see, for example, that after accusing the arrogant Lord Osborne of ''carelessness'' and ''awkwardness,'' she went back and added ''coldness'' for good measure. Austen wrote ''The Watsons'' in 1804, a year before her father died and after the early versions of what eventually became ''Sense and Sensibility,'' ''Pride and Prejudice'' and ''Northanger Abbey.'' Why she abandoned it is not clear. It's by far the bleakest of her novels, however, and its story - of an impoverished young woman, with no marital prospects, whose sole friend is an ailing clergyman father - may have been uncomfortably close to the facts of Austen's own life just then.

Brian Bedford's performance as the august Lady Augusta Bracknell in ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' was a glittering adornment to a season rich in superlative acting, most theater watchers would surely agree. But I can also imagine that Mr. Bedford's undertaking might have caused just a little bit of consternation in certain circles - namely among actresses who might regard a man assuming such a choice woman's role as an ungentlemanly bit of poaching. For while the Broadway season was a bountiful one in many ways - what's this, almost a dozen new musicals? - it was pretty thin on significant leading roles for women. For the first time in years the Tony nominators could find only four leading women in musicals they deemed worthy of notice. That's not particularly surprising, either, when you scan the list of new musicals and absorb how many of them didn't have any role at all for a leading lady.

It happens rarely, but when it does it causes a commotion of great proportions; it attracts the attention of all, becomes a popular topic for discussion and debate in marketplaces and taverns. It drives people to take sides, quarrel and fight, which for things philosophical is quite remarkable. It happened to Socrates, Hypatia, Thomas More, Giordano Bruno, Jan Patocka, and a few others. Due to an irrevocable death sentence, imminent mob execution or torture to death, these philosophers found themselves in the most paradoxical of situations: lovers of logic and rational argumentation, silenced by brute force; professional makers of discourses, banned from using the word; masters of debate and contradiction, able to argue no more. What was left of these philosophers then? Just their silence, their sheer physical presence. The only means of expression left to them, their own bodies — and dying bodies at that.

I’ve already written about Joe Lieberman’s very bad, no good idea of raising the Medicare eligibility age. Austin Frakt and Aaron Carroll show that it’s even worse than I thought: Americans near 65 who don’t have good health insurance delay needed treatment, causing a bulge in Medicare costs when they hit the magic age, and the same phenomenon would get even worse, so this might not even save money.

Summer in Berlin brings with it a sudden proliferation of sandy beach bars, lounges and all-night clubs perched along the banks of the Spree River. The  Ressort, now in its second year, is one such seasonal locale, though with an address more unusual than most. The restaurant and club is situated at the far corner of a vast parking lot behind the Hamburger Bahnhof Contemporary Art Museum, and its relative isolation turns out to be a welcome reprise from the city’s hectic summer vibe.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — “We’re Buffalo Springfield,” said Neil Young, by way of introduction on Saturday night. “We’re from the past.” They sure are. Some of the band’s reunion set at Bonnaroo, after a string of California concerts and more planned for the fall, felt older-guy casual: retirement rock. Richie Furay sings very much like what he has become, which is a church pastor. Stephen Stills sings like a bumpy road. And the bassist Rick Rosas and drummer Joe Vitale played comfortable older-guy grooves, slower than the songs in your head from their very short history.

FIEDLER--Johanna. Passed away on May 27, 2011. Daughter of long-time Boston POPS conductor, Arthur Fiedler. Former PRdirector for the National Symphony in Washington, DC, program editor for the New York Philharmonic, and general press representative for the Metropolitan Opera. Author of two books, "Arthur Fiedler: Papa the Pops and Me" and "Molto Agitato: The Mayhem Behind the Music at the Metropolitan Opera". A life-long lover of animals, Johanna helped to train and serve with therapy dogs in a number of New York City hospitals, as well as at Ground Zero after the tragic events of 9/11. Johanna's true loves were music, books and dogs. She is survived by her sister Deborah Stiles, brother Peter, sister-in-law Dieuwke, nephews Arthur and Camelis Fiedler, nieces Jessica Stiles and Johanna Fiedler. A memorial service will be held June 20th in Boston. For further information log on to: www.riversidememoriaI chapel.com.

The Boston Harbor Islands national park area (nps.gov/boha/index.htm) may no longer be Boston's best-kept secret. The opening of the Boston Harbor Islands Pavilion earlier this month offers a visibility boost for the park. At the welcome center visitors can buy ferry tickets, consult with park rangers, learn about the park's natural and historic resources and wander a 2,000-square-foot topographical map of the harbor's 34 islands.

The market for Web sites that offer flash sales and discounts for travel packages and hotel rooms has a new competitor. Groupon and Expedia have announced a new venture, Groupon Getaways (groupon.com/getaways), which will offer discounts for hotel rooms starting in late June. It joins the ranks of online travel deal sites, jetsetter.com, sniqueaway.com and vacationist.com. These sites offer discounted rates over a block of time for luxury hotels and resorts in destinations like St. Lucia, Montauk and Morocco.

ARTHUR KULKOV, the Siberian-born, Coney Island-raised, in-demand model who recently towered over the Port Authority Bus Terminal in an ad more than five stories tall, is known for his eccentric and super-stylish ways. His ease with fashion and sense of humor about it certainly add to his professional appeal. But it's his eye-catching outfits that really set him apart. ''I hate to say that this business has influenced my style, but it has,'' he said. He wore these Day-Glo orange pieces (athletic sandals and shorts by Adidas, hat by American Apparel) in Sarasota, Fla., while shooting an ad campaign. He ordered the flip-flops from a soccer magazine, bought the shorts at Y-3 and snagged the hat from another shoot. ''I thought it was brightly cool,'' he said before wondering out loud whether he should be ''rocking it all together.'' BRUCE PASK

A review last Sunday in some copies about the Lexus CT 200h misstated the comparison between its projected sales and those of some other small cars. Lexus's estimate of 1,000 sales a month is more than the monthly sales of each of the Audi A3, BMW 1 Series and Volvo C30; it is not more than the combined monthly sales of all those models.

A picture caption in the Long Island calendar of events in some editions last Sunday misstated the Hofstra University Museum gallery in Hempstead, N.Y., where the exhibition ''Body Mapping,'' is on display through July 29. It is the Emily Lowe gallery, not the David Filderman gallery.

After a long career as a designer, illus- trator and filmmaker, the French artist Charles Matton (who died at 77 in 2008) be- gan creating his mysterious boxes in 1985.''It all started because Charles wanted to make realistic paintings of interiors,'' said his widow, Sylvie Matton. But whenever he chose a space, ''the colors on the walls were not the right ones'' or ''he would have to wait hours for the sun to set,'' she said. To solve the problem Mr. Matton started building miniature rooms, which soon grew so richly detailed that he wanted to make them for their own sake. ''It was not like, 'Oh, I am going to do boxes,''' Ms. Matton said. ''It was a whole adventure of creation.''His subjects included the studios of art- ists like Francis Bacon and Giacometti, the empty halls of grand hotels and the librar-ies of Proust and Freud, for which he re- searched and modeled each individual book and bibelot. His longtime friend the philosopher Jean Baudrillard referred to the tiny atmosphere-packed environments as ''theatrum simulacrum.''Mirrors create the illusion of labyrin- thine corridors and make the interior of a box appear larger than its confines. In the library, above, with nine views, Mr. Matton amplified the confusion by introducing a ghostly figure -- a video projection -- who prowls the shelves without casting a shad- ow.''We love it when people try and under- stand'' how a box is made, Ms. Matton said, speaking as though her husband were still alive. ''But we also love it when they just accept the fact that it's there as a magic thing.''

REDLICH--Norman, former Dean of the NYU School of Law from 1975 to 1988, and prominent constitutional lawyer, died yesterday at his home on Park Avenue. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Evelyn Grobow Redlich, by their three adoring children, Bonny, Carrie, and Edward, and by his five grandchildren, Mara and Joshua Revkin, Abigail Montopoli, and Noah and Zoe Timberman Redlich. After serving in the 100th Infantry Division in France during World War II, he attended Williams College and was later graduated first in his class at Yale Law School. After Yale, he worked in his family wholesale plumbing business, wrote on civil liberties and the law, and received a LL.M. in Taxation from NYU in 1955. He joined the NYU School of Law faculty in 1960, was promoted to full professor in 1962, and served as the director of the Law School's Project on Urban and Poverty Law until he became Associate Dean in 1974. He was named Dean in 1975 and served until 1988, during which time NYU became a prominent national Law School. He championed clinical legal education, and taught primarily in the area of Constitutional Law, Taxation, Urban Affairs, and Professional Responsibility. In 1963-64, he served as Assistant Counsel on the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy (the Warren Commission) He served for seven years in high positions in New York City's Law Department, and, in 1972, was named by Mayor John Lindsay as Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, the City's highest legal office. He was also active in the organized bar, having served as Chair of the American Bar Association's Section of Legal Education and Admissions to the Bar. He was passionately devoted to many civil liberties and civil rights causes, was a member of the board, and of its executive committee, of the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, and was Co-chair of the Commission on Law and Social Action of the American Jewish Congress. He was the only law professor to serve as a Co-chair of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law and received that organization's highest award-The Whitney North Seymour Award-in 1993. He was Chair of Justice-PAC, a political action committee to support candidates for public office in New York State who oppose the death penalty. This represented a modern refrain of his earlier efforts in the same area; in 1959, as counsel to the New York Committee to Abolish Capital Punishment, he organized a group of the University's professors who were probably the first lawyers ever to litigate against the death penalty. He was on the Board of Trustees of The Vermont Law School, and after leaving NYU, he served as counsel to the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. He was a tireless defender of human rights who lived his life true to his favorite maxim, "There is no limit to what you can accomplish in the world if you don't care who gets the credit." And as he often laughingly added, "Or the blame." He loved Get Smart, Frank Sinatra, opera, cheesecake, and riding his tractor in Vermont. The gentleness of his spirit and the brilliance of his mind will be forever missed. Contributions in his honor may be made to The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. Funeral Services will be on Monday, June 13, at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 74th Street. The burial will be Tuesday, in Vermont at the cemetery of the Jewish Community of Greater Stowe. The family will sit Shiva on Sunday afternoon, June 12, Monday evening, June 13 Wednesday evening, June 15 and Thursday evening, June 16 at 480 Park Ave.

DRIVERS of sport utility vehicles are among the least likely to be killed in a crash, according to an analysis released on Thursday of driver death rates by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The institute found that the death rate for S.U.V.'s fell 57 percent, from 65 deaths per million in 2007 to 28 in the new report.

SECOND chances don't come around often, but this July, Celine is reissuing six of Phoebe Philo's best looks in a collection of boyish silhouettes (Celine Classics), that blend the designer's minimalist aesthetic with a palette straight out of Picasso's ''Actor.'' It includes collectibles like this black wool Crombie coat ($2,950 at Bergdorf Goodman), a mallard-blue poplin boy shirt ($580 at Jeffrey New York) and a cobalt-blue grain de poudre tuxedo (jacket, $2,800; pants, $1,000, at Bergdorf Goodman). Like a Picasso, the pieces don't come cheap, but like the master, they'll always be in style. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Elegance seemed to go viral in the photographs of George Hoyningen-Huene. A Russian emigre in Paris in the 1920s, and a baron at that, Huene produced an exquisite quality of longing - or was it remoteness? - in the pages of French Vogue, where he was chief photographer in the most glamorous of 20th-century decades. You might say that Huene (pronounced HEW-neh) sealed the deal between modern-thinking couturiers and photographers, seducing us with light and classical forms. Afterward, nothing seemed the same. In her review of a 2001 exhibition that brought together Huene and his great friend Horst, the critic Vicki Goldberg noted ''the two H's influenced almost everyone else.'' So I was intrigued by the pairing of Huene and the American photographer Kurt Markus in a new exhibition at the Staley-Wise Gallery in SoHo. Mr. Markus first came to my attention in the early '90s, when I bought one of his landscapes, a graceful, if somewhat desolate-looking tree marked by a country road. Around the same time, Mr. Markus did one of my favorite spreads to appear in the Times Magazine (with the stylist Polly Hamilton) called ''The Look of the '90s,'' in which a group of nonagenarians posed in mostly avant-garde designs. A native of Montana, drawn naturally to Western characters, Mr. Markus's fashion pictures have a rare quality of warmth and wit.

IF you're a woman who roared, snorted or sniggered at ''Bridesmaids,'' if you like watching other women on screen, you should see it again. Because that hit comedy written by Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo and directed by Paul Feig, turns out to be one of the few occasions this summer when you can enjoy a movie about and with women released by a major studio. From now through August, American films will again be almost all male, almost all the time (the occasional decorative gal pal notwithstanding) as this year's boys of summer -- the Green Lantern and Captain America, Conan the Barbarian and Conan O'Brien -- invade the multiplex, seizing media-entertainment minds and your dollars. Mind you there are a few high-profile girls and women here and there, including the title character of ''Bad Teacher,'' with Cameron Diaz as the romance- and etiquette-challenged teacher who at one point washes a car in slow motion while wearing a midriff and hot pants. Evidently nothing says new motion picture entertainment better than a female movie star in Daisy Dukes bending over and sudsing a car as if she were in a 2005 Jessica Simpson music video.

An article last Sunday about celebrities and others who shield their identities behind trusts and LLCs when buying real estate misstated the eligibility of such buyers for an exclusion from capital-gains tax when the property is sold. An individual who creates a trust or is the sole owner of an LLC may be eligible for an exclusion in some cases; it is not prohibited across the board.

Third baseman Anthony Rendon was the top-rated player in the Major League Baseball draft, according to Baseball America, but he fell to the Washington Nationals with the sixth pick. Looking at the first 35 years of the draft (1965-1999), Rendon appears to be in good company. His fellow No. 6 picks have fared well against the players taken ahead of them in terms of All-Star appear- ances and M.V.P. awards, buoyed by the superstars Barry Bonds, Gary Sheffield and Derek Jeter.

Sebastião Salgado began working on ''Genesis,'' his most recent project, seven years ago. His idea was to photograph 20 places where the landscape was still pristine, relatively untouched by humans. He traveled to southern Africa and to the Amazon rain forests, to the South Sandwich Islands in the southern Atlantic and to Patagonia. The pictures in this portfolio document his journey to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern Alaska. A friend of his, who worked for the Unesco World Heritage Center, had spent a lot of time in Alaska and spoke to him often about the refuge. ''He gave me a book about it,'' Salgado says. ''For me, it became a big dream to go there.'' The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge covers more than 30,000 square miles from the coast of the Arctic Ocean across the Brooks Range mountains and into interior Alaska, covering several ecological zones that include barrier islands, coastal lagoons, salt marshes and rivers. Salgado visited the region in the spring and summer of 2009, when the caribou travel to the coastal plain to give birth and raise their young. He set up base camp in the village of Kaktovik and traveled by small plane, boat and on foot to capture the migrating herd.

In 1791, while serving as secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton began an affair with Maria Reynolds, blackmailing her husband for several years to allow it to continue. When a muckraker exposed the affair and the cover-up, Hamilton turned to the communications technology of the day to defend himself, publishing a pamphlet in which he argued that he had never abused any public resources. More than two centuries and many scandals later, Twitter has replaced pamphlets as the medium of the moment and become the new means for politicians to engage in sexual misconduct. Now, it is Representative Anthony D. Weiner, under pressure to resign after he first denied and then admitted ''sexting'' lewd messages and pictures of himself in his underwear via Twitter to college students and a porn star, among other young women. (The New York Democrat has defended himself -- plus ça change -- by arguing that he did not abuse public resources in his misdeeds.)

CASBAH-LIKE alleys lined with stone houses wound upward toward hills cloaked in pine and cypress trees. Hand-painted signs beckoned visitors to the shops and studios of jewelers, potters and other artisans. Just past a popular brunch spot with a packed terrace, Christian pilgrims from Russia, Poland and the United States gathered around a spring where Mary and Elizabeth, the mother of John the Baptist, were said to have met. Tucked in the arid hills on the western edge of Jerusalem, the community of Ein Karem was teeming with tourists and with residents on a March afternoon. It was hard to remember that this was a Saturday, at the height of the Sabbath, and that the rest of Jewish Jerusalem had stopped dead in its tracks.

BRISTOL--Atherton "Toni", 87, of Lakeville, Minnesota died peacefully on May 21, 2011 after suffering from Alzheimer's Disease. Toni was born October 24, 1923 in Brooklyn, New York to William M. and Madeline W. Bristol, Jr., and was a brother of William M. (Mac) and Michal W. He attended Kimball Union Academy and graduated from the Pingry School where he was awarded the Letter-in-Life Award in 1990 and inducted into the Athletics Hall of Fame. Toni matriculated at Hamilton College and graduated from Columbia University. He was a beloved coach of football, lacrosse and soccer at Pingry and Westfield High School in New Jersey. Toni was an inspiring leader, teaching generations of students to play well in sports and in life. In 1999, he was inducted into the New Jersey Lacrosse Foundation Hall of Fame. Toni was a devoted uncle and stepfather and a loyal companion to his beloved Dandie Dinmont Terriers. After retiring from coaching, he moved to Minneapolis and married Joanne Purinton, who pre-deceased him. He is survived by his loving wife, Patricia Ann, and five stepchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Michal, nine nieces and nephews and a multitude of grands, who will miss his warmth, gentle humor and remarkable generosity of spirit.

MARX--Herbert L. Jr. Herbert L. Marx Jr.,89, on May 31, 2011. His was a life well-lived, well-savored, and well-loved. Arbitrator, writer, editor, teacher, leader, father and grandfather. His thirst for knowledge, ease with people, respect for a variety of perspectives and ability to express reasoned opinion found welcome audience in all parts of his life. He was very proud his career continued into his eighty-ninth year. He passed on his love of literature, arts and a collector's passion for playbills, tea tins, and most of all, dictionaries, to more than one generation. His family grieves his loss. Children: Jonathan, Timothy and Alison Marx; daughters-in-law Johanna Lackner Marx, and Nan Simons Marx; grandchildren: Alyssa Marx Gray, Ariel Marx, Sophie Marx; Benjamin Marx; grandson-in-law David Gray; Benjamin Lackner Marx; and Joshua Lackner Marx. Stepdaughter Tedra Schneider and her children Gregory, Andrew and Hilary; Benjamin and Samuel Levine, children of the late Michael Levine, stepson; Stepdaughter-in-law Ellen Levine and her children Victoria and Robert. His first marriage was to Hilda Fisher Marx who survives him. He later wed the late Dorothy Sachs Marx. Herbert was an esteemed arbitrator for 37 years, serving six Presidential Emergency Boards; founding President National Association Railroad Referees; VP, Chair and Parliamentarian Nat'l Academy of Arbitrators; Member American Arbitration Association, Federal Mediation Conciliation Service, National Mediation Board; and countless national and regional panels. He was author, editor and contributor to noteworthy publications on labor, bargaining and religion. He served as adjunct faculty Cornell, Pace and Rutgers Universities; lecturer at Stanford University and Worcester College, Oxford, UK. Prior, he was VP, General Cable Corporation for 23 years. His career began as editor Scholastic Magazines; editor "The Dartmouth", Dartmouth College ('43). During WWII, he served the OSS in London/Paris. Truly a splendid life. Contributions may be made to Reach Out and Read, in honor of Herbert's lifelong love of literature. Memorial to be held later this summer.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

SECTION Two of the High Line, which opened on Wednesday, passes just beyond Frank Gehry's IAC building and Jean Nouvel's 100 11th Avenue. Now, with the installation of Sarah Sze's ''Still Life With Landscape (Model for a Habitat),'' some more-modest denizens of the neighborhood will have a piece of starchitecture, too. The sculpture, a dynamic steel and wood complex of bird, ladybug and butterfly condos, sits between 20th and 21st Streets. Among its amenities are feeding trays that will be regularly stocked with seeds and miniature troughs to catch rainwater. But as with any real estate development, occupancy is no guarantee. ''It's really an experiment,'' said Lauren Ross, director of the arts programs at Friends of the High Line, adding that the artist consulted various birders and received conflicting predictions. ''It functions first and foremost as sculpture. We're not sure how wildlife will respond to it.'' ALIX BROWNE

A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Feherty's half-interview, half-improv weekly show, ''Feherty,'' will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Feherty's 2002 novel, ''A Nasty Bit of Rough.'' Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.Q.How would you describe your new show? A.A televised nervous breakdown is the way it feels at the moment. I've been on TV for 15 years now, but it's never been anything I can be held completely responsible for. We're going to try various different things and see what the reaction is. Some of it will be serious. Some of it won't. There'll be an interview every week because I'm interested in other people's opinions. I just interviewedCharles Barkley, who was hysterical.Q.Is there anyone on TV you'd like to model yourself after?A.I'm a huge Billy Connolly fan, always have been. I like Ricky Gervais, Bob Newhart; people who are more observers. We've gotten to the stage today if you want comedy, you watch the news, and if you want news, you turn to the comedy channel. It's gotten turned upside down. Q.Whom do you like to win the United States Open next weekend?A.Steve Stricker has got to be one of the favorites. Although he shouldn't be able to win any tournaments. He's too nice. [Laughs.] He's a sweetheart.

An article last Sunday about Gertrude Stein and Modernism had incomplete credit information with some picture captions. The credit for Picasso's ''Head of a Sleeping Woman'' is: Museum of Modern Art/Scala, Art Resource, Estate of Pablo Picasso/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York. The credit for Picasso's portrait of Stein is: Metropolitan Museum of Art, bequest of Gertrude Stein, 1946, Estate of Pablo Picasso/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York. And the credit for the photograph of Stein and Alice B. Toklas is: Courtesy of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Man Ray Trust/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York/ADAGP, Paris.

FELSMAN--Jackson Kirk, beloved husband, father, son, friend and colleague. Born August 9, 1950, Bethesda Maryland, passed away May 22, 2011 in London, England while in transit to the US. He will be dearly missed by his wife, Irene Crabtree Felsman, children Caitlin May, Colin Lee and Kai Hannon Felsman; and mother Hallie May Felsman. Preceded in death by father, Jack Lee Felsman and brother Mark Steven Felsman. Kirk attended Del Norte High School, Albuquerque, NM. He received a BA in political science from University of New Mexico, 1972, Summa cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa. Went on to earn an EdD, concentration in Child Psychology, Harvard University, 1981. He was the recipient of a Doctoral Research Fulbright, 1986 and a Lyndhurst Prize Recipient, Lyndhurst Foundation 1986-89. Kirk was a clinical psychologist who tenaciously dedicated his life to marginalized children all over the world- those who lived on the street, child soldiers, refugees, those displaced by war, and victims of disaster. He worked in and led projects in Colombia, Philippines, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, South Africa. and contributed to initiatives in Rwanda, Haiti, Afghanistan, Israel, Sudan. He most recently served as Senior OVC Technical Advisor for USAID'S Regional HIV/AIDS Program in Southern Africa. Loved to ski, swim, collect old cars and antiques and had an amazing Tarzan yell. A closed family service was held May 27th, 2011 in Uxbridge, England and a memorial tribute will be held at USAID, Pretoria on June 3rd. A memorial service to honor Kirk's life will be held in the fall in New Hampshire, date to be announced.

REDLICH--Norman. The family of Norman Redlich wishes to correct the previous Shiva listing. The family will be sitting Shiva on Wednesday evening, June 15, Thursday evening June 16 and Friday afternoon, June 17.

LAST Sunday evening Buck Brannaman strolled the High Line, two stories above the streets of Manhattan and hundreds of miles from his native habitat, the ranch country where he runs clinics in enlightened horsemanship. The documentary ''Buck,'' which won a Sundance audience award this year and will open on Friday in New York and Los Angeles, details his shamanlike skills around horses and the people who ride them. The sun was falling toward the skyline across the Hudson River and Mr. Brannaman was enjoying a stroll after dinner at the Standard Grill. He walked like a cowboy, traversing the High Line with a gait in which a horse can be inferred between his wide-set legs. He looked like one too, with an expensive custom-made straight brim from the Rocky Mountain Hat Company and a salmon-colored cowboy shirt. A woman shooting photos began firing off frames at the sight of a real live cowboy on the High Line, and Mr. Brannaman, humble in all aspects, promptly stepped aside so the woman can get a shot of whatever it is she is so interested in. It was him of course.

An article on May 22 about private kitchens in Hong Kong misstated the price for lunch and dinner at Ta Pantry. Lunch starts at 550 Hong Kong dollars per person, not 2,200. (That is about $72 per person, at 7.62 Hong Kong dollars to the United States dollar.) Dinner prices are per table, not per person. Dinner is a minimum of 4,400 Hong Kong dollars per table Monday through Thursday -- about $577. Dinner is 5,500 Hong Kong dollars per table -- about $721 -- Friday and Saturday.

POSNER--Doris. Our congregation mourns the loss of Doris Posner, beloved mother of our esteemed Senior Rabbi, David. To the Posner family we express our deepest sympathies. May her memory be a blessing and her legacy a reflection of the love she brought to all. Interment private. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York
Dance Claudia La Rocco

A picture caption with an article on May 29 about survival strategies for urban orchestras misidentified the man holding a record album. He is Robert Whitney, a former conductor of the Louisville Orchestra, not Charles Farnsley, who was mayor of Louisville from 1948 to 1953 and an enthusiastic supporter of the orchestra.

I will share the fact with my close friends. But should I tell people at work and in the neighborhood, the people I see casually around town? (By the way, I'm not vain -- really.) P.S., New York

SCHATZLE--Joe, II, of Poughkeepsie, NY, and Arlington, VA, died June 4, 2011, of complications from Alzheimer's disease. Joe was born September 10, 1931 in Jamaica, NY, to Joseph Nicholas Schatzle, Sr., and Molly McGurk Schatzle. He grew up in Queens Village, NY, and Cold Spring, NY, studied at St. Francis Xavier High School in New York City, and graduated from Haldane High School in Cold Spring and later began his teaching career there. He received his Bachelor's Degree from Manhattan College (1953), where he was a member of the college's legendary sprint relay team (1951-53). He also held numerous individual titles. In 1953, as a member of the United States track team, he won the 100 and 220-yard titles at the British Games. From 1953 to 1955, Joe served as first lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps as an air traffic controller and where he also exercised his passion for track. From 1963-1993 he taught physical education and coached track and field for Wappingers Central School District, and became known as the "father of track and field" in Duchess County. In 1991, he was inducted into the Manhattan College Athletic Hall of Fame, and in 2008 his former students and athletes dedicated a monument to their coach which is on the athletic field of R.C. Ketcham High School. As one former students stated, "His positive influence ripples out today through leaders in community and country." Joe was an unusual athlete in that he was deeply involved in the world of art and was himself and artful photographer. His "studio" on the Hudson River is filled with his photographs of the Hudson River Valley, a place dear to his heart, a place where he spent hours reading and writing poetry. Preceding him in death were his parents, his brother James and his son Peter. Joe is survived by his beloved wife, Dolores Leckey of Arlington, Virginia; his children from his first marriage to Louise S. Schatzle: Joseph Nicholas Schatzle III, Charles Schatzle, David Schatzle, and Molly Schatzle Immerzeel; his four grandchildren, Hannah Schatzle, Kalvyn Joy Immerzeel, Branden Immerzeel, and Oliver Nicholas Schatzle; and his stepchildren, Mary Kate Marcellus (Ron), Dr. Celia Leckey, Thomas J. Leckey (Margaret), Dr. Colum Leckey (Donna); and seven step-grandchildren, all of whom are grateful for his presence in their lives. Nieces, cousins, scores of former students, athletes and colleagues will also miss his humor, sensitivity, and gentle ways. He always reminded his family and friends that "we must have fun." Viewing in Virginia was held on Thursday, June 9, 2011 at Advent Funeral Home, 7211 Lee Highway, Falls Church, Virginia 22046. The funeral mass and burial will take place the following week in Cold Spring, NY: the wake will be at Clinton Funeral Home on Monday, June 13th, 5pm to 8pm; the funeral Mass will be Tuesday, June 14th at Our Lady of Loretto Church at 10am. Memorial contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research or Manhattan College.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Regret and Defense Amid Tressel Fallout,'' June 5: Dr. F. Robert Tabita, head of Ohio State's Athletic Council, was quoted saying that the former football coach Jim Tressel's main issue is that ''he has given too many knuckleheads too many chances in his never-ending quest to help these kids become productive citizens.'' The university's president, E. Gordon Gee, lauded the football team's ''strong recent academic performance.''

TWENTY Broadway productions have featured animals trained by the 2011 Tony honoree William Berloni over the past 35 years; exactly none of this year's nominated shows are among them. At press time Mr. Berloni remained undecided about whether he would bring one of his dogs to the awards ceremony this weekend, but if he does, that living, breathing animal will be a rare commodity among the feathered, hoofed and fanged critters on display this season. ERIC GRODE

WALLEY--Jean, passed away peacefully on June 9 at age 105 with her family and caregivers close by retaining her vitality almost until the end. She lived a rich life as a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother and is survived by son Donald (Liz Robbins) and daughter Harriet (Arthur Lohman); grandchildren Noah (Kristina Wollschlaeger), Sarah Kugelman (Daryl Nanes) and Matthew; and great-grandchildren Nastassia, Arabella and Alexa. A native New Yorker, she spent her retirement with her late husband Abraham in Plantation, Florida, before returning home for her final years. She led an active and varied life, including as secretary to the first rabbi to visit the former Soviet Union after the cold war years and as the credit manager of a major Manhattan bank. In her earlier years, she worked in the buying departments of DePinna and S. Klein. She will be remembered for her cooking, beautiful handwriting, touching notes, and her love and total commitment to her family who will never forget her.

''Would you buy a used car from that guy?'' was the old refrain. Now, that guy is desperate to buy your car. Prices for used cars have been on an upswing, and analysts do not foresee a leveling off during the summer.

''It was one of the worst meetings we've ever had.'' Ali al-Naimi, the Saudi oil minister, speaking after a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna ended in disarray last week, with ministers failing to reach a consensus to raise oil production levels. ''We are going to demote the PC to just be a device. We are going to move the digital hub, the center of your digital life, into the cloud.'' Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, envisioning a radical shift in the focus of personal computing. This would be made possible, he said, by the company's new online storage and syncing service for music, photos, files and software, announced last week.

IT was a train that saved Britomart, a three-block-square piece of downtown Auckland, New Zealand's most populous city. The area, which borders the port and gets its name from a British fort established there in the 1860s, had long been home to derelict buildings, tacky tourist shops and dingy strip clubs. But in 2003 a refurbished railway station, which hadn't been a working terminal since 1912, reopened, and four suburban train lines began delivering commuters to the neighborhood again. In 2006 the city's first farmers' market was established in the square outside the station. Stores and cafes followed, and in the last year a handful of new bars and restaurants have popped up in the character-filled storefronts that were once home to warehouses and shipping companies. The East building, a new high-rise at the south end of the precinct, was completed in April, bringing thousands of bankers and accountants -- and an accompanying hustle and bustle -- to the area each workday. KIRSTEN MATTHEW

An article on May 29 about television programs tied to the 150th anniversary of the start of the Civil War misspelled the surname of the president of the History channel. She is Nancy Dubuc, not Dupuc.

When the San Francisco Giants needed a player to speak to the crowd before their game with the Los Angeles Dodgers on April 11, the choice was obvious. It would not be a star, but a journeyman left-handed middle reliever. It had to be Jeremy Affeldt. The first time the teams met, on opening day at Dodger Stadium, a Giants fan named Bryan Stow was severely beaten in the parking lot. This was the teams' next series, in San Francisco, and Affeldt was asked to deliver a message of peace and unity.

GRAHAM--Mary Tooker. Born March 15, 1924. Died in her sleep June 8, 2011. Graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute, she was a talented dressmaker with an eye for beautiful fabrics. Loving mother, loyal friend, she enjoyed sailing, and was an avid New York Times crossword puzzle solver (including Saturday's.) Daughter of George and Angela Tooker of Brooklyn Heights, NY and Bellport, NY. Sister of painter George C. Tooker. She is survived by son Peter Hume and daughter-in-law Phyllis of Brooklyn, son Russell Hume and daughter in law Susan of Leominster, MA, Angus Graham and daughter-in-law Christy of Brookhaven, NY, daughter Angela Graham and son-in- law Jonathan Dahl of Brooklyn and grandchildren Amy, Caitlin Phoebe, Andrew and Heather. Mary was also very fond of her extended family, Leida, Loolly, Orson, Hugo and Cecil.
To the Sports Editor:

Although Peter Feigenbaum, 27, grew up near Boston, he was always obsessed with New York -- particularly the ruined street- scapes he knew only from films made long be- fore his birth, like ''The French Connection'' and ''Serpico.'' While studying architecture as an undergraduate at Yale, he began making scale models of archetypical New York build- ings and photographing them in different com- binations. His concept for the project, ''Train- set Ghetto,'' he said, is that ''New York has a certain style of vernacular architecture and blocks often feel like they're interchangeable.''Although Mr. Feigenbaum has worked in different architecture firms since moving to New York five years ago, he has not changed his basic approach to building a row house. Al- though sometimes he makes a wooden mold and casts it in plaster, and other times he de- signs on a computer and has plastic parts cut in a shop, the trick is always in building up enough layers of tempera paint, along with plenty of wet brushing, dry brushing and air- brushing, to summon up the necessary patina of grime and decrepitude (left and above right). Sometimes he adds a dirtied model car to the scene to suggest a sign of life.These days, to make sure his project ''evolves away from a hobbyist aesthetic,'' Mr. Feigenbaum said, he often disassembles his models and photographs them outside, amid the real streets of New York. In the resulting pictures it's hard to tell where toy town ends and the full-scale buildings start. But that's the point. ''I'm trying to create scenarios where reality tries to fight back against hyper-reali- ty,'' Mr. Feigenbaum said, ''and makes itself known again.''

An article on May 22 about the history of teenage-werewolf movies erroneously attributed a distinction to American International Pictures. It pioneered the practice of releasing a pair of B-movies as a double feature, in the 1950s. It did not invent the double feature, which began in the 1930s.

THE NEWS The embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh , was badly wounded and burned by an explosion in a mosque in the presidential palace. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Saleh was flown to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, for medical treatment, along with dozens of other officials and relatives, leaving the vice president to manage in Sana, the Yemeni capital. Uncertainty about Mr. Saleh's condition further complicated the chaotic situation in Yemen, where peaceful protests against Mr. Saleh's rule were eclipsed by increasingly hard fighting among government troops, various tribal forces and militants.

8 P.M. (CBS) THE 65TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, right, always a boost for awards-show ratings, sings and dances his way through the role of host for this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway, to be broadcast live from the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Performers include the casts of the nominees for best musical and best musical revival -- ''Anything Goes,'' ''Catch Me if You Can,'' ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' ''Sister Act,'' ''The Book of Mormon'' and ''The Scottsboro Boys'' -- as well as ''Memphis,'' ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' ''Ghetto Klown'' and ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert.'' The cast of the New York Philharmonic's production of ''Company,'' including Stephen Colbert, Jon Cryer, Christina Hendricks, Patti LuPone, Martha Plimpton and Anika Noni Rose, will also reassemble. Among the presenters are Matthew Broderick, Harry Connick Jr., Viola Davis, Joel Grey, Whoopi Goldberg, Kelsey Grammer, Samuel L. Jackson, James Earl Jones and Robin Williams. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews the 2012 Republican presidential candidate Tim Pawlenty, a former governor of Minnesota.

HALPERN--Jack Zachary, from March 7, 1948 to June 11, 2011. Survived by his loving wife Debra Halpern (nee Brandt), his two beloved daughters Gillian and Lynden. Also survived by brother Jeffrey Halpern. Born in Bronx, NY. Married at the Plaza Hotel July 2, 1972. He was employed as a psychotherapist and served as a Vietnam War Veteran. Funeral Services Sunday at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway at 9am. Like her signature sheath dresses, the handbags are refined, crisp-edged and vivid. And, at $20,500 for the burgundy crocodile, so very civilized. Barneys.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

Baseball fans had reason to be envious of the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. last week. Each sport's championship series stood at 2-2 after four games. The World Series has not been tied 2-2 since 2003, when the Yankees played the Florida Marlins. Since then, three series have been sweeps, and a team has led three games to one four times. The series extended to six games only once in that time, in 2009. Competitive balance is not the problem; 11 teams have filled the 14 spots in those World Series.
Pop Jon Pareles

KAPIT--Dr. Hanna, 93, on June 9, 2011. Beloved wife of Dr. Milton Kapit, who predeceased her. Loving mother of Susan and Andrew. A distinguished psychoanalyst for over 50 years, a friend and mentor to many. She was a training analyst of the Postgraduate Center of Mental Health and professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

SCHAEFER--Rudolph J. III, of Stonington, CT and Key Largo, FL died June 10th in his home, surrounded by his loving family. Mr. Schaefer was born August 29, 1930 in New York City to Rudolph Jay Schaefer Jr. and Lucia Moran Schaefer. Rudie attended the Rye Country Day School, Choate, Washington and Lee and graduated from Hofstra University with a BBA. Rudie also attended the Harvard Business School PMD Management Program. After graduation, Rudie enlisted in the Navy in June 1952. He served active duty aboard the USS MaGowen DD678 from 1953 to 1957 in the Middle East, attaining the rank of Lieutenant JG. He remained in the Naval Reserves until 1969. Rudie married Jane A. Isdale of New Rochelle, NY at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, NY in 1956. Joining the F&M Schaefer Brewing Co. in 1957 he later served as president of the brewery from 1972 to 1975. His great-grandfather founded the F&M Schaefer Brewing Company in 1842. Mr. Schaefer was involved and worked on many boards throughout his life. He was vice president and board member of the New York School For The Deaf, board member of the United Hospital in Port Chester, NY, the New Rochelle Hospital as well as the L and M Hospital in New London, CT. Rudie was also a board member of the Lincoln Savings Bank and the New London Savings Bank. A philanthropist throughout his life, Rudie was especially proud of his work with the Mystic Seaport, serving as a trustee in 1975 and later president and chairman of the board from 1983 to 1989. His love of the sea and yachting sparked a life long interest in marine art. He was very proactive in supporting many aspiring marine artists. Rudie was instrumental in building the Mystic Maritime Art Gallery at the Mystic Seaport in honor of his father, Rudolph J. Schaefer Jr. Mr. Schaefer was actively involved in many clubs and organizations including the Cruising Club of America, founder of the Stonington Country Club, Stonington Harbor Yacht Club, Ocean Reef Club, member and commodore of the Key Largo Anglers Club, New York Yacht Club. Former memberships include the American Yacht Club, Larchmont Yacht Club and the Shelter Island Yacht Club. Rudie is survived by his wife Jane, son Rudolph J. Schaefer IV, daughters Martha H. Schaefer, Edmee S. Zahringer, Lucia S. Chase, Greta J. Schaefer, sons-in-law Charles J. Zahringer and Mark M. Chase. Mr. Schaefer is also survived by his eleven grandchildren, Alexandra M. Schaefer, Rudolph J. Schaefer V, Helena K. Schaefer, Janie K. Schaefer, Lucia M. Zahringer, Charles J. Zahringer Jr., Graham H. Zahringer, Kylie S. Zahringer, Frederick J. Zahringer, Max M. Chase, Dylan J. Chase. Mr. Schaefer is survived by his stepmother, Janet Udall Schaefer, brother William M. Schaefer and sister Edmee S. Combs. He is also predeceased by his sister Lucy S. Pedersen and daughter Anne E. Schaefer. Service to be held Thursday, June 16, 2011 11:00am Calvary Episcopal Church, 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mystic Seaport, P.O. Box 6000 75 Greenmanville Avenue Mystic, CT. 06355 Or Hospice Southeastern Connecticut 227 Dunham Street, Norwich, CT 06360

Twenty years ago Didier Massard was a studio photographer in Paris who amused himself by shooting European landscapes in his spare time. Gradually he felt compelled to photo- graph more exotic locales, but only as they ex- isted in his mind.''There were many places in the world I wished to photograph and visit,'' Mr. Massard, 57, said, ''and I realized that they wouldn't be as I imagined them.'' Eventually he decided to build a scene in his studio.His early photographs depicted places like India and China; then came nature scenes. More recently he has added animals, like this monkey, left, clutching an applelike fruit, in- spired by a Du rer engraving.Mr. Massard spent six months creating the monkey, first using layers of cardboard to sug- gest its form. The face, hands and feet are made of dental composite and the fur of darn- ing wool, which he blended, combed and glued in tiny tufts to mosquito netting.This Edenic diorama is the first Mr. Mas- sard has shown in public. It also represents the first time he has captured an animal facing his camera. ''I wouldn't say that it is a self-portrait,'' he said, mentioning the primate-human bond, ''but there is something of that in it.''

HEINZERLING--Anna (Westergaard), 89, on June 9. Survived by her husband Ralph Heinzerling, their children Laura, Steve, Nina and her sister Thora Frank. Proud graduate of Smith College. Born in Oslo Norway. Taught ESOL till her final days.

Visitors may wonder who died, so many New Yorkers are dressed head to toe in black. Two of the most consistently and fabulously black-clad are Marjorie Stern, the philanthropist, and Timothy John, an artist and designer who favors Asian clothes, pictured here on their way to work at 9 a.m. over 10 days. They always pause to admire each other's flowing robes, often in diaphanous fabrics with surface textures. Equally exotic are the pitch-black irises at Old Westbury Gardens, the former Phipps estate on Long Island, with its newly restored pergola.

He went on to have a successful career with major architecture firms including SOM, Swanke, and HLW before opening Colvin Design seven years ago. His legacy will live on in the beautifully inspired corporate and residential interiors he leaves behind. He is survived by his loving partner of over 26 years, Philip Bialer, his dearest friends, Nat and Whitney Stern his brothers Don, Tommy, and Larry and his beloved dog Lola. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in his honor may be made to The Good Dog Foundation.

ARMY STAFF SGT. JOSH PELTZ, 33 (shirtless, far left): We were settling in at an abandoned compound after a long day's patrol, and I could finally ''turn down'' being in a constant state of alertness and become almost human again. I was enjoying the camaraderie that only comes from living together as a group, but I was missing my dog, my car and simple things like being able to shower without shoes on. Then a camel spider fell off the wall and into a pile of gear, and I think this photo was snapped just after the guys all jumped up. That soldier behind me is deathly afraid of spiders. He didn't sleep much that night, but I slept fine.
GREEN--Sylvia. March 10, 1913 - June 15, 2007 Four years have gone by and I miss you more each day. Your words of wisdom are always with me. I love you , Barbara

ZANDMAN--Felix. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Felix Zandman. A Holocaust survivor, Dr. Zandman was a devoted Zionist and generous benefactor of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, where he and his wife Ruta established the Zandman Center for Thick Film Microelectronics. An active participant in AABGU's Philadelphia chapter and a vice chair on BGU's board of governors, Felix Zandman received an honorary doctorate from BGU in 1996. He will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with Ruta and her extended family. Alexander M. Goren, President Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President

Jorge Semprún, a Spanish writer whose novelistic memoirs (or memoirish novels) drew on his experiences as a French Resistance fighter, concentration camp survivor, Communist organizer and Communist dissident, and who wrote distinguished screenplays for Alain Resnais, Costa-Gavras, Joseph Losey and other directors, died on Tuesday at his home in Paris. He was 87. His grandson Thomas Landman confirmed the death, Agence France-Presse reported.

SOPHIA EDSTRAND, the designer behind the jewelry label Sophia 203, is from Sweden, but her C.V. has a French accent. She studied fashion design in Paris, worked as a salesgirl at Colette (''for pocket money while I was a student,'' she said, ''but I spent it all on shoes''), then did a 10-year stint as creative assistant to the jeweler Marie-Hélène de Taillac. Ms. Edstrand's silk embroidered necklaces, belts and headbands, produced by craftspeople in Jaipur, India, are Yves Saint Laurent via Williamsburg. The designer claims to have had no thoughts of YSL while conceiving the line but is happy to report that Stefano Pilati has already bought a belt; Sophia.203@hotmail.com. NANCY MacDONNELL

IRVINE--Keith. We mourn the passing of our friend Keith Irvine. TOWBIN--Irene Kathleen June 10, 2011. A unique person, independent mother, artist, and friend. A citizen of Ireland and the USA, Irene was born in Brooklyn, attended catholic schools and became a graduate nurse from the Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing. She married and had three children; Minna, whose husband, Ned Pinger and children Belmont, Dash, and Zyla mourn her passing; Bram and his wife Erica, and Zachary and his wife Hannah and their children; Harry, Phoebe and Cayetana all share the tragedy of losing a mother and grandmother, as she approached her 75th year. She will also be mourned by her brother, Dan Lyons and his wife Judy and their children; Cathlin, and husband Eric, and their two children, Daniel and his wife Donna, and their two children, and Matthew Lyons. Finally, she will be missed by her former husband and friend Robert Towbin, who admired her unique understanding of good and bad and her willingness, to express her strong opinions. Irene was an accomplished artist who worked many years in her SoHo studio which she shared with her dear friend and fellow artist Kiki Kogelnik. Irene was more than a painter and maker of unique constructions, be it amusing statements of undeniable truths, or photos of things that would surely lose their glamour and moments of popular appeal. Her photos in the Dublin, Ireland, eatery, the Temple Bar, capture the SoHo of New York in the 1980's that no longer exists. Her growing interest in what governments are obligated to do for their citizens which started during the McCarthy era of the 1950s and translated, over the years, to a fierce defense of women's rights and disenfranchised people everywhere on this earth characterized her incisive strong and brave attitude to life. A growing distaste for the movement in her home country by right wing politicians infuriated her and as President George W. Bush became the favorite to win a second term, she decided to leave America and live in Ireland. She chose Galway as her home and created a unique spot in which to live. As she settled in, she began to travel and returned to Budapest, Hungary where Kiki had had a show years earlier, and bought an apartment there, on the river, and made her home both in Ireland and Budapest, entertaining her friends in both places in the ensuing years. Irene will be missed by friends in Ireland, Hungary and Staten Island where she bought two flats when the Staten Island Yankees came to town and sold one. The Yankees have not done as well. A memorial service will be held in New York City and details will be announced soon.

GYORIK--Ilona Maria, (nee Szabo) passed away in Winchester, VA on May 7 at 85. Escaping from Hungary in 1956 and arriving in the USA in 1959, she devoted her life to incorporating Hungarian refugees into American life and raising American consciousness of Hungarian-born citizens contributions to American life, including Nobel prize and Congressional Medal Of Honor winners. She was on "The President's Council On Aging" from 1981-2005. Serving as Secretary General to the World Hungarian Freedom Fighters' Federation from 1960 to 2000, she was also its lobbyist. Her fundraising patrons included philanthropist Catherine Filene Shouse.

AFOUR-BEDROOM four-and-a-half- bathroom condominium in the Park Millennium on West 67th Street that closed for $12 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com and brokers with knowledge of the final sale price.The seller, Eugene Melnyk, the owner of the Ottawa Senators of the National Hockey League, originally listed the property, a com- bination of three units on the 44th floor with 4,800 square feet of space, for $16.9 million last September with Halstead Property. The price was reduced to $14.9 million in Janu- ary, and the property went into contract in late April, according to Streeteasy. VIBRANT, independent and home to one of Europe's oldest universities, Bologna is a dynamic counterpoint to more popular, touristy cities like Rome and Florence. About 50 miles north of Florence, the city is as famous for its cuisine as it is for its fiery left-leaning politics. Market stalls brimming with asparagus and fava beans, specialty shops selling cured meats, and osterias serving fresh pasta with the city's signature ragù (known as Bolognese in the rest of the world) offer compelling reasons to linger. And then there are architectural masterpieces like the church of Santo Stefano and the iconic Due Torri (Two Towers). Grittier than in most of its northern counterparts, Bologna's politics -- the last mayor, Flavio Delbono, resigned when it was alleged that he was using public money on his mistress, and now residents are waiting to see if the new mayor, Virginio Merola, will make good on his promise to spruce up the city center -- somehow only adds to the excitement of a visit here. Even as a child, Matthew Albanese said, ''I always wanted to be a photographer, however it manifested it- self.'' Now a product photographer at Barneys, he hap- pened upon his creative bliss in 2008, while shooting gadgets for his family's former online business.Bored by the subject at hand, Mr. Albanese, now 28, was playing around with lighting when he overturned a can of paprika in the warehouse kitchen. ''It reminded me of the surface of Mars,'' he said, ''and I thought I would try to create a barren landscape with it.'' Hun- dreds of pounds of sugar, spice and steel wool later, he had grown adept at coaxing humble materials into look- ing like something else (an ice floe, say, or a tornado) when fixed by his camera.The photographs, top and above right, and the dio- rama for them, above left, are homages to the wetlands of the Hackensack River in New Jersey, near where Mr. Albanese grew up. This is the only diorama he has built to last. He spent more than seven months turning os- trich feathers into willow trees (a painstaking process that involved dyeing, stitching and weaving each indi- vidual barb), tying raffia ribbon bits into cattails, and carving chocolate into mud. To capture the stormy scene Mr. Albanese turned on a fan and planted dry ice behind the cattails; for the sunset version, he placed cotton bat- ting and colored light bulbs behind a muslin sky. But as with all his work, he said: ''A lot of it is about how it's photographed. That's when the process comes alive.''

As the new pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' rookie-level team in the New York-Penn League, Frank Viola will have few pupils who were born in the 1980s, when he starred for the Minnesota Twins. But his pitchers will discover who he is. ''A lot of the kids have to Google you to see what your career was,'' Viola said last week. ''Once they realize what you did, you've got their respect and they're into you. But then if you can't help them along the way, it doesn't matter what you've done. So there's a fine line between using it to your advantage and losing the kid because you're talking about it too much. So hopefully, I'm doing it the right way.''

NETHERCOT--Dr. Arthur H.,87, 35 year resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, passed away May 28, 2011 at his home of 20 years in Bellingham, WA. Predeceased by two wives, Phyllis Scifres and Phyllis Warner, Ned leaves sons Ben, Peter, Tom, and Zach of California. Nine grandchildren.

On this side of the Atlantic, Orla Kiely is best known for her instantly recognizable leaf-print bags, which hang on strollers from Brooklyn to Santa Monica. But the Irish-born, London-based designer makes much more than just mummy-friendly diaper bags. She also has home décor and ready-to-wear lines, both of which feature cheerful graphics and mod silhouettes. And while it’s taken a while, London hipsters have finally lit upon her her clothing designs, which make references to the Chelsea girl charm of Mary Quant, Julie Christie and Jean Shrimpton. Thanks to bright young fans like Alexa Chung and Keira Knightley, Kiely is enjoying some well-deserved celebrity on her home turf. It helps, of course, that she has a bevy of cool girls working for her. Venetia Scott, the Marc Jacobs stylist-turned-photographer, shoots her ad campaigns, and Leith Clark, the Canadian editor of the British indie fashion magazine Lula, styles them. Her first American store is set to open in SoHo in September. In anticipation, Kiely’s hosting an event at the Ace Hotel tomorrow night. Chung will D.J. and Mercedes Heinwein’s short film about the fall collection, which was inspired by Tippi Hedren’s wardrobe in “The Birds,” will be screened. Describing her recent success, which she’s hoping to replicate in the United States, Kiely is as well mannered and ladylike as her neat blouses and primly tailored coats. “Oh, gosh, I’ve really just been enjoying it,” she says. “I hope Americans like the clothes, too.”

For all of the magazine’s themed issues, the art department strives to develop a look and feel that is specific to the issue’s topic, yet still feels like The Times Magazine. This often involves rolling out a new font. This past Sunday’s Voyages issue was about travel in America. The destinations in the articles weren’t exotic but, rather, familiar places made interesting by the experiences and observations of the writers. With the design, we wanted to develop a visual language that subtly evoked Americana and also felt unique and personal, like the articles themselves. We looked at a variety of travel-related materials: everything from postcards to airline identities to airport-way-finding systems.

A new, all-day ferry service along New York City’s East River is set to be announced on Wednesday, Michael Grynbaum wrote in The New York Times. The service, which will start later this month, will make seven stops along the route, including stops in Long Island City, Queens, and the Fulton Ferry landing in Brooklyn. In Manhattan, stops will include Pier 11 in the financial district and at East 34th Street. The ferries will run every 20 minutes during morning and evening rush hours, and every 30 minutes during off-peak hours. Weekday hours will be from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m., with ferries running from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. on weekends. Fares will be as low as $3. Read more »

At Fueguia, a new scent lab and shop in Buenos Aires’s Palermo Viejo neighborhood, Julian Bedel creates candles, room scents and perfumes from 100 different notes and a large helping of imagination. For a candle named after the fanciful writer Jorge Luis Borges, Bedel turned to the Asian champaca flower. “Borges would have dreams of tigers moving through fields of champaca,” he explains. Pulpería, named for a traditional gaucho’s pub, has notes of cedar, musk and pepper; Pampa Húmeda smells of the Argentine countryside; and the store’s namesake, Fueguier, is redolent of Patagonia (the name of the scent comes from the indigenous people Darwin encountered while on an expedition to the region). There are 23 soy-based candles in all, set in red, blue and clear glass and packed in hand-carved oak boxes. Customers can also create their own fragrances from ingredients like red mandarin, bergamot and Cis-3 Hexenol, which smells like grass.

REDLICH--Norman, NYU School of Law mourns the loss of Dean Emeritus Norman Redlich (LL.M. '55) who served on the faculty from 1960 to 1994 and as dean from 1975 to 1988. A visionary leader, Norman oversaw the profound transformation of clinical and interdisciplinary education, as well as the expansion of the School's campus. A dedicated public servant, a fearless defender of civil liberties and civil rights, and a champion of the legal profession, Norman inspired generations of students, faculty, and the broader community of lawyers. He will be deeply missed. Anthony Welters, Chair of the Board, Richard Revesz, Dean, NYU School of Law.

It has been a tough couple of months for Sony. The company's PlayStation Network was breached by hackers in late April, and now several other units of the company have suffered broad security breaches. In the last two weeks alone, half a dozen Sony Web sites and servers, including some in the United States and Brazil, have been breached. And a group of hackers calling themselves LulzSec posted proprietary Sony source code on file-sharing Web sites.
