Millions of dental patients who have successfully avoided unpleasant drill-and-fill procedures owe much to Dr. Irwin D. Mandel -- an expert on dental chemistry jocularly known among colleagues as a leader of ''the Salivation Army.'' Dr. Mandel, a founder of the preventive dentistry movement who did research into the biochemistry of saliva that has had significant impact in medical fields beyond his own, died on May 26 in Montclair, N.J., his daughter Carol Ann Mandel said. He was 89 and lived in West Caldwell, N.J.

NETHERCOT--Dr. Arthur H.,87, 35 year resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, passed away May 28, 2011 at his home of 20 years in Bellingham, WA. "Ned" was a Big Ten champion wrestler at Northwestern, worked on the Manhattan Project during WWII, and later had a 35 year career as a research physicist with IBM. Predeceased by two wives, Phyllis Scifres and Phyllis Warner, Ned leaves sons Ben, Peter, Tom, and Zach of California. Nine grandchildren.

The photos and quizzes in Hearst's online magazines are about to get a digital upgrade. On Monday, Hearst Magazines Digital Media will announce two new features for its online publications that will make it easier for readers to buy the products they see on the page. Kristine Welker, chief revenue officer for Hearst Digital, said the publication wants its magazines to be a ''shoppable experience'' for users.

JASAITIS--John J. M.D.,77, of Manhattan, NY and Avon by the Sea, NJ passed away Saturday June 11, 2011 at Jersey Shore University Medical Center, Neptune, NJ. Dr. Jasaitis maintained a practice in General Surgery in Midtown Manhattan, NY for the past 40 years before his retirement in 2009. He was a 1955 graduate of Rutgers University and the Yale University School of Medicine in 1959. He served his internship and residency in General Surgery at Roosevelt Hospital, New York City, NY. After establishing his private practice for one year, he was drafted by the United States Air Force into the Vietnam War. He proudly served as a Captain and the Chief of Surgical Service, USAF Hospital at Edwards Air Force Base. He was then deployed to the 12th USAF Hospital, Cam Ranh Bay, South Vietnam, serving from 1967 to 1968. He was discharged with the rank of Major in the USAF Reserve until May 1974. He was appointed a Diplomate of the American Board of Surgery on November 9, 1970, followed by an appointment as a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons on October 5, 1972. Among the many positions he held during his illustrious career, he served as the President of the Medical Staff of St. Clare's Hospital from 1984 to 1986 and then again from 1994 to 1998. He was also affiliated with Cabrini Medical Center, Beth Israel Hospital, NY Infirmary/ Beekman Downtown/NYU Downtown Hospital, and Roosevelt Hospital, all of Manhattan, NY. Dr. Jasaitis was a passionate believer in occupational health care and was affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Health Center and Colgate Palmolive Co., Medical Department, New York, NY. Born in Newark, NJ to Edward and Ona Mackevicius Jasaitis, he lived in Manhattan, NY and maintained a summer residence in Avon by the Sea, NJ which later became his permanent home. He was an avid and knowledgeable gardener who took great pleasure in growing plants and flowers. He maintained a very close relationship with his loving family. He was a Communicant of St. Elizabeth's RC Church, Avon by the Sea. He is survived by his devoted wife of 42 years, Mary Ann Carey Jasaitis, his children and their spouses Edward G. and Kathleen Jasaitis of Marblehead, Mass. and Patricia Ann and John Wnek of Pine Beach, NJ, his three beloved grandchildren Nicholas, Eleanor, and Chloe, his brother Dr. Joseph Jasaitis and wife Joanne of Sea Girt, and his two sisters in law, Betty Barrett and Kathleen Carey. Relatives and friends are invited to call on Tuesday from 4-7pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall followed by a Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, June 15, 2011 at 11am at St. Elizabeth's Church, 424 Lincoln Ave., Avon by the Sea, NJ 07717. Burial with military honors will be in the NJ Veterans Cemetery, Wrightstown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to St Elizabeth's Church in Avon by the Sea, NJ . For further information or to send condolences to the family please visit www.obrienfuneralhome.com

It's almost impossible to walk a block or two in Manhattan and not spy a Chinese-food deliveryman on a bicycle. For years, the tool of the trade was an inexpensive mountain bike, usually banged-up and grimy and trimmed with large wire baskets. But a new type of vehicle has emerged in the world of Chinese-food delivery: the electric bike.

On many if not most weekdays, A. Rey Pamatmat follows the same routine: Wake at 5 a.m., then two hours of ashtanga yoga followed by two hours of playwriting, before heading from Jackson Heights, Queens, to the East Village and his day job as a database manager at the Public Theater. He usually hits the sack at 10 p.m. - a lifestyle with which he has no complaints, he said, other than one: He has craved more time for writing.-''I arranged my schedule so, if I was feeling tired, it would be during work and not during playwriting,'' Mr. Pamatmat said. ''I used to try to write five pages a day. Now, it's two pages a day and I'm at least satisfied. But I've always thought it'd be great to figure out how to have a life that was wholly organized around my plays.'' He will soon have a chance. The Lark Play Development Center, now in its 17th year as a significant, nurturing artistic home in Manhattan for writers, announced Friday that it had given its fifth annual Playwrights of New York Fellowship to Mr. Pamatmat, 35, a Yale School of Drama graduate. His best-known play is also a relatively new one, ''Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them,'' which has been receiving regional theater productions since its premiere at the Humana Festival this year. (No New York production is set, he said.)

Before the subjects of headlining news stories agree to a television interview these days, some have one question: how much money can I make? ABC and NBC, embroiled in a fight for viewers in the mornings, are increasingly in the news for their willingness to pay thousands of dollars to gain exclusive access to news subjects.

9 P.M. (HBO) A MATTER OF TASTE: SERVING UP PAUL LIEBRANDT (2011) In 2000, at the restaurant Atlas, Mr. Liebrandt, left, then 24, became the youngest chef to win three stars from The New York Times, praised by the critic William Grimes for his ''daring, distinctive style'' in dishes like espuma of calf brains and foie gras, and beer and truffle soup. ''The starting point is French, with a reverence for good ingredients and classic technique,'' Mr. Grimes wrote. ''The animating principle, however, is working-class cheek.'' But after 9/11 haute cuisine in New York City lost favor to comfort food, and Mr. Liebrandt, demoted to two stars at Papillon and Gilt, spent the next decade working his way back up the city's food chain. In March 2007 he became the chef and part owner of Corton, Drew Nieporent's TriBeCa restaurant. This film from Sally Rowe follows Mr. Nieporent and Mr. Liebrandt, along with his girlfriend, Arleene Oconitrillo, the restaurant's director, as they worked to get Corton ready for its opening. Among those interviewed are Mr. Grimes and Frank Bruni of The Times, and the chefs Grant Achatz, Heston Blumenthal, Daniel Boulud, Thomas Keller and Eric Ripert. 8 P.M. (ABC FAMILY) THE SECRET LIFE OF THE AMERICAN TEENAGER Season 4 begins as Adrian (Francia Raisa) and Ben (Ken Baumann) struggle to keep their relationship intact after the unexpected loss of their baby. Meanwhile Amy (Shailene Woodley) feels guilty that she's so happy in her life with Ricky (Daren Kagasoff), while he finds her worries a waste of energy and invites her to move in with him.

It was never going to be easy to find the actress who could step into Barbra Streisand's shoes and star in a new Broadway-bound production of ''Funny Girl,'' the 1964 musical comedy that propelled Ms. Streisand's career. But the man searching to fill the role of Fanny Brice - Bartlett Sher, the Tony Award-winning director of ''South Pacific'' - has newly reckoned with how challenging it will be. ''This is the hardest part I've ever had to cast,'' said Mr. Sher, who will direct ''Funny Girl'' at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles, with performances in January and February 2012 before an intended transfer to Broadway.

Nickelodeon has often underpinned its preschool television shows with curriculum-based teaching, but like a parent sneaking vegetables into the pasta, it tended to hide the educational values. Not any more. With the July 1 introduction of a line of Team Umizoomi Preschool Math Kits, produced internally and pegged to the Nick Jr. math-based show of the same name, the company said it was moving more squarely into the educational realm. ''We have never been that loud and proud about it as now,'' said Cyma Zarghami, Nickelodeon's president and chief executive.

After a disappointing start to the 2008 season, months removed from falling one game short of an American League pennant the previous October, the Cleveland Indians' front office decided to blow up the roster midway through the campaign. The rebuilding process began with trading the aceC. C. Sabathia to the Milwaukee Brewers in 2008 and continued when the then-reigning A.L. Cy Young Award winner Cliff Lee was dealt to the Philadelphia Phillies the next season. As expected, dismal results and despair followed, punctuated by Sabathia and Lee battling each other in the 2009 World Series for their respective clubs.

WASHINGTON -- A day after a spokeswoman for Representative Anthony D. Weiner said he was checking into a rehabilitation center, his aides on Sunday could not say what kind of treatment he was receiving or when he would be released. Pressed on whether Mr. Weiner, a Democrat, had plans to return to work in the House once he had completed his treatment, his spokeswoman, Risa B. Heller, declined to comment beyond a statement released on Saturday saying he needed time to determine what he would do next.

Could one reporter cover six professional New York sporting events in 24 hours and not lose his mind? The answer: sort of. MIKE TANIER, laptop in tow, and the photographer TODD HEISLER, with only an iPhone to capture the day's images, rented out the Bats blog on Saturday and documented the experience. After coveing Friday night's Red Bulls game, Tanier attended five more area events Saturday: the New York Mini 10K, the Yankees-Indians game, the Adidas Grand Prix, the Belmont Stakes and the Liberty-Fever game. He did make it to all six events. Whether or not his mind is intact is yet to be determined. 'Edgy experiment' or 'elaborate joke'?

Bespoke clothing has been a luxury for the rich. But a men's e-commerce start-up, J. Hilburn, wants to use the Internet to make custom-made suits and shirts more affordable. On Thursday, J. Two insurers, Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance, said on Sunday that they plan to combine in a $3.2 billion merger that will create a big provider of specialty insurance and reinsurance. The deal will give Transatlantic, previously a reinsurance unit of the American International Group, more exposure to international business and specialty products like product and environmental liability policies.

Cinephiles, microphobes and people for the ethical treatment of cartoon characters should cover their eyes now. The world is about to crawl with little blue people, at least if the movie marketers at Sony have their way. ''The Smurfs,'' in 3-D no less, does not arrive until July 29. But Sony, which operates one of Hollywood's most twisted marketing shops (that is, successful), has declared June 25 Global Smurfs Day. On that Saturday, Sony wants people to gather in cities around the world, including New York, dressed as Smurfs: white hat, white pants and shoes, body painted blue.

He was a past president of the national youth group NFTY and president of the Greater New York Council. JOHNSON--Eleanor Muir, 91. Died at home in Far Hills, NJ, June 9, surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by Coddy, her devoted husband of 70 years, her children, Sheila Wise, Terry Johnson and Lee Auchincloss, grandchildren, Alisa Kuhn, Eben MacNeille, Kelley Boyd, Coddy Johnson, Malcolm Auchincloss, Emily Auchincloss, and five great-grandchildren. Born in New York on February 11, 1920 to Malcolm and Lida Muir, she attended the Chapin School and Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT. On May 17, 1941 she married Coddy, the love of her life. She was an accomplished horticulturalist, serving as Director and Vice President of the Garden Club of America, President of the Garden Club of Somerset Hills, receiving numerous awards. Beginning in 1928, she spent every summer on her beloved Martha's Vineyard. She was a sailing member of the Edgartown Yacht Club, and many Island organizations. She will be remembered as a loving person of great executive ability, whose passionate devotion to her family and friends will endure always. A memorial service will be held at 11am, Friday, September 16, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Bedminster, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations for The Eleanor Johnson Horticultural Speakers Fund to The Garden Club of Somerset Hills, PO Box 82, Oldwick, N.J. 08858.

Ira, who started his career as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County, spent 17 years in the entertainment business working for NBC, CBS, and several large music companies. WASHINGTON - Tony Knowles helped make Sarah Palin a political celebrity by losing the Alaska governor's race to her five years ago. Now he is seeking another legacy. As president of the National Energy Policy Institute, Mr. Knowles aims to kick-start Washington's stalled dialogue on curbing the nation's oil habit. But because his potential solutions include higher gas taxes, his odds of success are about the same as defeating Ms. Palin in a publicity contest.

Car manufacturers reported that overall sales were down 3.7 percent in May compared with the same period a year earlier, a drop attributed in part to shortages at Toyota and Honda after the Japanese earthquake. Manufacturers were also offering fewer incentives. Some car makers did well: Kia had a 53 percent increase in sales from May 2010 to May 2011, Hyundai, 21 percent, and Volkswagen, 24 percent. At General Motors, sales of passenger cars like the Cheverolet Camaro, above, rose by 13 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Derek Jeter has paused his pursuit of history, landing on the 15-day disabled list Tuesday with a strained right calf, six hits short of 3,000 hits for his career. Jeter, who said he hurt his calf jogging off the field after the top of the fifth inning Monday, is eligible to come off the disabled list June 29, a home game against Milwaukee. After another home game with the Brewers, the Yankees play three against the Mets at Citi Field, then go to Cleveland for a three-game series. Barring a setback, then, Jeter could get his 3,000th hit at the same ballpark, Citi Field, where Mariano Rivera reached 500 saves. Or he could do it in George Steinbrenner’s hometown, Cleveland, on the Fourth of July, which would have been Steinbrenner’s 81st birthday.

Alber Elbaz opened Lanvin’s resort collection with a poster-board slide show of everything that’s been inspiring him of late — island vacations, island women, Elizabeth Taylor, the royal wedding uniforms, Madame Grès — and most important, he added, “the idea of women wearing clothes over and over again.” He said he tried to nail down a decade that would envelop this. “I thought maybe the 1920s, then the 1980s, but nothing came.” What did emerge was glammed-up versions of island life: draped Grecian dresses, ruched secretary skirts and this silk fringe dress with stacked jewels. However, when it came to unveiling Lanvin’s new children’s line — little versions of the house’s favorite looks — the present was just precious.

At his Givenchy resort presentation, the designer Riccardo Tisci was clear: “The collection is still 1950s mixed with surfing, but everything is about cropping and pieces missing.” Dangling dorm-style key chains, neon visors and rope heels (inspired by Birkenstocks) accompanied bird-of-paradise prints and a computerized update of last season’s panther print in the form of pencil skirts paired with cutout stretch-knit sweatshirts. “My obsession is daytime to evening,” Tisci says. As proof he showed a very French couture frilled bustier evening dress with a cropped sweater thrown over. “I’m obsessed with sweatshirts and T-shirts — that’s how I live my life.”

For his first resort collection, Joseph Altuzarra thought a lot about travel and staying in hotels. “Everything is a wrinkle-free fabric, very pack-and-go,” he says. The clothes look effortless and feel surprisingly feminine, including the baby blue lightweight poplin smock dresses or tunics paired over pants (which call to mind a very chic housemaid at one of the hotel’s Altuzarra is channeling). There are also updated versions of his fall 2011 parka in white organza (“I’m still on that utility kick,” he says) over crisp eyelet dresses. When you’re ready to step out of the lobby and hit the street, there are flirty ruffled dresses like this one.

The last few decades have wrought a revolution in finance. One thing, though, remains stubbornly the same. It is the control that investment banks wield over initial public offerings.

BOSTON — The Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, held biannually since 1981, takes over churches, libraries and concert halls, and turns the city into an early-music fan’s idea of paradise for a week. The performances include operas, symphonic concerts, chamber music and recitals produced by the festival. They also include a huge slate of fringe events, concerts presented by musicians and ensembles from around the country who flock to Boston in hopes of being heard by an audience of enthusiasts as well as managers and concert presenters who are in town for the festival’s starrier offerings. This year’s festival, the 16th, opened on Sunday and runs through next Sunday.

The Museum for African Art is postponing the opening of its new home on Fifth Avenue and 110th Street by a year, to late 2012, to give it more time to raise money, the museum said on Tuesday. It has so far raised $86.3 million toward its $95 million goal and is delaying the final stage of construction until it has reached $92.5 million.

A handful of the world’s small-batch roasters have outsized reputations, tiny operations that are less like coffee companies than coffee workshops. They might look and feel like neighborhood stores – places where you run into a friend while standing in line for a Saturday morning cappuccino – but because they function at such a high level of craft and quality, they lead the entire industry. A few of them have a near-mythic status that falls between Red’s Eats and Le Corbusier’s Notre Dame du Haut, a refined and aesthetic experience that’s worth the detour because what you’ll find there tastes so good.

During Monday night’s debate among declared Republican presidential candidates in Manchester, N.H., there was near-unanimous criticism of the federal government’s intervention in 2009 to buoy ailing Detroit automakers, despite marked turnarounds at General Motors and Chrysler, the biggest recipients of government funds. In January we published an article by Anand Giridharadas called “The Caste Buster,” about Ravindra Misal, an Indian striver from the town of Umred who pulled himself out of the laboring class of “daily wage earners” and opened a finishing school for others like himself. That article, which also ran in our sister publication, The International Herald Tribune (under the title “India’s Future in a Self-Made Man”), has now been honored with the award for excellence in feature writing from the Society of Publishers in Asia. Smart decision, because it’s really a remarkable, unexpected story. Wild patterned pants dominated the fall runways, and, judging by Céline’s resort collection, which included leopard, jailhouse stripes and neon pink trousers, they’re not going anywhere. Julie Taymor is planning to attend Tuesday’s opening night of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” her spokeswoman said, returning to the Foxwoods Theater three months after the producers ousted her as director as part of their remake of the $70 million show into a more family-friendly entertainment. I just learned (first from a friend, then from the many comments people posted on my previous post) that what I’ve been looking for from Gmail (reposting of received messages at a future date) actually exists in the form of Boomerang—a free Gmail plug-in that does exactly what I described. Montauk, N.Y., may be the last hold out against the looming tide of Hamptonization, but its stuck-in-time fisherman’s-village feeling is fading fast. Which might explain the appeal of a new collection of T-shirts by Local Knit, featuring the logos from Montauk institutions like Duryea’s Lobster Deck, the Montauket and Paulie’s Tackle. Montaukers are snapping them up, as are weekenders. The speculation has been incessant, but on Tuesday morning the Royal Ballet in London put an end to the chatter about who will take over once its current artistic director, Monica Mason, steps down in July next year. It will be Kevin O’Hare, a former principal dancer with the Birmingham Royal Ballet who has been steadily making his way up the Royal Ballet’s hierarchy since his retirement from the stage in 2000. He joined as company manager in 2004 and became administrative director in 2009.

In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks at a slice of surreal life in Luis Buñuel and Salvador Dalí’s 1928 short film “Un Chien Andalou.” The film, which catalogs a variety of random, sometimes shocking scenes, was part of the Surrealism art movement, one that rebelled against order and coherence. Mr. Scott says that even now, 80 years later, the movie “still seethes with creative, revolting imagery.” Mr. Scott praises Mr. Buñuel’s filmmaking, saying that he was “among the first to discover that the language of cinema could proceed beyond the boundaries of sense and produce powerful and strange effects and emotions.” Have you seen “Un Chien Andalou?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

A man attending the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., over the weekend died on Sunday, officials told The Associated Press. Stephen M. Graves, the sheriff of Coffee County, said that Christopher William Yoder, 24, of Raleigh, N.C., had died of hyperthermia after he was airlifted from the festival to a hospital in Chattanooga. The sheriff told The A.P. that he was awaiting the results of toxicology tests. The organizers of the festival said in a statement, “The safety of our patrons is our No. 1 concern, and we are deeply saddened by this.”

Just take this nautical mink coat and sheath dress (and supercute sailor striped socks). The collection is inspired by the gilded age in Europe. Embroidered floral tops and dresses, crisp checked Prince of Wales separates and jewels designed with Ileana Makri are reminiscent of the Belle Epoque. And in case you had a shred of doubt about how luxe they want to go, consider their handbags: classic totes, satchels and bags glow in rich tones of bright purple and neon green. ZANDMAN--Felix. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Dr. Felix Zandman, a dear friend, Holocaust survivor and an esteemed member of our Board of Governors. A generous benefactor of Yad Vashem, Jerusalem where he with his wife Ruta endowed the Family Plaza and sculpture by the renowned artist Menashe Kadishman. Dr. Zandman will be sorely missed. Our thoughts are with his wife Ruta, his son Mark, his daughters Dr. Gisele Zandman Goddard, Mrs. Ariele Klausner and their families. Eli Zborowski, Chairman

REDLICH--Norman. We mourn the passing of one of the giants in the history of the American Jewish Congress. Beginning with a law review note in 1948, Norman was a true leader of our organization and at the heart of its work for over 55 years. Fierce defender of the Constitution and advocate for the less fortunate, he combined a passion for justice and command of the law with unassuming modesty and wisdom. The personification of class and conscience, Norman exemplified the words of the rabbis: "He who runs from honor, will be pursued by it." Richard S. Gordon, President

The advertising column on Wednesday, about hotel companies forming partnerships to enhance their luxury brands, misstated the name of the Hilton hotel chain. It is Hilton Worldwide, not Hilton International, which was its name when the company was public. Because of an editing error, the column also misstated the location and timing of art auctions that are one element of a partnership between the auction house Christie's and JW Marriott hotels. Works of art that Christie's is displaying at the hotels, including the JW Marriott Marquis Miami, will be auctioned elsewhere later; they were not auctioned at the Miami hotel last December.

STARFIELD--Dr. Barbara, Distinguished University Professor at The Johns Hopkins University, died suddenly and unexpectedly while swimming on Friday, June 10, 2011. She is survived by her husband, Neil A. Holtzman, their children, Robert (Orlando, FL), Jon (Las Cruces, NM), Steven (Berkeley, CA), and Deborah (Menlo Park, CA), and eight grandchildren, all of whom adored her. Donations in her honor should be made to the Health Research Group, 1600 20th Street, NW, Washington DC 20009.

HONEYWELL ACQUISITION Honeywell International has agreed to acquire EMS Technologies, a maker of systems for mobile networks and satellites, for $506 million in cash. Honeywell is paying $33 a share, a premium of 33 percent above EMS's closing stock price on Friday and 59 percent above the price on April 18, the day before EMS said it would explore a potential sale. ''EMS is a terrific addition to Honeywell, adding leading positions in attractive markets that are closely aligned with favorable trends in the growing command, control, communications, computers, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance space and commercial aerospace,'' said Dave Cote, above, Honeywell's chief executive. NEW BID Graham Packaging Company, which is 61 percent owned by the Blackstone Group, said on Monday that it had received a rival, unsolicited takeover offer. The company had agreed in April to sell itself to Silgan Holdings for cash and stock worth roughly $21. 20 a share. The rival offer is $25 a share in cash. Graham did not it identify its suitor, but Reuters reported that it was the Rank Group of New Zealand. Rank acquired Pactiv, the maker of the Hefty bag, for $6 billion last year.

Beloved husband of Barbara Britton. Devoted father of Susan, Linda and James J. Rahal III. Dear brother of Joseph J. Rahal. Loving grandfather of Karyn, Carly and Christine Rahal. Memorial visiting hours at the Barrett Funeral Home, 424 W. 51st St., NYC, Thursday, June 16, 7-9pm, and at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, Friday, June 17, 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Laboratory for Infectious Diseases Research, c/o BMA Foundation, New York Hospital Queens, 56-45 Main St., Flushing, NY 11355, or to Histiocytosis Foundation of America, 800-548-2758 or www.histio.org.

9 P.M. (TNT) MEMPHIS BEAT Jason Lee returns as Dwight Hendricks, a Memphis police detective with a passion for his hometown and its music. Alfre Woodard, above with Mr. Lee, is Lt. Tanya Rice, Dwight's very demanding boss. In this Season 2 opener the squad investigates the death of an admired police officer who may have been involved with white supremacists. The case sets the stage for Dwight's introduction to Claire Ryan (Beau Garrett), a tough investigator from Internal Affairs. In the second-season premiere of ''Hawthorne,'' at 10, Christina Hawthorne, the chief nursing officer at James River Hospital, played by Jada Pinkett Smith, prepares to marry Dr. Tom Wakefield (Michael Vartan). Meanwhile, Det. Nick Renata (the new cast member Marc Anthony) returns to look into an attack at the hospital -- and perhaps to throw a wrench into Christina and Tom's wedding day. 6 P.M. (National Geographic) GEO BEE 2011 Young geography whizzes test their knowledge in this competition broadcast from the National Geographic Society headquarters in Washington and hosted by Alex Trebek. A repeat of Monday's round is followed at 6:30 by a look at how the 10 finalists came to beat nearly 5 million students to make their way to the competition, in which winners receive scholarships of up to $25,000.

Zvi Goffer, a trader nicknamed Octopussy because his arms reached into so many sources of information, was found guilty of insider trading Monday, the latest victory for the government in a sweeping crackdown on insider trading at hedge funds. A 12-person jury convicted Mr. Goffer and two accused co-conspirators, Emanuel Goffer and Michael A. Kimelman, on its fifth day of deliberations in Federal District Court in Manhattan. They each face up to 25 years in prison and are free on bail until their sentencing later this year.

CARABUENA--Cesar B.,M.D. of Mt. Vernon passed away on June 13, 2011. He was born in Bantayan Cebu, Philippines on November 2, 1929 to Tomas and Rizalina Carabuena. Predeceased by his daughter Joy Carabuena in 2000. Beloved husband of Leticia Carabuena; loving father of John and his wife Blanche Carabuena, Glenn Carabuena and Jean Marie Carabuena and her husband Luigino Nascimben and daughter in law Maria Teresita Carabuena; cherished grandfather of Thomas, Michele, Lee, Melanie, Steven, Julia, Diana, John, Charles and James. He is a retired physician who was known for his selfless nature and his compassion for others. Cesar will be remembered as a fun loving, very generous, kind person who especially cherished his grandchildren. Family will receive friends from 6-9 pm Thursday at Yannantuono Burr Davis Sharpe Funeral Home 584 Gramatan Ave., Mt. Vernon, NY (914)699-4010. Funeral Mass 1:00pm Friday at Sts. Peter & Paul Church, Mt. Vernon. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 in Memory of Dr. Cesar B. Carabuena.

SPRING--Leonard. Sisterhood of East End Temple deeply mourns the death of a major supporter, husband of Helene, past president and Board member. We extend sincere condolences to his wife and extended family. Judith Lorber, Sisterhood President

AMSTER--Daniel, aged 85, passed away from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved husband of 56 years of Lucille (Jacobs) Amster, dearest brother of Ethel Levine (Harris) and Ruth Amster, devoted uncle of Jack and Norman Levine. Veteran of World War II in the Pacific Theater. Graduate of John Marshall College and Rutgers University Law School. Member of the New Jersey Bar for sixty years. Resident of many years of HoHoKus, New Jersey and Palm Beach, Florida. Former Democratic County Chairman in Bergen County for over six years during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. Beloved by all who knew him including friends and relatives, as well as the aides, nurses and doctors who cared for him at the Jewish Home at Rockleigh. Donations may be sent to Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, New Jersey. Funeral Services at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel on Route 4 in Paramus, New Jersey on Tuesday, June 14, 2011 at 11:00am.

Fighting for the rights of British filmgoers to see horror movies about hostages stitched together in deeply uncomfortable ways, the distributors of the ''Human Centipede'' sequel have protested a recent decision by Britain's film board that will prevent the movie from being shown there and criticized the board for giving away some crucial plot details. Last week the British Board of Film Classification said it would not give any rating at all to ''The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence),'' a follow up to Tom Six's ''Human Centipede (First Sequence),'' saying the movie posed a ''real risk'' to audiences and made no attempt to depict the ''victims in the film as anything other than objects to be brutalized, degraded and mutilated for the amusement and arousal of the central character, as well as for the pleasure of the audience.''

Public and private donors have pledged $4.3 billion toward vaccinating children against a variety of diseases, according to the GAVI Alliance, which held its first fund-raising conference for vaccines in London on Monday. That exceeds the $3.7 billion that the alliance -- created 11 years ago as the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization to help poor countries pay for vaccines -- had hoped to raise. Some is matching money contingent on other pledges.

BAGLEY--Edythe Scott. Antioch College mourns the loss of Edythe Scott Bagley '47, board member of the King Center in Atlanta, who preceded her sister, Coretta Scott King 51, in attending Antioch College. We extend our sincere sympathy to her family.

The Environmental Protection Agency, facing intense opposition from Congressional Republicans and industry over a broad range of new air quality regulations, said Monday that it was delaying by two months the release of a proposed rule on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants and other major pollution sources. The delay of the rule, which will have a major impact on the nation's efforts to reduce emissions of gases blamed for the warming of the planet, is the latest step by the E.P.A. to slow the issuing of regulations that its critics claim will hurt economic growth, drive up energy costs and cut employment. The delay is a tacit admission that the regulations pose difficult political, economic and technical challenges that cannot be addressed on the aggressive timetable the agency set for itself early in the Obama administration.

BEAL--Hon. Ira F.,age 79, beloved brother of Marjorie and fond brother-in-law of Enoch Silverstein, passed away on June 12, 2011. Ira was the adored uncle of Thomas (Leslie), Bill (Karyn) and Ted Silverstein and grand uncle of Ariel, Beth, Carly, Josh, Joey and Brian Silverstein. Ira, who started his career as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County, spent 17 years in the entertainment business working for NBC, CBS, and several large music companies. In the late 1970's he was named Executive Vice-President of M.P.L. Communications, Inc., Paul McCartney's company and then became President of the Music Publishing Division of the New York Times. In 1982 he was appointed to the Bench of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. Three years later he was promoted to the New York State Supreme Court, where he served until his retirement in 2002. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 14 at 10:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at E 81st St).

Representative Anthony Weiner may have taken it to an extreme. But the online flirtations and provocative photos that got him into so much trouble are far from unusual among adults these days, experts say. What with Facebook friends, Twitter followers and Skype video chats, it is now all too easy to flirt with strangers and engage in sexual fantasy without (technically) breaking a marriage vow. Digital dalliance has entered the mainstream.

FLAUM--Mitchel, 92, died at home June 10th. Beloved husband to Constance Stern Flaum, devoted father of Stephen and Gary, and loving grandfather of Rivka, Russell, Leah, and Isaac. He graduated Lafayette College in 1941, returning often as a Trustee, benefactor, and football fan. He joined S&S Corrugated Paper Mach. Co., became President and guided its growth to seven locations on four continents. In 1942 he married Connie, the love of his life. Mitch treated everyone with kindness, dignity, and respect. He was a Trustee at Beth Israel Medical Center and Schnurmacher Nursing Home. Donations may be made to: The Flaum Scholarship Fund at Lafayette College.

BEATON--Bettye Epstein, 64, died peacefully at her home on June 13, 2011 due to complications related to the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. Born January 2, 1947 in Woodmere, NY. Survived by Howard Beaton, MD, her loving husband of 29 years, dear sisters Nancy Kemper and Judy Villers, and her beloved children, son Joshua Beaton (Beth), daughters Audrey Margarite (Mike) and Jessica Beaton and grandchildren Jacob and Olivia. Bettye worked as a surgical physician assistant and for 10 years was the clinical director of the surgical PA program at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. She made countless friends throughout her life and held them all as close as family. Her special memory will live on forever in the hearts of those that she touched. Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, June 15 at 11am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St. in Manhattan. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma and Leukemia Society.

Not long ago, I came into possession of the names of the investors in the now-defunct Galleon Group, the hedge fund firm that was run by Raj Rajaratnam, who last month was convicted of insider trading. It's a long and impressive list. Cornell, Colgate and Texas A&M each entrusted part of their endowments to Galleon. State pension funds in New Hampshire and Virginia invested with Rajaratnam. There were a handful of foundations, like the Michael and Susan Dell Foundation, and lots of family trusts. Private wealth managers, like Banque Privée Edmond de Rothschild, steered clients to Galleon. A.I.G., the insurance giant, and Yuengling, the beer company, were investors.

JOHNSON--Eleanor Muir, 91. Died at home in Far Hills, NJ, June 9, surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by Coddy, her devoted husband of 70 years, her children, Sheila Wise, Terry Johnson and Lee Auchincloss, grandchildren, Alisa Kuhn, Eben MacNeille, Kelley Boyd, Coddy Johnson, Malcolm Auchincloss, Emily Auchincloss, and five great-grandchildren. Born in New York on February 11, 1920 to Malcolm and Lida Muir, she attended the Chapin School and Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT. On May 17, 1941 she married Coddy, the love of her life. She was an accomplished horticulturalist, serving as Director and Vice President of the Garden Club of America, President of the Garden Club of Somerset Hills, receiving numerous awards. Beginning in 1928, she spent every summer on her beloved Martha's Vineyard. She was a sailing member of the Edgartown Yacht Club, and many Island organizations. She will be remembered as a loving person of great executive ability, whose passionate devotion to her family and friends will endure always. A memorial service will be held at 11am, Friday, September 16, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Bedminster, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations for The Eleanor Johnson Horticultural Speakers Fund to The Garden Club of Somerset Hills, PO Box 82, Oldwick, N.J. 08858.

The VF Corporation agreed on Monday to buy the Timberland Company, the boot maker, for about $2 billion in cash, paying a big premium in an effort to bolster its outdoor clothing offerings. VF, which already owns lines like Wrangler and 7 for All Mankind, will add Timberland to a stable of outdoor brands like the North Face and Eastpak.

HALE--Marjorie Coldwell, 84, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, beloved wife of L. Gordon Hale, died Tuesday, June 7, 2011 at the Kaplan Family Hospice House in Danvers, MA surrounded by her family. Born and raised in Fall River, MA, she was the daughter of the late John S. and Maybelle M. (Johnson) Coldwell. She attended Durfee High School in Fall River and graduated from Northfield-Mount Hermon Academy in Mount Hermon, MA. Mrs. Hale continued her education earning her Bachelor's Degree from Duke University, class of 1948 where her husband was also a graduate (class of 1946 and fraternity, Phi Delta Theta), and a Master's Degree in psychology and childhood education from Manhattanville College. She was a fraternal member of both Kappa Alpha Theta and Phi Beta Kappa. Mrs. Hale had spent many years tutoring challenged children in the Chappaqua, New York area and gained much joy in helping her students achieve their goals. A resident of Chappaqua, NY since 1952 prior to moving to Wenham in 2010, she was an active member of the First Congregational Church in Chappaqua, NY and an alumni member of their Bell Choir. She was an avid gardener and an accomplished cook, knitter and seamstress. Marjorie was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister-in-law and friend who will be missed by all who knew her. In addition to her husband, with whom she shared sixty-two years of marriage, she is survived by three daughters, Christin Hale of VT, Jody Hale Norton of Beverly, MA, Libby Hale Reid of Maryland and one son, Greg Hale of New York City, NY; seven grandchildren, Evan, Emily, Joanne, Jeffrey, Tyler, Alexandra and Jack; and a sister-in-law, Maria Coldwell of Brookline, MA. She was also the sister of the late Jack Coldwell. Her funeral service will be private. Assisting the family with the services is the Campbell Lee, Moody, Russell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly. Information and condolences at: www.campbellfuneral.com.

LONDON -- Standard & Poor's, the credit ratings agency, lowered its grade on Greek debt to CCC on Monday in the latest sign that the market believes that Greece will be forced to default on its debt. The three-notch downgrade makes Greece's debt the lowest-rated in the world by S.& P., a spokesman for the agency said. The downgrade comes at a particularly awkward time for Greece. The government is trying to persuade legislators to accept a fresh set of austerity measures. At the same time, Germany, the dominant economy in the 17-member euro zone, is proposing that private sector bondholders accept some form of a loss on their Greek bonds as a condition for a broader rescue package for Greece that could approach 100 billion euros ($143 billion).

BURNS--Daniel Blake. September 16, 1932 June 10th, 2011. Daniel Blake Burns of Osterville, Massachusetts, passed away on June 10th, 2011. Mr. Burns, a prominent New York attorney and the former President of United States Bank Note Corporation in New York City, had retired from formal business some years ago. The second of seven children of the late Judge John J. Burns and Alice Blake Burns of Belmont Hill and Falmouth, Massachusetts, Mr. Burns attended the Fessenden School and thereafter, the Cranwell Prepatory School in Lenox, Massachusetts, prior to graduating in 1949 from St. Sebastian's Country Day School, now located in Needham, Massachusetts. Dan graduated from Boston College with a Bachelor of Science in 1954, where he also started on the Varsity basketball team. After graduation, Dan attended Virginia Law School in Charlottesville, Virginia, where he was a roommate and fellow law graduate of former Senator Edward Moore Kennedy his lifelong friend. Mr. Burns received his LLB from Virginia Law in 1957. Mr. Burns was a member of the New York Bar Association and worked on Wall Street with the prominent corporate law firm of Cahill Gordon, participating in the many of their major business transactions. Dan was a devoted alumnus of St. Sebastian's and was a major participant in the establishment of the Judge John J. Burns Library of Rare Books and Special Collections at Boston College. Mr. Burns leaves a family of two daughters, Mrs. Elizabeth Kirby and Mrs. Mary Alice Colich, and his son, Daniel Cabot Burns, along with fifteen grandchildren. Mr. Burns also leaves a sister, Mrs. Alice Therese Scanlan of Winchester, Massachusetts, his elder brother, John J. Burns, Jr. of New Canaan, Connecticut, and his younger brothers, Brian P. Burns of Palm Beach, Florida and Michael E. Burns of New York City, along with numerous devoted nephews and nieces. A wake will be held at the Lane Funeral Home at 760 Main Street in Winchester, Massachusetts on Tuesday June 14th, from 3-7pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Wednesday, June 15th at 10:30am at St. Eulalia Church at 50 Ridge Street in Winchester, Massachusetts. Internment at Mt. Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge, Massachusetts will immediately follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to the Judge John J. Burns Library of Rare Books and Special Collections at Boston College or, to the St. Sebastian's School in Needham, Massachusetts.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Brian Lenihan, the former finance minister of Ireland, erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Lenihan in parliamentary elections there this year. He was the only member of the Fianna Fail party's 47-member Dublin delegation to retain his seat, not the party's only member to do so.

BROCKMAN--Robert, an architect, died on June 12, 2011 at his home in Haverford, PA. He was 75. Bob grew up in New York City and graduated from Columbia University in 1957, where he rowed crew and was a member of the Alpha Delta Phi Literary Fraternity. After college, he practiced field archaeology in New Mexico and South Dakota. He went on to study architecture at the University of Pennsylvania. He completed commercial and residential projects in the Philadelphia region, Atlantic City, NJ, as well as in Africa, Canada and Europe. He enjoyed the outdoors and spent vacations camping and hiking in the national parks with his family. After being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, he studied Tai Chi and then Nia (Non-Impact Aerobics). He enjoyed the vitality of its movements and the music that accompanied Nia classes. He practiced Nia in New Mexico and became an advocate for it in the Philadelphia area. He is survived by his wife, Jeannette Flamm Brockman, and their two sons, Joshua, and George and daughter-in-law Amy. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Felix and Celia, and his brother Alan. The funeral service will be held Tuesday, June 14, at 11am at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood, PA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Cancer Support Community of Philadelphia, (215) 879-7733.

(The president of the center, which is based in St. Petersburg, is Michael V. Khitrov.)

TRIPOLI, Libya - If not exactly a chess match for the ages, it was at least a deliciously emblematic contest that caught something of the curious, and often deeply eccentric, world of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a man who has been known to want to pitch a tent for his comfort in Manhattan's Central Park, along with a host of other behaviors unusual in a national leader. Captured on Libyan state television, the match was played on Sunday in Tripoli between Colonel Qaddafi and the president of the World Chess Federation, a Russian politician and one-time goat-and-sheep-herder by the name of Kirsan Ilyumzhinov.

A manufacturer of decorative firepots and pourable fuel gel that were involved in two horrific accidents in New York asked retailers on Monday to stop selling its products nationwide. The move came two days after The New York Times reported on the two blazes, six days apart, caused by products made by Napa Home & Garden Inc. and sold at Bed Bath & Beyond. Three New Yorkers suffered severe burns in the accidents and remain hospitalized.

Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist who has played for nearly 40 years with Bruce Springsteen and the E-Street Band, has had a serious stroke, according to a Springsteen fan Web site with close connections to the band and tweets by associates of Mr. Clemons. The site, Backstreets.com, said that Mr. Clemons, 69, had undergone two brain surgeries at a hospital near his home in Florida after the stroke, which was described as ''massive,'' but is ''responsive and in stable condition.'' Quoting an unnamed friend of Mr. Clemons, the site said that the saxophonist's situation ''did not look good at all'' on Sunday, but that Mr. Clemons, known as ''the Big Man,'' had rallied and his vital signs were improving. ''He was paralyzed on his left side, but now he's squeezing with his left hand,'' the account said. ''The next five days will still be critical. But he's a fighter.''

Scientists have often been accused of letting their ideology influence their results, and one of the most famous cases is that of Morton's skulls -- the global collection amassed by the 19th-century physical anthropologist Samuel George Morton. In a 1981 book, ''The Mismeasure of Man,'' the paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould asserted that Morton, believing that brain size was a measure of intelligence, had subconsciously manipulated the brain volumes of European, Asian and African skulls to favor his bias that Europeans had larger brains and Africans smaller ones.

The Maple Group on Monday moved forward in its hostile play for TMX Group with a $3.8 billion bid, besting a $3.6 billion offer by the London Stock Exchange. Maple, a consortium of financial firms, is trying to challenge a deal with the London exchange that has already been approved by TMX. The group, which includes big Canadian banks and pension funds, is mobilizing to keep the Toronto exchange in national hands.

RAHAL--James J. Rahal M.D. James J. Rahal, M.D. The world of medicine, and the world, lost a giant this weekend as Dr. James Rahal passed away. His many colleagues at New York Hospital Queens join, in deep sadness, his beloved family his wife Barbara Britton, his children James, Susan and Linda as well as his grandchildren Karyn, Carly and Christine, to mourn his death. We also celebrate his successes on the frontlines of the battle against some of the most challenging diseases of our time. Jim, as we all knew him, had a distinguished and productive career that spanned more than four decades. He dedicated his professional life to being a physician, scientist and professor in infectious disease and infection control. He achieved his undergraduate degree from Harvard-cum laude; and earned his medical degree from Tufts University-cum laude in 1959. He came to New York Hospital Queens as Director of Infectious Disease in 1988, and beyond the enormous contributions he made to the medical center's patients and his colleagues, he shaped the Infectious Disease specialists of the future as a clinical professor of medicine for Weill Medical College of Cornell University. In the 1980s and 1990s, he was recognized internationally as the scientific leader who discovered, and then published, his findings on the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics. He was among the first to participate in trials with the then new cephalosporins. His work on multi-drug resistant gram negative bacilli has led the field and is often quoted. When HIV/AIDS emerged as a growing public health issue, he became actively involved in addressing innovative drug therapies, patient access to treatment and public policy decisions. Most significantly, he served as a member of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Data Safety Monitoring Board - a small group of multidisciplinary specialists, who determined the safety of national studies for HIV/AIDS. In 1999, he was one of the first physicians in the U.S. to recognize the outbreak pattern of the West Nile virus when it began infecting patients in Queens. He became one of the nation's foremost experts on the West Nile virus. He developed the first FDA-approved treatment for the West Nile virus in 2002, and he created a national, multi-site research protocol to determine the results of the Interferon alpha-2b for treatment of the virus. This unique protocol was patented in 2005. On a personal level, Dr. Rahal was recognized for his self-effacing and gracious manner. He was a consummate teacher and as a result, he received countless awards for teaching and research--including the Albion Bernstein MD Award in 2004 by the Medical Society of the State of New York. His work has been published in numerous prestigious journals, such as the New England Journal of Medicine, JAMA and Science magazine. The news media often sought his expertise on antibiotic resistance, the West Nile virus and infectious diseases. His studies, including those developed for the NIH, have affected many lives and have served to raise the bar of excellence in medicine and science for future generations. President Obama said on Monday that if he were in Representative Anthony D. Weiner's position, ''I would resign,'' according to NBC, which conducted an extensive interview with him. Mr. Obama called Mr. Weiner's conduct ''highly inappropriate'' and said the New York Democrat had ''embarrassed himself'' and his family.

SEATTLE - Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington, a two-term Democrat who has steered the state through a period of painful budget cuts, said Monday that she would not seek a third term. Her decision was not unexpected, and it clears the way for what some political observers believe will be one of the closest gubernatorial races in the country in 2012. Rob McKenna, the state's respected Republican attorney general, announced his long-anticipated candidacy last week. Representative Jay Inslee, a popular Democrat whose district includes parts of the politically crucial Seattle region, has signaled for months that he would run if Ms. Gregoire chose not to.

For Kristin Jones, rock bottom arrived with a pile of noisemakers, a side of champagne, and the specter of tipsy lovers embracing with glee at a time of no particular significance. ''They were completely oblivious it was 40 minutes off.''

Carole King, the longtime singer-songwriter, has written her first memoir, her publisher, Grand Central Publishing, said on Monday. The memoir, ''A Natural Woman,'' is scheduled for release in April 2012. Deb Futter, the editor in chief of the hardcover division for Grand Central Publishing, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, said in a statement, ''It will be a thrill to bring her life's journey to her devoted following who have waited so long to read her story in prose.'' The book will chart Ms. King's upbringing in Brooklyn and her career as a songwriter and musician.

This week the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations threw its weight behind a new push for sustainable agriculture in developing countries. While declaring that “we have no option but to further intensify crop production” to feed a growing and increasingly affluent world population, the F.A.O. nonetheless urged a broader application of techniques that, while raising yields, have also been shown to reduce inputs of water, energy and fertilizer, compared to more conventional farming approaches.

Weird Al Yankovic continues to find his way into the hearts and minds of America’s youth, and this time there’s nothing that Lady Gaga can do to stand in his way. On Wednesday, HarperCollins Children’s Books said an application would be released for Apple iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch devices based on Mr. Yankovic’s best-selling children’s book, “When I Grow Up.” The original book, written by Mr. Yankovic (who, in a rare career move, did not declare himself to be “Weird” on its cover) and illustrated by Wes Hargis, follows an 8-year-old boy named Billy as he considers grown-up career options, such as becoming a doctor, firefighter, giraffe milker or snail trainer. The “When I Grow Up” app, which is developed by the Web design company Bean Creative, offers interactive games and features based on the book, including the option to have Mr. Yankovic read it to you, and opportunities to practice some of Billy’s more fanciful future occupations, such as shaving a tarantula or massaging a gorilla. Mr. Yankovic said in a statement that when he was a child, “I dreamed of one day helping to produce a cross-platform app that would be sold in the iTunes Store.” He added: “I was a very prescient kid.”

As the last hot weeks of the summer of 1933 settled over the working-class edges of Paris, a tall 18-year-old murderess, robed in a dark dress purchased hours before at an opulent department store, surveyed her family’s two-room apartment in the crowded Rue de Madagascar. The poison that she had fed her parents had by that time left her father dead and her mother unconscious. The girl stepped around their bodies as she searched the apartment for money, then opened the gas valve in the kitchen. After waiting for the gas to fill the air, she walked quietly out of the apartment to her neighbor’s door. “Help!” she called. “I think my parents have committed suicide!”

FLAUM--Mitchel. The entire Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Mitchel Flaum, a longtime member of our Board of Trustees. Mitchel joined the Board of Beth Israel Medical Center in 1969, including tenure as Vice Chairman. He served with distinction during a period of extraordinary growth and expansion for the hospital. He subsequently served on the Board of Continuum Health Partners, the parent company for the partnership between Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Mitch will forever be remembered for his steadfast support of the mission of these organizations and his commitment to the highest quality, most compassionate care. To his beloved wife, Connie, his sons, Stephen and Gary, the entire Flaum family, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Steve Hochberg Chairman, Board of Trustees Morton P. Hyman Lawrence S. Huntington Chairmen Emeriti Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO

JOHANNESBURG -- Edgar Z. Tekere, who was imprisoned for a decade with Robert Mugabe during the struggle to end white minority rule in Rhodesia, and later unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Mugabe's political domination of what had become an independent Zimbabwe, died on June 7 in the eastern city of Mutare, Zimbabwe. He was 74. The cause was prostate cancer, a family friend, Ibbo Mandaza, said.

An obituary on Saturday about the travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor referred incorrectly to the backpack he took with him when he set out to walk across Europe in 1933. It did not contain an automatic pistol. (The error also appeared in a review of Mr. Leigh Fermor's books ''A Time of Gifts'' and ''Between the Woods and the Water'' in the Travel section on Nov. 6, 2005.) The obituary also misidentified the official at King's School, Canterbury, who referred to Mr. Leigh Fermor as ''a dangerous mix of sophistication and recklessness.'' It was his housemaster, not his headmaster. (A housemaster is in charge of a residence at a school, the headmaster is responsible for the entire school.)

The last few decades have wrought a revolution in finance. One thing, though, remains stubbornly the same. It is the control that investment banks wield over initial public offerings. The way companies go public looks almost identical to the Ford Motor Company's I.P.O. more than 55 years ago. A company hires lead underwriters, which serve as the company's spiritual and logistical advisers, helping the company prepare the necessary regulatory documents and marketing the offering to potential investors. The lead underwriters, and sub-underwriters hired by them, then build a book of investors who buy the shares. Through this process, an I.P.O. price is set and the company's shares are sold into the public market.

LINDAHL--Evelyn Marie, died June 10, 2011 in Plainsboro, NJ. Late of Monroe Township, NJ and Sotogrande, Spain, she was the widow of Gunnar Lindahl and born August 14, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of Frank and Lillian McCausland, sister to Donald and long-time New York Times employees, Kenneth and Frank. Graduate of Saint Joseph's College, Brooklyn. She is survived by eight nieces and nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, June 18, 2011 at 11am at Nativity of Our Lord RC Church, 185 Applegarth Road, Monroe Twp., NJ 08831. Services made by Lester Memorial Home, Jamesburg, NJ.

TOOHY--Reverend Monsignor William J. May choirs of Angels lead you into Paradise, and the Martyrs come to welcome you to bring you home to the Holy City, so you may dwell in New Jerusalem. May Holy Angels be there at your welcoming, with all the Saints who go before you, that you may know the Peace and Joy of Paradise; that you may enter into everlasting rest. With Respect, Love and Prayers The Ladies of Charity Archdiocese of New York Dorothea A. McElduff, President

After numerous failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation's main union for retail workers has decided to try a different approach: it has helped create a new, nonunion group of Wal-Mart employees that intends to press for better pay, benefits and most of all, more respect at work. The group, Organization United for Respect at Walmart, or OUR Walmart for short, says it has quietly signed up thousands of members in recent months, and it is going public this week with a Web site, ourwalmart.org, and a Facebook page. Organizers say they have more than 50 members at some stores, and they hope to soon have tens of thousands of members. Wal-Mart has nearly 1.4 million workers nationwide.

DUPRE--Tristan G.,97, died peacefully on June 11. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Clare (nee Berecz), his daughters Andrea and her children, Adrianna Mason and Michael Riolo, Jr., and Madelyn and her son, Harris. Also by his sons Richard and his daughter, Christina, and Alan, his wife Ann, and their children Max, Suzanne, and Elizabeth. Born in NYC on May 27, 1914, Tris graduated from Blair Academy in New Jersey and attended NYU as a business major. He served with honor in Europe in WWII. Upon return to New York, he entered the financial services, a stockbroker until his retirement in 1975. He was an active member in St. Kevin's parish in Queens, serving as lector, a member of the Holy Name Society, and a rifle and boating instructor for the St. Kevin Sea Cadets and Wavettes. Tris was a carpentry craftsman creating over the years furniture his children and grandchildren still cherish. He played the trombone and the piano, loved opera, photography, cooking, and gardening. He managed the family business, Triclare Realty, and attended his gym regularly until age 94. He was a man who embraced the dramatic changes of a life spanning almost 100 years with wonder and enthusiasm. He was a loving and devoted husband and father. We are enriched having had him in our lives. He will live forever in our hearts. Memorial service on Friday, June 17, 4pm-7pm, at Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY.

BROWN--Annette (nee Applebaum) of St. Andrews Country Club, Boca Raton, FL, died at 89 years of age on June 13, 2011 following complications from a stroke. She leaves her adoring and devoted husband, Leo Brown, of 67 years, her daughters Ellen Stein (Seth), Cindy Brown, son Morrie Brown (Marianne), granddaughters Rachel Fernbach (Jason), Emily Stein, grandson Benjamin Brown and great-grandchildren Ethan and Sarah Fernbach. She will be dearly missed by her beloved husband and family.

Stockbridge, Mass. PATRICK LEIGH FERMOR, who died last week at age 96 at his home in England, was one of the great minor men of the 20th century. A hero for helping undermine the German occupation of Crete during World War II, he went on to become one of the greatest travel writers of his era.

An article on Friday about the death of Leona Helmsley's dog, Trouble, misstated the reason that Trouble's inheritance from Ms. Helmsley's estate was reduced to $2 million from $12 million, the amount specified in the will. A judge determined that the greater amount exceeded that necessary to care for the dog, not that Ms. Helmsley was of unsound mind when she made the will.

STARFIELD--Dr. Barbara, Distinguished University Professor at The Johns Hopkins University, died suddenly and unexpectedly while swimming on Friday, June 10, 2011. She is survived by her husband, Neil A. Holtzman, their children, Robert (Orlando, FL), Jon (Las Cruces, NM), Steven (Berkeley, CA), and Deborah (Menlo Park, CA), and eight grandchildren, all of whom adored her. Donations in her honor should be made to the Health Research Group, 1600 20th Street, NW, Washington DC 20009.

IS it worth it? This is the question that has attended Masa, the stupendously expensive sushi emporium in the Time Warner Center, ever since it opened in 2004. The food at the restaurant is exceptional, offering tastes and preparations that can be unforgettable.

ADRIAN--Richard A.,on June 12th. Former member of the NY Stock exchange. Survived by Irene Adrian. Beloved father of Richard Adrian, Carol Price and Robert Adrian. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Elizabeth, Conor, Morgan, Sam, Alexandra and Matthew. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4pm and 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st. Mass of Christian burial, Friday, 9:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84 St. and Park Ave. Interment private.

Following the widespread uproar over a recent standup routine that was condemned for several anti-gay remarks, Tracy Morgan said he will meet with gay youths in New York and return to Tennessee, where he performed the show, to apologize to people who were offended by his act. Mr. Morgan, a star of the NBC comedy ''30 Rock,'' sparked an online outcry with a show he performed at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville on June 3. After that concert, an audience member named Kevin Rogers wrote in a widely circulated Facebook post that Mr. Morgan said ''gay was something kids learn from the media and programming'' and if his son were gay and talked in a high-pitched voice, ''he would pull out a knife and stab'' him to death.

We wanted this child to have everything. That's why we worked this hard. That's why we poisoned ourselves at this factory. Now it turns out the child is poisoned too. I have no words to describe how I feel. HAN ZONGYUAN, on learning that his 3-year-old daughter had suffered brain damage because of lead pollution from a factory in his village in China. [A1]

TOOHY--William J. Rev. Monsignor William J. Toohy, of Blessed Sacrament Parish in Manhattan died June 12, 2011 at age 80. He served the parish as parochial vicar 1961-1969 and 2002-2005. He also served for 32 years at Archdiocese Catholic Charities as Director of Social Research. From 1981 to 2001 he was the Archdiocese Director of Legal Affairs. In 1990 he served for six months as Acting President and Chief Executive Officer of Covenant House. Rev. Monsignor Toohy was born in Newton, MA, son of the late Loretta Hughes Toohy and John J. Toohy. The family moved to Rye, NY in 1934. He graduated from Resurrection School and Rye High School. In 1951, he graduated cum laude from Harvard College and from Harvard Law School in 1954. After several years as a lawyer at Kelley, Drye, Newhall, and Warren, he decided to enter the Seminary and was ordained in 1961 and named a Monsignor in 1986. In addition to his legal talent, he was fluent in Spanish and French. His assignments included Marseille, France as well as the Catholic University in Ponce, Puerto Rico. He is survived by two sisters, two brothers and their spouses: Mary Toohy Hyson and Francis Hyson, Cos Cob, CT; Margaret Toohy Sweeney and Robert Sweeney, Rye, NY; Peter Toohy and Jane Toohy, Houston, TX; Thomas Toohy and Mary Toohy, Manchester Center, VT. He had 13 nephews and nieces along with 21 grandnephews and grandnieces. The family will be receiving friends at Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY on Wednesday from 5:30 to 8:00pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will celebrated Thursday, June 16, 2011 at 10:30 at Church of the Blessed Sacrament at 152 West 71st, Manhattan. The interment will be at the Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Catholic Charities.

An article on Monday about fees paid by television networks for exclusive access to news subjects, misstated the title of Jeff Fager, a CBS executive. He is the chairman of CBS News, not its president.

BEATON--Bettye Epstein, 64, died peacefully at her home on June 13, 2011 due to complications related to the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. Born January 2, 1947 in Woodmere, NY. Survived by Howard Beaton, MD, her loving husband of 29 years, dear sisters Nancy Kemper and Judy Villers, and her beloved children, son Joshua Beaton (Beth), daughters Audrey Margarite (Mike) and Jessica Beaton and grandchildren Jacob and Olivia. Bettye worked as a surgical physician assistant and for 10 years was the clinical director of the surgical PA program at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. She made countless friends throughout her life and held them all as close as family. Her special memory will live on forever in the hearts of those that she touched. Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, June 15 at 11am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St. in Manhattan. Donations may be made to the Lymphoma and Leukemia Society.

REDLICH--Norman. We mourn the passing of one of the giants in the history of the American Jewish Congress. Beginning with a law review note in 1948, Norman was a true leader of our organization and at the heart of its work for over 55 years. Fierce defender of the Constitution and advocate for the less fortunate, he combined a passion for justice and command of the law with unassuming modesty and wisdom. The personification of class and conscience, Norman exemplified the words of the rabbis: "He who runs from honor, will be pursued by it." Richard S. Gordon, President

RAHAL--James J. Rahal M.D. James J. Rahal, M.D. The world of medicine, and the world, lost a giant this weekend as Dr. James Rahal passed away. His many colleagues at New York Hospital Queens join, in deep sadness, his beloved family his wife Barbara Britton, his children James, Susan and Linda as well as his grandchildren Karyn, Carly and Christine, to mourn his death. We also celebrate his successes on the frontlines of the battle against some of the most challenging diseases of our time. Jim, as we all knew him, had a distinguished and productive career that spanned more than four decades. He dedicated his professional life to being a physician, scientist and professor in infectious disease and infection control. He achieved his undergraduate degree from Harvard-cum laude; and earned his medical degree from Tufts University-cum laude in 1959. He came to New York Hospital Queens as Director of Infectious Disease in 1988, and beyond the enormous contributions he made to the medical center's patients and his colleagues, he shaped the Infectious Disease specialists of the future as a clinical professor of medicine for Weill Medical College of Cornell University. In the 1980s and 1990s, he was recognized internationally as the scientific leader who discovered, and then published, his findings on the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics. He was among the first to participate in trials with the then new cephalosporins. His work on multi-drug resistant gram negative bacilli has led the field and is often quoted. When HIV/AIDS emerged as a growing public health issue, he became actively involved in addressing innovative drug therapies, patient access to treatment and public policy decisions. Most significantly, he served as a member of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Data Safety Monitoring Board - a small group of multidisciplinary specialists, who determined the safety of national studies for HIV/AIDS. In 1999, he was one of the first physicians in the U.S. to recognize the outbreak pattern of the West Nile virus when it began infecting patients in Queens. He became one of the nation's foremost experts on the West Nile virus. He developed the first FDA-approved treatment for the West Nile virus in 2002, and he created a national, multi-site research protocol to determine the results of the Interferon alpha-2b for treatment of the virus. This unique protocol was patented in 2005. On a personal level, Dr. Rahal was recognized for his self-effacing and gracious manner. He was a consummate teacher and as a result, he received countless awards for teaching and research--including the Albion Bernstein MD Award in 2004 by the Medical Society of the State of New York. His work has been published in numerous prestigious journals, such as the New England Journal of Medicine, JAMA and Science magazine. The news media often sought his expertise on antibiotic resistance, the West Nile virus and infectious diseases. His studies, including those developed for the NIH, have affected many lives and have served to raise the bar of excellence in medicine and science for future generations. Services include Two Memorial Visitation Services: Thursday, June 16, 7:00- 9:00pm at Barrett's Funeral Home 424 West 51st Street, NY, NY, Friday, June 17, 7:00- 9:00pm at Barrett's Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ www.BarrettFuneralHome.net A Memorial Church Service will be held Saturday, June 18 at 10:00am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 4 Woodland Road, Montvale, NJ (201-391-3181) www.saintpaulsmontvale.org In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to either of the following: Laboratory for Infectious Disease Research c/o BMA Foundation, New York Hospital Queens, http://www.nyhq.org/Ways--to--Give or 56-45 Main Street, Flushing NY 11355 Histiocytosis Foundation www.histio.org or 1-800-548-2758. On behalf of his family, our trustees, administration, employees and medical staff, as well as the dedicated physicians and staff of the Infectious Disease Division, we say goodbye to a wonderful husband, father and grandfather, an amazing physician, an unflagging scientist, a loyal teacher and mentor, and our beloved colleague. The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about people living with Parkinson's disease, misstated, because of information from the Michael J. Fox Foundation, the relationship of Dr. Karen Jaffe, a Cleveland physician who has Parkinson's, to a clinical study of biological markers that can help monitor progression of the disease. Dr. Jaffe is not a participant in the study, although her husband, as the article said, is enrolled as a control subject.

AN END TO TOO BIG TO FAIL? Michael H. Krimminger, below, the general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said in testimony before a House Financial Services Committee panel that regulators now have ''the tools to end too big to fail.'' The passage of the Dodd-Frank Act has ended the era of bailouts, he told lawmakers, by creating ways to unwind troubled financial firms.
